HEADLINE: Clinton Backs a $1 Billion Plan To Spare Trees and Aid Loggers

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Acting to resolve a battle over the fate of the ancient forests in the Pacific Northwest, President Clinton has approved a plan to reduce logging on Federal lands and provide more than $1 billion to retrain loggers and help distressed timber communities.
The policy was drawn from recommendations developed by a group of scientists and was presented to the timber industry, environmentalists and members of Congress from Washington and Oregon. It is the Clinton Administration's first important attempt to walk the fine line between economic growth and environmental protection. 
 The plan was immediately attacked from all sides. The industry said the new rules would destroy already hobbled businesses, while environmentalists complained that exceptions would allow cutting to go on unabated in vast tracts of forest.
 
Owl Habitat Protected
 The plan calls for restricting logging in national forests to 1.2 billion board feet a year, down from about 3 billion a year now and far below the peak of 5 billion reached in the mid-1980's. The forests are managed by the United States Forest Service, which has jurisdiction over 20 million acres in the Northwest.
The plan also provides perhaps $1.3 billion to $1.6 billion for economic relief and puts the areas in the forests where the northern spotted owl lives off-limits to logging.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's compromise plan, which could require Congressional support to protect it from legal challenge, was the best way to address a problem that lends itself to no easy solutions.
"If the bar we set is to make everybody happy, we're not going to do it," one official said.
Others put a different interpretation on the reaction. "This has been put forward as take it or leave it," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon. "And both the environmental groups, and the labor and industry groups have said they'd rather leave it. Sometimes the conventional wisdom is that you upset the extremes and strike a middle you've done a good job. I don't think this is one of those instances."
Loggers said the decision would devastate rural communities that have already been depressed by reductions in logging sought by environmentalists to protect about three million acres of ancient growth. It is unclear what effect the plan would have on the retail price of lumber.
Environmentalists are equally unhappy, saying that provisions in Mr. Clinton's plan that are intended to set aside portions of the forest from cutting would actually allow it to continue because of loopholes built into the plan.
Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, who is from Washington State, said the Clinton plan would represent "a dramatic and radical reduction" in timber cutting that he described as "extraordinarily rigid."
In remarks outside the White House, after a meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Foley also criticized what he described as overly broad applications of the Endangered Species Act, which he said protected too many species of wildlife at the expense of economic well-being.
"The Endangered Species Act is flawed because it does not make any distinction" between the sorts of animals that should be protected under the statute, he said.
 
'Utopian' View Assailed
 Mr. Foley added that some environmentalists held a "utopian view that we might by Federal law guarantee that no species would ever become extinct."
The Administration needs Mr. Foley's support to shepherd legislation that would protect Mr. Clinton's policy from becoming tied up lawsuits.
But some senior Administration officials, including Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, have suggested that the President could prevent legal challenges through administrative action and therefore let Mr. Foley and others duck a nasty Congressional fight over the plan.
"It certainly would have been very difficult to come up with something that everyone supported," said Cary Jones, the executive director of Douglas Timber Operators, a group based in Roseburg, Ore., that represents smaller companies in the industry. "But our industry was hopeful that the President would come up with more of a balanced solution that would have protected the timber communities."
Mr. Clinton chose from a package of proposals drawn up by officials in five agencies and the White House. He requested the options in early April, when he, Vice President Al Gore, Mr. Babbitt and several other Cabinet members traveled to Portland Ore., for a public hearing on ways to resolve the conflict.
 
Classic Trade-Off
 In the sort of classic exchange that allows troublesome legislation to win Congressional support, the economic assistance is the main sweetener for lawmakers who have predicted that up to 9,000 jobs would be lost.
Even this provision does not please some lawmakers, who are unhappy that the recommendations were formulated in private meetings by scientists. Mr. DeFazio said most of the money in the assistance package would probably be redirected from programs that already exist.
Other provisions in the plan, which were intended to mollify competing interests, have also attracted immediate criticism. Fran Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation said provisions that seem to put preserves off-limits to logging in fact allowed giant loopholes.
 
Margin of Safety at Issue
 For instance, Ms. Hunt said the proposals would allow companies to remove timber from the protected areas if the trees are no longer growing or overgrowth must be thinned. She said loggers had stretched those definitions to such a degree in the past that there was little practical difference in logging in the protected and unprotected areas.
"In reality, salvaging is frequently used to log standing green trees that are alive, that some forester walks out in the woods and decides it will be dead in three or five years," she said. "We're concerned that if the effort has been made to keep the logging levels as high as they can justify them -- that the margin of safety for catastrophic events would be diminished."
For two years, a court order barring new contracts for cutting timber in the ancient forests has depressed logging activity, keeping it well below the levels to be suggested in the Clinton plan and far below the peak harvests of the mid-1980's.
Because of the court order, environmentalists were anticipating that most timber cutting on Federal lands in the Pacific Northwest would stop by 1995, when most of the contracts let before the order would have expired or been fulfilled.

HEADLINE: Clinton Will End U.S. Opposition To Vietnam Loans, Officials Say

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is planning to drop its opposition to loans to Vietnam by international lending institutions, Administration officials said today.
The move would be a way of acknowledging Vietnam's recent cooperation in accounting for Americans still missing in Southeast Asia and to encourage it to do more, the officials added. 
 White House officials said the final details of the new policy, which are still being hammered out, would probably be announced by President Clinton on Friday.
While dropping the lending ban falls short of ending the American economic embargo against Vietnam, the step is likely to help pave the way for an opening of trade with Hanoi in the near future.
It certainly would be the biggest easing of the trade embargo imposed by the United States on Vietnam since the country was unified under Communist rule in 1975.
President Clinton will meet at the White House on Thursday with a coalition of groups involved in the efforts to account for military personnel missing in Southeast Asia to explain his thinking, hear their views and enlist their support for the proposed move. These groups have given such proposals a mixed reaction.
 
Incentives to Cooperate
 The President will argue that when obstacles to international lending to Vietnam are removed, Hanoi will have an even greater inducement to cooperate with Washington in accounting for missing personnel, with the understanding that further cooperation will probably lead to a lifting of the trade embargo.
The Administration is expected to tell Hanoi that it can move ahead now with international loans and that its cooperation will be reviewed when the Administration makes its annual reassessment of the trade embargo on Sept. 14.
"The key word is progress and not just cooperation," said a senior Administration official. "Cooperation is just merely helping us out. What the president is committed to is the fullest possible accounting. So lifting the embargo is tied to tangible results."
To underscore the point, Mr. Clinton is expected to accompany announcement of his new policy on the lending ban with a decision to send a senior official, most likely Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia, to Hanoi to press for further help on accounting for the missing.
Technically, what the Clinton Administration will be doing is lifting its opposition to a French-led proposal to refinance Vietnam's $140 million debt to the International Monetary Fund -- a move that will enable Hanoi to clear its arrears, restructure its debt and attract further international financing.
Because Hanoi was in arrears on its I.M.F. debt, it was not able to secure much larger loans from the World Bank and other international lending institutions to underwrite the sort of major infrastructure projects it needs to make its economy more competitive.
Administration officials said the draft announcement, which they cautioned was subject to change between now and Friday, was the unanimous recommendation of the inter-agency task force, headed by the National Security Council, that had been charged with shaping policy on this issue. It included representatives from the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Treasury, the State Department and the Pentagon.
 
A Sensitive Issue
 The emphasis that officials put on the unanimity of the recommendation underscores how politically sensitive this issue is for Mr. Clinton, who avoided the Vietnam war draft.
On this issue, Mr. Clinton finds himself caught between several pressures. From one side, business groups are eager to make certain that American companies will be able to get in on business opportunities in Vietnam.
Indeed, the changed policy on lending to Vietnam is bound to highlight the fact that American companies are still barred from trading with Hanoi and will not be able to bid on some of the huge infrastructure projects likely to be financed by international banks there in the coming years.
But from another direction, the President knows he is vulnerable to complaints from groups concerned about those still officially listed as missing in Vietnam. These groups accuse the Hanoi Government of failing to reveal everything it knows about those listed as missing.
At the same time, officials said, Mr. Clinton and his national security advisers felt that to maintain Vietnam's cooperation in the search for information on those listed as missing, they probably needed some symbolic way to acknowledge that Hanoi has been providing a fuller accounting in some missing-persons cases as well as better access by American investigators.
There are now roughly 90 so-called "discrepancy cases" in which there is information that a person listed as missing was at one time alive in captivity in Southeast Asia, but has still not been accounted for.
In the meantime, according to the Reuters news agency, one compromise idea being considered by the Administration would keep the embargo in place for now but let American companies carry out contracts financed by lenders like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, has been meeting with veterans' groups in recent weeks to sound them out on this change of policy. Veterans' groups, together with politically powerful organizations of relatives of those listed as missing, appear to be divided about ending the official opposition to the I.M.F. loan restructuring, though clearly there are more opponents than supporters.
"We believe that if you do this, the United States would lose all leverage for negotiating with the Vietnamese," Dolores Alfond, head of the National Alliance of Families for the Return of America's Missing Servicemen, said in an open letter to Mr. Clinton this week.

HEADLINE: Loss at OTB Is Reported

 BODY:
The State Comptroller's office said yesterday that New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation lost about $500,000 in the 1992-93 fiscal year. If the report by the office of Comptroller H. Carl McCall is accurate, OTB would be the first legal bookmaker in the country to lose money. But the agency insists that by delaying mandatory bonuses totaling $1.1 million to 1,698 employees it will end the year with an operating profit of about $700,000. Hazel N. Dukes, OTB's president, acknowledged in April that the corporation was in a financial crisis

HEADLINE: Three States Investigating Tale of Killing

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., June 30

 BODY:
Police investigators from three states met here today to pool their information on the murders of dozens of young women in hopes of answering this single question: Just how many did Joel Rifkin kill?
It is the question already preoccupying 50 state troopers, who are checking out Mr. Rifkin's claims that he murdered 17 prostitutes he had picked up on the streets of Manhattan over the last three years. 
 The New York State police said that as of today, they had found links between Mr. Rifkin and the murders of eight women, whose bodies were discovered as far from Manhattan as the Orange County town of Cornwall, N.Y., and as close as a creek in Brooklyn.
The New York City police, meanwhile, said that they had found links between Mr. Rifkin and the murders of at least four other women, whose bodies were found in steel drums, suitcases and steamer trunks in city waters a year ago or more.
 
Blood-Stained Wheelbarrow
 Mr. Rifkin's detailed descriptions of where and when he dumped the bodies, coupled with the discovery of some of the women's personal items in his house in East Meadow, led the police to their conclusions. Among the items removed from his house, the police said, were some of the women's driver's licenses and other forms of photo identification, as well as credit cards, library cards and jewelry. The police said they found the names of approximately 10 women on the identity cards.
Also taken from the house were women's undergarments, a chainsaw and a wheelbarrow that state officials said was stained with human blood.
As more of the information provided by Mr. Rifkin proved to be accurate, the police said, they became more sure that the 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, now being held without bail in the Nassau County Jail, is the murderer he claimed to be.
"The definition of serial killer by the F.B.I. is someone who has killed more than three people and takes a cool-off period in between each of them," Capt. Walter Heesch, who is heading the state police investigation, said at a news conference at the agency's Long Island barracks. "That's what we have here."
The authorities say Mr. Rifkin admitted the slayings during 10 hours of questioning by the state police on Monday. The interrogation took place after troopers stopped Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck on a street in Mineola before dawn that day and discovered the body of a woman in his vehicle. He has been charged with one count of second-degree murder in connection with the body in his pickup.
State police investigators from New Jersey and Connecticut joined law-enforcement officials from Long Island, New York City, Rockland, Westchester and Orange counties at a meeting at the state police barracks this afternoon to begin comparing notes and determine whether other cases might be linked to Mr. Rifkin.
"The state police are now working closely with other departments that have established a link with this case," said Major Anthony J. DiResta Jr., commander of Troop L, which is based here.
 
Inquiries About Many Cases
 Detective Lieut. John W. Gierasch, chief of the Suffolk County homicide squad, who attended the two-hour session, said it had been held "to establish some protocol for sharing information." The bodies of two women linked to the Rifkin case, including one unearthed Tuesday based on information that officials said was supplied by Mr. Rifkin, have been found in the Hamptons in eastern Suffolk County.
Other agencies arrived with open cases that have not been connected to Mr. Rifkin. Master Sgt. Scott O'Mara of the Connecticut State Police said that three of his department's detectives went to the meeting to inquire about the unsolved murders of 22 women -- 19 in the Hartford area and 3 near Waterbury. A Yonkers detective, Sgt. Frank A. LoCascio Jr., said he was looking into four unsolved homicides in his city.
Sergeant LoCascio was not sure, however, whether he would find what he was looking for. "It's all speculative at this point," he said.
Although the state police said Mr. Rifkin willingly answered their questions, they did not make a videotape or have the suspect sign a confession. That lapse was criticized today by other law-enforcement officials, who said the lack of a documented confession could make the cases more difficult to prosecute. One Long Island official, who declined to be identified, said some top police officials did not learn of the arrest of Mr. Rifkin until they heard it reported on the news.
Mr. Rifkin's lawyer, Robert Sale, said he was astonished to learn that any statements that might have been made were not recorded or transcribed. "It's just so startling to me," Mr. Sale said of the lack of videotaping, a procedure often used by police agencies in investigations. "To not take a written statement is even more astounding."
At the news conference, Captain Heesch said the state police had taken only "an oral statement" from Mr. Rifkin. "Based on the things that were available to us at the time, we didn't do it," he said, referring to the lack of a recorded statement.
Captain Heesch said that all the victims linked so far to Mr. Rifkin were believed to be 5 feet 3 inches or shorter and worked in Manhattan as prostitutes.
Today, the authorities provided the names of three of the victims: Anna Lopez, a Brooklyn woman whose body was found on May 25, 1992, near a park-and-ride area off Interstate 84 in the Putnam County town of Patterson, Yun Lee, a 31-year-old woman from lower Manhattan whose body was found in a steamer trunk in the East River off Randalls Island on Sept. 23, 1991, and Leah Evens, a 28-year-old Brooklyn woman whose body was found May 9 in a wooded area in the hamlet of Northampton on the east end of Long Island. The Suffolk police said that Ms. Evens was an unemployed mother of two and that they could not say whether Ms. Evens was a prostitute.
A woman who gave her name as Patricia A. Sullivan and identified herself as a lawyer with Barry, McTiernan & Moor walked up to reporters outside a building at 299 Pearl Street and said she was representing Hiram Lee. She would not say whether Mr. Lee, who lives in the building, was related to Yun Lee. Asked by reporters whether Yun Lee was her client's sister or daughter, she said no.
 
Bodies Found at Various Sites
 State police officials, meanwhile, said they were linking the body of a woman found on Oct. 1, 1991, off Route 32 in the Orange County town of Cornwall, to Mr. Rifkin. Major James D. O'Donnell of the state police barracks in Middletown said the body of the woman, who was white and about 5 feet tall, with long hair, was found in an area covered with grass clippings and other debris. They also linked Mr. Rifkin to the body of a woman found in a steel drum in Newtown Creek in Brooklyn on May 13, 1992. Both bodies remain unidentified.
Raymond W. Kelly, the New York City Police Commissioner, said that four other women found in the rivers around New York had been added to the city's list of suspected victims of Mr. Rifkin. In addition to the body of Ms. Lee, two were found in steel drums in Coney Island Creek in July 1992 and one was found in in pieces in plastic bags and a suitcase in the Harlem and East rivers that same month.
The Commissioner said that at the time, the police had thought the murders were drug-related.
The authorities said that though the location of the bodies encompass a wide portion of the metropolitan area, they remained uncertain where the women had been killed.
"Basically, his operation consisted of picking up the women, having sex with them, killing them and disposing of them," Captain Heesch said.

The 12 murder victims thus far linked by the New York State Police or the New York City Police to Joel Rifkin, who has confessed to killing 17 women since 1991.
 
1. An unidentified woman whose body was found in the rear of Mr. Rifkin's pickup truck early Monday when he was stopped by the New York State Police after his truck hit a light pole on Old Country Road in Mineola. The police said Mr. Rifkin confessed to strangling the woman in his mother's car last Thursday night. Mr. Rifkin told the police he kept the body in the garage of his East Meadow home over the weekend and was on his way to Republic Airport, where he intended to bury the remains.
 
2. An unidentified woman whose decomposed body was found Tuesday morning about 80 feet off of County Route 31 in Westhampton.
 
3. An unidentified woman whose skeletal remains were found Tuesday afternoon under a mattress 200 feet off Rockaway Boulevard in a deserted area southeast of Kennedy International Airport in Queens.
 
4. Jenny Soto, whose body was found at the foot of Lincoln Avenue near the Harlem River in the Bronx on Nov. 18, 1992.
 
5. An unidentified woman whose body was found in a steel drum floating in Newtown Creek near Greenpoint Avenue in Brooklyn on May 13, 1992.
 
6. Leah Evans, whose body was discovered in a wooded area off County Route 51 in Southhampton on May 9, 1993.
 
7. Anna Lopez, whose body was found in the woods near a park-and-ride area off Interstate 84 in the Putnam County town of Patterson on May 25, 1992. The police said an earring found on the victim matched an earring found after a search of the Rifkin home.
 
8. An unidentified woman whose body was found in a ditch off Route 32 in the Orange County town of Cornwall on Oct. 1, 1991.
 
9. An unidentified woman whose body was found in a steel drum in Coney Island Creek in Brooklyn, near West 23d Street, July 9, 1992.
 
10. An unidentified woman whose body was found by fishermen in a steel drum in Coney Island Creek in Brooklyn, off Bay 54th Street, July 11, 1992.
 
11. An unidentified woman whose torso was found wrapped in a blue plastic bag in the Harlem River near Randall's Island on July 22, 1992. Three days later, the arms and a leg were found in a suitcase in the East River off lower Manhattan.
 
12. Yun Lee, whose body was found in a steamer trunk in the Harlem River near Randall's Island on Sept. 23, 1991.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lifts Ban on Sale of Nonlethal Military Equipment to Angola

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Removing the last remnants of trade restrictions on Angola, the Clinton Administration has cleared the way for sales of nonlethal military materiel to the formerly Marxist Government of Jose Eduardo dos Santos.
State Department officials described the lifting of export restrictions as part of the normalizing of economic relations with the dos Santos Government on May 19. 
 But the decision marks a turnaround in United States policy, which for years provided arms to Mr. dos Santos's enemy, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, and its leader, Jonas Savimbi, who has waged a bitter war against the Luanda Government.
 
Angolans Confident
 Representatives of the Angolan Government and Unita, as Mr. Savimbi's organization is known, both view the latest actions by Washington as a prelude to the endorsement by the United States, Russia and Portugal of the complete lifting of the arms embargo to both sides in the war. The embargo was put in place as part of peace accords negotiated in 1991, though both sides have continued to buy arms on the international black market.
"As far as we are concerned this is the arms embargo abolition," said Jardo Muekalia, Unita's representative in the United States. "Of course you can call it phased or staged, but, in the end, it is going to be lifted."
State Department officials said today that George Moose, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would meet in Moscow next week with officials from Russia and Portugal, who, along with the United States, have been the countries most involved in seeking a solution to the Angolan civil war. Angola was once a Portuguese colony.
"I suspect they will discuss both positive measures to aid the Government and punitive measures to punish Unita," a State Department official said.
Among the Troika, as the three countries are collectively known, both the Portuguese and the Russians favor removing the arms embargo, State Department officials said. But they added that the Administration still opposed ending the ban.
Still, representatives of the Angolan Government say they hope some forceful action on their behalf and against Unita will be decided at the Moscow meeting.
"I'm quite sure that in the next Troika meeting in Moscow, the three observers will take an appropriate, a more strong decision about the situation in Angola," said Jose Patricio, Angola's Ambassador to the Organization of American States. Mr. Patricio added that at a White House reception on June 15, Vice President Gore told him the United States would not allow Unita to take power in Angola by force.
 
Focus on the Economy
 Couching the easing of restrictions on sales of military equipment in economic rather than martial terms, Administration officials say the decision brings to a virtual end all sanctions that had been placed on Angola and on businesses that do business with the Luanda Government.
The Administration has already dropped a regulation prohibiting the Defense Department from buying oil products from United States companies, including Chevron, that operate in Angola, officials said.
But allowing even the sales of uniforms or jeeps carries much more of a symbolic weight than other actions to ease trade restrictions. It is an especially important morale booster for the dos Santos Government, which has suffered a number of battlefield reverses since the latest round of peace talks broke down on Sept. 15.
"What this does is give a blessing to the M.P.L.A.," said Mr. Muekalia, using the intitials in Portuguese for Mr. dos Santos's political party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola. "It has a psychological impact on the Government people."
Administration officials said the easing of the embargo would mean that the Angolan Government would be able to buy items like boots and uniforms.
But they acknowledged that the definition of nonlethal materiel of left sufficiently vague that the decision could also allow Angola to buy C-130 transport planes, so long as they were not configured to mount armaments.
One official said there was nothing the United States could do if a transport plane was bought and later fitted with gun mounts.
Mr. Patricio declined to say whether his Government would try to buy such planes. In the past, the Angolan Government was turned down in its attempts to buy them.

HEADLINE: As Mandela Arrives, Elections Fund Starts $10 Million Corporate Drive

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD

 BODY:
A corporate effort to raise at least $10 million to help South Africa hold democratic elections next year was announced yesterday, hours before Nelson Mandela arrived in New York to begin a two-week tour of the United States.
The South Africa Free Elections Fund was organized by Theodore C. Sorensen, a senior partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, with encouragement from Mr. Mandela. The anti-apartheid leader was to meet with the fund's board. 
 The announcement underscored the primary purpose of Mr. Mandela's visit, which is to gain money and other assistance for South Africa and for Mr. Mandela's African National Congress.
Encouraging foreign investment in South Africa is also a primary goal of South Africa's President, F. W. de Klerk, who was to arrive in Washington yesterday and leave on Sunday. President Clinton is scheduled to present the Liberty Medal to both men in a ceremony in Philadelphia on Sunday, the Fourth of July.
The African National Congress is preparing to compete against Mr. De Klerk's National Party and others in voting next year that could end more than three centuries of white minority control of South Africa. The congress was banned in South Africa for more than 25 years, until Mr. de Klerk legalized it in 1990.
 
Other Cities in Tour
 Organizers of the Mandela tour said that the trip would include stops in Washington, Philadelphia, Chicago, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Indianapolis.
Mr. Mandela was wasting no time in his fund-raising efforts. Within hours of his arrival on a British Airways Concorde flight at Kennedy International Airport, the 74-year-old president of the African National Congress appeared at a rally at Concord Baptist Church of Christ in Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn.
Mr. Mandela said the African National Congresss needed money to help mobilize the vote next year. "What we want is to have the capacity on the day of the election to bring our people from their homes, from their places of work, to the voting booth," he said. "If we don't have that capacity, we may lose the election even though we may be the most popular party."
Mayor David N. Dinkins, who addressed the crowd before Mr. Mandela, said Americans now had an "opportunity to play a role in easing the transition to majority rule in South Africa."
Mr. Dinkins joked that Mr. Mandela was tiring because "so many of oiur ministers were so generous -- he was standing there receiving checks."
The Rev. Patricia Reeberg, executive director of the New York City Council of Churches, which organized the event, said she was anticipating an overflow crowd of 3,000 and $250,000 in pledges and donations.
 
Meeting With Board
 This morning, a meeting is scheduled with the board of the corporate fund-raising effort, led by Anthony J .F. O'Reilly, chief executive of the H.J. Heinz Company.
Others on the board include its vice chairman, A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., a former Federal appeals judge now with Paul, Weiss; former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance; former Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta; Robert S. McNamara, former World Bank president and Defense Department Secretary, and Peter Guber, chairman and chief executive officer of Sony Pictures Entertainment.
Mr. Sorensen, who was a speech writer and top aide to President John F. Kennedy, worked behind the scenes on issues involving South Africa with several of the other people involved. He will serve as counsel to the group. Mr. Sorensen was unavailable for comment yesterday.
 
To Meet With Clinton
 Mr. Mandela was to spend this afternoon in Washington, meeting separately with the House and Senate foreign relations committees. Tomorrow, he is to have separate discussions with President Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher.
Friday is also the day that constitutional negotiators in South Africa are expected to ratify an April 27, 1994, date for the nation's first universal suffrage elections.
Mr. Mandela was said to be considering using that occasion to call for the lifting of economic sanctions against South Africa. But the timing of such a proclamation is considered politically sensitive as the constitutional delegates are still debating the creation of a multiparty committee that would run South Africa until the elections are held.
After campaigning for years for sanctions, the African congress now believes they must be lifted to provide the kind of economic investment in South Africa needed to allow a new government to meet black aspirations for a higher standard of living.
 
A Challenging Task
 But getting sanctions lifted quickly may be easier said than done. Although the Bush Administration ended comprehensive Federal sanctions, at least 28 states, 24 counties and 92 cities, including New York, also passed laws against doing business with South Africa.
Dumisani Kumalo, projects director for the New York-based Africa Fund, said getting all of them repealed would require a coordinated effort and would hinge on the ability of Mr. Mandela and others to convince the various governments that apartheid is indeed on the way out.
Meanwhile, as elections approach, the African National Congress must mount a campaign against an entrenched National Party Government, in power for 45 years, that has access to both money and the media.
Although whites make up less than 15 percent of South Africa's population of 40 million, and the African National Congress is regarded as the most influential and popular black political group, nonwhite politics are fragmented in many groups, based on ethnic or ideological differences.

HEADLINE: Lucky to Be in the Bronx? Bombers Aren't So Sure

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER

 BODY:
There is a peculiar hysteria that strikes New York City every time George Steinbrenner threatens to move the Yankees from the Bronx. A low-grade panic fixates on one image: could a C (for Connecticut) or an NJ (perish the thought) ever be superimposed on the elegant and justly famous Yankees pinstripes?
To Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the image is unthinkable and has led him to champion -- as last a resort, he says -- the idea of constructing a gleaming new stadium on a railyard in midtown, even if that means moving the Bronx Bombers out of their legendary home and into Manhattan. 
 But even if the Yankees stay put, just the notion of a move to say, New Jersey's Meadowlands, exposes long-simmering anxieties about the decline of cities and especially this city, whose heart has been broken before by teams it loved.
It also forces uncomfortable questions: Is the Bronx, home to the winningest and most lucrative baseball team, still a good place to play the game? Are cities the best places for baseball if its fans live outside them?
The debate touches on issues like the population shift to the suburbs, the fear of crime in urban neighborhoods and the failure of baseball to attract minority customers -- the Bronx is half Hispanic, and Puerto Ricans and Dominicans are huge baseball fans even if they do not attend Yankees games in huge numbers.
"To some degree baseball is being thought of in the same way as American cities, that its best days are passed," said Roger Angell, the baseball writer for The New Yorker. "Maybe that's another reason for them to stick together."
Though nine years remain on the Yankees' lease in the Bronx, speculation about a possible move has intensified in recent weeks, in part because the team is doing well after years of mediocrity. But also Mr. Steinbrenner is back in baseball and making his voice heard.
People are listening: on Tuesday, a person close to Mr. Cuomo said the Governor planned to meet with Mr. Steinbrenner on Friday to discuss a new stadium on the western edge of midtown Manhattan. Also reportedly invited was Rupert Murdoch, the new publisher of The New York Post, to talk about building television studios or an arena to help finance a project whose price tag starts at $200 million. Vincent Tese, the state's director of economic development and Governor Cuomo's liaison to Mr. Steinbrenner, was also scheduled to attend the meeting.
 
Cuomo Backs the Bronx
 But yesterday, in an apparent measure of just how sensitive the issue of a Yankees move is, Mr. Cuomo repeated in a news conference in Albany that the Bronx is his first choice and that he would not meet with the two men together. A state official said it was not even clear that Mr. Cuomo would keep his appointment with Mr. Steinbrenner.
Neither Mr. Cuomo nor the official denied that such a meeting was scheduled, nor would they say whether he had simply changed plans after reports of the meeting were published yesterday. The Governor's dilemma, various state and city officials say privately, is whether he can talk about a new stadium in Manhattan without seeming to impale current negotiations to keep the team in the their 70-year-old home astride the Harlem River.
"I know that the Governor and Vince feel that George may not wish to stay in the Bronx," Mayor David N. Dinkins said at a news conference yesterday at City Hall. "But I haven't certainly reached the conclusion he won't stay."
Although all discussion is preliminary at this point, the concern on all sides underscores how seriously officials are taking Mr. Steinbrenner's complaints about parking, security and attendance, which has declined steadily over the last five years (though it has picked up considerably in recent weeks). For city and state officials the worst-case scenario would be for Mr. Steinbrenner to take his team to New Jersey, a move that would crush the city and be no help to Mr. Dinkins in this fall's tough election nor to Mr. Cuomo next year if he seeks a fourth term.
To many Yankees fans, even talk of a new stadium nears blasphemy and there are few fans who do not see Mr. Steinbrenner as baseball's chief heretic.
"We would be prosecuting him within a few days if he moved out," said Michael Friedlander, 24, a Yankees fan and intern with the Bronx District Attorney's Office.
Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said: "You can't blame it on the Bronx. What you can blame it on is that the Yankees have been dwelling near the basement, and fans don't come back that quick."
As a permanent home for the team, Yankee Stadium carries a decided New York appeal, along with a healthy portion of the city's baggage.
On the plus side is the emotional tug to keep the team that has won 22 World Series at its home. The stadium is also a major anchor for the Bronx and is expected to play an important role in the recently announced Bronx Center plan. That proposal would include a 3,000-car garage, a Metro North Station, a baseball museum and other perquisites to keep the team in the borough for the long haul.
The stadium would also be in step with recent thinking in baseball, if not in other sports, toward keeping stadiums inside cities: Toronto and Chicago have recently opened well received city stadiums and fans are still falling over the new Camden Yards in Baltimore as a model for new parks. By the same token, so would the site on the West Side of Manhattan.
But city, state and borough officials all concede that Mr. Steinbrenner is right on several fronts. They agree Yankee Stadium should have more parking, more police, more lighting and better cleaned highways surrounding it. All these issues are the subject of negotiations between the city and the ball club, even though city officials said it is not clear yet where the money will come from in the effort to attract fans during this winning season.
 
Negative Perception
 What the officials cannot do is overcome the negative perception of the Bronx, and even more important, the significant shift of city life to Westchester County, New Jersey and Long Island. The team claims that 68 percent of its fans come from outside the city. From the bleacher seats of the suburbs, the borough looks nasty, dangerous and hard to get to.
"I wouldn't drive through there at night on a bet," said Richard Lettwin, 62, a retired packaging manufacturer from Harrison in Westchester County, who in fact has stopped going to night games. "They have Uzi's down there at night. It's a no-man's land. And walking through the streets? Forget about it."
Mr. Ferrer accuses Mr. Steinbrenner of exaggerating the borough's danger. And he has produced figures showing an average of two reported crimes, excluding ticket scalping, per game -- mostly theft from cars. The Yankees do not dispute the numbers, but say the matter is one of perception.
Mr. Ferrer also contends that Mr. Steinbrenner could fill the stadium if he just looked to his back yard and tried to develop the new Bronx residents as fans.
"Latinos, particularly Dominicans and Puerto Ricans, are rabid baseball fans, not only in the Bronx but in upper Manhattan," Mr. Ferrer said. "So George, instead of leaving the stadium, cut the ticket prices a buck or two."

HEADLINE: Russia to Get $1.5 Billion Loan

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund approved a $1.5 billion loan for Russia today, assistance viewed as crucial to President Boris N. Yeltsin's reform efforts.
The decision was immediately praised by the Administration, which has made support for Mr. Yeltsin a major element of its foreign policy. The approval came less than a week before President Clinton and other leaders are to meet with Mr. Yeltsin in Tokyo. 
 I.M.F. officials said they had waited to approve the loan because they wanted to make sure that Russia was committed to taking steps to slow inflation and control its budget deficit.
The fund said Russia would be able to qualify for an additional $1.5 billion in six months, "provided that progress continues to be made in the implementation of the policy program." The I.M.F. said it wanted Russia to get monthly inflation below 5 percent by the end of the year. The rate, which had been almost 30 percent a month, slowed to 19 percent in May.

HEADLINE: Judge Gives Order That May Delay Trade Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
In a move that will delay and perhaps even derail approval of a free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada, a Federal judge ordered the Government today to prepare a lengthy study on the agreement's effects on the environment.
The Clinton Administration immediately said it would appeal the order. Supporters and opponents in Congress said that unless the order was overturned the agreement's chances of approval could be seriously hurt. 
 "My fear is that Nafta is finished unless this ruling is overturned," said Senator John C. Danforth, a Missouri Republican who supports the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Congress is sharply divided over the agreement. If the vote is delayed until next year, lawmakers would then be faced with a hotly disputed measure in an election year.
Until today's ruling, the Administration had planned to submit the agreement to Congress by September. The order by United States District Judge Charles R. Richey does not prohibit it from doing so. Nor did the judge prohibit Congress from ratifying the accord, even before the environmental study is done.
But trade experts said that with Congress sharply divided over the pact, chances of passage were slim if the Administration tried to push it through without first waiting for the environmental study. Administration officials and environmentalists said it would probably take at least six months to do the study, which is known as an environmental impact statement.
Representative Robert Matsui, a California Democrat who is one of the pact's leading supporters, said the ruling would make it easier for Congress's many fence-sitters to oppose the agreement, at least for now.
"Since a judge said there must be an environmental review, members can now say there must be major environmental problems with the agreement," he said. "This hurts us at a time when we felt we were gaining momentum for the agreement."
Representative Sander Levin, a Michigan Democrat who has frequently criticized the pact, said that today's ruling was a "warning flag that the environmental issues have to be seriously addressed." He added that "the Bush Administration, in a rush to negotiate the treaty, ignored these important concerns."
The three environmental groups that brought the lawsuit hailed the ruling, saying it would force the Government to pay more attention to environmental factors when negotiating agreements with other countries.
But Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the Government would appeal quickly and would ask that the case be expedited. He said the ruling "interferes with the President's ability to negotiate international trade agreements."
Judge Richey's ruling also worried the Mexican Government, and the new uncertainties about the pact helped push down Mexico's stock market by nearly 2 percent today.
Ruling in favor of the three groups -- the Sierra Club, Public Citizen and Friends of the Earth -- Judge Richey said the trade agreement could affect everything from pesticide regulations to air pollution on the Mexican border. For the most part, the judge faulted the Bush Administration for not carrying out the study and said his ruling "should not be construed as a failure of the present Administration."
"An impact statement," he wrote, "is essential for providing the Congress and the public the information needed to assess the present and future environmental consequences of, as well as the alternatives to, the Nafta when it is submitted to the Congress for approval."
The Parliament in Canada has ratified the agreement, but the ratification does not take effect until the pact is approved by the United States Congress. Canada is to hold parliamentary elections later this year, and with that country divided over the pact, there is a possibility that opponents of the pact will pick up seats and try to at least change some of its provisions, if the accord has not gained Congressional approval by President Clinton's self-imposed deadline of Dec. 31.
 
A Plaintiff's View
 Joan Claybrook, director of Public Citizen, one of the plaintiffs, said the environmentalists might have done President Clinton a favor by causing a delay in Congress's voting on the accord. After being battered and bruised from the fight over his economic package, the President was facing two all-out fights this fall to win approval of the pact and of his health-care package.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said the ruling might not be such a defeat for the President, because he was not sure the Senate would approve the accord right now.
The Administration is negotiating side agreements to the accord, one of which would address environmental concerns. Judge Richey's decision does not involve the side agreements, which have yet to be completed.
He ruled that an environmental study was mandated under the National Environmental Policy Act. Such a study would probably examine how the agreement would affect the environment of border states, and whether air and water pollution in border areas would increase if the pact caused industries to flock to Mexico. Environmentalists said the study should also look at whether the pact would affect American regulations on pesticide content in imported food.
A major delay in approving the pact would be an embarrassment for Mexico's President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari. A delay could stir resentment in Mexico and make it more difficult for Mr. Salinas's party to win in next year's elections. Mexican law prevents him from running for re-election.
However, Mexican Goverment officials insisted today that the treaty would go forward. "This decision by the judge will absolutely not delay the process of negotiation," said Jaime Serra Puche, the Mexican secretary of commerce, who believes the treaty will still be in place by Jan. 1.

HEADLINE: Out of the Classroom and Into the Working World

SERIES: Starting the Climb -- A periodic look at summer interns.

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
It is that time of year again, when thousands of America's brightest swarm to the office towers in New York and other cities to meet the real world. The summer interns, associates, fellows -- and not a few gofers eager to learn a thing or two between errands -- have arrived.
There are pathways up from internships in a wide range of careers, and internships are on the resumes of many top executives. Accordingly, these ambitious young people bubble with high hopes, though the line between dreams and delusion may prove perilously thin. 
 What clearly hangs in the already humid summer air is a sense that things are scarcer than before. In most fields, internships have become harder to get. The idea of a summer job becoming a career, always extant, is ever more compelling.
For people who have worked for a long time, there is a bit of foolishness to all this purposefulness, of course. Careers evolve over years, decades. But to an intern, as the summer begins, 10 weeks seem precisely enough time to build a stairway to the stars.
Knowingly, or not, they are marching to the wisdom of E. B. White who said, "No one should come to New York unless he is willing to be lucky."
The stories of five who came follow. Each will be revisited over the summer to see how things are going. Their employers, too, will be asked how and whether expectations are being met.
 
William McRae:
Learning Lessons In the Law
 William McRae is keenly aware that summer associate positions with big law firms are in shorter supply, and that he is lucky to have one. But he is still nervous.
"You and the firm are trying to size each other up," he said. The stakes are the offer of a permanent job after he finishes his third year of Harvard Law School. "A lot of people graduate without jobs," he said flatly.
His approach is to focus on practical legal tasks, a process he likens to putting a puzzle together. "Sooner or later, you have to sit down at the beginning and work through the long, drawn-out training," he said. "It's the beginning of my long apprenticeship."
Already, he has worked on a complicated corporate transaction and is now taking a turn in the litigation department at Chadbourne & Parke. He is keenly conscious of the trust placed in him. "You really don't want to mess up," he said. "Even if you have an excuse, you just wouldn't feel good about what you'd done."
He has also been part of the social whirl big firms have traditionally thrown for summer associates: a reception in the firm, a party in the apartment of the senior partner, a baseball game and, soon, a full day at a country club.
The background of this 24-year-old is delightfully quirky. He grew up in Atlanta where his parents are in sales, his father in a liquor store, his mother in a department store. He unsuccessfully tried to teach himself Sanskrit in high school. He chose to major in philosophy at Williams College, in part to learn the difference between good and bad thinking.
Last summer, he worked with the Harvard economist Jeffrey Sachs in the Russian Parliament. He translated and helped with legal research, answering such questions as "How do they do this in Delaware?"
He is making $1,600 a week, lives on the Upper West Side and enjoys jogging around the Central Park reservoir.
"I suspect this is the type of place that would keep me interested for a very long time," he said, a bit wistfully.
 
Nick Lobel-Weis
Making Ends Meet In the Theater
 Nick Lobel-Weis, by contrast, makes $100 a week at the League of American Theaters and Producers, keeps a roof over his head by moving around and cat-sitting and works three nights a week as a busboy to hold everything together.
But he is so happy that he thinks of himself as a surfer riding a great wave. In the theater world, he says, many companies take on summer apprentices to do lighting and other chores, printing up brochures to attract them. The catch is that they pay for the privilege, as many of his friends do.
So Mr. Lobel-Weis is actually grateful for the 10-hour days. He has learned to keep lists to keep his hundreds of assignments from falling through the cracks.
"It's insanely paced, the hours are eternal and I love it," he said.
Mr. Lobel-Weis, 20, grew up in Woodstock, N.Y., then attended Fieldston School in Manhattan. His theater experience began at age 14 when he worked as an intern in a summer theater in Woodstock. He started in acting but found he preferred theater's technical side. For four summers, he hung lights, worked on sound and the like.
He will be a sophomore at Oberlin College, which gives credit for off-campus independent study. Last summer, his father, a lawyer, happened to meet Barry Weissler, producer of "Falsettos" and other Broadway shows. "Have him send me a resume," he said.
The result was an 14-hour-a-day internship last summer, the chance to see "Falsettos" 65 times and, ultimately, this year's internship, in which the biggest project is promoting the 100th anniversary of Broadway.
One of Mr. Lobel-Weiss's tasks has been to market Broadway T-shirts, an enterprise that has put him in contact with many of the nation's larger regional theaters. His plan is to build a career in theater's business side, perhaps as a producer, and all this helps immensely.
"Relationships in this business, as I see it now, are very important," he said.
 
Nitika Smith
Setting Examples In Medicine
 Nitika Smith does not really fit brief descriptions. She is part American Indian and dances in pow-wows. She is part African-American and serves as president of the Empowered Blacks United in Science, an organization she helped found at University of California at San Diego.
The goal is to encourage blacks in the sciences at a time she says many are turning away from them. "You just have to know you don't have limits," Ms. Smith said. "If you want to go for science, go for it."
Ms. Smith, 21, from El Centro, Calif., is one of 25 participants in Cornell University Medical Center's Summer Research Fellowship Program for Minority Premedical Students. The idea, getting more blacks into medical school, works: usually 95 percent decide to apply and 99 percent of those get in. "I can't lose," she said matter of factly.
Ms. Smith's research project involves searching for antibodies that might contribute to women's infertility. She works a full day, studies two or three hours a night and is learning that her $120 a week stipend does not go all that far in New York.
Sometimes she thinks she may someday find the cure to cancer. And sometimes she just feels more comfortable with the idea of medical school.
"People get through it," she said. "Every year, there are more doctors."
 
Brett Grossman
Facing Reality In Advertising
 Brett Grossman, 21, has had some rude experiences since starting at Avrett, Free & Ginsbery Advertising three weeks ago. One of his assignments has been to visit drugstores to study the placement and pricing of pharmaceuticals that compete with one of Avrett's accounts, which he would not name.
"I was kicked out of five Duane Reade stores," he said. "But Pathmark, they're nice."
What the Southern Methodist University student says he is learning is the limitations of textbook theories. Real-world problems, he is learning, hinge on how much of a campaign the client can afford. "Playing a video game with a military fighter is a lot different than flying a mission," he said.
Mr. Grossman was one of five advertising students selected from 250 applicants for the Vance Stickell Internship Program of the American Advertising Foundation, which gave him $4,500 to cover transportation and all expenses and placed him with Avrett. He previously worked as an intern in two Dallas agencies.
He is a Mexican citizen and grew up in the California's San Fernando Valley. This is his first trip to New York, and he senses a certain tension; a sharp example was a woman's tirade when his briefcase brushed her leg on a bus.
"I find myself not smiling on the streets," Mr. Grossman said, "and that's a disappointment."
But he never forgets his purpose. "I want to feel like I'm ready to get a job when I finish this," he said. The agency's intern from last summer works in an adjoining office.
 
Amy Luberto
Taking Stock In Accounting

Amy Luberto calls the gray-flannel image of accountants a cartoon artifact, though the 21-year-old accounting student laughs about being called "a digit head" at Pennsylvania State University.
She is one of 18 interns at KPMG Peat Marwick's New York office, where she is auditing big companies' books. She says it is fun to try to guess what they had in mind, but that hard work is how one finds the real answer.
"In anything you do, you have to have some sort of internal control," Ms. Luberto said of her chosen field.
Peat Marwick's program pays interns the equivalent pay for its starting auditors, who make $30,000 a year, plus overtime. It also provides them with a mentor -- "a guardian angel," she says -- and invites them to baseball games and a country club.
Ms. Luberto guards against inflating her sense of self-importance. "I'm just the intern; I'm here to learn," she said.
But she worries that senior accountants will be too busy to answer questions and then criticize her should she make a mistake. So far that has not happened. She smiles, holds her breath and dreams of a permanent job with Peat Marwick.
Her parents live in Wood-Ridge, N.J., about a half-hour's drive to Manhattan, so she commutes to work by ferry and bus. Though she has visited the city many times over the years, she has been unfavorably impressed by the crush of humanity on Monday mornings. "You see things that you never see in New Jersey," she said.
It hardly dulls the college cheerleader's infectious cheer. "How could I pass this up?" she asked. "As long as I do O.K., I'll be happy."

HEADLINE: Trade in Auto Parts Favors Japan Despite Gains by U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 30

 BODY:
Japanese automobile manufacturers appear to be on track toward reaching their target of doubling their 1990 purchases of American-made auto parts by 1994, according to executives and analysts on both sides of the Pacific.
But that is not reducing the flow of auto parts Japan keeps shipping to the United States. To the chagrin of some American executives, the trade deficit with Japan in auto parts actually increased almost 10 percent last year to $10.9 billion. 
 Now, as Washington is pushing Japan to agree to numerical goals for buying more American products, the auto parts experience provides evidence that such an approach can open doors in Japan. Indeed, American parts are now starting to be incorporated into the designs of future Japanese autos, which could lead to bigger sales in the future.
But the experience also underscores the complexities of the target-setting approach, which critics brand as managed trade.
"It is true that we have increased auto parts sales," J. P. Reilly, president and chief executive of Tenneco Automotive and chairman of the Auto Parts Advisory Committee to the Commerce Department, said in a speech at a conference earlier this month in Detroit.
"But we have made only marginal progress in reducing the trade deficit," he continued. "It is not because we have not tried. It is very frustrating. It seems the harder we try, the further behind we get."
What is causing this to happen, he said in a later interview, is that Japanese auto makers are shifting more production to America. Even as they buy more American-made parts for their American factories, they are also importing more parts from Japan. The result: the auto parts deficit does not shrink.
Americans also said that while they were happy the overall target could be reached, they had been somewhat dissatisfied with the exact nature of the purchases. To wit:
*A substantial but undetermined portion of the "American" parts being purchased are made in the United States by Japanese suppliers that have set up shop in America. Such purchases, while helping Japanese-owned companies that employ Americans, do not help existing American suppliers who believe that they are locked out of the Japanese market.
*Most of the American parts being purchased are for use in the American factories of Japanese auto makers. Exports of American parts to Japan are not increasing fast enough to satisfy American trade officials.
*Many of the parts being purchased from American companies are simple mechanical parts as well as carpets and aluminum, rather than high-technology components like engines and electronic controls that account for much of the vehicle's value. This, however, appears to be changing.
The Japanese car companies announced during President George Bush's trip here in January 1992 what they called voluntary plans that collectively would amount to purchases of $19 billion of American parts by the 1994 fiscal year, which ends in March 1995. That compared with $9 billion in the fiscal year ended March 1991.
In the fiscal year that ended in March, Japanese auto companies bought $13.6 billion of American parts, up 30 percent from a year earlier, according to the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association. If that rate of increase continues for two years, the target will be easily exceeded.
The Administration is now trying to come up with proposals for what to ask Japan to do next, such as setting a new, higher target for 1996 or 1997.
Japanese industry and Government officials say the purchase plan is a voluntary goal, not a promise, and that they do not want to set any more. The United States, they say, is already misinterpreting the plan as a commitment.
"If we do not reach the goal we will be criticized, and if we do reach the goal the U.S. will demand a larger figure for fiscal year '95 and '96," said Hisayoshi Umemoto, manager of the auto association's parts and materials department.
In any case, the United States' $31.5 billion trade deficit in autos and auto parts with Japan, which accounted for nearly two-thirds of the entire trade deficit with that country in 1992, will prove to be highly resilient.
 
Deficit May Decline
 In a soon-to-be-released report, the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan estimates that the parts deficit will range between $8.8 billion and $10.6 billion in 1996 compared with $10.9 billion in 1992. The small reduction reflects the fact that Japanese auto production in the United States is increasing, bringing in more parts from Japan.
The trade deficit in autos might decline somewhat more significantly, reflecting fewer exports from Japan. The report predicts it will range from $16.6 billion to $21.08 billion in 1996 compared with $20.6 billion in 1992.
Auto executives agree that the numerical target has led to a sharp increase in discussions with Japanese companies, though that has not always led to sales.
"I used to go to Toyota and get shifted back and forth between international purchasing and Nummi and we couldn't get our foot in the door," said Glen Fillion, executive director of engineering for the Japanese subsidiary of the Dana Corporation. Now the Toledo, Ohio, company is supplying drive shafts for Toyota pickup truck production in both Japan and at New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., Toyota's joint venture with General Motors in California.
To be sure, Japanese purchases of American parts had been rising before the target was set and would have continued rising even without a target. As more Japanese auto production has shifted to the United States, local content regulations, as well as the convenience of a nearby supplier, have worked in favor of more parts purchases from the United States. And now, with the appreciation of the yen, it makes economic as well as political sense for Japanese companies to buy American parts.
But the downturn in Japan's domestic auto production has made it more difficult for the auto companies to import American parts. Japanese suppliers are hurting and starting to complain about new competition.
Teiji Suzuki, executive managing director in charge of international purchasing for Nissan, recalled hearing from Mr. Reilly at the Detroit conference that American parts makers had increased their sales to Japan but not sufficiently. "I told him, 'Congratulations, Mr. Reilly, Japanese parts makers have decreased their sales to auto makers in Japan.' He didn't say anything after that."
 
Trade Representative's Concern
 Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said here this week that he was concerned that American exports of car parts to Japan were only $1 billion annually, or about 1 percent of Japan's $98 billion market. The 1992 purchase plan calls for $4 billion of the $19 billion in American parts purchased to be exported to Japan.
Japanese officials say that imports from the United States accounted for $2.4 billion of the $13.6 billion in American parts procured last year, and that imports have more than doubled in four years. The discrepancy between the United States and Japanese figures is that the Japanese count general items like carpets and leather that are used in cars but are not classified for customs purposes as auto parts.
As for the claim that they are not buying high-technology parts, Japanese companies say that such parts must be designed into the car from the outset, making it difficult to buy such parts immediately.
"At the beginning, we tended to purchase parts like tires and glass that don't require joint development," said Hiroyoshi Ono, a spokesman for Toyota.
Now more complex parts are being purchased, they say. Toyota recently announced it might buy cruise-control systems from the Ford Motor Company. Nissan is buying steering gears and other parts from TRW.
 
Target Too Early
 Mr. Kantor, the trade representative, said Washington had already expressed its concern to the Japanese Government that much of the American parts purchased by transplant auto factories came from 400 or so Japanese-owned suppliers that had set up factories in the United States.
"This is just replicating their exclusionary practices in the United States," said Lee Kadrich, director of government affairs for the Automotive Parts and Accessories Association, a trade group.
But Japanese officials say that such Japanese parts factories in the United States employ Americans and often buy their components from American companies.
The Japanese auto makers association will not provide figures that distinguish between American-owned and Japanese-owned factories.
But a new study by the Boston Consulting Group, which was commissioned by the association to assess the quality of United States suppliers, estimates that Japanese auto factories in the United States obtain only 26 percent of their parts from traditional American suppliers. Some of the imports of American parts to Japan also come from Japanese owned companies.
Still, that situation now appears to be changing as well. "Traditional suppliers have been brought into the process," Mr. Reilly said.
The Boston Consulting Group said there was still a gap between American and Japanese suppliers in their ability to support Japanese auto companies.
The Big Three American auto companies make 50 to 70 percent of their parts themselves and give detailed designs to suppliers for the rest. The report said American suppliers had had trouble adjusting to the system used by Japanese auto companies, which is to buy most of their parts from outside and let suppliers design those parts.
Toyota established a supplier support center in Lexington, Ky., last year and is now working with 19 American suppliers on improving quality and productivity.

HEADLINE: Mexican Stocks Post Losses

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Mexican stocks fell in heavy trading in the United States yesterday on worries that an American court ruling would delay the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Traders said selling pressure was somewhat restrained because it was unclear during trading hours whether the ruling would be supported by the Clinton Administration. 
 One trader said the news gave investors an excuse to take profits. Mexican stocks advanced Tuesday on expectations of a decline in Mexican interest rates, he said.
Rates on Mexico's 28-day Treasury bill fell yesterday, which helped offset the selling pressure on stocks, traders said.
The shares of Telefonos de Mexico, the Mexican telephone company, took the brunt of the selling, in part because it is so widely held. Telmex shares fell $1.625, to $46.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: May Factory Orders Fell 1.4% for 3d Drop in Row

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
Orders received by the nation's factories tumbled in May for the third straight month to the lowest level since November, the Commerce Department said today.
The 1.4 percent decline in May orders followed a revised three-tenths of 1 percent decrease in April orders. The April drop was previously reported as one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 Economists said manufacturers again curbed output to trim stocks of unsold goods, which grew for the fourth consecutive month. Inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, to $381.4 billion, after a two-tenths of 1 percent rise in April.
They also attributed the drop to weak demand for United States exports and a reluctance among businesses to purchase big-ticket items because of uncertainty over President Clinton's economic program.
"U.S. manufacturing is stagnant at this time," said Allen Sinai, Economic Advisers Inc.'s chief economist. "Manufacturing has been dragging the economy down."
 
String 0f Consecutive Declines
Economists had expected factory orders, which include everything from diapers to missiles, to decline just eight-tenths of 1 percent in May. Orders have dropped in four of the last five months, and the string of three consecutive declines was the first since the three months ending in March 1991.
May's level of orders -- $249.3 billion adjusted for seasonal factors -- was the lowest since November of last year, when they were $244.0 billion. But orders still were up 4 percent from May 1992.
The drop in orders offered more evidence the economy is growing only modestly. The Commerce Department said this week sales of new homes had their biggest drop in May in 13 years, and the Government's key economic forecasting gauge slipped.
Economists said the weakness in the manufacturing sector was widespread. Unfilled orders -- a sign of future production -- fell nine-tenths of 1 percent in May to the lowest level in four and a half years.
While stocks of unsold goods are not considered to be at alarming levels, they continued to swell. But economists singled out as a problem the uncertainty over what tax changes will be in the President's budget.
Certain changes are sure to affect how businesses will spend money on machinery, turbines and other big-ticket items used in production. As a result, companies are delaying purchases of such products, economists said.
"Why make the commitment until you see how things shake out?" said Richard Berner of Mellon Bank.
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods, a measure of business expansion plans, fell 1.1 percent after a 3.7 percent rise in April.
Shipments of manufactured goods, an indication of current demand, fell five-tenths of 1 percent in May after a 1.5 percent tumble.
Military contractors' orders, which are subject to wide monthly swings and have been hurt by military spending cuts, skidded 15.6 percent after a 7.5 percent drop in April.
Excluding military-related industries, factory orders fell 1 percent in May and slipped one-tenth of 1 percent in April.

HEADLINE: For a Grieving Mother, Freshened Tears

BYLINE: By LYNDA RICHARDSON

 BODY:
Maria Alonso buried her daughter in a rural New Jersey cemetery under a cloud of questions last July. But this week, she shed fresh tears after learning that her daughter may have been one of 17 prostitutes who were victims of a serial killer.
In a dimly lighted apartment in East New York, Brooklyn, Ms. Alonso grieved over the old wounds rubbed raw again, and over the labels that people will place on "poor dead girls" like her 33-year-old daughter, Anna Lopez. 
 "Prostitutes," Ms. Alonso said with a bitter half-laugh. "It hurts a mother's heart. Why not call them victims of circumstances? He killed 17 daughters, you know. He killed 17 sisters to somebody. That's who he killed."
 
'Is He Laughing?'
 Authorities say that Joel Rifkin, an unemployed landscaper from Long Island, is a suspect in the death of Ms. Lopez, whose partially nude body was found May 25, 1992, in a wooded area off Interstate 84 in the Putnam County town of Patterson.
"The similarities in the way she was found, where she was from, what she did for a living and the way she was killed would strongly suggest he is a very good suspect in our case," said Lieut. John Noonan of the State Police Bureau of Criminal Investigations.
Since her daughter's disappearance last year, Ms. Alonso said she has not had a good night's rest. She said her mind has raced constantly. "I wondered who killed my daughter. What is he doing now? Is he laughing? Is he living a normal life."
Now, she said, she feels a mixture of relief and anger. She is glad the man who may have killed her daughter is off the streets, but she will need to summon strength for another painful chapter in the courts.
 
A Happy, Outspoken Child
 "I want to get all these families together and I want everybody to be there in court with me," Ms. Alonso said, tears welling in her eyes. "I want to show that these girls, these prostitutes, have families who care. They were probably alone on the streets, but not in the world."
As she spoke, family members nodded in agreement. "We're going to be in court every day," said Monica Aguayo, Ms. Lopez's sister. "He wants to plead insanity. But he's not insane. He's just an evil person."
Ms. Alonso, 51, said her daughter was not born a prostitute. When Ms. Lopez was young, her mother said, she was a happy, outspoken child. But she was a girl whose life began to take wrong turns.
Ms. Alonso remembers getting on her knees to plead with her daughter to not drop out of the 11th grade. She recalled seeing the signs of drug addiction in her daughter after the death of Ms. Lopez's husband from a drug overdose.
She remembers seeing her daughter, worn down by drug addiction, on the streets, and listening to her promises to seek treatment. And she recalls weeping when her homeless daughter told her that she had almost frozen to death while sleeping on a stranger's doorstep.
Most of all, Ms. Alonso, remembers the sinking feeling that she had when her daughter did not show up to collect a widow's pension check last June. "I knew in my heart she was dead," she said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Calvin Sims Southern California's Top Grocery Chain Will Explore 2 New Niches.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
MORE Southern Californians do their grocery shopping at the Vons Companies than at any other supermarket chain. Last year, 347 Vons stores generated $5.6 billion in revenues, making the chain the nation's ninth-largest retail grocer.
But Vons has seen its sales slip lately, as it has been hit hard by an economic downturn and stiff price-cutting by competitors and wholesale grocery clubs. In the first quarter, which ended on March 28, sales at stores open more than a year declined 8.3 percent. So, Vons is looking for new ways to grow. 
 In an expansion that could make or break its dominance in the West, Vons plans to spend more than $100 million to build 10 stores in low-income areas of Los Angeles and tens of millions of dollars more to develop mega-stores that sell everything from wholesale groceries and discount drugs to dry cleaning and video services.
Vons says that the inner city has great potential because it is grossly underserved. The chain said that as many as 1.2 million people in South-Central Los Angeles do not have access to a supermarket.
After losing customers to the wholesale clubs, Vons plans to open three "Expo" stores that provide one-stop shopping for customers looking for bargain prices. The stores are planned for Riverside and San Bernardino Counties, where wholesale clubs have been highly successful. If these stores prosper, Vons plans to open more.
Some industry analysts say that while the two new ventures represent good growth opportunities, they are fraught with risks. Operating a supermarket in an urban area is more expensive than in the suburbs because of the high cost of real estate, utilities, insurance, transportation and security. In addition, the wholesale grocery club industry is rapidly consolidating, and this does not bode well for a new entrant, analysts say.
"There's no question that the inner city is a place where you can make money in the grocery business," said Douglas Christopher, an analyst for Crowell, Weedon & Company in Los Angeles, "but there is the risk that after investing millions of dollars to open these new facilities, they could be trashed or destroyed."
Mr. Christopher, who has rated Vons's stock a "hold," said that the chain had good long-term prospects but that he did not see any near-term increase in revenues, which should remain flat for the year because of weak economic conditions in the region. He estimates that Vons will earn $1.90 a share for the year, compared with $1.89 last year.
Vons's shares closed yesterday at $23.125, off 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Their range in the last 12 months has been $21 to $26.375.
Charles E. Cerankosky, an analyst for Hancock Institutional Equity Services, praised Vons's plans. "California is such a diverse market that it makes sense for them to try to reach as many different customers as possible," he said. Vons has been pursuing that strategy through its Pavilions stores, which cater to affluent customers, and its Tianguis stores, which aim at Hispanic customers.
Mr. Cerankosky also rates the stock a hold, estimating per-share earnings at $1.95 for the year. "This is a challenging year economically in Southern California, and consumers are being very careful with their dollars and there's nothing that indicates it will get better," he said.
Mary M. MacAboy, Vons's director of investor relations, said the company believed that the best way to enhance shareholder value was to reinvest in operations. By the end of this year, Vons will have spent about $1 billion over five years opening new stores, remodeling and updating technology.
