HEADLINE: Issues of Corporate Securities Hit a Record

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The lowest interest rates in 20 years fueled corporate America's drive to raise cash in the public marketplace in the first six months of this year, and a record amount of securities was issued. In turn, investment firms raked in record fees.
Corporations issued $530 billion in debt and equity securities in the six-month period that ended yesterday, up some 19 percent from the previous record of $445 billion that hit the market in the first two quarters of 1992, according to the Securities Data Company, a research company. 
 The rush to raise cash slowed slightly in the second quarter, with $258.2 billion in securities issued, down from the record amount in the first quarter of $271.4 billion. But the second-quarter figure was still a healthy 15.8 percent jump over the $223 billion in securities issued in the second quarter of 1992.
 
Rush to Refinance
 With interest rates so low, corporations have rushed to refinance their debt to lower costs, even as institutional and retail investors were driven into a search for higher yields. That search has helped the equity markets, where companies have been fetching top dollar for new stock issued to the public.
The search for yield grew more intense in the last quarter, underwriters say, as more and more institutional investors and money managers decided to risk more in their investments to make up for the interest they were losing on safer securities, like Treasury debt.
"With historically low Treasury yields, fixed-income accounts are more willing to extend out along the yield curve and down the credit curve," said James B. Quigley, managing director with domestic debt new issues at Merrill Lynch & Company. "The lower rates go, the less selective accounts can afford to be in their search for yield."
That has meant that Wall Street has successfully underwritten deals that might not have been doable six months ago, helping increase Wall Street's fees. Firms earned $2.2 billion in the second quarter, and a record $4.3 billion in the first six months of the year. That is up from $3.6 billion in the first two quarters of 1992, according to Securities Data.
 
Initial Offerings Gain
 Initial public offerings continued at a strong pace, with $26.5 billion in new securities issued in the first six months, up from $20.9 billion in the first half of 1992. But underwriters said that the initial offering market had begun changing in recent weeks, as investors turned away a bit from companies expected to grow rapidly and toward more defensive investments, like convertible or preferred securities, which offer high yields.
Merrill Lynch, the perennial leader in underwriting since the late 1980's, again captured the top spot, with $99.6 billion in the six-month period, for 18 percent of the market.
The biggest changes in rank in the period came in equity underwritings. Dean Witter Reynolds, which ranked 11th in common stock underwritings in the first six months of 1992, rose to rank fifth. Salomon Brothers, which had been hobbled by the 1991 Treasury markets scandal and ranked 10th in the first half of last year, showed signs of renewed vigor, rising to rank sixth in common stock underwriting.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains After Clinton Urges Lower German Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against major foreign currencies in active trading yesterday in New York following President Clinton's suggestion that Germany should lower its interest rates.
Gold and silver prices fell. Gold for August delivery slipped 20 cents, to $378.40 an ounce; July silver was 0.5 cent lower at $4.558 an ounce. 
 Traders said the dollar moved higher on a combination of Mr. Clinton's comment and technical factors.
 
 
'Expand the Economy'
 The President, speaking to reporters and relating his goals for the Group of Seven summit meting in Tokyo next week, said the Bundesbank should lower interest rates "so that all of us together can expand this economy."
The German central bank is scheduled to meet today. It has been under pressure for months to lower rates to stimulate the lagging world economy, but has resisted because of inflation fears.
If German interest rates fall, United States rates would become more competitive. That would make American investments more attractive and tend to drive the dollar higher.
Early in the day, the dollar was trading lower. Traders were concerned about the United States June employment report, scheduled for release tomorrow, said Randolph Donney, director of research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
But improvement in the Chicago purchasing managers' index, which measures economic activity in that area, prompted some concern about higher American interest rates in the future, Mr. Donney said.
 
 
Inflation Concerns
 If stronger economic activity brings inflation, that could prompt the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates, making the dollar more valuable against foreign currencies. This may have fueled dollar buying even more, Mr. Donney said.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 106.51 yen, down 0.34 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 106.60 yen. In New York, the dollar traded late at 106.95 yen, up from 106.50 Tuesday.
In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.4930, down from $1.5035 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound was trading late at $1.4915, down from $1.5118 Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, were: 1.7060 German marks, up from 1.6893; 1.5135 Swiss francs, up from 1.4990; 5.7470 French francs, up from 5.6910; 1,550.00 Italian lira, up from 1,536.00, and $1.2822 (Canadian ), up from $1.2821 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Hartford May Try to Lure Patriots

BYLINE: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 30

 BODY:
A plot to bring the New England Patriots to Hartford to play in a new stadium here was revealed today by the Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., and the chief plotter, Francis W. Murray of Philadelphia.
The state would build the stadium and Murray, a former minority owner of the Patriots, would provide the team. 
 However, Weicker and Murray both acknowledged that for this plan to unfold, by its target date of 1996, several things need be sorted out.
Primary is the acquisition of the National Football League franchise by Murray's group of financiers, which yesterday made an offer of $133 million to the Patriots' owner, James Busch Orthwein of St. Louis.
Murray believes that such a sale in turn is dependent upon St. Louis being granted one of the two expansion franchises the N.F.L. will award in October. A 70,000-seat indoor stadium is under construction there in anticipation of an N.F.L. team.
 
A Cost of $200 Million
 The price offered Orthwein, said Murray, is the equivalent of the $140 million the N.F.L. seeks for its expansion franchises, minus a 5 percent discount.
According to Murray, the 65,000-70,000-seat outdoor stadium -- with a grass field plus skybox amenities missing at spartan Foxboro Stadium, where the Patriots have played since 1971 -- would cost about $200 million. Six sites along the Connecticut River are under consideration. "We're not at the point where I can give details about costs and locations," Weicker said.
The new stadium is tied to an economic plan whereby a bond issue would provide construction funds. Its debt service would be covered by tax revenues generated by stadium events from ticket sales, concessions, increased hotel, restaurant and transportation activity.
"The facility can pay for itself without cost to the taxpayer," said Murray, who has a 30-year lease in mind for the team.
 
Share With the Huskies
 An offshoot of the plan would be co-tenancy of the new facility here, now called Connecticut Riverfront Stadium, by the University of Connecticut football team. Weicker foresaw an upgrading of the UConn football program from its present Division I-AA status in the Yankee Conference to I-A and possible Big East membership.
"I've already spoken to Lew Perkins about that," said Weicker, referring to the UConn athletic director.
The stadium would be designed for football only, Murray said. It would be in use about 17 times a year: eight regular-season and three preseason games for the Patriots and six home games for the UConn Huskies.
 
'Moving Next Door'
 The Foxboro Stadium, seating 60,794 and seldom filled, cost $9 million and was the least expensive of the first-generation of 16 sports stadiums for professional baseball and/or football teams built between 1961 and 1976.
The usual economic impact and market-area statistics were offered while stress was made on "keeping the Patriots in New England," said Murray, rather than snatching them away from the Boston market. "We would just be moving next door," he said.
Foxboro Stadium is 22 highway miles south of Boston and 60 milesnortheast of Hartford. Downtown Hartford is 105 miles from Boston and 120 from New York. Territorial boundaries in the N.F.L. extend 75 miles so, in theory, there would be no invasion of the New York television market.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
MARATHON OIL TO IDLE INDIANA REFINERY TEMPORARILY

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The Marathon Oil Company said yesterday that it would temporarily stop production at its unprofitable 50,000 barrel-a-day refinery in Indianapolis beginning Oct. 1. The company, a subsidiary of the USX Corporation, said it would idle the refinery because of "unfavorable plant economics" and the growing expense of meeting environmental standards. The refinery is Marathon's smallest, producing about 8 percent of the company's refined products. 
 The plant employs 255 people -- 111 salaried and 144 union workers -- but it was not clear how many employees would be laid off, a plant spokesman, Steve Wagner, said.

HEADLINE: Mr. Stein Quits

 BODY:
There is more to life than politics, and more to public service than being an elected official.
 -- Andrew Stein, in his statement retiring from politics
 It often seemed, during most of his 25 years in public life, that there really was nothing but politics for Andrew Stein. It drove him and shaped him. He loved the hobnobbing, the glamour, the celebrity. A child of John Kennedy's shirt-sleeved generation of gilded politics, most of all Andrew Stein reveled in the game. 
 Now he says he just doesn't love it anymore. He's giving up his job as President of the City Council, just renamed Public Advocate, and declares he will never run for office again. That's hard to believe for those who have watched him from the early days when he dreamed out loud of being the first Jewish President, to his recent debacle as a failed candidate for mayor. But Mr. Stein claims he means it, and if he does, his decision speaks to his hard-earned political acumen.
Most public figures don't know when to call it quits. Weakened by his unsuccessful mayoral campaign and facing a job diminished in power, the 48- year-old Mr. Stein had the sense to bow out gracefully. He might have won re-election, but if his ambition had fled, why bother?
That, of course, is the hardest to accept -- the idea of an ambition-free Andrew Stein. He has been a fixture in the public life of New York City since he ran for the Assembly when he was 23. He won, largely thanks to his father's money, and has tried ever since to live down his reputation as a creature of political extravagance and parental largess.
To some degree, he managed to improve his image. His probe of fraud in the nursing home industry, despite some investigative excesses, helped clean up corruption and saved many elderly people from poor care. Subsequently, as Manhattan Borough President and then City Council President, Mr. Stein exposed problems in the city's emergency medical service, in the school custodians' union and in the training of doctors. Candid about his limitations, he always surrounded himself with knowledgeable, talented staff members, and always knew how to earn the media's attention.
That was his greatest strength but also his greatest weakness: Mr. Stein cared too much about publicity and image, which made the most damaging error of his mayoral campaign all the more curious. His conspicuously lavish fund-raising events left a sour taste in the mouths of recession-weary New Yorkers. Instead of celebrating the reforms of the city's system of campaign financing, he resisted them. This reliance on outdated money politics, and other flaws in his campaign, stalled Mr. Stein's mayoral effort; in May he dropped out.
What now for Andrew Stein? He isn't quite saying, but here's a guess. Whatever the next phase of his career, New Yorkers will be hearing from him. In the words of his father, the publisher and businessman Jerry Finkelstein, politics is "never out of anybody's blood forever."

HEADLINE: The Shrinking African Giant

 BODY:
Once Nigeria was considered the anchor and bellwether of a huge continent. Blessed with clever and energetic peoples, favored with ample oil resources, it is also Africa's most populous country, with 110 million inhabitants. But despite size and wealth, Nigeria lingers in the doldrums, perpetually a country of the future.
This year was supposed to be different. Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, a self-installed President since 1985, promised to hand over power in August to an elected successor. Nigeria's armed forces had organized two political parties, one right of center, the other tipping to left. Nigerian diplomats disseminated glossy brochures, filled with diagrams showing how a new federal system would unite the mostly Muslim north with the Christian and animist south. 
 Alas, it all proved illusory. Twice General Babangida postponed elections. After Nigerians were finally allowed to vote on June 12, the general canceled the result, claiming the poll was marred by widespread fraud. Over the protests of the presumed winner, Moshood Abiola, a wealthy industrialist and publisher, the general promised yet another election in late July, but with different candidates.
The President-General has earned his nickname: Maradona, after a soccer player celebrated for his stealthy footwork. He talks enough democracy to placate Americans and other foreigners, yet prevents the growth of a credible opposition. And now, faced with the threats of a general strike and the resignation of 30 senior military officers, he speaks menacingly of crushing opposition with force.
The Clinton Administration was right to suspend its modest foreign aid programs when the election was voided. Nigeria can never evolve a political system commensurate to its size and importance if its military leaders, as in bad old colonial times, treat civilians as incompetent. Meantime, billions of petrodollars melt into the sands, and Africa's giant continues to shrink.

HEADLINE: Veteran Communist Crowns A Comeback in Azerbaijan

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan, June 30

 BODY:
Heydar Aliyev, the former Communist boss of Azerbaijan and Politburo member in the Soviet Union, consolidated a dramatic comeback today by naming the republic's dominant warlord as his Prime Minister and head of all internal and external security forces.
After two days of negotiations with Surat Husseinov, the 34-year-old maverick military commander whose move on the capital earlier this month drove the elected President into exile, Mr. Aliyev convened a Parliament and presented Mr. Husseinov as head of his Government and of the military, security ministry and interior ministry. There was only one dissenting vote. 
 Mr. Husseinov, a dapper man who had been director of a wool factory and amassed a mysterious fortune in recent years, spoke briefly and deferentially, leaving the floor largely to the 70-year-old Mr. Aliyev. The latter mixed pledges of economic and military revival with references to Islam and warnings to the opposition both before the Parliament and at a news conference.
 
Return From Political Limbo
 The parliamentary session effectively consolidated Mr. Aliyev's return after six years in political limbo. While he waited in the wings, for a while in exile in Moscow and then as leader of his native region of Nakhichevan, Azerbaijan was wracked with a debilitating war with Armenia over the mountainous region of Nagorno-Karabakh and by see-saw power struggles in Baku.
The last of these, a year ago, brought to power President Abulfez Elchibey, a scholar and former dissident, at the head of a broad coalition called the Popular Front. Though enormously popular at the time and elected President with 60 percent of the national vote, Mr. Elchibey failed to reverse Azerbaijani setbacks in Nagorno-Karabakh or to control the disintegrating economy and rampant corruption.
Mr. Elchibey's final defeat began on June 4, when the Government staged a clumsy attempt to disarm Mr. Husseinov's militia in the northern city of Gyandzha. Mr. Husseinov had been dismissed as military commander the previous February by Mr. Elchibey, and he now sent his militia toward the capital.
In the ensuing panic, Mr. Elchibey asked Mr. Aliyev to come to Baku as a mediator but then fled the capital for his native village in Nakhichevan. Mr. Aliyev was chosen as head of the Parliament and on Mr. Elchibey's flight was named the acting president. Mr. Elchibey, however, has refused to resign as President.
 
U.S. Recognizes Rival
 The United States and Turkey have so far continued to recognized Mr. Elchibey as President, though Russia demonstrated its satisfaction with the return of Mr. Aliyev by suspending the activities in Russia of a small ethnic group that has been agitating for independence from Azerbaijan.
Mr. Aliyev has joined the ranks of 11 former Soviet officials, including President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, who have remained or returned to power in newly independent republics. Asked about that at a news conference today, Mr. Aliyev feigned surprise at the question.
"The question makes no sense," he said. "There is no longer a Soviet Union, no Communist Party which led the Soviet Union alone through force. The people who come to power are those people can trust. What they did for the old Soviet Union has no significance. It makes no sense to divide officials into the 'former' and the 'new.' "
Like his other former comrade, Mr. Aliyev has his work cut out for him. There is the immediate challenge of Mr. Elchibey, who still has a following that could mount a mettlesome opposition and even resort to arms.
 
Threats to Opposition
 In his comments to Parliament, Mr. Aliyev issued veiled threats against the Popular Front and other political movements. "I don't want to use force, but while they should know that pluralism and political discussion can continue, armed groupings cannot," he said.
There is also no guarantee that Mr. Husseinov will work smoothly with Mr. Aliyev. An ambitious and popular leader, Mr. Husseinov is backed by a powerful militia, whose blue-bereted soldiers strutted on the streets outside Parliament during all the meetings.
There is also the five-year-old war in Nagorno-Karabakh, the most tenacious ethnic struggle in the former Soviet Union. Seizing on the chaos in Baku, Armenian forces have consolidated their grip on the disputed territory and in recent weeks have attacked Azerbaijani towns well beyond its borders.
Both Mr. Aliyev and Mr. Husseinov pledged to "win back lands lost to the enemy," but reports from the front indicate little Azerbaijani resistance.
 
Meeting With Oil Companies
 Mr. Aliyev also has the task of reassuring foreign governments and oil companies of his intentions. Mr. Elchibey's Government had been in the process of negotiating a lucrative deal with several foreign oil companies from Britain, the United States, Turkey and Norway for the development of offshore oil deposits in the Caspian Sea.
The Council of Ministers moved a week ago to suspend negotiations to cancel the "unified field" plan that would have treated the foreign companies as single consortium, raising the likelihood of a prolonged new round of bidding and negotiations. Mr. Aliyev today insisted that foreign companies and governments had nothing to worry about and scheduled a public meeting with oil company executives to demonstrate his good will.
As he has since Mr. Elchibey fled on June 18, Mr. Aliyev maintained that he has "great respect" for the absent President but that he could not run the country from his remote village. Mr. Husseinov was more blunt, branding Mr. Elchibey a "criminal" who should be prosecuted for crimes against the state.
At the same time, Mr. Aliyev has wasted no time building his image and authority. The state television has aired daily programs hailing his achievements, and the Russian-language Baku daily, Bakinets, carried a brazenly adulatory declaration on its first page, headlined in part, "HE Has Returned!!!"
Though many another republic has experienced Azerbaijan's pattern, passing from the elation of independence to disillusionment and the desperate recall of a former Communist chief, Mr. Aliyev's comeback was especially dramatic.
The former K.G.B. chief in Azerbaijan, he was named the Communist leader of the republic in 1969 under Leonid I. Brezhnev and soon gained a reputation as one of the most sycophantic regional leaders in the Soviet Union. In 1983, Mr. Brezhnev made him a full member of the Soviet Politburo and in the first years under Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he became a Deputy Prime Minister of the Soviet Union.
Mr. Aliyev was ousted from the Kremlin in an internal political shake-up in 1987. For three years he languished in oblivion in Moscow. His rehabilitation began in January 1990, when he addressed a rally in Moscow denouncing a bloody military intervention by Soviet forces in Baku and soon after he returned to Azerbaijan, now as a anti-Communist nationalist.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 3, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about the comeback of a veteran Communist, Heydar Aliyev, in Azerbaijan misidentified the Soviet leader who made him a full member of the Soviet Politburo and misstated the year. Yuri V. Andropov appointed him, in 1982.

HEADLINE: Kuwaitis Back U.S. Missile Strike on Iraq Capital

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, June 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's decision to fire missiles at Iraq's intelligence complex last weekend has been greeted warmly by Kuwaitis, for whom Iraq's guilt in an attempt to assassinate former President George Bush in April was never in doubt.
"It is part of the punishment that most people around here believe is well deserved by the Iraqi Government," said Fatma Hussein, editor of Samra, a publication concerned with women's issues in Kuwait. "We hope there will be more." 
 Her remarks echoed national sentiment in the small emirate, which is still traumatized by the Iraqi occupation and devastation of its economy during the Persian Gulf crisis of 1990-1991.
The trial of 16 men accused of plotting to kill Mr. Bush with a car bomb is to resume on Saturday, but may be further postponed "to permit the continuing questioning of defendants and their access to lawyers," Al Watan, a Kuwaiti daily, reported.
Two sessions of the trial have so far failed to attract much of an audience, and most Kuwaitis reached by telephone did not immediately recall its status. The sessions, held on June 5 and June 26, were reported on the inside pages of Kuwaiti newspapers and hardly at all in other regional news outlets.
"Frankly no one cares about the trial," said Mohammed al- Ghoderi, the director of an art gallery in Kuwait. "The fact that Saddam is a bad guy needs no proof for Kuwaitis. Still, the American hit of the Mukhabarat headquarters had tremendous support here for a day or so; then people slipped into the other concerns of the country."
The Mukhabarat is the Iraqi intelligence service.
Mahmoud al-Ghanem, a businessman in Kuwait, said: "The verdict on whether the Iraqis tried to kill Bush has been passed by the virtue of the American strike. Obviously the Americans believe these guys did try to kill Bush. We never doubted it. So, the trial is just a procedural thing now."
Kuwait's mood seems to be far from the trial. Attention is focused on other issues, including a parliamentary inquiry into financial irregularities by former officials -- among them members of the Kuwaiti ruling family -- that may involve as much as $5 billion missing from the public treasury.
In the last week, another highly emotional issue has erupted with a vehement public rejection of what seemed to be an awkward Government attempt to start reconciliation talks with Yemen and Tunisia, which supported Iraq during the gulf crisis. Last week, Tunisia's Foreign Minister went to Kuwait on an official visit and was greeted with cries of "Go Home."

Iraqi Is Conciliatory
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 1 (Reuters) -- Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz said today that Iraq had no intention of retaliating for the United States missile attack on Baghdad and that his Government hoped for better relations with the Clinton Administration.
"We would like to have a quiet peaceful relationship with the United States of America and the world at large," Mr. Aziz said in an interview in Baghdad with Cable News Network.
In the first comment to the West by a senior Iraqi leader since the attack, Mr. Aziz also repeated the Iraqi Government's denial of involvement in any plot to kill George Bush.
"This attack on Iraq was totally unjustified," Mr. Aziz said of the missile attack. "Iraq is not the enemy of the United States. We might have differences, yes, but those differences should be solved in a civilized manner."
Asked whether Iraq planned to retaliate, he said: "We are not contemplating any designs of revenge."

 GENEVA, July 1 (Reuters) -- Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali declined to comment today about whether the United States missile strike on Baghdad was legitimate under the United Nations Charter.

HEADLINE: Seoul's Leader Says North Is Manipulating U.S. on Nuclear Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, July 1

 BODY:
A week before President Clinton arrives here to reaffirm American solidarity with a longtime ally, President Kim Young Sam cautioned today that North Korea was manipulating its current negotiations with the United States "to buy time to finish their project" to build nuclear weapons.
In a turnaround from three months ago, when South Korean officials voiced fears the United States might be too aggressive in its dealings with the Communist Government in Pyongyang, Mr. Kim said he hoped the United States "will not continue to be led on by North Korea" when talks over nuclear inspections enter a third round in Geneva in two weeks. 
 His comments seemed to reflect a growing concern in Seoul that the Clinton Administration had already offered much to the North -- including legitimacy by engaging in the direct talks with the Government of Kim Il Sung for the first time since the end of the Korean War -- in return for little.
 
Says 'Time Is Running Short'
 Mr. Kim, who took office four months ago, declined to say exactly how long the talks should continue before the United States, South Korea and Japan should seek approval of the United Nations Security Council of economic sanctions on the North for its refusal to allow full international inspections.
But he said that "time is running short" and suggested that "by early next year they will be able to produce plutonium" in large enough quantities to produce several weapons.
His Foreign Minister, Han Sung Joo, said earlier this week that the North should only be given another month or two before the issue moves to the Security Council.
President Clinton's visit here, after the summit meeting of the seven leading industrial nations in Japan, will cap his first venture into Asia as President. The White House is planning to use it as a chance to portray him as prepared to face down the North Korean threat.
As many Presidents have done on their visits here, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to travel to the heavily armed demilitarized zone, have lunch with some of the Americans troops and make an address on Asian security to South Korea's national assembly.
Like Mr. Clinton, Mr. Kim is combatting an image at home of inexperience in diplomacy and military matters, and today he appeared to be taking a harder line against the North than in previous public statements. In the past, Korean officials have spoken of the risk of reviving a military confrontation.
In a wide-ranging interview at Blue House, the presidential mansion, he also said that since taking office he has been astounded to discover "how deeply corruption had embedded itself in government and society" and suggested that his predecessor, Roh Tae Woo, had ignored overwhelming evidence of wrongdoing in his Government.
Mr. Kim said that in his first few months in office he had purged South Korea's military and its intelligence services so that "never again can this kind of corruption take root."
 
Investigations Under Way
 But he said that many investigations were still under way, including one involving huge unexplained deposits in the accounts of senior officials of Mr. Roh's Government who were involved in a $6 billion purchase of American-made F-16 fighters to South Korea.
Mr. Kim's comments on the North Korean talks come at a critical juncture in the effort to get the North to abandon its nuclear project, although there is conflicting intelligence about how close it is to producing a workable arsenal of nuclear weapons.
So far the American talks, headed by Robert Gallucci, a deputy secretary of state, have succeeded in getting the North's hard-line Government to "suspend" its plan to leave the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons.
 
'A Tug of War'

But they have failed to make any progress on the inspection issue, meaning that the situation is almost exactly where it was in March.
Now the North appears to be trying to slow down the subsequent negotiations. "At this point we are into a tug of war with them" over how fast to move, one of Mr. Kim's senior aides said.
When North Korea first announced that it was planning to withdraw from the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, the Government here took a soft line, hoping quiet persuasion would work.
The United States took a tougher view, with some officials hinting that if a diplomatic route could not be found to end the North's nuclear program, a military one might be considered.
 
Endless Discussions Feared
 Now the roles seem reversed. Some Korean officials are concerned that the United States could get dragged into endless discussions with the North, veering into questions of when economic aid could begin to flow or the establishment of diplomatic relations.
In another sign of recent American flexibility in the talks, United States delegates made it clear that if North Korea allowed inspections, Washington would cancel joint military exercises with South Korea and reaffirm that it would not introduce nuclear weapons into the Korean peninsula.

HEADLINE: A Russian Tradition So Old It's Revolutionary: Trial by Jury

BYLINE: By DEBORAH STEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 1

 BODY:
"It will be hard to change," admitted Judge Galina Zmicharovskaya, who presides in the Siberian region of Irkutsk. "I'm used to deciding on the evidence myself. But I'd like to try it."
Judge Zmicharovskaya and dozens of her colleagues from all over Russia are weighing what they've learned from a short course in a tradition long forgotten in this country: trial by jury. 
 The course, offered at the Russian Legal Academy here in the capital, is part of an effort by advocates of change in President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government to introduce jury trials in Russia -- as a symbol of human rights and as the best way to correct decades of judicial abuse.
"Under Stalin, there was the complete subordination of criminal procedure to Party rule," said Aleksandr Yakovlev, a professor at the Russian Academy of Science's Institute of State and Law. "The idea now is for the jury to guarantee the independence of the court."
 
Compulsory 'Civic Duty'
 The details hang on a bill now pending in Parliament, but the advocates say they hope to put juries in some criminal courtrooms in five of Russia's 88 regions, including suburban Moscow, by the end of the year. Jurors, chosen from voting rolls and paid a daily fee out of the Federal budget, will serve, if the defendant so chooses, in the mid-level courts that handle everything from robbery to the capital crime of murder.
Jurors must be at least 25 years old and free of criminal convictions. And jury service is to be compulsory. "It will be a civic duty," said Sergei Pashin, the young lawyer who heads the reform unit in the State Legal Agency and who is the project's chief architect.
The bill, expected to become law during the summer, also allows the 12 jurors to ask questions of witnesses as well as the defendant, and to reach a verdict via simple majority, rather than unanimously, if deliberations go beyond three hours. "It's not exactly like your jury trial," the 30-year-old Mr. Pashin told an American visitor. "But we have to go step by step."
 
2 Snarling Dogs and a Bike
 The classes at the Legal Academy are a start. On a recent Monday morning, about 50 Russian judges and law students crowded into a classroom to watch a jury at work, in a civil case involving an unattended auto yard, two snarling dogs and a man riding by on a bike.
The mock trial -- everything from the "all rise" to the jury charge -- was performed by a team of American judges and lawyers on a visit sponsored by the American State Department. The jurors were drawn from the Russian judges and lawyers in the audience. After deliberating for 90 minutes, they found for the defendant, rejecting the fallen bicyclist's charge of negligence and his request for damages of $500,000 (an amount so mind-boggling to the academy's interpreter that she twice asked for clarification).
"It was a good verdict, given the evidence," said Judge Judith Chirlin of Los Angeles County Superior Court, who presided over the case. (The real-life Los Angeles trial on which the drama was loosely based, she notes, ended with an award of about $175,000 to the plaintiff.)
The civil trial, requested by the academy in light of Russia's move toward a market economy, came a day after the American team walked their students through a typical criminal trial. That detailed discussion prompted a flurry of questions about evidence ("Why is hearsay not allowed as testimony?") and about the jury's role in evaluating it ("Does a defendant's good or bad character bear on the verdict?")
 
'Reconstruct the Mentality'
 Members of the Russian legal system have come to the United States, too, to learn about jury trials. In December, four Russians, including Mr. Pashin, came to Harvard University Law School for a two-week seminar with law professors, lawyers and jurors. The program was headed by Philip B. Heymann, who was then the director of the school's Center for Criminal Justice and is now the deputy Attorney General.
The Russians also went on field trips to Boston and Cambridge courtrooms. "They were fascinated by the jury creation process," said Carmen Ortiz of the Middlesex County Attorney's Office. "They asked, 'How do you make people come in for jury duty, and maybe give up two weeks of their time?' "
About 600 of Russia's 12,000 judges, mostly from the five designated regions, have completed jury training in Moscow. Besides mock trials, the training involves reading, lectures and practice sessions. "You can't make a good judge in a month," said Lev Khaldeyev, the program's dean. "But we try to reconstruct the mentality, the presumption that there's no need for evidence."
Under the lingering Soviet system, criminal cases are decided by a judge and two "lay assessors," whose compliance is almost guaranteed. Procurators, as prosecutors are called here, have broad investigative powers. As "supervisors of legality" in society, they have much sway with the judge.
 
Don't Always Show Up
 Often they do not even show up in court; they simply send in a dossier chronicling the case against the defendant. Despite recent changes, the defense lawyers, known as advocates, can do little more in court than chip away at the charge or the sentence. Conviction rates run to 99 percent.
"Defense attorneys feel they are up against the prosecutors and the judges here," said Aleksei P. Galoganov, a prominent advocate, in a recent talk with experts from the United Nations' Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice Branch, here to assess legal reform. "As for presumption of innocence, we were taught it was a 'bourgeois' concept."
For Mr. Pashin and his team, jury trial is more than a short cut on the road to changing all this. It is the only road, given the legacy of Soviet justice. "The judge is thinking that the accused person is guilty," he said. "So we have to give the layman the right to be the judge." What's more, Mr. Pashin says, only juries can make lawyers, especially prosecutors, perform more professionally. "They will have to prove their indictments to independent people, who demand better evidence," he said. "Juries are a way to wake them up."
Some American experts caution that the Russians may be putting too much stock in the power of juries. "To look at the jury as a quick fix is an illusion," said Michael Posner, executive director of the Lawyers Committee For Human Rights, a private group that works to promote human rights and has just published a report on legal reform in Russia. "It's a radical change that takes power out of the hands of the government, and that's a right instinct.
 
Pressure Can Be Unfair
 "But it must be brought in after an independent judiciary is in place," he said. "After all, if a juror is threatened or bribed, he has to have a legal system to stand up for him. To put all the pressure on 12 people to make up for a century of legal abuse is unfair."
Already, the Russian regions involved in the first planned phase of jury trial are complaining of limited resources, though their leaders support the idea of jury trial. Suburban Moscow authorities fear that their pretrial detention cells, already filled to four times their capacity as crime rises, will be taxed further by the longer jury trials. In Ryazan, about 180 miles southeast of Moscow, there aren't enough prosecutors, courtrooms, telephones or chairs. None of the regions yet have computers for jury selection or court-stenographic equipment.
But Mr. Pashin, who drafted the law that created Russia's Constitutional Court in 1991 and pushed through bills on the right of habeas corpus and the independence of the judiciary, is convinced that reforms will not work without juries. "Established democracies like America can afford to be disillusioned with jury trial," he says. "In our country, we have no other way to reform."
Juries are not new to Russia. They first appeared as part of the great legal reforms of 1864, shortly after Czar Alexander 2d abolished serfdom. The jury system gradually flourished over the next 50 years, producing lawyers like the legendary Fyodor Plevako, who became famous for brilliant courtroom speeches that acquitted hundreds of peasants and workers. "Historically, jury trial seems to go in parallel with the development of democracy here," said Mr. Yakovlev, a participant in the Assembly now drafting Russia's new Constitution, which will provide for juries.
Jury trial was banned by the Communists soon after they took power in 1917. "The Bolsheviks were full of praise for jury trials as long as they acquitted revolutionaries," Mr. Pashin said. "But when the Red Terror was unleashed, there was no place for trial by jury anymore."
 
Still a Hazy Concept
 For most Russian citizens today, trial by jury is a hazy concept, clarified only a bit by exposure to American crime movies. Few know about the planned reform, and some still feel that serious crimes like murder are better judged by legal experts. Many, though, express support for a system that puts justice in the hands of more than a few. "Jury trial is how many, 12? Then I'm for it," said a private chauffeur who regularly picks up fares for extra rubles near the Parliament. "It's a better way to get to the truth."
Mr. Khaldeyev of the Legal Academy likes to point out what happened at a mock jury trial presented by an American team last year in President Yeltsin's hometown, Yekaterinburg. "I had asked the American playing the prosecutor to act as one of our prosecutors would," Mr. Khaldeyev said. "So when he lost the case, he began to berate the judge." After a few minutes of repeated warnings, Mr. Khaldeyev says, the judge finally ruled the prosecutor in contempt of court. "His hammer came down, and he said, 'Five days in jail,' " he recalled gleefully. "And the audience, which was full of our judges, broke out in applause."

Yeltsin's Government, lawyers and judges from all over Russia are taking courses in trials by jury at the Russian Legal Academy in Moscow. Sergei Pashin lectured to a group of lawyers from central Russia at the academy. (Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Haitian Army Aide Sees Progress Toward Accord

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
Appearing to break a five-day deadlock in talks aimed at restoring democracy to Haiti, a spokesman for Haiti's army leader announced yesterday that the commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, was close to approving a settlement package proposed by United Nations mediators.
In an evening news conference after an intense afternoon of discussions on Governors Island, in New York Harbor, the spokesman, Serge E. Charles, called the plan "a good proposal." He added, "We don't see any reason why a solution cannot be reached soon." 
 Mr. Charles said the proposal called for the restoration of Haiti's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, by Oct. 30. Mr. Charles said the settlement, once sealed, included the end of the international embargo on oil supplies for Haiti and the resumption of "technical and military aid to the country."
Shortly before 9 P.M., a United Nations spokesman said that an agreement with the Army was imminent, but that no further announcements would be immediately forthcoming. Journalists were asked to leave the island.
Minutes before Mr. Charles's announcement, officials in Washington said the Administration would request $37.5 million in aid for Haiti, to be made available immediately after a settlement, to help repair damage to the country's devastated economy and rehabilitate the 7,000-member Army.
Mr. Charles would not say explicity that General Cedras would step down immediately, as has been demanded by Father Aristide, but he told reporters, "We believe that the laws in our constitution will deal adequately with the question of the Army staff."
Mr. Charles, speaking in French, said that "if General Cedras's departure would contribute to a solution, he is ready to go."
Senior diplomats involved in the negotiations said the military delegation had all but accepted the United Nationsplan.
A member of Father Aristide's delegation, told of the Haitian military's response to the proposal, said that if it held up under examination, "it would be important, very important, and would move us significantly in the direction of something lasting."
The announcement by the Haitian military came after a day of apparent setbacks in which the delegation of Father Aristide angered United Nations officials by mentioning only two of the elements of the solution in briefings with reporters: the departure of General Cedras and the military high command, and the early return of the President. The two sides appeared to be sparring over dates for Father Aristide's return as President.
Dante Caputo of Argentina, the United Nations special envoy to Haiti who has led the talks, emerged from meetings in the early evening to tell reporters that the Aristide delegation had "distorted the equilibrium of the proposal and created risks and dangers."
 
Risk of a Backlash
 Later, diplomats said that by emphasizing the price the military had to pay, Father Aristide's aides were potentially inciting hard-line elements of the armed forces in Haiti and the most conservative elements of the business community to mobilize against an accord. Early yesterday, there were reports of mysterious bomb explosions in several neighborhoods of the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince.
Responding to the United Nations criticisms, one adviser to the President said, "We purposely, honestly tried to put the onus on the Army."
A senior diplomat who has played an active role in the talks said the apparent breakthrough, after five days of frustrating talks marked by advances followed by sudden setbacks and then long, sterile waits, was the product of a new negotiating strategy by Mr. Caputo.
Late yesterday, it was still unclear what form the international presence in Haiti would take after a settlement. Mr. Charles, General Cedras's spokesman, said the United Nations proposal no longer contained mention of an international police force, which had been a centerpiece of past efforts.

HEADLINE: Mandela to Hold Off Calling for an End to Sanctions

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela said today that despite some recent progress on talks over the transition to majority rule in South Africa, he is not yet able to make a much-anticipated call for a lifting of all sanctions against his country.
On his second day in the United States, Mr. Mandela said he might be able to make such an announcement within three weeks if talks with the white South African Government and other parties make sufficient advances on plans for establishing an interim government until elections next year. 
 But his comments disappointed many in the Clinton Administration and on Capitol Hill who had hoped that the negotiations would have made more progress by now. The American officials had anticipated that Mr. Mandela would take advantage of his visit to the United States, including two appearances with President Clinton, to make a dramatic announcement calling for the lifting of sanctions in the next few days.
 
U.S. Prepares Incentives
 The black nationalist leader, who is president of the African National Congress, explained that such an announcement continued to hinge on progress toward the creation of an interim government that would run South Africa until multiracial elections -- the first under universal suffrage -- take place next April.
One Administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said American officials had prepared a package of incentives in anticipation of the simultaneous visits by Mr. Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa, both of whom arrived in the United States on Wednesday.
Announcement of a package, including election assistance and help in obtaining foreign investments, will now not be made during their trip, the official said.
"Some elements of it will be in a presidential statement, saying that if we get a date for the election and the transitional executive councils we can push ahead on these things," the official said.
The Bush Administration lifted comprehensive Federal sanctions against South Africa last year, but many state and local restrictions continue.
 
New York City Sanctions
 New York City's sanctions, for example, bar city contracts and investments by municipal pension funds with banks and other companies that do business with South Africa. Mayor David N. Dinkins has indicated that he is prepared to seek the lifting of sanctions at Mr. Mandela's request.
The creation of a transitional government is being debated in constitutional talks in Johannesburg. Delegates there are expected Friday to ratify an April 27 date for the election, but with something short of full agreement by all parties in South Africa's political spectrum.
Mr. Mandela said today that he had been getting updates on the talks by telephone and that he had discussed the situation with Mr. de Klerk. The two leaders are scheduled to receive the Liberty Medal from Mr. Clinton in Philadelphia on Sunday, the Fourth of July.
After decades of campaigning for international sanctions against the white Government in South Africa, Mr. Mandela and the African National Congress are walking a fine line in seeking commitments for future investment in South Africa without asking for the lifting of sanctions before a black or multiracial government actually is established.
A key challenge for Mr. Mandela is to convince the international community that the era of apartheid -- legalized racial segregation -- is indeed ending.
 
Complications of Violence
 The question is not just one of semantics and timing. Many of the 29 states and more than 100 American cities that have adopted sanctions against South Africa said explicitly that they were not to be lifted until apartheid had ended.
Mr. Mandela's task is complicated by continuing violence in South Africa, including the recent storming of the constitutional talks by hundreds of armed white extremists who damaged the hall and roughed up some delegates and journalists.
Dumisani Kumalo, projects director for the New York-based Africa Fund, said the incident undermined both an end to sanctions and the inclination of businesses to invest in South Africa even if restrictions were lifted.
Mr. Mandela met with members of the House and Senate foreign relations committees today. On Friday, he is scheduled to meet separately with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Mr. Clinton.
Speaking after his meetings with committee members, Mr. Mandela said the African National Congress had at one point opposed lifting sanctions until after South Africa's Parliament ratified a transitional government.
The Parliament is not scheduled to resume until September. But Mr. Mandela said that, with an unemployment rate among blacks of 48 percent and a "rocketing" crime rate, the A.N.C. hopes to persuade other parties to adopt a transitional formula beforehand. He said Mr. de Klerk had assured him that Parliament would move quickly on the matter.
Mr. de Klerk meanwhile spent the day in private talks with leaders of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, which continue to bar assistance to South Africa. He also has meetings scheduled on Friday with Mr. Clinton and Mr. Christopher.

Talking with him were Representatives Lee Hamilton, left, the committee chairman, Harry Johnson, right, and Tom Lantos. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Mayor Faces Hard Part: Running Los Angeles

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 1

 BODY:
He's made all the right moves so far, cajoling legislators in Sacramento for money, jogging with President Clinton in Washington, riding in the gay-pride parade on Sunday and appointing a respected City Council aide as chief of staff.
Now the question is whether Richard J. Riordan, as Mayor, can rescue this city of fan palms and hibiscus blossoms from its slide into racial discord, criminal violence and economic despair. Will American urban salvation be found in the likes of this conservative 63-year-old Republican, a millionaire businessman who has never held elective office before? 
 The tall, ruddy Mr. Riordan, who was born in Queens, was sworn in today as the first Republican in a generation to lead what is now the second largest, most diverse and perhaps most problematic city in America.
"We must together create a will among all Angelenos to take back our neighborhoods," he said, standing on the south steps of City Hall before about 1,000 people. And, in an exhortation that reflected the gloom in Los Angeles, he urged Angelenos, "Don't lose heart."
 
Farewell to Bradley
 It was a festive occasion, almost as much an emotional farewell to Tom Bradley, who retired today after 20 years as Mayor, as a welcome to the new Mayor. But for now, at least, nearly all Angelenos are rallying around Mr. Riordan as this city's only chance.
"How could you not want him to succeed?" asked William G. Ouchi, a professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles and an adviser to Mr. Riordan. "The stakes are too high. I, like others, have wondered whether L.A. suffers from some deep underlying disease that is incurable. But if you use the very considerable resources here, this place can be a place New Yorkers love to hate again."
Mr. Riordan's election victory over City Councilman Mike Woo, coming a year after the city's devastating riots, symbolized a growing frustration with liberal Democratic remedies for urban ills. He has pledged to expand police protection, contract out many government services to private business and improve the business climate.
 
City in Deep Trouble
 If he has been spared the partisan barbs that might be expected in an overwhelmingly Democratic city, that is because everyone here knows that Los Angeles is in big trouble, having cut the city work force by 10 percent over the last three years and facing what economic forecasters say are another two years of recession.
"Riordan's off to a good start," said said city Controller Rick Tuttle,' a Woo backer. "He has impressed me by his willingness to jump right in."
Mr. Riordan has taken pains to prove himself anything but a conservative ideologue. The chairman of his transition team was William Wardlaw, who headed Bill Clinton's California campaign. Another transition team member was J. Stanley Sanders, a black lawyer who was a losing candidate for Mayor in the April primary. In Washington, Mr. Riordan was greeted warmly last week by President Clinton, even though the President endorsed Mr. Woo.
Mr. Riordan's appointment of William McCarley, the chief legislative analyst at the City Council, as his chief of staff has won raves here as a sign that he means to work closely with the fractious 15-member Council. Mr. Sanders, who is overseeing appointments to the city's 32 boards and commissions for Mr. Riordan, said the new Mayor would not put a high priority on cultural diversity just for the sake of diversity when it comes to filling jobs.
"He may be the least political of recent mayors," Mr. Sanders said. "So reaching out in the traditional sense is probably not going to be as high a priority as you would think, not as high as economic development in South Central and joblessness. You will see a lot of different faces on boards, more businessmen and not nearly as many community activists.
"His No. 1 priority, which is central to his take as a businessman," Mr. Sanders said, "is public safety."
Indeed, in a move clearly meant to restore morale among the police force, Mr. Riordan on Wednesday appointed Bill Violante, president of the Police Protective League, the police union, as a deputy mayor. He also named two other deputy mayors, Michael Keeley, a law partner of Mr. Riordan's who is gay, and Jadine Nielsen, his campaign manager, who was an aide to former Senator Alan Cranston, a Democrat.
 
Dose of State Reality
 Mr. Riordan has already got a cold dose of reality. When he visited Sacramento, the state capital, two days after his June 8 victory to lobby Gov. Pete Wilson, a fellow Republican, and lawmakers against cuts in state money for the city, he came away stunned. He called the state fiscal process "infinitely more complicated and difficult than man could ever dream of."
And when he went to Washington, he got bad news from Senators Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein, both Democrats, who told him that his main campaign pledge to raise money for 3,000 new police officers by leasing Los Angeles International Airport to a private operator would not pass Congress. But they agreed to help change Federal laws and rules to permit diversion of airport-generated revenue to city purposes other than the airport.
Returning to Los Angeles, Mr. Riordan pragmatically trimmed his jib. "I have not given up leasing the airport," he told reporters. "But, as I said during the election, I am not an ideologue. If we can find other ways to take money off the airport for police purposes, I have an open mind to that."
Mr. Riordan, whose father was president of the Stern Brothers department store in New York, moved to Los Angeles in 1956 as a young lawyer. He built a fortune here estimated at more than $100 million as an entrepreneur and venture capitalist, reaping investments from high-tech computer and pharmaceutical companies and the toy concern, Mattel, among others. Though never a candidate before, he became an important power broker in Los Angeles and California, giving generously to Democrats and Republicans alike.
For now, Mr. Riordan is being welcomed at City Hall as fresh air.
"For a change, the city is getting some good press," said Councilman Zev Yaroslavsky, the influential chairman of the Budget and Finance Committee, who accompanied Mr. Riordan to Washington. Mr. Yaroslavsky had endorsed neither candidate. "We need to help Riordan succeed," he said. "This city is at a state now where ego and pride of authorship are no longer tolerable."
But he warned that Mr. Riordan would need patience, not his strongest suit, and would have to "recognize he is not the chairman of a company."
 
Pushing Privatization
 Mr. Riordan is an enthusiastic proponent of the privatization of garbage collection and other services, drawing heavily on the theories of the Reason Foundation, a Santa Monica libertarian group that argues for privatization of nearly all government services except police and courts.
"Having a city as large as Los Angeles, which has been so resistant to privatization now poised to at least seriously consider it is very exciting to us," said Robert W. Poole Jr., president of Reason.
In this, the Mayor will be fought by labor unions, and much of the traditional Democratic apparatus that still controls the City Council.
But Kelly Candaele, political representative of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor, which endorsed Mr. Woo, considers Mr. Riordan a pragmatist who will adjust to political realities. "He's got people around him who realize he is running a Democratic city with a Democratic council," Mr. Candaele said.
The Mayor's effectiveness will depend in good part on the extent that he can use his force of personality to make up for a city charter that gives him relatively little formal power.
"People say this is a weak-mayor system," Professor Ouchi said. "They have a big surprise coming. Strong leaders have great flexibility given weak structures."

HEADLINE: Flood Idles Barges on Mississippi, Raising Costs of Shipping Products

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 1

 BODY:
The flood-swollen Mississippi River will be closed to boat traffic for three more weeks or longer, causing tens of millions of dollars in losses to the shippers and companies that must find other, more expensive ways to move their products.
Some consumers could see higher prices in the weeks and months ahead on everything from grain to electricity because shipping costs are increasing and the cost of grain futures contracts at the Chicago Board of Trade have been rising as fast as the river. 
 A rise in the price of futures contracts strongly indicates that retail prices will increase. And barges loaded with coal are tethered at ports along the southern Mississippi River, unable to reach the coal-powered power-generating plants north of St. Louis.
A 500-mile stretch of the Mississippi between St. Louis and St. Paul remained closed to barge traffic today as the water continued to rise. The river is not expected to crest in Davenport, Iowa, until Saturday, said a spokeswoman for the Army Corps of Engineers in Davenport. The crest is expected to reach 22.3 feet, but it could be higher, depending on rainfall.
 
Clinton to Visit
 In Washington, the White House announced today that President Clinton would tour eastern Iowa on Sunday on his way to Tokyo for an economic summit meeting. Mr. Clinton will visit Davenport with Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa.
"It's a very, very serious thing for the farmers," Mr. Clinton said. "It's the most rain they've had in over 100 years."
The National Weather Service has predicted rain for the next five days for parts of the upper Midwest..
The Corps of Engineers reported Wednesday that it would take at least 20 to 25 days to reopen locks and dams along the upper Mississippi to barge traffic.
The companies that do business on the river are being hurt by the flood. Nearly 50 percent of the 2,000 barges and 30 towboats that the Archer Daniels Midland Company operates on the river are idle. A spokesman for the Decatur, Ill., company predicted that lost revenue from the idled barges would reach $20 million.
The American Commercial Barge Line Company, one of the largest barge operators on the river, said 300 of its barges and about 12 of its towboats had been tied up for safekeeping. As the flood waters move south, the number of barges that eventually are idled "will grow," said Norb Whitlock, the company's senior vice president.
The company loses about $300 each day that a barge is idled and must also pay out about $3,000 a day for crew salaries and the fuel to keep the barge generators operating.
Cargill Inc. of Minneapolis said it was incurring significant costs and lost revenue because 40 percent of its 600-barge fleet could not navigate the flooded river.
A Cargill spokeswoman said the time was fast approaching "when we'll have to decide on whether to use alternate methods of transportation" to move grain. Cargill loaded no barges Wednesday at its port in Savage, Minn., near St. Paul. Normally, four or five barges would be loaded, each with 50,000 bushels of grain.
The most likely alternatives for transportation are rail and trucking, but they cost at least $5 more per ton than barge shipping, said Mr. Whitlock of American Commercial Barge Line.
Some barges loaded with coal and cement are already waiting at docks along the southern Mississippi, unable to move north because of the flooding, Mr. Whitlock said.

HEADLINE: Remnant of Jobs Bill Approved in House

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Congress passed today what remained of President Clinton's jobs bill, 10 weeks after Senate Republicans killed a much larger version, which was then one of Mr. Clinton's top economic priorities.
The House vote was 280 to 138, mostly along party lines. The measure was sent to the Senate, which sent it to President Clinton on a voice vote. The votes came a day before the scheduled release of the June unemployment figures, which were expected to edge upward from May's 6.9 percent. 
 The bill contains about $1 billion for summer jobs, small-business loans and other programs Mr. Clinton had sought earlier this year in hopes of quickly helping the economy. The President had originally sought nearly $20 billion.
The Administration said its original bill would have created 500,000 jobs but gave no estimate for the smaller plan. Republicans argued that today's bill was loaded with wasteful projects.

HEADLINE: Parties Play Budget Game By Different Sets of Rules

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Call it the battle of the pie charts.
Having lost the budget battle in the Senate last week, the Republicans appear convinced that they will win the political war by using pie charts to argue that President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan would mean more than twice as much in tax increases as in spending cuts. 
 Worried by the Republican onslaught, the Administration has undertaken a counteroffensive. Wielding pie charts of its own, the Clinton team contends that its plan is evenly weighted between tax increases and spending cuts and that the Republicans are too cowardly to vote for tough deficit-reduction measures.
The debate is far more than academic. The Republicans want to tar Mr. Clinton with the label of tax-and-spend Democrat, an image he is struggling to avoid. The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, is already boasting that he will bludgeon the Democrats with the tax issue in the 1994 elections.
 
2 Teams, 2 Sets of Rules
 The debate often seems like a rugby scrum on a muddy field where the players cannot agree even on how to keep score. The two sides part company not only over the ratio of tax increases to spending cuts but also on the very size of the President's package. The Administration says the Medicare cuts, gasoline taxes, income tax increases and other measures passed by the Senate would pare the projected deficit in the Federal budget by $499 billion over the next five years; the Republicans put the figure at $380 billion.
As for the ratio, the Administration claims a virtual balance: $243 billion in higher taxes and $256 billion in spending cuts. The Republicans say the actual figures are $258 billion in tax increases and only $122 billion in spending cuts. That is a tax-to-cut ratio of 2.11 to 1, and the Republicans contend that the version of the package previously passed by the House is a good deal worse.
Although the debate is harsh, divisive and often confusing, there is a simple explanation for how the two sides arrive at estimates so vastly different. That explanation lies in varying definitions of spending reductions.
The Republicans say Mr. Clinton is up to some budgetary sleight of hand when he counts as spending cuts the increases that his package would impose in user fees; the savings that the plan claims in interest payments on the Federal debt, and some of the savings that were dictated by a budget accord that President George Bush struck with Congress in 1990.
So the Republican number crunchers subtract from the Administration's spending-cut estimate the $15 billion increase in user fees, the $55 billion savings in interest and the $44 billion savings resulting from the 1990 accord. The Republicans treat the user-fee increase as a tax increase instead, and do not count as deficit-reducers at all the savings from either the lower interest payments or the 1990 agreement.
When all three of these elements -- along with some lesser sums claimed by the Democrats but disputed by the Republicans -- are subtracted from the Administration's estimate of $256 billion in spending cuts, the result is the $122 billion figure that the Republicans put forth.
And if the $15 billion rise in user fees is treated not as a spending cut but as a tax increase, then the $243 billion in tax increases estimated by the Administration becomes the $258 billion estimated by the Republicans.
The Democrats call this kind of calculating hypocritical. They note that Mr. Clinton is treating user fees and interest savings in the same way the Bush Administration did. Further, they point out, although $44 billion in "new" savings result from the accord of 1990, the Bush Administration was never required to specify then, as Mr. Clinton is doing now, exactly which programs would be cut to realize those savings.
Which side is the more credible with regard to these three major budget issues?
USER FEES. The Administration says it can collect $15 billion over five years by raising the fees that Americans are charged for activities like logging and livestock grazing on Federal land and the use of inland waterways and national parks.
The Administration treats these fee increases as spending reductions because they would help offset certain outlays, for instance the Government's spending on national parks. The Republicans' position: User-fee increases are tax increases.
The director of the Congressional Budget Office, Robert D. Reischauer, a Democratic appointee whose role is to be a nonpartisan budget scorekeeper, said past Administrations had treated user fees differently from taxes.
When the Government taxes, it extracts resources from the public, he said. "But user fees are by and large payments for goods and services that the Government provides; by and large they are voluntary transactions," he said. "That's why they are treated on a different side of the ledger" from taxes.
INTEREST SAVINGS. The Administration says its budget would achieve the $55 billion saving in interest payments by holding down not only the buildup in the Federal debt but also, because the demand on the credit markets would be restrained, the interest rate on that debt. The Republicans counter by saying interest savings are not a direct result of any policy decision but instead largely a result of factors over which the Administration has little control, including low inflation.
Clinton aides call that argument disingenuous. They say the $55 billion is a direct result of the $444 billion they claim in other deficit reduction and is therefore a genuine cut. They also point to Bush Administration documents that counted interest savings as spending cuts in the 1990 budget agreement.
Mr. Reischauer's verdict: "The fact is, interest is an outlay of the Federal Government. And by commonly accepted definition, lower interest payments mean that spending will be lower."
SAVINGS FROM THE 1990 ACCORD. Since the Administration is taking credit for $44 billion in spending cuts mandated by a three-year-old agreement, the Republicans allege double-counting. But as the White House points out, neither Mr. Bush nor that earlier Congress had to make the politically painful decisions as to where those cuts would be made.
Mr. Reischauer's view: "This is a case of the glass is half-full or half-empty. It's true the $44 billion was agreed to in 1990, but it will be this Congress and this President who take the political heat. Nobody was ever voted out of office for capping expenditures in general in some future year."

HEADLINE: New GATT Chief Turns Up Heat

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 1

 BODY:
Declaring that "it is simply not good enough for international leaders to mouth good intentions about trade," Peter Sutherland became the world's top trade official today and said the core of a long-delayed world trade agreement must be hammered out in Tokyo next week.
In an interview here at the quaintly staid headquarters of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade just a few days before the Tokyo summit meeting of major industrialized nations, Mr. Sutherland, a 47-year-old Irish lawyer, immediately served notice that he would be as blunt and outspoken as his predecessor was mild and circumspect.
 
 
'Shoot From the Hip'
 "I am going to say it as it is, and shoot from the hip," Mr. Sutherland said, using language in sharp contrast to the chain-smoking Arthur Dunkel, his predecessor. Mr. Sutherland said he had twice rejected the job but took it this time after receiving assurances from trade officials -- including Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative -- that they want a GATT accord this year. 
 "I am taking this position having been led to believe that world leaders intend to conclude the Uruguay Round of trade talks by Dec. 15," Mr. Sutherland said. "For that target not to be utopian, we need a market access-agreement at the Tokyo summit."
Mr. Sutherland added: "If the summit fails -- and there are ominous signals right here on day one -- then the trade negotiations will become very difficult. It can't all be done on the back of an envelope on Dec. 14. Tokyo is an acid test."
In effect, the new GATT chief made it abundantly clear that both Mr. Kantor and the European Community's trade commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, had promised him progress in Tokyo, and that he would feel double-crossed if this did not materialize.
"It is essential," he said, "that the United States, the community, Japan and Canada provide the launching pad for the takeoff of negotiations in Tokyo. Rhetoric about the importance of the Uruguay Round is not good enough. I am a facilitator. But I cannot facilitate a lack of will."
 
 
Goal: World Prosperity
 The last four economic summit meetings have all failed to advance the trade negotiations, which began in Uruguay in 1986. The talks are aimed not only at increasing world prosperity by lowering or removing tariffs and other trade barriers, but also at incorporating whole new areas of economic activity -- including services and intellectual property -- into GATT regulations to expand commerce in these areas.
To avoid a fifth, humiliating failure to advance the Uruguay Round at the summit meeting, trade officials from the United States, Japan, Canada and the European Community have been holding talks aimed at reaching a so-called market-access agreement that could be announced in Tokyo and would be an important part of an overall GATT accord.
The market-access talks aim to lower existing high tariffs on products like textiles, clothes and agricultural goods, eliminate tariffs altogether on some like pharmaceuticals and set out reciprocal arrangements in new GATT spheres like the protection of copyrights and the establishment of financial services in foreign markets.
But, apparently irked by America's threats to impose duties on European steel products, French officials have balked, saying no market-access agreement will be possible in Tokyo.
Their stand has flatly contradicted the message that emerged from trade talks in Paris in early June, when all parties was distinctly optimistic.
"I am extremely worried by the French attitude," Mr. Sutherland said. "If any one country is intent on bringing down the multilateral trading system, I'd be very surprised. But if there is such a country, it should say so." He added, however, that France was not alone in making difficulties.
 
 
Shaming World Leaders
 Mr. Sutherland -- whose abundantly direct style at times appeared close to shaming world leaders into finally honoring their trade promises -- said he was a passionate believer in open trading systems because he viewed the alternative as "a return to the darker pages of our history."
"I have given up an entire career," he said, referring to his decision to leave his position as chairman of Allied Irish Banks in order to take the GATT director general post, "because I wanted, so to speak, to put my money where my mouth is. I intend to make sure that others -- and I mean world leaders -- do the same."
Turning to recent claims by President Francois Mitterrand and other French politicians that the developed world cannot trade openly with developing countries that use cheap labor, offer no social security and pollute the environment, Mr. Sutherland said he saw such talk as veiled protectionism.
"Protectionism is a recipe for making Europe an industrial graveyard, a museum piece, paralyzed by inefficiencies," he declared. "Look at the failure of the industries we've tried to protect -- steel and shipyards. It's a basic fact that open trade has been positive for the world. The Uruguay Round cannot, at this stage, start trying to impose social and environmental legislation on developing countries."
Cracking his fingers in apparent agitation, Mr. Sutherland added: "It's time to stop pointing fingers and seeking excuses. The alternative to open multilateral trade could be terrible rifts both within the developed world, and between the developed world and developing counties."
