HEADLINE: Upheaval in the Forests;
Clinton Plan Shifts Emphasis From Logging But Does Not Create Off-Limits Wilderness

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 1

 BODY:
he plan that President Clinton announced today to bring peace, jobs and a degree of protection to the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest will not end the decade-long civil war in the woods here.
But the plan does signal a historic shift in the way the Federal Government will manage more than 23 million acres of public forests in America's timber basket. Logging will no longer dominate decisions, with the number of trees cut reduced by more than two-thirds from its highest levels. At the same time, there also will not be any large formal wilderness areas, which would be off-limits to anything but light-footed visits by man. 
 Mr. Clinton's program also calls for about $1.2 billion in aid for displaced workers and economic development.
Amid the predictable chorus of criticism from both sides, and an extraordinary shouting match between Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, the plan is viewed as somewhat of a curiosity by those who live and work in the woods. Some workers see in it the outline of a painful, but at least predictable, future.
 
'It's Up to the Marketplace'
 "In the short-term, this looks like a significant amount of timber for us," said Robert Cugini, a third-generation mill owner in Renton, Wash., just outside of Seattle.
When Mr. Cugini's father took over the family timber operation, there were 15 sawmills in the Seattle area. Now there is only one: his Barbee Mill. And he said the President's plan should allow him to stay open. "Beyond that, it's up to the marketplace," he said.
As outlined by the President, the plan would set aside about seven million acres of old-growth reserves, or about 80 percent of the nation's remaining ancient forests, with some limited logging in those areas. The reserves would not be straight lines on a map, or formal wilderness areas, but would be set up to protect streams and watersheds, primarily those with salmon. If fish return to these streams in significant numbers, it could help the sagging Northwest fishing industry, Administration officials said.
Ten areas, ranging from 80,000 to 380,000 acres each, would be set up as experimental logging areas. The Forest Service has already announced that it is phasing out clear-cutting, in which all trees in a given area are leveled. In the experimental areas, logging would be selective.
The rest of the timber would come from lands where species are not threatened. The total cut would be about 1.2 billion board feet a year. In the 1980's, the Forest Service allowed nearly 5 billion board feet to be cut.
The White House, boxed in by environmental laws that are politically difficult to change, has chosen to try to fix what is most valuable in the forests -- the salmon streams and watersheds -- and let scientists experiment with how to allow logging in other areas without damaging the ecology.
All this will make for a new day at the Forest Service, which has managed the public woodlands with timber industry's best interests at heart.
But it is not the new era Mr. Clinton had in mind. The President was forced to accept a plan that he clearly did not like and that infuriated Mr. Foley, who has long guided Northwest forest decisions with behind-the-scenes power and a tilt toward the industry.
"I finally had to tell the President that this is the best we can do," Mr. Babbitt said in an interview.
The President was under pressure from Mr. Foley, who said he was shocked by how low the projected timber harvest would be. In the past Mr. Foley -- whose district includes the huge Colville National Forest, which is not subject to spotted owl restrictions -- had been able to see that forest plans were more to his liking.
But not this time. An 11th-hour effort by Mr. Foley to get more logging in the plan broke down into an hour-long shouting match with Mr. Babbitt on Monday.
"The meeting was extremely intense," Mr. Babbitt said. "The Speaker was very candid. He said: 'This is an unbalanced result. A bad result. And I'm just very unhappy with it.' I told him that the President cannot duck this decision."
 
Lawmakers Plot Strategy
 Most of the plan will not need Congressional approval, Administration officials said. But Mr. Foley is now hinting that he may try to change the Endangered Species Act, which would put him in conflict with most Democrats in Congress.
Mr. Babbitt told the President there was no other choice unless the Forest Service wanted to be tied up in a court fight for two years. Virtually all logging in Federally managed forests in the Northwest has been off-limits because of court injunctions on behalf of endangered species.
Had the Administration allowed logging to return to anything near the levels of the last decade, it could have faced dozens of lawsuits to protect species that are disappearing as the forest is logged.
The plan is not the win-win compromise that the President had promised in the campaign. Owls and loggers could live with each other, he had said.
What has driven Federal forest management more than anything for three years have been the rulings of Judge William Dwyer of Federal District Court in Seattle. He has ruled that past timber-cutting levels were "a remarkable series of violations of environmental laws."
The Clinton plan will be presented to the judge next week, with the hope by the Administration that he will lift the injunctions and allow logging to resume.
"The real question for us is whether this is enough to get timber into the mills," said Mr. Cugini, who has 80 employees at his Barbee Mill.
Timber prices have fallen considerably in recent weeks, after a run-up earlier in the year. The Federal forests of the Northwest provide about 10 percent of the building lumber produced in this country.
The Administration plans to provide $1.2 billion in economic assistance over the next five years to depressed timber communities. The money, most of which would come from existing Forest Service and Interior Department budgets, would be used to provide new jobs in forest restoration, for retraining loggers and for schools, roads and community centers in areas hit hardest by the reductions.
The Administration estimates about 6,000 jobs would be lost. When paired with the economic package, it would work out to better than $200,000 a lost job.
The timber economy of the Northwest has been retracting for 20 years, but the decline has accelerated with spotted owl restrictions. In 1990, there were 145,000 people working in the Northwest forest products industry. Two years later that number was down to 125,000.
With this plan, the Administration says it can stop the slide of job loss and set up a sustainable forest economy, but many timber workers are suspicious, if not openly hostile.
"I've seen the ups and downs," said Lonnie Matter, who works at the Barbee Mill, "but I've never seen it this bad."

HEADLINE: Purchasing Managers Report a Drop for June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
The spate of weak economic numbers continued today as the nation's purchasing managers reported that their industrial index skidded in June to under 50 percent, the dividing line between expansion and contraction. It was the lowest reading in 18 months.
Meanwhile, outlays for construction were reported to have edged up a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in May, which analysts considered disappointing, and confidence among top business executives ebbed. 
 The only bit of upbeat news was that 11,000 fewer people made first-time claims for unemployment benefits last week, a development that fanned some hopes that the June unemployment data to be published Friday would be encouraging. Expectations were that payrolls expanded by perhaps 150,000 while the unemployment rate remained close to May's 6.9 percent.
 
 
Fresh Concerns
 But the sharp decline in the purchasing managers' index, to 48.3 percent from 51.1, attracted the bulk of today's attention. This prompted fresh expressions of concern about the durability of the business expansion, which has been officially under way for more than two years but has been below normal and, in some sectors, hard to even detect.
"The desired improvement in new orders failed to materialize in June, resulting in a decline in the manufacturing sector and a dismal conclusion to the second quarter," said Robert J. Bretz, director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. and chairman of the National Association of Purchasing Management's business survey committee.
Only eight of 20 industries reported June growth greater than May's, and the weakness was reflected in lower employment and production as well as the slump in orders.
"It's pretty compelling evidence that there's not much sign of life in the manufacturing sector," commented Richard B. Berner, chief economist for the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. He called the situation disappointing in light of interest rates that have tumbled.
 
 
Clinton Budget Cited
 One common explanation, of course, is that the Clinton Administration's budget legislation and still-developing health-care program is prompting employers to avoid making new investment or hiring commitments.
Mr. Bretz guessed that while many corporate decision-makers "don't like" the Clinton budget, which is heavy on tax increases and may be unrealistic about spending cuts, companies could be cutting back more than will prove necessary.
Whether significant deficit reduction will actually be achieved was one of the main points of contention at a meeting early this week of an 11-member economic advisory committee of the American Bankers Association.
Despite the parade of mostly poor June statistics, however, the panel projected a 3 percent rate of growth in the third and fourth quarters of the year. This would be markedly better than the first-half pace, which was marked by a slim seven-tenths of 1 percent January-March gain followed by a gain of probably less than 2 percent for the second quarter that ended Wednesday.
Low interest rates, lively motor-vehicle sales and robust capital spending should keep driving the economy forward, the panel contended.
 
 
New Orders
 The decline in the purchasing managers' index, to the lowest point since December 1991, was the fourth in the last five months after the index rose without interruption from October through January, the association's report showed. The new orders component, accounting for 30 percent of the index, fell even more steeply, to 49 percent in June from 53.5 in May, and was the lowest reading since September 1992.
Employment in factories fell once again -- and at the most rapid clip since early last year -- and even the pharmaceutical industry, which kept adding jobs through the latest recession, has now begun "downsizing," the group found.
The Commerce Department's construction report for May showed a one-tenth of 1 percent advance, but the pickup was entirely in the nonresidential sector, which had plunged nearly twice that much in April. Spending on new homes fell four-tenths of 1 percent, consistent with recent reports of poor starts and sales.
The Conference Board, which earlier this week reported a second straight decline in consumer confidence for June, said today that its quarterly gauge of executive confidence dropped nine points, to 57. While this was the lowest since late 1991, by historic standards business confidence remains "fairly high," the organization said.
First-time applicants for state unemployment benefits numbered 340,000 last week, down from 351,000 in the week ended June 19, the Labor Department reported. This decline, which followed two increases, helped nudge the four-week moving average down by 1,750, to 344,750.
A total of 33 states and territories had lower regular claims for the week ended June 19, with New York and Tennessee posting the biggest declines, more than 2,000 each. The biggest increase, 4,436 claims, was in Illinois.

HEADLINE: Police Detail Confession of L.I. Murder Suspect

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 1

 BODY:
In their first detailed account of the confession of Joel Rifkin, the New York State police said today that it was hours into their interrogation before he hinted that he had killed many more women than the one found in the back of his pickup truck.
For hours after his arrest early Monday, Mr. Rifkin sat in the state police barracks here, talking to a senior investigator, C. Thomas Capers, and others about that decomposing body, said Thomas A. Constantine, the superintendent of the state police. The case seemed bizarre but not extraordinary. In fact, investigators thought they were dealing with, as one top official put it, "just a one-person homicide." 
 And then, shortly after 12:30 P.M. -- with a crowd of reporters gathering outside the barracks for a news conference about the discovery of the body in the truck -- Mr. Rifkin, a 34-year-old unemployed landscaper, began talking about more bodies. And more bodies. And more bodies.
 
After the Revelations
 "He suddenly opened up," Mr. Constantine said of the man who the authorities say confessed that afternoon to killing 17 women. "Until then, the focus had been on the one body in the car."
In a telephone interview today, Superintendent Constantine talked about the sequence of events in the barracks that precipitated one of the most extensive murder investigations in state police history. He also described the mobilization that followed Mr. Rifkin's revelations, a 24-hour period in which teams of state police investigators who had worked on other mass-murder cases were dispatched to Long Island, and state computer experts engaged to begin drawing links between open murder cases in the metropolitan area and the astonishing claims of the mild-mannered suspect. For the state police, whose image has been tarnished by an evidence-tampering scandal upstate, the confession has given the agency a starring role in a public drama that is being covered intensively by the media and monitored closely by other law-enforcement agencies involved in the case.
In the last few days, however, some of the agency's tactics and decisions have been criticized, notably the failure to videotape the interrogation or to obtain a signed confession, an omission that has been criticized by some police officials and prosecutors.
Robert Sale, the lawyer for Mr. Rikin, questioned the public way the state police are conducting their investigation.
"It wouldn't surprise me," Mr. Sale said today, "that if Amelia Earhart washed up on Coney Island, an effort was made to connect her to Joel Rifkin." In addition, Mr. Sale said he could not rule out the possibility of challenging the admissibility of the confession and whether Mr. Rifkin's Miranda rights were properly read to him.
On Wednesday, Capt. Walter Heesch, who is heading the state police investigation, said that "based on the things that were available to us at the time, we didn't do it," referring to the lack of a recorded statement.
The comments of Mr. Constantine -- whose agency is spearheading the inquiry into Mr. Rifkin's claims -- cast doubt on speculation that Mr. Rifkin had hoped to be captured and thus prevented from killing again. The suspect, who is charged with one count of second-degree murder, was stopped by troopers just after 3 A.M. on Monday. He was stopped for failing to have license plates on his pickup, the police said.
 
Those Identified, and Found
 Indeed, the Superintendent's account suggested that it was the trusting relationship that developed between Investigator Capers and Mr. Rifkin that led to the confessions.
As of today, state police officials said that they had the identities of 17 people whose names were taken from driver's licenses, credit cards and other forms of identification found among the articles seized this week from the bedroom of Mr. Rifkin's house in East Meadow. Of that number, they said, three people have been identified as possible victims, while three others have been contacted and found to be alive.
State police officials said they were linking Mr. Rifkin to the murders of 13 women, including eight whose bodies were found in New York City, two in Suffolk County and one each in Nassau, Putnam and Orange Counties. Except for two bodies found on Tuesday, one near Kennedy International Airport and the other in the Hamptons, and the body found in the pickup, all the other victims had been found months or even years before Mr. Rifkin's arrest, and their cases had languished, unconnected and unsolved.
The newest addition to the list of those suspected of being Mr. Rifkin's victims was a woman whose body was found in a cardboard box floating in the Hudson River off Pier 45 at West 10th Street on July 14, 1991. The New York City police identified her as Barbara M. Jacobs, 19, of 2 St. Marks Place in the East Village.
Additionally, the New York authorities said they were looking at a New Jersey case as possibly being connected to Mr. Rifkin. In recent days, the New Jersey State police have been saying they were seeking to learn whether Mr. Rifkin was involved in the death of a woman with the tattoo of a tiger on her thigh. Her body was found in Warren County.
Some state police officials say that the troopers' suspicions about Mr. Rifkin had been raised almost from the moment he was arrested. "We were aware from the initial moment from his character and profile there was more to look for than the initial crime," Lieut. Eugene Corcoran, one of the supervisors on Long Island of the investigation, said today.
But Mr. Constantine said it was many hours into the interrogation of Mr. Rifkin before the discussion escalated to talk of more than one body.
He was in police custody for about 12 hours before his lawyer, Mr. Sale, called by Mr. Rifkin's family through an intermediary, ordered the questioning stopped.
 
Asking the Right Question
 Superintendent Constantine said that with reporters waiting just a few yards outside the doors to the barracks, Investigators Capers had to decide whether to try to draw the suspect out slowly, case by case, or glean as much as he possibly could about the scope of his confession before word leaked to the press.
"He had a choice," Superintendent Constantine said in the interview today, "and he opted to get as much as he could, to get all he would talk about as quickly as he could."
Lieutenant Corcoran said that it was a matter of asking Mr. Rifkin the right question. "We asked if there was anything else he wanted to tell us and he described the other 16 crimes he committed," he said.
A news conference originally scheduled for about 1 P.M. was pushed back later and later in the day. By about 3:30 P.M., rumors began to circulate among the reporters at the barracks that the case involved mass murder.
Mr. Sale, the lawyer, said he was contacted about the case at 3:30 or 3:40 P.M., about 12 hours after Mr. Rifkin's arrest. About 20 minutes later, he called the authorities. "The police were called by me at approximately 4 o'clock and advised that there was to be zero further questioning," he said. State police officials said they immediately complied.

HEADLINE: For 5 Regents Graduates, Goals Delayed, and Reached;
Academic Elite of a Poor Bronx High School, 5 Years Later, Tell of the Roads They Traveled

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Five years ago, the 270 graduates of Theodore Roosevelt High School packed the auditorium of Lehman College for commencement. Every other word sounded like "success" and "destiny" as cameras clicked and families grinned. It was so hot that day, June 24, 1988, that some of the girls wore bikinis under their flowing white robes, anticipating a later celebration on the beach.
Among the graduates from this poor Bronx neighborhood where just finishing school was a big deal were 26 young people who received Regents diplomas, the school system's certificate of academic achievement. They included the valedictorian, Marcia Morgan, an aspiring physician whose family came from Jamaica, and Arnold Arias, a quiet Dominican who hung out with a group of guys who called themselves The Lost Boys. 
 In the years since, the two have led very different lives. Ms. Morgan just received her bachelor's degree in biomedicine and is preparing for medical school. After a dark journey through the Navy, a handful of clerical jobs and two suicide attempts, Mr. Arias is unemployed and hoping finally to begin college full-time in the fall.
Their stories vividly illustrate the obstacles faced by inner-city students all over America, the children of communities where many people cannot see a clear connection between school and later success. And they offer a vision of a way out, too, of the triumphs possible with the help of special programs and caring people.
 
Depression and Uncertainty
 The conventional wisdom of most middle-class Americans is that education is the route out of poverty, but the academically elite Roosevelt graduates say that it is not so simple. They saw many a potential doctor or teacher felled by street violence, low expectations, family troubles, a lack of role models or knowledge about getting financial aid or good jobs.
Ms. Morgan had much of what Mr. Arias lacked -- family support, clear goals, inner strength, mentors and role models found in programs for minority students interested in health care.
Mr. Arias, 23, was bedeviled by clinical depression, a troubled family that relied on welfare, and uncertainty about what concrete steps he needed to take to escape the chaos around him.
"None of us were too sure what would happen or where we wanted to go," Mr. Arias said. "I saw my neighborhood as a bunch of losers -- crackheads, people hanging in the streets. I wanted more; I deserved more. I just wasn't sure of how to go about it."
Some of the others among the academic elite that day tell similar tales. They include Zuzet Menendez, a bubbly 22-year-old woman whose family had fled Cuba; Ruble Hastu, 22, whose family came to New York from Guyana, and Jeanette Cotto, who learned English at age 9 after her single mother moved the family from Puerto Rico. Their special diplomas signified that they had passed Regents exams in a variety of subjects and taken a course load above the state minimum requirements.
Ms. Cotto, 22, now entering her junior year as a Spanish major at Hunter College, was forced to take time off from school to care for her ailing mother. Ms. Menendez, who has a bachelor's degree in communications and Spanish from the State University of New York at Cortland, is a corporate communications student at Ithaca College. Mr. Hastu, who figured the Army was the best way out of the Bronx, hooks patients up to dialysis machines in a New Jersey hospital. He dreams of being a nurse.
"I always knew I wanted to go to college," Ms. Menendez said, "but a lot of other people I knew who were just as smart never believed they would go anywhere so they never acted like they would."
 
Studious, and an Outsider
 Roosevelt had a bad reputation. In 1984 -- the year that most of the Regents graduates were freshmen -- one in four Roosevelt students quit school, fewer than one in seven graduated within four years, and almost one-third had limited proficiency in English. The neighborhood was such, Ms. Cotto recalled, that to be studious was to be labeled an outsider.
"Only two people in the building where I live graduated from high school," said Ms. Cotto, whose impoverished mother had little education. "They didn't call me a nerd, but they didn't want to be around me."
What made the difference for both Ms. Cotto, Ms. Menendez and Ms. Morgan was caring teachers and family support, especially from older siblings who encouraged them to stay in school or who set an example themselves by work or study.
"My parents have always instilled certain values in me," the 21-year-old Ms. Morgan said. "That you're unique; that there's something out there for everyone and you have to make up your mind to go for it."
 
A Troubled Journey
 Arnold Arias found himself lost almost from the beginning.
Mr. Arias, whose mother grew up "dirt poor" and with a second-grade education, came here from the Dominican Republic when John F. Kennedy was President and the country was awash in prosperity and promise. A divorced mother on welfare, she was simply not able to show her four children a better way, Mr. Arias said.
Mr. Arias's older brother ran the streets, teasing him about his bookish ways, he said. He took home excellent report cards, but his mother never saw them as his way out of their hand-to-mouth existence. Instead, he escaped by watching seven or eight hours of television a night.
He did not identify a career goal at Roosevelt, so he was passed over by counselors and teachers. He did not take part in extracurricular activities. Except for a 12th-grade gym teacher who asked what he wanted to do with his life, Mr. Arias said that no one at the school gave him information about college applications or questioned his aspirations. Because he was quiet and had good grades, no one knew that he was troubled.
"I wanted to go into the service," he said of his decision to go into the Navy. "People told you what to do."
Navy life only lasted four months after Mr. Arias was shipped out to San Diego. Navy officials failed to keep their promises about sending him to school and promoting him, he said. After his honorable discharge, Mr. Arias got a job as a mail clerk and began seeing a therapist. He tried to kill himself twice and was hospitalized for several weeks.
Mr. Arias slowly recovered and began to return to his dream of academic success. He garnered credits in data processing at Bronx Community College and spent one semester at the State University in Albany. He plans to enroll as a psychology major at Lehman College in September.
If there was one thing Marcia Morgan had, it was people. Her parents, who sent her to a strict private school in the verdant little Jamaican town of Manchester, made it clear that they would help their oldest child reach her goal. Ms. Morgan, a tall woman with beautifully clear skin and expressive eyes, decided she wanted to be a doctor when she around 7 years old after her mother was briefly hospitalized.
In her senior year, Ms. Morgan participated in a program called Bridge to Medicine. For three hours, five days a week, she took college-level courses in chemistry, calculus and English literature at City College.
Ms. Morgan said that she eventually hopes to work somewhere like Harlem Hospital, where she can make a difference.
"A lot of kids aren't encouraged to make it," Ms. Morgan said. "A lot of teachers don't care. Most of the homes I know are broken, so it is very important for the schools to take the responsibility to say how important education is."

HEADLINE: Trade Pact Vital for Mexico's Leader

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 1

 BODY:
Jan. 1 has become a do-or-die date for President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico, and nothing -- not fence-sitting by American Congressmen, high Mexican interest rates or a United States judge's ruling that could threaten the North American Free Trade Agreement -- has weakened his pledge to have the pact in place on that day.
That stiff-necked attitude shows just how vital a role the accord plays in his attempt to transform Mexico. In many ways, he has staked the judgment of history on timely approval of the agreement. 
 The expectation that the accord will be in place by the first day of next year has also become the touchstone of Mexico's economic and political policies. Defeat of the agreement on Capitol Hill, or even a delay, is now likely to cast a shadow of doubt over the ability of Mexico to maintain momentum for its broad economic reforms, and even on the outcome of next year's presidential elections.
"This could underscore just how fragile Mexico's whole economic and political balance actually is," said Denise Dresser, a professor of political science at the Autonomous Technological Institute of Mexico.
The surprise ruling on Wednesday by Judge Charles R. Richey of Federal District Court, which required an environmental statement on the free trade pact, sent the Mexican stock market down 30 points, or nearly 2 percent, on Wednesday as big stocks like Telefonos de Mexico lost about 3 percent of their value.
Today, the market staged a weak rally, advancing 1.46 points. In New York, Telmex American depository receipts actually rose 25 cents to close at $47 a share, the third-busiest issue on the Big Board.
Despite the concern and the market's slide, some analysts in Mexico and the United States, including John F. H. Purcell of Salomon Brothers, doubted that the ruling would impede the progress of the accord.
Mr. Salinas is on a tour of southern Mexico and has not made any public statement. His Commerce Minister, Jaime Serra Puche, in a news conference on Wednesday, basically ignored the ruling, saying the negotiations on side agreements concerning labor and environmental issues would continue, and that there was no need for a contingency plan because the agreement would be in place by Jan. 1.
While they clearly have the most at stake in the pact's future, Mexican officials are virtually powerless to do anything but note publicly that Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, has said that he is confident the court ruling can be quickly overturned on appeal, and that Congress can consider the pact in September.
Of course, Mr. Salinas's Government has had to maintain the promise of the free trade pact with the United States and Canada to keep foreign capital flowing here, though that has been costly. To push inflation down to around 10 percent, the economy has slowed and unemployment has risen.
It was expected that once the agreement was passed, Mr. Salinas would find it easier to undertake a peso devaluation that many analysts have predicted because foreign capital would be flowing easily. He was also expected to loosen fiscal restraints and pump money into social programs in the last year of his administration.
After his own near-defeat in 1988, Mr. Salinas and his Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has governed Mexico for more than 60 years, consider next year's election critical. Under the Mexican system, Mr. Salinas personaly selects his party's presidential candidate, which until 1988 has meant without qualification that the president picks his successor.
By custom, the president does this in November or early December of his next-to-last year in office. But Mr. Salinas, now in his fifth year, had been expected to hold off until the agreement was certain, so that the state party candidate would not be hurt by any uncertainty stemming from a pact still up in the air.
Now it appears he will have to make his choice without knowing the agreement's fate, leaving the opposition a potentially serious opening.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Price on Treasury Long Bond Falls

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond slipped yesterday as soaring prices of gold and other commodities briefly reignited fears of inflation.
But prices for short-term Treasury securities rose on speculation that today's employment data would be weaker than expected. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond fell 3/32 point, or 94 cents for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 6.68 percent, from late Wednesday's 6.67 percent.
Short-term Treasury prices rose 1/16, and intermediate maturities rose 1/16 point to 3/32 point, the financial information service Telerate Inc. reported.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 3.03 percent as the discount rate dropped three-tenths of a percent, to 2.98 percent. Six-month yields fell to 3.18 percent as the discount fell two-tenths of a percent, to 3.10 percent. One-year yields dropped to 3.39 percent as the discount rate fell four-tenths of a percent, to 3.27 percent.
 
 
Manufacturing Weakness
 Traders partly attributed the advance in short-term prices to news of weakness in the manufacturing sector.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index fell to 48.3 percent in June from 51.1 percent in May, indicating a contraction in manufacturing.
"People were expecting a reading between 50 and 51," said Jason Franklin, a trader at Prudential Securities Inc.
The weaker number suggests there will be less pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates to combat inflation, said Dana Johnson of First Chicago Capital Markets. Higher interest rates, which can be a drag on economic growth, erode the value of already-sold fixed-income securities.
Remarks at a Senate Banking Committee hearing added to sentiment that the Fed, which reportedly leaned toward a tighter monetary policy at its policy meeting in mid-May, would be hard pressed to raise interest rates.
Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he was concerned about the dampening effect President Clinton's deficit reduction program would have on economic growth. He said the Fed should compensate by keeping interest rates low.
 
 
Employment Expectations
 The employment data for June, due out this morning, were expected to further expectations that the economy was growing only sluggishly. A consensus of economists calls for an increase in nonfarm payroll jobs of 125,000 to 140,000. But many economists have reduced their forecasts following the recent accumulation of data showing weakness during the month.
Meanwhile, a spurt of $9 an ounce in gold prices touched off some selling of long-term bonds and pushed prices down. Gold is considered a hedge against inflation.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 0.26, to 1,306.97.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3 3/8 percent, down from 3 1/2 percent late Wednesday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 102 17/32, up 1/32 from late Wednesday. The average yield to maturity was 5.72 percent, down from 5.76 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The President's Logging Plan Finds Its Fans on Wall Street.

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
HAVE stocks of companies in the wood and paper business finally hit the rebound? Or will prices start sinking again faster than investors can yell "timber"?
Those questions were raised yesterday when President Clinton disclosed a plan to reduce logging on Federal lands to meet environmental concerns. Timber companies groaned with dismay, saying the plan would harm the industry. But on Wall Street, investors cheered, giving shares in most paper and forest companies a sharp boost. 
 That split decision underscores the steel nerves it will take to invest in the paper and forest products business for the near term. It is an investment that could prove immensely profitable, but only for investors willing to hold tight on what is sure to be a wild ride.
The investment issues begin with a simple primer in the laws of supply and demand. Under the Clinton plan, the average annual timber sale from Western national forests would be cut to about a third of the booming levels of the mid-1980's. Investors recognized the sharp cutback would likely drive up lumber prices -- the most important element in the industry's profitability.
And so the run-up began. On a day when the Standard & Poor's 500 was down a bit, the S.& P. paper and forest product group rose more than 15 points to close at 875.63. Even companies with little business in Federal forests in the Pacific Northwest rose, in anticipation of a firming of lumber prices industrywide. Among the biggest winners in the group were Georgia Pacific, which rose $2.625 to close at $61 a share; the Weyerhaeuser Company, which climbed $1.375 to close at $44 a share, and Louisiana Pacific, which rose 75 cents to close at $32.75.
Investors would seem to have good reason to make a dash for the timber-related stocks. Lumber prices have tumbled more than 40 percent since the record highs in March after a speculated housing boom failed to materialize -- and the stocks of paper and forest product companies went right along with them.
But some investors may have overlooked a critical fact: Nothing has changed on the demand side of the equation. And that is where these companies face big challenges.
"The biggest concern for these stocks is not on the supply side," said Michael Bowyer, an industry analyst with Duff & Phelps. "The most important factor underlying what price these stocks should have is happening on the demand side."
With new-home sales and housing starts falling, the demand for wood products has been slackening significantly, and analysts say they expect results for the timber industry in the second quarter to be far below those of the first.
"There is not enough demand in this economy at present to push even the constricted supplies," said Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures in Seattle.
And, even with the apparent cutback in production under Mr. Clinton's proposal, the timber industry could well see a spurt in production if it met the planned limit of average annual timber sales. The Clinton plan would allow for an annual production average of 1.2 billion board feet over the next decade for Northwest national forests. But timber production from those forests this year is expected to be an anemic 600 million board feet, because environmental lawsuits have blocked the Government from awarding new logging contracts in the area for two years.
"If the President gets his proposals through, as they are currently presented, we might have more timber available for harvest than in the last three years," Mr. Cunningham said.
That prospect was reflected in the futures trading of lumber yesterday. After opening at $274.80, up almost $10, the contracts plummeted in price, closing at $265.60, up only 80 cents from the previous day.
The bottom line for investors: put aside supply. When the economy seems as if it's picking up, paper and forest products will be a good long-term bet -- but expect some sleepless nights.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices of Precious Metals Surge on Inflation Concerns

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures prices surged to their highest point in nearly three years on New York's Commodity Exchange yesterday on fears of inflation.
On other commodities markets, energy futures fell, grains and soybeans continued higher, copper futures advanced, pork futures rose and beef prices slipped. 
 Metals analysts said announcements from the central banks of Germany, Austria, Belgium, Switzerland and the Netherlands that they would cut interest rates could signal increased inflation abroad.
 
 
'A Little Less Concerned'
 "The mind-set of Europeans now is perhaps the central banks are going to be a little less concerned about controlling inflation as they try to bolster their flagging economies," said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in Weehawken, N.J.
Early weakness in the United States dollar and technical factors touched off wide buying of all the metals, including palladium and platinum.
Gold for delivery in August rose $9, to $388.20 an ounce; July silver gained 21.3 cents, to $4.771 an ounce. July platinum on the New York Mercantile Exchange advanced $8.30, to $394.30 an ounce; September palladium rose $2.80, to $140.20 an ounce.
Energy futures contracts sank on the New York Mercantile Exchange after traders misinterpreted remarks made by Madeleine Albright, the United States representative at the United Nations, about the one-time sale of Iraqi oil.
She was reiterating an American position to let oil be sold for Iraq to purchase humanitarian supplies, but traders believed the remark signaled new United States willingness to lift a ban on Iraqi oil sales and flood an already burdened market. Light sweet crude oil for August was 40 cents lower at $18.45 a barrel.
 
 
Government Report
 On the Chicago Board of Trade, investors shrugged off a daunting Government report and lifted soybeans futures prices back to three-year highs achieved a day earlier. Wheat surged to six-week highs and corn futures also gained.
Rainy weather and its resulting threat to crops in the Midwest proved more important than the Agriculture Department's report late Wednesday that the number of soybeans planted as of mid-June was much more than expected.
July copper on New York's Commodity Exchange surged 1 cent, to 86.8 cents a pound, amid signs that workers at the Kennecott Corporation, a major United States copper producer, could strike.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Shows Weakness Despite German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar traded lower against leading European currencies yesterday despite a long-awaited cut in German interest rates.
Traders said the dollar was weak because of poor economic news in the United States and because it had been bid higher in anticipation of the German rate cut. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen. 
 "Today can be characterized as the classic 'Buy the rumor,' coming into the Thursday Bundesbank meeting, and 'Sell the fact,' " said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president in the foreign exchange department at Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. in New York.
Germany's central bank lowered its discount rate half a percentage point, to 6.75 percent, the lowest level since February 1991. It also cut the so-called Lombard rate a quarter of a percentage point, to 8.25 percent. Some other European central banks followed suit.
Since market participants have been trading in expectation of the cuts, the moves did not prompt buying. But news of a sluggish American economy did provoke selling, analysts said.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its monthly index fell to 48.3 percent in June from 51.1 percent in May. That level indicates contraction in the manufacturing sector.
"At the time of the release of the purchasing managers' report, there was a flurry of activity," said Kevin Logan, chief United States economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "The dollar went down a little bit, but it came back," he said.
The dollar's gain against the yen was mostly a result of technical trading, Mr. Flanagan said. Much of the market's activity, he said, was muted in advance of the American employment report to be released today.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 108.10 yen, up 1.59 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, it fell to 107.40 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 107.38 yen late in the day, up from 106.95 on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5085, from $1.4930 late Wednesday. In New York, it was quoted at $1.5150, up from $1.4915 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Jersey City's Interim Mayor Is Sworn In for First Full Term

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 1

 BODY:
People just couldn't do or say enough about this city's future or its new Mayor today as Bret Schundler, a Democrat turned Republican, was sworn into his first full term.
The ceremony under flowing flags at Liberty State Park attracted a crowd that was a Who's Who of state politics -- testimony to the perception that the comparative political newcomer being inaugurated today could provide important support to those up for election later this year. 
 Gov. Jim Florio, who needs a big vote out of Hudson County to win re-election in the fall, brought $3.3 million and a summer-jobs program with him as he joined other speakers in predicting that Mr. Schundler would lead the city in a revitalization that would become a national model.
 
Recollection From Kemp
 "I am more than anxious," Mr. Florio told the 1,000 residents at the ceremony on the banks of the Hudson River, "to work with your Mayor and all of the people of Jersey City to make it not just one of the best cities in the state but one of the best in the United States of America."
In a day when expressions of love for this post-industrial city of 228,000 was on everyone's lips, Jack F. Kemp, the former Republican Congressman and ex-Federal Housing Secretary, was more than up to the challenge. Recalling when President John F. Kennedy expressed solidarity with the people of West Berlin by declaring "Ich bin ein Berliner," Mr. Kemp said, "As an American, in this time and place, I want to say Ich bin ein resident of Jersey City!"
The 34-year-old Mayor obviously enjoyed being courted by political figures of both major parties. As he began his inaugural address on the theme of a "new beginning" for the city, he said, "Something is happening -- it must be, just look at the people on this podium."
The Legislature's Republican leaders, Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian; Christine Todd Whitman, Republican candidate for governor; former Governors Thomas H. Kean, a Republican, and Brendan T. Byrne , a Democrat, and members of the Legislature and the nine-member City Council sat in two long rows, smiling in the midday heat through the two-hour ceremony.
 
Senate Bid by Kean?
 As he walked to the dais, Mr. Kean confirmed reports that he was considering a run for the United States Senate next year against the Democratic incumbent, Frank R. Lautenberg. "I'm giving it serious thought," he said. "I'll have something to say in four to six weeks."
Mr. Florio made the $3.3 million that the city will receive under a bill distributing utility tax revenue seem like a personal gift to Jersey City, though the the bill he signed during his address will distribute $77 million to municipalities across the state. The Democratic Governor said he would sign the summer-jobs bill at a later stop.
Mrs. Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, reminded residents that she has campaigned with Mr. Schundler in the past.
"The people were waiting for a leader," she said, "And in Bret they found someone who cared deeply." She said Mr. Schundler's success in lowering the city's property tax, putting more police officers on the streets and reviving one of the city's main shopping streets shows it is possible "to allow our cities to breathe again and grow."
Mr. Schundler told reporters before the ceremony that it was "conceivable" that he would endorse either Mrs. Whitman or Mr. Florio "but not today."
Mr. Schundler, who was a field coordinator for Gary Hart's Presidential campaign in 1984, changed his party registration to Republican in 1991 to make an unsuccessful run for one of Hudson County's three State Senate seats. Last November he finished ahead of 18 other candidates in a special election to complete the term of former Mayor Gerald McCann, who was sent to Federal prison after his conviction on fraud charges. And in May he won a full term, defeating a candidate backed by the city's Democratic organization headed by Robert C. Janiszewski, the Hudson County Executive.
 
Another Theme
 It is because he appears to have his feet in both parties that Mr. Schundler is being wooed by the candidates for governor and the Legislature. But today he pressed another theme: that party labels mean little in a city fighting for its economic life.
He noted that he won in May as the Republican incumbent with 70 percent of the vote in a city with a 70 percent Democratic registration.
"This doesn't suggest a victory of party, it suggests a transcendence of party and a victory for the people," he said. "It proves that people do not dream partisan dreams; they dream human dreams."

He promised a "new beginning" for the city. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Germans Reduce 2 Key Rates

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 1

 BODY:
The German central bank lowered two key interest rates today, answering calls from President Clinton and European leaders to loosen the monetary reins in Europe's largest and most depressed economy.
The Bundesbank's moves, which were made at a meeting in the economically devastated eastern German city of Leipzig, also took Chancellor Helmut Kohl off the hook on the issue of high German interest rates in advance of next week's summit meeting in Tokyo of the seven leading industrial nations. 
 The bank's central council reduced the discount rate, the rate it charges commercial banks for short-term loans, to 6.75 percent from 7.25 percent, the lowest level since early 1991. It also cut a second measure, the Lombard rate, which acts as a ceiling on money market interest, to 8.25 percent from 8.5 percent.
 
 
Fifth in a Series
 The decision today to reduce both rates was the fifth in a series of reductions that began in September, when they were at post-World War II highs of 8.75 percent and 9.75 percent, respectively.
"The money market can no longer say we have a high interest rate policy," said Dr. Helmut Schlesinger, who as president of the Bundesbank since 1991 has been criticized throughout Europe and in Britain for having waited far too long to bring rates down, and then for reducing rates only in modest steps.
Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt, said: "It is not a high interest rate policy, nor is it a low interest rate policy yet. It is more of a middle policy."
"Everyone understands that the G-7 governments want to see lower German interest rates," Mr. Pietsch added, referring to the Group of Seven industrial nations. "I think today's step is a reasonable effort to meet those concerns and will be a positive contribution to the Tokyo summit."
The bank had made its last cut on April 22, before a series of pessimistic economic forecasts predicting that German economic activity would shrink by more than 2 percent this year and drag the rest of Europe down.
 
 
Move Pleases Clinton
 President Clinton had pleaded on Wednesday for a further reduction. "I think the German central bank should continue to lower interest rates there so that all of us together can expand this economy," he said at a photo session with Congressional leaders in Washington. The White House welcomed the bank's announcement today.
Financial and monetary analysts had been expecting a further move by the bank today, and in anticipation the dollar had surged -- to 1.7103 marks on the currency markets in Frankfurt today, 7.3 percent higher than its value at the beginning of June.
After the announcement, the dollar retreated somewhat, to 1.7055 marks in late trading in Frankfurt. In New York, the dollar was at 1.6950 marks late in the day, down from 1.7060.
Since the Bundesbank is considered unlikely to make any further decisions on interest rates until the end of summer, other bankers thought any further significant rise in the dollar's value would come only if the Federal Reserve Bank in Washington raised its discount rate, which is now 3 percent.
 
 
No Danger for the Mark
 Since spring, the Bundesbank has had one eye on the effects in the currency markets of its decisions affecting the mark. Dr. Schlesinger said today that the bank was determined to preserve the currency's position as an anchor in the European monetary system, and analysts said that the reduction seemed unlikely to endanger it.
Brendan Brown, chief economist for Mitsubishi Finance International P.L.C. in London, said: "The economic geography of Europe is overwhelmingly in favor of the Deutsche mark. Also, the Bundesbank has built a longstanding reputation as the best independent central in the world at maintaining the currency's stability and keeping inflation down."
German rates, he said, were now "not all that high if you take into account what is happening with monetary growth or the record budget deficit in Germany, which is unprecedented in any cyclical comparison."

HEADLINE: City Opera Musicians Bar Wage Freeze

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The musicians of the New York City Opera Orchestra have rejected the company's request for a wage freeze this season, the company and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians said yesterday. The union had agreed to a wage freeze for the month of June, when the company was on tour, but negotiations for a freeze for the coming season broke down early this week.
The City Opera, which posted a deficit of $2.9 million in 1992 and is projecting a deficit of about $1 million for the fiscal year that ended on Wednesday, first asked the unions for a freeze last October. Christopher Keene, the company's general director, said at the time that a seasonlong wage freeze would save the company about $500,000, and would make it possible for City Opera to break even in its 50th-anniversary season, which opens on July 28. 
 In rejecting the freeze, Florence Nelson, the vice president of Local 802, pointed out that in 1989 the musicians had agreed to a contract in which the greatest benefits -- salary and pension fund increases, and an extra vacation week -- were scheduled to take effect this year.
 
Guarantee Rejected
 "Even so," she said, "we said we would accept the freeze in exchange for a guarantee that we would not lose working weeks next season, when the company changes its schedule from summer and fall to fall and spring. They either could not or would not give us that guarantee."
The current contract expires on May 30, 1994, and Irwin Schneiderman, City Opera's co-chairman, said yesterday that the company could not offer the players the assurance they sought. "By agreeing to the guarantee, we would be agreeing in advance to the most important economic issue in a contract that we have not yet begun to negotiate," he said. "We can't do that."
Mr. Schneiderman said that the company's failure to obtain a wage freeze would not imperil the coming season, but that the board and Mr. Keene would have to search for other economies. Mr. Keene was on vacation and could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Arbour Deal Is Done: The Man Is an Islander

BYLINE: By JENNIFER FREY

 BODY:
The playoff ride was too exciting, the future possibilities too intriguing for Al Arbour to give up now. And so Arbour, who seriously considered ending his 18-year coaching career with the Islanders this summer, has instead agreed to sign on for at least one more year as the team's head coach.
General Manager Don Maloney said yesterday that he and Arbour had come to a good-faith agreement that would keep Arbour behind the Islanders' bench for a minimum of one more season and in the organization beyond that. Consistent with his past agreements with the Islanders, Arbour will sit down with Maloney following the 1993-94 season and reassess his options, deciding then whether to extend his coaching contract or move into a front-office role.
 
'Gets Your Juices Going'
 "There's no doubt that when you're out of it for a while and you get back into the playoffs, it certainly gets your juices going," said Arbour, who led the upstart Islanders past the Pittsburgh Penguins and into the Wales Conference finals this spring. "The question is always whether the challenge is there, and that's what brings me back. I thought with the club and the way we finished, there would certainly be a challenge to keep it going that way." 
 The decision, in effect, means that Arbour will finish out his career with the Islanders, the team that he has coached for all but three and a half seasons of its existence. With his credentials -- and, particularly, his success with a young team last season -- Arbour had been considered a candidate for other head coaching jobs in the National Hockey League.
"I thought of that," Arbour said. "I decided the one thing was I didn't want to go somewhere else. Really, I'm an Islander, and I want to remain one."
 
With Team Since '73
 After coaching three seasons in St. Louis, Arbour joined the Islanders in 1973, the team's second season in the league. Since then, he has coached the team for all but a two-and-a-half season stretch in the mid-1980's, when he retired briefly. He has coached more games (1,522) than any coach in N.H.L. history, compiling a 745-541-236 record (703-501-211 with New York) over that span. He guided the Islanders' franchise to four consecutive Stanley Cups from 1980-83.
"At this stage, the youth of our team, the mix of our team with personalities, Al's the guy who fits the bill," said Maloney, who said he was "thrilled to have him back."
"He's the guy we wanted on the job," added Maloney. "I'm sure it speaks for itself the effort and commitment he gave this year."
 
Won't Come Cheap
 Maloney said he and Arbour had not come to terms on his salary. Maloney has acknowledged that he will have to pay Arbour according to the market rate for the current crop of elite coaches, and these days, the elite do not come cheap. Mike Keenan, the new head coach of the Rangers, is reportedly making about $900,000 a year, and Scotty Bowman was given a salary of about $800,000 when he signed on with the Detroit Red Wings last month.
"Certainly the economic climate has changed and we are respectful of that," Maloney said.
Arbour spent some time at his home in Florida mulling the decision after his team was eliminated from the playoffs by the Montreal Canadiens, who went on to win the Stanley Cup. He then joined Maloney in Quebec for the N.H.L. draft last week, but said he did not want to complicate matters during the draft, so he put off his decision until a few days ago.
 
SLAP SHOTS
 DARIUS KASPARAITIS, the Islanders' hard-checking defenseman, was arrested early Wednesday morning in Suffolk County on Long Island and charged with driving while intoxicated. According to SALVATORE YOVINO, a police spokesman, Kasparitis, 20, was spotted driving his 1993 BMW in an erratic manner in an eastbound direction on Rt. 25 in Huntington, L.I. He then led police on a high-speed chase before being stopped in Commack at 4:25 A.M., said Yovino. He was arraigned yesterday in a Central Islip Court and released on his own recognizance, pending a Sept. 7 hearing. According to Kasparitis's lawyer, ROBERT CURRAN, his blood-alcohol level was reported to be at .20, double the legal limit. Islanders' General Manager DON MALONEY said yesterday that he had spoken with Kasparitis, but that he had no comment about the situation.

HEADLINE: Raise Social Security Taxes

BYLINE: By Robert M. Ball; Robert M. Ball, chairman of the board of the National Academy of Social Insurance, was Commissioner of Social Security from 1962 to 1973.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nobody likes being singled out for a tax increase, and it's no surprise that most higher-income Social Security beneficiaries oppose President Clinton's plan to tax more of their benefits. Nevertheless, it is a good idea.
It is only fair. Why should Social Security -- by far our biggest pension system -- be taxed differently from private pensions and Government career pensions? Retirees under these other plans pay income tax on the part of their benefit that exceeds what they paid in. They don't pay on their own contributions because those have already been taxed, but the rest of the benefit is income with no more special claim to exemption than other income, like workers' wages. 
 The President has proposed to tax 85 percent of Social Security benefits for higher-income retirees, as against the 50 percent now taxed.
Mr. Clinton proposed a fixed percentage because it just isn't worth doing (and explaining) the complicated individual calculations necessary to apply the exact rules for private pensions to millions of Social Security beneficiaries. Anyway, virtually every beneficiary will be better off with the 85 percent figure. Employees' contributions to Social Security are almost always less than 15 percent of the expected lifetime benefit because while benefits are indexed to wages and prices, employees pay Social Security taxes as they earn their wages, unaffected by subsequent inflation.
I favor the President's plan not only because it would make the tax code more equitable but because I believe it would strengthen Social Security as an institution. Identifying it with all other earned retirement income would emphasize that Social Security is not welfare. Taxing Social Security like other pensions would show that it is an earned right and help hold off proposals to cut benefits.
Social Security was tax-free until 1983, not because of a specific exemption but because of an interpretation of its benefits as a Government grant, really a gratuity, and not an earned right. When the Social Security law was drafted in 1935, some feared the Supreme Court might rule it unconstitutional because of its unprecedented linkage of levying taxes and granting benefits in a social insurance system. So the parts of the law granting benefits were kept entirely separate from the parts imposing taxes.
But if the benefits weren't connected to the taxes, what were they? One Treasury ruling said Social Security was "considered a payment in promotion of the general welfare and is not taxed," while the taxable portion of a civil service pension was "considered to be in the nature of deferred compensation paid by the employer."
This distinction is damaging to Social Security, which also grows out of employment and is paid for by employees and by employer contributions -- a deferred wage.
Besides reinforcing the program's philosophical basis, taxing Social Security benefits would end up costing the elderly less than the benefit cuts proposed as an alternative. Since the proposed tax (like the current tax) exempts single taxpayers making less than $25,000 a year and couples making under $32,000, only 22 percent of beneficiaries would pay. And those taxes would most affect the elderly early on, when they can best afford it. Total income, including work earnings and private pension income, which is not indexed for inflation, often declines over the years. Tax rate brackets and exemptions increase with inflation. So over time, a larger share of income falls into a lower bracket or becomes exempt, allowing retirees to keep more of their benefits in old age, when they most need them.
By contrast, cutbacks in cost-of-living adjustments or an across-the-board reduction in benefits would affect lower-income people as well as higher-income people and would tend to hit harder as retirees grew older.
Ultimately, Social Security should be taxed as regular income, without special low-income exemptions. But eliminating exemptions now would cut too deeply into what many pensioners count on. Instead, inflation will eventually make today's low-income thresholds obsolete, while regular income tax exemptions will in-sure that about 40 percent of recipients will still pay no taxes on benefits.
The President's proposal would reduce the deficit some $32 billion in five years. But the major virtues of this particular plan are philosophical: to promote tax equity and to emphasize working people's earned right to Social Security by treating it like any other earned pension.

HEADLINE: Who Can Harness History? Only the U.S.

BYLINE: By Brent Scowcroft; Brent Scowcroft, president of the Forum for International Policy, a foreign affairs foundation, was national security adviser to George Bush.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For the first time since the Hitler era, no would-be global dictator is working to overthrow the established order. Despite the many civil wars in the world, the U.S. has an opportunity to mold an international system more compatible with the values we have held for two centuries. But we may be letting that chance pass through our fingers. The tremendous domestic tasks facing us call not just for our immediate attention but for continued real sacrifice.
Some say that we have carried the weight of world leadership long enough and that we no longer need to maintain a large military establishment. These attitudes are understandable but misguided. Beyond the responsibility that goes with power and the altruistic obligation most Americans feel toward their fellow man, very practical, even selfish reasons should move us. 
 America has never been more dependent on the outside world for its well-being and that dependency is steadily growing. International economics and the global environment are by definition two issues that know no boundaries yet demand skillful management to avoid large-scale disaster. National boundaries are also becoming irrelevant barriers to terrorists, drug traffickers, and even refugees whose motives are simply a better life -- or life itself.
Foreign trade -- open trade -- also is vital to America. Since 1988, 70 percent of U.S. growth has come from exports, exports of consumer goods are up 55 percent and export-related jobs have increased 42 percent.
The U.S. cannot prosper amid chaos and conflict, economic isolation or hostile trading blocs. Foreign policy and domestic policy have become two sides of the same coin.
A better world can emerge only as a result of strong and enlightened leadership. Whether we like it or not, the U.S. alone can provide that leadership. No other power, no international organization, has the global view, respect and the reach to touch every corner of the world. Left to its own devices, history will sooner or later serve up another nasty surprise.
This is not an argument for the U.S. to be the world's lone policeman. There will remain, however, a critical need to lead the world into action. This is not a call for unilateralism. But "multilateralism" is no option if it becomes an excuse for inaction or for waiting for others to galvanize the international community into action. In the gulf crisis, for example, the U.S. mobilized a great international coalition to defeat Iraqi aggression against Kuwait, at the same time leading the U.N. Security Council to provide the moral and legal judgments and authority for the military action.
Somalia is a more recent case in point. No country but the U.S. had the military and logistical ability to restore order quickly so that humanitarian relief could be delivered to end the starvation. That was all done in cooperation with the Security Council, by a U.S.-led coalition, with the understanding that after the initial relief operation U.S. forces would be replaced by other U.N. contingents.
Somalia has turned out to be more complicated than originally perceived. The warlord Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid challenged U.N. authority, killing a number of U.N. troops. This led to U.N. forces engaging in offensive military action and U.S. forces fighting under a U.N. commander, both precedent-breaking steps. Still, the operation is on course, and the U.S. can be proud of the role it played in Operation Restore Hope and continues to play under U.N. authority.
Neither the U.S., a U.S.-led coalition nor the U.N. can intervene to right every wrong, deal with every injustice or reverse every breach of the peace. The first priority should be external behavior -- political, economic and military -- in the international community. In addition, we must lead the way toward promoting respect for and the sanctity of the individual in societies everywhere.
When the international community acts, especially these days when its enhanced authority is getting established, it is critical that each test of strength be successful. Success will breed success and deter aggression that might otherwise take place. Early failures would encourage flouting of the world order. During the cold war, this principle was called deterrence, and we should never forget that, while the context may have changed, the principle remains valid.
The seemingly intractable conflict in Bosnia illustrates the complexity of the problem. The Bush Administration concluded that the situation on the ground created by the warring parties could not be significantly modified without enormous amounts of force. Even in such a case, achieving success, in any reasonable definition of that term, as in Kuwait and Somalia, appeared illusory, if not impossible.
The Clinton Administration seemed initially inclined toward military intervention but backed off, confronted by the lack of international and domestic support. The decision clearly shows that leadership also consists in knowing the limits of multilateralism.
We cannot lead effectively if the already shrunken military establishment has to bear the disproportionate weight of budget reductions, as seems to be the case these days. We need to maintain a global presence backed up by credible forces. Deterrence and defense depend on it.
All Americans have a desire to bequeath to their children a more stable and prosperous world than they inherited. We can strive, while foreign affairs are in a relatively unsettled state, to be the indispensable ingredient in fashioning a stable world order -- or we can turn inward as we did after World War I, until another mortal threat reminds us that our fate depends on the world in which we live. We do not have the luxury of putting our leadership on hold until we get our domestic house in order. Unfortunately, there is no holiday from history.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why New Yorkers Have Fought Hard to Keep Rent Regulation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
After the tulips, the first robin and the rhubarb, there invariably comes your editorial excoriating New York City rent regulation. This year a bumper crop: not one, but two (June 14 and June 22). 
 As usual, you blame rent regulation for property tax losses, no new construction, the deterioration of buildings, abandonment and "making a sick real estate market sicker." Landlord greed, of course, has nothing to do with it. Unfortunately, these fictions don't fit the facts.
Abandonment, for instance, occurs to the same degree in cities with rent regulation as in those without, and abandonment in this city is highest in neighborhoods with the fewest rent-regulated buildings and lowest in neighborhoods with a high proportion of regulated buildings.
Many things affect new construction, but rent regulation isn't one of them, as new buildings are not regulated unless the owner voluntarily submits to regulation in exchange for tax abatements. (Most do, by the way, which should make one wonder how onerous the controls really are.)
Regulation fosters maintenance because owners who make major capital improvements, like new windows or heating systems, are rewarded many times over the actual cost through permanent bonus rent increases. Moreover, landlords who refurbish an apartment between tenants get to increase the rent permanently by one-fortieth of the cost.
Could the city collect higher property taxes if rents were deregulated? Probably, at least for a while, but the bottom line wouldn't be better. To raise $100 million more in property tax revenues, rents would have to be raised $500 million to $600 million. This is not new money; it's just a transfer of funds from tenants to landlords and would mean tenants would have less to spend on everything else. Those who can will move elsewhere; those who can no longer afford the rent will turn to the city for shelter. Instead of a revenue gain, a net loss is all but inevitable.
Contrary to myth, more than half of regulated tenants are nonwhite or Spanish speaking; since 1978, rents for regulated apartments have grown faster than inflation and wages, which means that, despite controls, shelter takes an ever larger share of household income; well over half of rent-regulated households paid more than 30 percent of income to rent in 1991; in 1990, 77 percent of rent-regulated households had incomes less than $40,000, while a mere 3 percent of rent-regulated households had incomes of $100,000 or more.
This 3 percent has some people's knickers in knots. You and some State Senate Republicans propose that the state take on the huge administrative burden of ascertaining every regulated household's income to flush out these possibly unworthy beneficiaries. That would cost us taxpayers at least $10 a year per unit, more than $10 million a year for the million-plus regulated units. Court battles will ensue. It hardly seems worth it.
New York's real estate market may indeed be "sick," but the infecting agent is the delusion of easy and quick profits carried by the owners and those who finance them. Tenant fears of deregulation can hardly be characterized as "misplaced." It's not for nothing that it's called rent stabilization.
 
RAY BAILEY
New York, June 24, 1993
The writer is a member of the board of the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition.

HEADLINE: Student Loan Bill Fixes What Isn't Broken;
Slower on Federal Role

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In an otherwise excellent article, you state inaccurately that "the national service program is designed to meet President Clinton's objectives of reducing interest rates on student loans by replacing banker intermediaries with Education Department administrators" ("Clinton Wins Key Votes on Plan for Service Tied to School Loans," front page, June 17). 
 National service is surely a tremendous idea. But it will have no effect on the interest rates on Federal college loans.
National service is a stand-alone issue, perfectly able to exist apart from the President's other major higher educational proposal -- which might have some effect on interest rates -- to make student loans direct from the Federal Treasury.
Unfortunately, there is no guarantee that direct Government lending will lower interest rates. There is a good chance it will do the opposite. As Representative William F. Goodling, a Pennsylvania Republican, told a House subcommittee June 10, if the Administration's proposed interest rate formula under direct lending were in place today, student loan borrowers would be paying a rate 3/4 percent to 1.4 percent higher than under current law.
My organization, a nationwide coalition of nonprofit education loan organizations, including guarantors and secondary markets, supports national service. But that is a different issue from direct Government lending. We believe there is too much risk involved in full and immediate implementation of direct lending.
Instead, the program should be phased in, tested and evaluated before a final commitment is made. This is the approach taken by the proposal approved by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee.
 
DANIEL S. CHEEVER JR.
Chairman, Coalition for
Student Loan Reform
Washington, June 24, 1993

HEADLINE: The Trouble With Punitive Smokers' Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jeffrey Harris states that a $2 increase in the Federal excise tax on cigarettes (Op-Ed, June 4) would increase excise tax collections from $5 billion to $32 billion. Michael Grossman (letter, June 18) accuses Professor Harris of underestimating the response of smokers to higher taxes, thus overestimating the likely tax revenues. Mr. Grossman's research suggests a tax of $1.26 a pack would maximize Federal revenues from the cigarette excise tax. 
 A statistical analysis of state excise taxes on cigarettes, based on data from 1960 through 1990, suggests that both Mr. Harris and Mr. Grossman may be wrong. In this study Kevin Grier and Richard Wagner, economists from George Mason University, calculated that 35 cents to 40 cents a pack was a revenue-maximizing rate for state excise taxes on cigarettes. Increases beyond that level, it was predicted, led to reductions in tax collections. This can be generalized to the Federal level, with the caveat that cross-border effects will be less strong, reducing the relevant elasticity somewhat.
Nonetheless, the Grier-Wagner study assumed a given level of the Federal excise tax, now 24 cents a pack. Raising this to $2 or $1.26 a pack is a radical increase in the level of excise taxation. If the Grier-Wagner estimates are correct, there is a much higher response by smokers to an increase in the excise tax than Mr. Harris and Mr. Grossman suggest.
It seems very likely that tax increases of this magnitude will lead to a reduction in tax collections. This means that Government has milked smokers for all the revenue it can.
Tax increases of $2 or $1.26 a pack will lead to a reduction of Federal excise tax collections if the experience of the states is repeated. Such a level of taxation on smokers is simply punitive; it succeeds in nothing but fleecing low-income, working-class smoking families of more than $2,000 a year.
 
ROBERT D. TOLLISON
Director, Center for Study
of Public Choice, George Mason U.
Fairfax, Va., June 25, 1993
