HEADLINE: Clinton Proposes to Soften the Blow of Base Closings

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
In an effort to cushion the economic blow to communities suffering military base closings, President Clinton today announced a package of proposals to speed and increase assistance to scores of affected areas.
Mr. Clinton's plan, a combination of existing programs and new proposals that would require Congressional approval, was announced by the President at a White House news conference. 
 Mr. Clinton also said he had approved an independent commission's recommendations to close 35 major bases and expand or reduce 27 others. The recommendations of the panel, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, now go to Congress for approval, which is expected.
Under the Administration's plan, the Pentagon would speed the transfer of former military bases to communities for other uses, quicken the environmental cleanup on the sites, improve coordination between Federal and local authorities and increase economic planning grants.
The White House said the package would cost about $5 billion over the next five years. The Federal grants that are part of this package would amount to an average of $1 million for each community over that period. Most of this money has already been appropriated or is included in legislation before Congress.
 
All Jobs Won't Be Saved
 Mr. Clinton, joined at the news conference by Vice President Al Gore and five Cabinet Secretaries, cautioned that the measures were not a panacea for the cites and towns about to lose their bases.
"Even with all these aggressive efforts, the closing of a military base, as with any large employer, will inevitably be traumatic for the host community," he said. "I cannot promise that every job will be saved."
Independent analysts applauded the Administration's proposals but urged Mr. Clinton and his senior advisers to be more specific.
"It's a good start, but we're going to need more details on how he hopes to solve problems than the glimpse we saw today," said Keith Cunningham, an analyst with Business Executives for National Security, a policy group in Washington.
Not all local officials were willing to accept Mr. Clinton's plan as a consolation prize. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that New York State might offer a legal challenge to the commission's recommendations to close Plattsburgh Air Force Base and the Staten Island Homeport and reduce Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome, N.Y.
Mr. Clinton's proposals build on several existing Federal programs, but they also include a few new ones. He said he would consider asking Congress to change the law to allow the Defense Department to transfer bases to communities at a discount from their market value, or even at no cost, for purposes of economic development. At present, such transfers are allowed only if the bases are converted into parks or other public sites.
Finally, the Defense Department's Office of Economic Adjustment has increased the average size of planning grants it offers to communities where bases or military industry plants are closed, to $300,000 from the previous average of $100,000.
The new proposals are directed at all communities where bases are being closed, including those from the earlier rounds of closings, in 1988 and 1991, Pentagon officials said.

HEADLINE: Aid for Owls, Trees and Loggers

 BODY:
President Clinton's plan to manage and protect 800-year-old forests and spotted owls in the Northwest won't end the tension between loggers and environmentalists, but he has taken a giant step in the right direction. He shields not just a bird, but a rich, irreplaceable ecosystem of timber, water, fish and fowl, while still permitting sustainable logging.
The President offers a reasonable compromise. He would allow logging that environmental absolutists prefer to ban outright, but would set tight limits that timber interests misrepresent as ruinous. 
 The issue was joined two years ago when a Federal judge in Seattle ruled that rapid cutting on lands controlled by the Forest Service violated the nation's environmental laws. He ordered cutting halted until the Government devised protections; the Clinton plan is subject to his approval.
The most striking feature of the President's proposal is its sharply reduced ceiling on logging in the affected forests. It allows less than one-third as much cutting over all as in the 1980's, with tight control in designated areas of old growth. Loggers will protest the rollback, with the outspoken support of House Speaker Tom Foley, who hails from the state of Washington. But cutting could not have continued at the earlier pace; sooner or later there would have been nothing left to cut.
While the industry and its workers blame Government curbs for their troubles, there are at least three other factors -- automation, Southeastern timber development and subsidized exports of logs for finishing in foreign mills. (Mr. Clinton sensibly wants to end those subsidies.)
To compensate for the inevitable loss of work under new logging limits, the President offers retraining and new jobs in forest preservation, plus economic aid for affected communities.
With impressive foresight, the Clinton plan also seeks to head off future trouble by concentrating on watershed areas; preservation of streams and rivers as well as the surrounding forest should prevent new crises over fish and wildlife and, not incidentally, keep water supplies clean. In addition, 10 areas are to be designated for joint experimentation by local interests and the Government, looking for better methods of logging and preservation.
Closer inspection and judicial review of Mr. Clinton's plan will doubtless raise challenges to its particulars. For now, credit the Administration for serious effort to resolve a troublesome conflict.

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Guarded Optimism

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
Inside the small offices of the Caribbean Air Mail on Church Avenue in Brooklyn, a constant flow of Haitians poured in and lined up yesterday, waiting to wire money to relatives in Haiti.
During these often long waits at the Haitian version of a Western Union, the conversation usually consists of pleasantries about the family back home and the difficult economic times. 
 But yesterday the talks centered on the sudden twist of events that may bring about the return to power of Haiti's President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
 
'A First Step'
 "It's a first step," said Frantz Toussaint as he waited to wire about $100 to family members in Port-au-Prince, the capital. "It's about time the situation is resolved. The Haitian people have suffered long enough."
After nearly two years of disappointment, the development has been received here with guarded optimism.
"In a struggle it's hard to define the struggle immediately," said Mr. Toussaint, who has lived in Flatbush for more than six years. "But there was a beginning to this crisis, so there will be an end and that end will be democracy."
Yesterday, under a cloudy sky, there was no dancing in the streets of Flatbush. Instead, along Nostrand and Flatbush Avenues, Creole-speaking men and women huddled around radios in barbershops, grocery stores and record shops, grasping for every bit of information.
"Cedras might as well stay here," said Jean Simeus, a resident of the Midwood section of Brooklyn, who was standing in front of St. Aude Barber Shop. He spoke of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, Haiti's military leader, in Creole. "There's nothing for him to do in Haiti."
Just a few doors away from the barbershop, Jean-Robert Momperousse, owner of La Difference Bake Shop, quickly took out a pink and blue coffee cup with a picture of Father Aristide encircled in hearts.
"He is the solution," Mr. Momperousse said of Father Aristide, Haiti's first democratically elected president. "He started to do a job and when he returns he will continue to do a good job."
Under the agreement, Father Aristide will choose a Prime Minister. When the Parliament accepts the candidate, it will grant an amnesty to those involved in the coup, including General Cedras and the Port-au-Prince Police Chief, Michel Francois. Then the army's high command will resign.
"It's not just Cedras and Francois -- the whole high command has to go," said Alain Moise standing in front of the bakery shop. "And they should go even before the sanctions are lifted and before there is a new Prime Minister. Otherwise it's just a continuation of the coup d'etat."
Jacques Larose added, speaking of Father Aristide returning: "I'll believe it when I see it. These Haitians can come up with all kinds of ways to surprise you."

HEADLINE: Istanbul Journal;
Turks Espouse Change (She Has a 'Smile of Steel')

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey

 BODY:
Her family's wealth is said to total some $50 million. Her clothes are designer-chic and her command of languages makes her just as at home in Munich or Maine as on the Sea of Marmara.
That is to say, even if she had not just become the first woman to be Turkey's Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller would be a defining emblem of what unabashed success means in a land that has propelled itself in a decade from military rule to free-market riches -- a boom that has restated Turkey's claim for acknowledgement as a worthy partner of the West. 
 Yet there is a twist to Mrs. Ciller's rise to prominence that underlines the uncertainties of a country rooted in Asia and Islam but yearning to be European: when some Turks fete her appointment as their leader, it is not so much to simply celebrate a woman breaking a masculine and Muslim mold, but to go further and say that with a woman at their helm who can now deny their claim to a modernity defined in Western terms?
"This shows that Turkey is a part of the Western world, that Turkey is a civilized country," said President Suleyman Demirel, her predecessor.
Mrs. Ciller's election on June 14 by the dominant True Path Party, Mr. Demirel said in an interview, sent "a very good message."
"Many people are afraid that Turkey is becoming fundamentalist," he said. "People are asking that question. And then, here's the answer."
Paradoxically for the 67-year-old Mr Demirel, though, the election of the 47-year-old Mrs. Ciller sends the rather less comforting message that people have tired of a generation of old-guard politicians, like himself, who have traversed the stage of public life -- sometimes at center, sometimes in the wings, sometimes in military-enforced silence -- for more than three decades.
"Everybody said, 'She's a change, let's try her,' " said Nur Batur, a prominent journalist in Ankara. "Nobody rejected her because she is a woman. What they think is that she'll bring change. What change? That's the big question."
Mrs. Ciller (pronounced CHILL-air) herself has cast her appointment in the same way. "Nobody can resist a ripe idea," she told the party congress that nominated her as leader of the True Path Party, and thus as Prime Minister-designate. "The idea today is change."
In a land that has pursued Western aspirations since the founding of the modern Turkish republic in 1923, Mrs. Ciller has obvious credentials. The daughter of a wealthy Istanbul family, she was educated at the city's prestigious, American-run Roberts College.
In the 1970's, she lived in the United States, studying economics. She received a master's degree from the University of New Hampshire and a doctorate from the University of Connecticut and pursued further studies at Yale.
Such is her association with America that her leftist adversaries say she actually is American, although she has denied their assertion that she and her husband were granted United States citizenship 14 years ago.
Not only is she the first woman to be the country's Prime Minister, she is also the first Prime Minister since 1923 to be born on the European side of the Bosphorous.
What she is, Turkish newspapers have decided, is the "lady with a smile of steel" -- a description supposed to denote the powerful will that was already evident in 1963 when, at her marriage to Ozer Ucuran, a businessman, she refused to take his name and persuaded him to take hers, an unusual feat in a Muslim society.
Neither is she afraid of saying out loud what others say privately about Turkey's European allies. "The Europeans," she told one interviewer, "should realize that Europe is not an exclusive Christian club."
"She is not a person who's frightened of breaking eggs to make the omelet, and she has very strong determination," a Western diplomat said. "If that means that some people won't like her, she'll say, 'Too bad.' "
 
At a Disadvantage
 But her relative lack of political background puts her at a disadvantage, some say. Mrs. Ciller entered politics from academia, and was an economics professor only three years ago.
Neither has her track record so far shown an ability to convert her knowledge of economics into the practicalities of tussling with the huge inflation that has come on the wings of Turkey's booming, export-oriented growth.
While still in opposition in the late 1980's, Mr. Demirel appointed her an economic adviser, hoping to broaden his party's support from its roots in Turkey's vast hinterland and embrace urban intellectuals and business people.
When Mr. Demirel won power in 1991, Mrs. Ciller became a junior minister and the newspapers took to calling her "The Princess" or "The Daughter" -- a patronizing label that soon fell into disuse as she tilted against Mr. Demirel's instinctive caution and consensus-building in economic policy.
Whatever the relationship, though, she was unable to redeem her pledge to bring down inflation -- currently running at 65 percent -- to around 40 percent, and has failed to accelerate the selloff of Turkey's vast, loss-making state enterprises. The two issues lie at the core of the country's economic problems, despite its 1992 growth rate of almost 6 percent, one of the world's highest.
"She has not so far proven herself to be a manager," a Western official said.
As Prime Minister, she has more freedom to attack those problems. As leader of a party whose popularity is faltering and as head of a coalition whose future is unclear, however, she arguably has less.
Her coalition partner, the Social Democratic Populist Party, is to elect a new leader in September who may be less accommodating than its present boss, Erdal Inonu, diplomats say. Her adversaries have been whispering darkly to diplomats and journalists that they have compiled 13 "dossiers" concerning the ways she and her husband made money in real estate.
But she is still enjoying a honeymoon with both Turkey's bellicose press and opposition parties.
"She represents the same thing in Turkey that Clinton represented in the U.S.: change," a Western diplomat said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tansu Ciller acknowledging supporters in Ankara on Sunday after she became the first woman to be Prime Minister of Turkey. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Orders Sharp Budget Cuts To Save New York's Bond Rating

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Responding to pressure from fiscal monitors and Wall Street, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday took the unusual step of ordering significant new cuts in New York City's budget only two days into the new fiscal year.
Mr. Dinkins said he was trimming the new budget and planning to make similar reductions in future budgets to head off a threat by Standard & Poor's, a major credit-rating agency, to lower the city's bond rating. 
 In practical terms, a lowering of the bond rating would have made it more costly for the city to do business because its bonds would have been more expensive and more difficult to sell to investors. In political terms, a lowering would have opened Mr. Dinkins to charges of poor fiscal management by his opponents in this fall's election, including Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal.
 
Rating Remains at A-
 After hearing the administration's proposals in meetings over the last few days, Standard & Poor's announced yesterday that it would maintain an investment-grade rating of A- for New York City, though it continued to express some reservations about the city's future budgets and overall fiscal health.
Mr. Dinkins's plan would cut about $130 million from the city's $31.2 billion budget through reductions in capital spending on projects like roads, bridges and schools; attrition of the work force, and other cost-saving measures, officials said.
Those cuts will grow to about $400 million in next year's budget, which is now projected to have a deficit of $1.7 billion. The city's fiscal year runs from July through June.
Asked at a news conference why he was cutting the budget only three weeks after negotiating it with the City Council, Mr. Dinkins replied, "You don't have a usual situation. We're taking an action now that seems to be indicated by the circumstances."
That comment seemed to be a reference to the reaction that greeted the budget, which was passed on June 12.
It was criticized by many fiscal analysts and government monitors, who said it relied on too many stopgap measures, avoided tough decisions and threw future budgets into jeopardy. Standard & Poor's, which began to review its rating with the adoption of the budget, was among those critics.
Some analysts also maintained that the Mayor had shied away from making significant and necessary cuts in the city's budget because he feared alienating supporters in an election year.
Perhaps for the same reason, the Mayor yesterday did not publicly announce the amount of the reductions in this year's budget, preferring instead to emphasize the cuts that would take effect in the next fiscal years. Senior administration officials supplied the amount of the current cuts but would speak only vaguely about their impact.
Though mayors often tinker with spending plans during the course of the year, it is rare for them to make cuts so soon after a budget has been passed. The moves seemed to indicate that Mr. Dinkins had been stung by criticism of his fiscal management and was trying to shore up his reputation as he readies for a bruising fall election campaign against Mr. Giuliani.
"It's highly unusual to begin a process of modifying the budget the day after the budget goes into effect," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that monitors the city's finances. "Usually you have to wait until further in the year to see if you have any further problems in the way revenues are coming in or expenditures are going out. I would interpret this as the city starting early the process of cleaning up the mess that everybody recognized was in the 1994 budget."
Richard Bryers, a spokesman for Mr. Giuliani, declined to comment on the cuts ordered by Mr. Dinkins for the current year, saying that Mr. Giuliani had not yet seen the proposals.
Standard & Poor's evaluation of the city's fiscal health differed from that of another major credit-rating firm, Moody's, which has pegged the city's bonds at a lower rating.
A downgrade of the city's rating would have forced it to pay perhaps $3.5 million in extra interest for each offering of $700 million in new bonds, which are used to finance roads, sewers, schools and other projects. Typically, the city issues $4 billion in new bonds annually. A downgrade also would have prevented mutual funds and bank trust departments that limit their investments to bonds with at least an A- rating from buying city bonds.
Mr. Dinkins tried to put the best face on the new cuts by emphasizing themes that he has often turned to during his tenure: that he has balanced all his budgets, that the recession has limited his options, and that the Federal and state governments must pay more attention to urban problems.
Senior administration officials said they would spend the next few weeks compiling a list of specific reductions that they would present at a meeting next month of the state's Financial Control Board,

HEADLINE: HAITIAN MILITARY IS SAID TO ACCEPT PLAN TO END CRISIS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
In what they described as a breakthrough in efforts to resolve the political crisis in Haiti, United Nations negotiators said yesterday that they had won the approval of Haiti's army commanders for a series of steps aimed at returning the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power by Oct. 30.
Father Aristide withheld agreement from the settlement proposed by the United Nations, however, holding out for a more rapid schedule for his return to power, the negotiators and aides to Father Aristide said. 
 The reported agreement by the military commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, put the international negotiators in what they said was the uncomfortable position of pressing Father Aristide for his approval after many long months of diplomacy, pressure and sanctions carried out on his behalf.
 
Removal of Sanctions Proposed
 Under the proposed settlement, a global embargo on oil and arms sales to Haiti imposed by the United Nations would be suspended after Father Aristide picks a new Prime Minister who would be ratified by the Haitian Parliament, a process that could take weeks.
The fact that the sanctions would not be lifted right away was apparently intended to make sure that the transition to a new government would be well under way first. The embargo was imposed by the United States and other leaders of the United Nations Security Council to force the Haitian military to agree to withdraw from power.
The pressure on Father Aristide to accept the terms of the accord was considerable, since the terms signed by General Cedras had been proposed by the United Nations mediator, Dante Caputo, and supported by the United States.
 
'A Golden Opportunity'
 In a statement in Washington, Secretary of State Warren Christopher said that it would be "highly desirable that President Aristide agree" to the proposals.
"We think that they present a reasonable solution and approach to this matter," he said. Late Thursday, Mr. Christopher called Father Aristide himself, according to members of Haiti's presidential delegation, to reinforce the point, calling the settlement "a golden opportunity."
Negotiators for both Father Aristide and General Cedras have been meeting in the United States Coast Guard Officers' Club and various residences on Governor's Island in New York harbor. Both men were on the island last night as discussions went ahead, but they did not meet.
There have been several times when hopes for a resolution arose only to be crushed by word that one party or the other remained inflexible on some aspect of the talks that the negotiators thought was about to be settled. Diplomats and advisers to the exiled President said yesterday that Father Aristide was urging United Nations mediators to move up the date for his return, making it much earlier than the Oct. 30 date agreed to by General Cedras.
Father Aristide was also reportedly pushing for the immediate retirement of General Cedras, along with that of other military leaders.
 
Cedras Would Resign
 Under the United Nations plan put before both sides early Thursday, General Cedras would resign his command only days before Father Aristide's return.
Diplomats said that several other crucial issues on the transition of power remained to be settled. Among these were the deployment under the authority of the United Nations of hundreds of international assistants with expertise in fields as varied as police work and military training, construction and economic development.
Senior United Nations officials visited the talks on Wednesday, saying that a timetable of four months was necessary because of the need to resolve these issues. But Father Aristide's advisers said yesterday that they remained unconvinced that it cannot be done sooner.
As early as next week, Haitian political parties were expected to begin meeting, probably at the headquarters of the Organization of American States in Washington, to discuss the formation of a new government with Father Aristide.
 
Amnesty for the Army
 Under the transition plan, the Parliament would also pass an amnesty for members of the Haitian army covering their involvement in political crimes related to the coup, and shortly before the President's return, a new commander would be named who would then name a new army high command.
A huge international economic development package would be started for Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest country, in an attempt to alleviate the poverty, which has grown much worse since the coup. In the first announcement of the aid, Washington said Thursday that it would release $37.5 million almost immediately after a settlement to create jobs and help restructure the army.
Another senior official said the current plan does not envision American participation in an international police force, in part because there is a desire to use French speakers.
The United States also does not want to have a large military or police force in Haiti because any American military presence in the region is politically sensitive.
 
Problems With Timing
 Emerging from a second session with United Nations mediators late yesterday afternoon, Father Aristide's envoy to Washington, Jean Casimir, told reporters that the United Nations proposal "contains all the elements necessary for a return of democracy" but that the presidential delegation had problems with "timing and sequence."
Mr. Casimir said his delegation hoped that, with "some concessions from both sides," an agreement could be reached.
Diplomats involved in the talks said that there was no prospect of obtaining an immediate resignation of the military leaders and that Father Aristide would have to trust the international negotiators' guarantees of "constant monitoring and verification" of compliance by both sides with the settlement's terms.
"If something happens, we'll know who is responsible and how to impose penalties," one diplomat said.
 
Overhaul of the High Command
 After hundreds of deaths in his country at the hands of soldiers since the coup in September 1991, Father Aristide has pressed for an immediate overhaul of the army command, particularly because its members have frustrated past diplomatic initiatives aimed at bringing about his return.
Aides to the President say the army is delaying handing over power partly because of huge profits it has reaped through control of much of the economy, as well as from drug-smuggling and other illegal activities.
Some diplomats were openly exasperated by the slow progress in the talks and the delay in Father Aristide's approval after a breakthrough was achieved with the army.
Diplomats said the Haitian military delegation had served notice it would wait until the last possible moment to sign the document before its return to Haiti today.

Chart: "The U.N. Plan for Haiti"
Photo: Many Haitians conditionally welcomed the announcement of an accord leading to the restoration of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President, providing the United Nations sanctions are lifted, including the embargo on fuel. Haitians pushed an out-of-fuel truck through Port-au-Prince. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. 2)
 The United Nations plan to restore democracy in Haiti and to reinstate the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as president is based these elements, which have yet to be approved by Father Aristide:
A meeting of Haitian political parties to lay the groundwork for a new government.
Nomination of a prime minister by Father Aristide and its approval by parliament.
Adoption of a law to provide amnesty to soldiers who joined in the coup against Father Aristide in September 1991.
Resignation of the military high command, whose replacements would be appointed by Father Aristide and of the police chief.
Arrival in Haiti of an international mission to help form an independent police force to replace the military police and to retrain the army as a professional force that would be under civilian authority.
Resumption of aid from the United Nations and other international organizations.
Return of of Father Aristide to Haiti on Oct. 30. (Source: THe Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Foster Care's Horrors Argue for Intact Families

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For every horror story Patrick Murphy cites in "Family Preservation and Its Victims" (Op-Ed, June 19), I can give 10 examples of the horrors of his preference: continued overreliance on foster care.
Eighteen-month-old Sara Eyerman was taken from her mother in California because child welfare authorities thought she wasn't growing fast enough. Six weeks later, she was dead of viral pneumonia because those same authorities ignored her 104-degree fever for two days. 
 Two-year-old Joey Huot was taken from his parents in Philadelphia because they were fighting with each other -- and placed in foster care with a convicted rapist. Three months later, Joey Huot was dead. The foster parents were convicted of involuntary manslaughter.
Five-year-old Melissa King was placed in foster care in Tampa, Fla. Two months later, she was dead after a beating so severe it ruptured her spinal cord. The foster mother was convicted of murder.
Mr. Murphy cites two deaths in family preservation programs and claims they are not isolated cases, but offers no evidence. In contrast, though the majority of foster parents are excellent, evidence of widespread abuse in foster care is overwhelming.
A Baltimore study found abuse in 28 percent of the homes examined. A second Baltimore study found four times the number of substantiated reports of sexual abuse in foster care as in the general population. And when alumni of what is said to be an exemplary, model foster care program in the Pacific Northwest were questioned, 24 percent of the girls said they were victims of actual or attempted sexual abuse in their foster homes.
Family preservation is not only more humane than foster care. It's also safer than foster care.
Mr. Murphy cites only one study of the impact of family preservation on placement rates. Other studies have found dramatic benefits, including a reduction in placement. After an extensive review of the literature, the Commission on California State Government Organization and Economy (the "Little Hoover Commission") concluded that the studies have produced mixed results, but there has been more than enough success to justify a major expansion of family preservation in that state.
We can, and should, debate the extent to which family preservation is a proven success. But this much we surely know: Foster care is a proven failure.
 
RICHARD WEXLER
Albany, June 22, 1993
 
The writer is the author of "Wounded Innocents: The Real Victims of the War Against Child Abuse" (1990).

HEADLINE: Foster Care's Horrors Argue for Intact Families;
Assault on the Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The cleverness of Patrick T. Murphy's challenge to pending Federal family preservation legislation (Op-Ed, June 19) masks an insensitive assault on poor families who struggle to contend with inadequate housing, insufficient employment opportunities and the unavailability of decent child care. As Mr. Murphy has done repeatedly in Illinois, he argues from a handful of horror stories about families who have brutalized their children, concluding that family preservation dollars spent on parents charged with neglecting or abusing their children is wasted money.
Yet Mr. Murphy's tales bear little resemblance to the vast majority of families who face state intervention based on charges that they have failed to take proper care of their children. Most of the parents who populate the halls of our country's juvenile courts are not child abusers, but individuals who have been charged with "inadequate supervision" or "environmental neglect," and who have fallen short of society's high standards in their struggle to feed, clothe and house their families on pitifully inadequate resources. 
 Family preservation funds may spare many of these children from the horrors of the woefully inadequate foster care system that awaits them once they are removed from their homes.
Mr. Murphy's demonization of parents supported by family preservation funds -- most of whom come from low-income and minority backgrounds -- has little connection to the mundane routine of a typical juvenile court. It is simply wrongheaded to think that economic conditions have little to do with what distinguishes "good" parents from "bad" parents.
Congress should recognize that family preservation is not "patronizing," but rather a recognition that children generally do best with their families, and that even "good" parents may sometimes need a little extra help.
 
BRUCE A. BOYER
Chicago, June 24, 1993
 
The writer is supervising attorney, Children & Family Justice Center, Northwestern University Law School.

HEADLINE: In U.S., South Africa Leaders Press Clinton for Aid

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela and F. W. de Klerk held separate meetings with President Clinton today, underscoring their position as political rivals but individually carrying the message that each views American economic assistance as vital to South Africa's future as a multiracial democracy.
A crucial step will be to lift economic sanctions against South Africa. That awaits a signal from Mr. Mandela, leader of the African National Congress, which led the worldwide campaign that resulted in the sanctions being imposed on the white-minority government there. 
 Mr. Mandela, who had hoped to call for lifting the sanctions during his current two-week tour in the United States, said a debate over how South Africa will be run until free elections next April could delay for three weeks a decision on lifting the sanctions.
 
Reassured Americans
 But today, as Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk, the South African President, crisscrossed Washington on a busy schedule of closely parallel but separate meetings, both men sought to reassure Americans that the negotiating process in South Africa was on track and that business investment would be welcome there.
"We are keen to insure that sanctions are lifted as soon as possible," Mr. Mandela said after meeting with Mr. Clinton.
"We will make the necessary breakthroughs," Mr. de Klerk said earlier, after a session with Secretary of State Warren Christopher. "It is just a matter of time."
In a statement after the meetings, the White House said that at next week's economic summit in Tokyo, the United States would press for a commitment "to reintegrate South Africa into the world economy," contingent on further progress toward a nonracial democracy.
A senior Administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonimity, said that could include discussions on lifting sanctions imposed on South Africa by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
The statement said Mr. Clinton praised both Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk during the respective 30-minute meetings and pledged that the United States "would be a full partner in building democracy in South Africa, including continued support for programs of voter education and training of election monitors."
The Bush Administration lifted Federal sanctions against South Africa, but some 29 states and more than 100 cities, including New York, maintain them. The United States also continues to support the sanctions imposed by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
Both Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela agree that help from the world lenders is needed to help stave off the nation's deepest recession of the century, which has left nearly half of the country's black population unemployed.
 
Criticized Opponents
 Both Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela used their appearances in Washington to criticize their opponents and to state the importance of keeping the negotiating process on track.
Mr. de Klerk referred to the "lunatic fringes" on the left and right in South Africa, and Mr. Mandela, answering a question during an appearance at the Freedom Forum in Arlington, Va., sharply upbraided the leader of the Inkatha Freedom Party, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, an influential Zulu leader who prefers a federation to the unified state supported by Mr. Mandela.
In a recent meeting with Mr. Buthelezi, Mr. Mandela said he told him: "In effect, you are saying: 'I want to be ruled by whites. I am not prepared to take over power.' " Mr. Mandela said he told Mr. Buthelezi that was an odd position for a black leader to take.
Mr. Mandela's day also included a luncheon with about 20 prominent black political, labor and business leaders, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly, the presidents of the N.A.A.C.P. and the Urban League, and officials from Phillip Morris, Coca-Cola and Anheuser-Busch.
 
Chided on Sanctions
 Mr. Mandela and Mr. de Klerk refrained for the most part from criticizing each other. Mr. de Klerk did chide Mr. Mandela for not moving more quickly on sanctions.
For his part, Mr. Mandela said of Mr. de Klerk: "He did not impose sanctions. He has no right to set any timetable for their removal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa speaking at a luncheon yesterday in Washington. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Weary Town, Mississippi Shows Its Might

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAFTON, Ill., July 2

 BODY:
The last time the Mississippi River betrayed this town this badly, it flooded Betty Gerber's street two blocks away. She and her four children were forced to live for eight weeks without electricity or cooking gas in their mobile home.
When the river finally retreated far enough, she ran an extension cord to the local car wash so she could operate her refrigerator and a small fan. 
 That nightmare was only two months ago. "This time is worse," Ms. Gerber said today of the rising river that threatens to close downtown. "I think this town is jinxed.'
Indeed, the mighty Mississippi will not leave tiny Grafton alone. It has been taunting this town of antiques shops and fruit stands since the broken promise that was springtime here. For 104 days in a row, the Mississippi and its cousin the Illinois River have been at or above flood stage along Grafton: 18 feet in this stretch of muddy banks and limestone bluffs about 45 miles from St. Louis. Grafton is where the two rivers merge.
 
Town Is Not Alone
 "The river won't stop coming," said Paul Arnold, the city's overworked flood coordinator, "and people are really getting frustrated and depressed. I've seen a lot of eyes filled with tears."
Grafton has been under siege for months, but it is not alone. For more than a week the Mississippi has been spilling over its banks from St. Paul to St. Louis, 500 miles of damage and disruption.
The flooding has stalled commercial shipping traffic on the river for two weeks or longer. Some estimates put the losses to barge companies at $1 million a day -- and climbing with every rise of the Mississippi.
The Mark Twain bridge connecting Hannibal, Mo., to Illinois was closed early today because of high water.
The river has crested in St. Paul and is expected to crest in Davenport, Iowa, on Saturday at 22.3 feet, just shy of the river's record level in Davenport of 22.5 feet in 1965. Still, Davenport has evacuated 600 people from low-lying areas, and 200 members of the Iowa National Guard have been called to help sandbag and patrol the city. President Clinton is expected to tour the Davenport riverfront on Sunday.
 
1,000 Barges Stalled
 Before touring parts of Missouri, Illinois and Iowa by air today, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said in St. Louis that the flooding was beginning to "devastate" the region's economy.
"We are very concerned about the impact to all the communities up and down the Mississippi," the Secretary said today, with the river pouring over its banks in a downtown St. Louis park. "It's clear to me that this is a significant impact already."
Up to 1,000 barges are being prevented from traveling on the river, he said, the equivalent of 40,000 trucks stalled on a highway.
The flooding has soaked businesses and spirits. It has closed bridges and streets and forced at least one post office to move. It has caused millions of dollars in losses to towns and businesses that have grown up along its banks because of the river's charms, beauty and access to markets.
"When the river stays where it's supposed to, it's a great attraction; there's nothing like it," said the Mayor of Grafton, Gerald Nairn. "But when it jumps its banks, look out. You better find a high hill and wait it out."
 
Much Under Water
 In Grafton, the river was at 25.5 feet and capturing dry ground like an advancing army. A fish stand has closed because the customers cannot get there without a boat: the lot has disappeared under the water.
So far, the river has covered Water Street, a parking lot, a bike path, stop signs, boat docks, mailboxes, backyards, fences, trees, grills, hopes, dreams and an overstuffed trash bin.
This morning, 20 families packed their belongings. The city had told the 132 families and businesses along the river to move to higher ground, before it was too late. While the city itself does not have the resources to help people move, a group of Baptist volunteers from other towns has arrived to help residents pack up and move.
All the houses in town are still standing, even though some, like Julie Zimmerman's, are in six feet of water. Since April, Ms. Zimmerman has slept wherever she could find a dry place. She has not lived in her house on Water Street since flooding forced her to live like a refugee. She first moved in with friends, but the river flooded them out, too. Then she moved into an apartment rented by the Red Cross. That was flooded on Saturday. On Monday, she slept in her car. Now she has moved on to other friends.
With the crest expected to be even higher this time, Ms. Zimmerman guided a pontoon boat up to her house to retrieve a cedar chest full of clothes and her daughter's computer. The April flooding had knocked her porch down, blocking the front door, so she had to climb in through a window.
 
River 'Like an Old Friend'
 "A lot of people who weren't here before are really upset about the flooding," she said. "I don't like it either. I bought my house in 1986 and had to move out six weeks later because of flooding. But I was baptized here, my family's here, so I'll clean up and start all over. Most of the time the Mississippi is like an old friend."
By Monday, town officials said, the river will be at 28 feet, licking at the edge of Main Street. When that happens, officials say the town will be closed off to outsiders, an unsettling prospect here because so much of Grafton's survival depends on the tourist trade that stops to fuel up on its way to a nearby state park, browse the craft shops or splash in the Raging Rivers Water Park, which is on high enough ground on the outskirts to escape the Mississippi's advance.
Grafton has also begun requiring special flood travel passes to enter certain parts of town.
Sandbags are one approach this town of 1,000 residents is not even trying. "It won't do any good," Mayor Nairn said.
The river is expected to crest here at 30 feet on Tuesday -- two feet higher than during the April flooding, which forced 25 businesses to close for 36 days.
 
Harm to Businesses
 One business that shut down in April was Uncle Andy's Corner Market, operated by Brenda Dublo. Water was more than an inch deep on the store's floor. Now the river is coming back again, and is beginning to wear her spirit down.
"I don't know from day to day if I'm going to be able to get into my store," Ms. Dublo said. "I'm doing about half of what I normally do at this time of year."
But, she said, she's better off and drier than many other merchants in town. "A lot of businesses say they just aren't going to be able to come out of this again," she said. "They're going to go belly up."
For the last week or so, Mayor Nairn has held a daily flood briefing at 1 P.M. for whoever shows up. On Thursday, about 40 people, mostly townspeople, showed up and nodded their heads in solemn knowing agreement when he said, "You people with flood insurance better get ready to use it."
Then Paul Main's voice and humor spread through the room. "This just proves what I've always said about Grafton," said Mr. Main, a 64-year-old lifetime resident. "Grafton is between a rock and a wet place, and the wet place is getting bigger."

HEADLINE: In U.S., South Africa Leaders Press Clinton for Aid;
Date Set for First Election

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 2

 BODY:
South Africa's major political parties today confirmed next April 27 as the date for elections that will end white rule and ratified a set of constitutional principles that amounted to a repudiation of the country's political past.
Seven of the 26 parties, including the Zulu-based Inkatha Freedom Party and the white separatist Conservative Party, voted against setting a date for the elections, saying several key aspects of the future state have not been resolved. 
 Although a few of the dissenters stalked from the meeting room moments before adjournment, Joseph Matthews, the head of the Inkatha delegation, said the party had no plans to withdraw from the talks.
"In two weeks, after the break, we will be here," he told reporters.
 
Progress, But Limited
 Leaders of the African National Congress said they were delighted by the progress at the negotiations and the fact that no party had yet abandoned the process. But they said the agreements so far have fallen short of the congress's criteria for lifting economic sanctions against South Africa.
Cyril Ramaphosa, the congress's chief negotiator, said leaders of the organization would meet after Nelson Mandela returns from the United States in mid-July to consider revising their conditions. A.N.C. officials predicted that a call for the repeal of sanctions is no more than a few weeks away.
By consensus, the parties endorsed a set of binding constitutional principles that would commit future governments to Western-style democracy.

Winnie Mandela Pays a Fine
 JOHANNESBURG, July 2 (AP) -- Winnie Mandela paid an outstanding fine today that was imposed by an appeals court for her conviction in the kidnapping of four people, a court official said.
An arrest warrant for Mrs. Mandela, the estranged wife of Nelson Mandela, was issued this week because she had failed to pay the $4,500 fine imposed on June 2.
Mrs. Mandela was convicted in 1991 of kidnapping and being an accessory to assault in the beating of four young black men at her Soweto home. Instead of a five-year prison term, Mrs. Mandela was given the option of paying the fine or spending one year in jail. She was also ordered to pay $1,500 to the victims.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Some Searing Criticism Of Foreign Bond Funds

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
THE P.R. guy at the table was twitching, but Nicholas Bratt pressed ahead with his argument that the benefits of investing abroad come only from stocks. Foreign bonds? "I think they are speculative," said the star manager of the Scudder International Fund, with a percussive British accent on the last word.
The P.R. guy interjected that Scudder happens to have a top-performing international bond fund -- with just over $1 billlion, by far the most popular no-load fund in its category. No matter. Mr. Bratt insisted that only stocks compensate for currency risk by letting investors benefit from rising corporate earnings. "You get bailed out in equities, not bonds," he said. 
 Add Mr. Bratt to the small but prominent band of mutual fund executives willing to warn against the foreign income and bond funds that have sucked in so much money since United States interest rates sank to such unrewarding levels.
Mr. Bratt and his allies see great advantages in foreign stocks. United States shares are far more expensive, relative to their earnings, than European shares. Economic growth and earnings gains are likely to be stronger in Asia and Latin America than in the United States.
Such earnings growth allows shareholders to profit from higher stock prices and dividends. Bondholders get their fixed income, nothing more.
Foreign bond and income funds continue to multiply, with 19 making their debut in the 12 months ended in May, for a total of 94, according to Lipper Analytical Services. Assets totaled $30.4 billion. Investors traumatized by losses in last September's currency turmoil registered more than $5 billion in net redemptions through March, but became net buyers again in April and May,
They often buy and sell at the wrong time. "When everybody's talking about high interest rates abroad, the money comes pouring in," said John C. Bogle, the crusty chairman of the Vanguard Group. "When something bad happens, the money goes out."
Mr. Bogle is most skeptical about short-term global income funds, which often draw investors who think that short-term foreign debt is as stable as domestic debt. Investors who saw the value of their global income funds fall by 10 percent or more in a few days last September got a quick lesson in currency risk.
Customers shopping for what they think is a high, stable return face further danger: The more these global income funds lunge for high yields, the harder they fall. As with junk bond funds, too many buyers of global income funds confused yield, or current payout, with total returns. Total returns can become negative if the value of a fund's securities declines.
Over the last year, the highest-yielding currencies have been the most vulnerable to sudden devaluation. The Pilgrim Short-Term Multi-Market Income Fund (beware of any fund with more than five words in its name) still boasted a 9.2 percent yield in May, but currency losses had cost shareholders almost a fifth of their investment over the previous 12 months.
At the end of last year, Pilgrim turned in desperation to a new, outside adviser. A Pilgrim executive proudly noted that during the first quarter, the fund finished just above the average of similar offerings, but didn't add that the total return was just four-hundredths of 1 percent. At that rate, $1,000 invested in the fund Jan. 1 would earn $1.60 this year. And that's before a 3.5 percent, or $35, load.
Many investors in global income funds have shifted their money from savings accounts and certificates of deposit. Since these funds often attract investors who know little about currency markets, the Dreyfus Corporation has resisted introducing one. "We were worried that people would not understand the risks involved," said Diane M. Coffey, a spokeswoman for Dreyfus. "They would be buying them for the wrong reasons." Dreyfus does plan to introduce a foreign bond fund in a few months, under the assumption that investors are prepared for volatility from bonds.
The most successful foreign income and bond funds have hedged some of their currencies. Money managers can use swaps, options, forward contracts and other means of transferring the risks. Some mutual funds don't hedge at all, and generally say so in their prospectuses. Otherwise, investors are left guessing how much their fund hedges, and how great their currency risks are. The cost of hedging eats into the returns, to the point that 100 percent protection against currency risks would leave investors with yields no better than they can get from United States securities.
The T. Rowe Price International Bond Fund switches its hedging strategies depending on its currency outlook. Founded in 1986, well before most similar funds, it returned an average of 7.3 percent annually for the five years through March.
Mr. Bogle of Vanguard, ever willing to needle a competitor, said that despite its size and success, the T. Rowe Price fund had been tossed about by jittery investors. The fund's managers say that of the $450 million in the fund at the beginning of last year, about $400 million was long-term money. The fund's assets peaked at $612 million in August. During Europe's currency turmoil in September, the fund fell 6.5 percent in 10 days, almost wiping out the year-to-date income.
Many investors then fled. By the end of the year, losses and withdrawals trimmed the fund to $520 million. It has since rebounded and recaptured money to be near its peak.
William F. Wendler, an executive with the T. Rowe Price foreign funds, says that despite the perils, foreign bond and income offerings deserve attention from investors who want to diversify and capture higher yields. He delicately adds that investors might buy a foreign stock fund first. "The risk-reward ratio for international equity investments appears to be higher than it is for bond investments," he said. But most mutual fund executives are tempted to give investors what they want, not just what's best for them.

HEADLINE: Long Bond's Yield at a Low of 6.66%

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices advanced broadly yesterday after a weak employment report put to rest market fears that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates soon to combat inflation.
Increases in long-term bond prices, however, were muted by inflation concerns during a second consecutive day of sharp gains in commodity prices. 
 The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond advanced 9/32 point, or $2.81 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, fell to 6.66 percent, from 6.68 percent late Thursday.
Yesterday's long Treasury yield was the lowest since the Treasury began regular sales of 30-year bonds in 1977. Previous record lows were set only last Monday and Friday, as further evidence of a soft economic recovery dampened inflation fears and prompted buying.
 
Anemic Payroll Increase
 Bond prices spurted yesterday after the Labor Department's morning report that nonfarm payroll jobs increased by an anemic 13,000 in June, far below economists' expectations of as much as a 150,000 advance. The jobs survey had shown increases of more than 200,000 in each of the previous two months.
The Government also said the nation's unemployment rate edged up to 7 percent in June from 6.9 percent in May, and that manufacturing jobs declined for the fourth straight month.
The employment report led to particularly strong buying of short-term securities, whose value would be hurt the most by a central bank action.
The jobs report "raises questions about the durability of the job market expansion that we had seen recently," said Alan Levenson, money-market economist at UBS Securities Inc. "The general sentiment is that the Fed is on hold for the foreseeable future."
Mr. Levenson and other economists said the central bank would be hard pressed to raise interest rates in light of the June employment data, since higher rates can drag down growth.
But yesterday, another sharp advance in the Commodity Research Bureau index, considered a harbinger of inflation trends, prompted some selling of long-term bonds.
 
Wheat and Soybeans Soar
 The index rose 2.43 points, to 212.16, after a surge of 2.61 points on Thursday, amid rocketing prices of wheat and soybeans futures brought on by rain-damaged crops in the Midwest.
Long bonds were also hurt by concern that weakness in the economy might jeopardize President Clinton's deficit-reduction package, said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Dean Witter, Discover & Company.
"Lower returns in the bond market have been predicated on effective deficit-cutting legislation," Mr. Sullivan said.
The market recovered most of its earlier gains, however, as traders squared up their trading strategies in the holiday-abbreviated session. The Treasury market closed at 2 P.M. in advance of the Fourth of July holiday.
Short-term Treasuries were up 1/8 point to 7/32 point and intermediate maturities rose 3/16 point to 1/4 point, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, rose 2.35, to 1,309.32.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills were down to 2.99 percent as the discount dropped 0.04 percentage point, to 2.94 percent. Six-month yields were lower at 3.13 percent as the discount fell 0.05 point, to 3.05 percent. One-year yields were down to 3.31 percent as the discount fell 0.07 point, to 3.20 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1029/16, up 1/32 from late Thursday. The average yield to maturity was unchanged at 5.72 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading And Gold Slips in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against most major foreign currencies yesterday, despite a disappointing report on job growth in June.
Gold prices fell on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with gold for August delivery closing $1.50 lower at $386.70 an ounce, after climbing $5.40, to $393.60, a level unseen since the Persian Gulf war in January 1991. 
 Ben Pugliesi, chief dealer and director of precious metals at the Swiss Bank in New York, attributed the move up to a follow-through on Thursday's strong gains and some technical factors.
 
Disappointment in Data
 Traders said the dollar's action was driven in early New York trading by the Government's June employment report, which showed that the jobless rate rose to 7 percent from 6.9 percent in May. Manufacturing jobs declined for the fourth straight month, the Government said, and the overall economy gained just 13,000 new jobs.
One trader said the market was looking for job growth of about 125,000.
"We had some impact from the number that we saw, the unemployment number showing almost no job growth," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
Many traders left their desks early to get a jump on the Fourth of July weekend, and trading volume was relatively light, said Lee Kassler, a senior trader at the National Westminster Bank USA in Jersey City. That exaggerated the dollar's movement, both up and down, he explained.
In Tokyo, the dollar ended at 107.93 yen, down 0.17 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it rose to 108.70 yen. In New York, the dollar traded late at 108.55 yen, up from 107.38 on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5080 from $1.5085. In New York, the pound traded late at $1.5075, down from $1.5150 late on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.6965 German marks, up from 1.6950; 1.5115 Swiss francs, up from 1.5095; 5.7383 French francs, up from 5.7240; 1,540.00 Italian lire, down from 1,542.00, and 1.2873 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2874.

HEADLINE: A New Glimmer of Recovery For New Jersey Employment

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
In a continuing improvement, the unemployment rate in New Jersey fell in June to 6.9 percent from 7.4 percent in May, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. June was the first month since January 1992 that New Jersey, one of the states hit hardest by the recession, posted a rate below the national figure.
The Federal report said that the unemployment rates in New York State and New York City remained worse in June than the nationwide rate, which rose to 7 percent from the 6.9 percent of May. 
 The rate for New York State rose to 7.8 percent in June from 7.5 percent in May. For New York City, the rate in June was 9.4 percent, down from 9.5 percent in May.
The rate for Connecticut was not available, because it is not among the 11 large industrial states for which the Federal Government releases monthly employment data at the same time it releases the national figures.
The improvement in New Jersey has been pronounced, considering the dismal levels reached early in the spring. In April, after three months of economic deterioration, the New Jersey rate was up to 9.1 percent, the highest that month for any of the 11 big industrial states.
The upturn may have political ramifications, with Gov. Jim Florio in a tight gubernatorial campaign against Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican candidate. She has said Mr. Florio's economic policies have played a role in creating New Jersey's economic problems.
The lower rate reported yesterday "seems to offer proof that New Jersey may be on the right road to economic recovery," said Ray Bramucci, Commissioner of the state's Department of Labor. He added, however, that he and others in the Florio administration "continue to keep our enthusiasm under control."
"We still need a faster rate of growth nationally to accelerate the rate of job creation in New Jersey," he said.
New Jersey's unemployment rate for June put the state in a tie with Pennsylvania for fourth-best performance among the 11 industrial states. The states with lower unemployment for June were North Carolina (5.4 percent), Ohio (5.8 percent) and Massachusetts (6 percent).

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Oil Prices Fall on Speculation About Iraqi Exports

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Oil prices tumbled yesterday to the lowest level since before the Persian Gulf war 30 months ago as traders, reacting to comments by an American official, speculated that a ban on Iraqi crude oil exports might soon be lifted.
The August futures contract for domestic crude fell 50 cents, to $17.95 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after the United States delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, told reporters in Geneva that the United States would not object to a resumption of Iraqi exports if Iraq met United Nations conditions when Iraqi and United Nations officials meet on Wednesday.
 
A Long-Held U.S. Position
 Although her comments reflected a long-held American position and she said the oil proceeds could be used only for humanitarian purposes approved by the United Nations, traders speculated that a resumption of exports was imminent. They cited the fact that her comments came five days after American missiles severely damaged Saddam Hussein's military intelligence center in Baghdad. 
 Analysts said deteriorating health and economic conditions in Iraq, and widespread opposition among Arab leaders to the bombing attack on Sunday, might have prompted the Administration's reaffirmation of its policy. Iraq has also indicated that it will not retaliate for the bombings.
But an imminent resumption of Iraqi exports poses enormous troubles for the 12 nations in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The members are currently producing a total of 24.5 million barrels a day, or a million barrels more than the quotas set a month ago.
Iraq would add at least 500,000 barrels a day, and perhaps as much as 800,000 barrels at its current production capacity, under proposed United Nations terms. Those terms would limit its total revenue to $1.6 billion, regardless of price, over the next two years.
Philip K. Verleger, an energy economist at the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said those conditions put President Hussein in a position to punish his bitter enemies in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait -- and not harm Iraq -- by selling oil at any price.
"Kuwait will have to make room for its vanquished foe" by agreeing to reduce its oil output, "or it's going to pay a terrible economic price in lower oil revenues," Mr. Verleger said. "The dynamics look to be very bad. It's going to be very nasty."
He said that before "cooler heads prevail in OPEC," prices could drop to $10 a barrel this summer if the worst case developed, similar to a plunge to $9.75 in 1986.
Nauman Barakat, energy futures analyst at Merrill Lynch, said OPEC would likely respond to a pact between the United Nations and Iraq with an emergency meeting to force lower production quotas on its members. But, he said, the organization lacks the discipline to hold to tighter limits.
Kuwait ignored OPEC pressure last month to scale back its rising output of 1.6 million barrels, and Saudi Arabia, which had claimed virtually all of Iraq's output of three million barrels a day after the Persian Gulf war, refused to cut its production below eight million barrels.
Like all OPEC members, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are desperate for revenue to finance spending programs. With no other producers likely to curb their output voluntarily, a pricing battle seems likely.
"Iraq's thinking is, even if they get $5 for their oil, that's $5 more than what they are getting now," Mr. Barakat said. "With that kind of thinking, no one can tell what is the bottom of this market." Iraq could expand its output if it has cash to buy equipment and expertise from willing suppliers in India, Mr. Verleger said.
Norman P. Higby, an energy forecaster in Menlo Park, Calif., said President Hussein might not agree to the United Nations terms to lift the crude export ban if the United Nations insisted on controlling all of the export revenues. Ms. Albright told reporters that the revenue would be used for humanitarian purposes.
"Saddam doesn't care about prices, or the number of barrels, he just cares about how much money he'll get -- for himself," Mr. Higby said. "His goal is to negotiate for some percentage of the revenues."

GRAIN AND SOYBEANS UP
 CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Wheat and soybeans futures prices rose to new highs on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday amid reports of yet more rain in important growing areas. Corn futures also gained.
Wheat futures surged in heavy trading to two-month highs, amid talk that heavy overnight rain in Kansas would cause the mostly unharvested crop to be of low quality.
Soybeans futures prices also continued higher amid belief that the rain in the top two-producing states, Illinois and Iowa, would cause extensive damage and disease.
"Corn and wheat are trading higher on the emotions of soybeans' surge," said Mickey Luth, senior grains analyst with Merrill Lynch in Chicago. "But for the beans, there's still the issue of what can be planted if and when the rains ever stop, realizing that you're running out of time."
The optimal period for planting soybeans runs through the first week of July. The Agriculture Department said this week that about 11 percent of soybean acreage remained unplanted.

HEADLINE: Down on the Farm, With Russians

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 2

 BODY:
The average tourist driving through the Midwest might not notice neatly trimmed farmhouse lawns, but along with spotless cheese factories, high-tech tractors and standard pickup trucks, such details can be inspiring to Russian farmers.
The sights are the hallmarks of a life style that gives people a far larger personal stake in their homes and workplaces than residents of the collective farms in Russia have. And the American life style -- not incidentally -- tends to be far more productive and attentive to the little things, like the way a home looks. 
 "Life is just completely different here and the main explanation has to be private property," said Vasily Uzun, a senior researcher at the Russian Agrarian Institute. Mr. Uzun saw all this and more as a member of a group of 20 Russian farm managers and agricultural experts who have been getting a top-to-bottom view of American agribusiness in the past two weeks.
The practice of dazzling Russian visitors with the prowess of American agriculture has become more frequent since the media-drenched visit of the Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev to an Iowa corn farm in 1959.
The latest tour, which concentrated on Minnesota and California, was arranged by the International Finance Corporation, the private-sector investment arm of the World Bank, which is managing a large Russian agricultural privatization program. Its goal is to stir up a missionary zeal for privatization among Russians whose farms and ministries will be on the front lines of the investment company's program to create model private agricultural enterprises in Russia.
"What's important is not that they see exactly how an auction or anything else works, but just to see that it works," said Alan Bigman, a field manager for the investment company, as the group viewed a cattle sale early last week at the Central Livestock Association stockyard in South St. Paul, Minn.
Universities, foundations and agribusinesses have sponsored numerous other visits over the years, often with funds from the United States Agency for International Development.
Unlike many visitors, this group has been knowledgeable enough to zero in on some of the more disquieting aspects of the American farm scene, like tensions over regulations and worries about the high failure rate of small farms. They have been asking unusually detailed questions about everything from price supports to treatments for root diseases that affect barley, according to their hosts.
Like those before them, though, the latest visitors have been enthralled by the scenes their American counterparts take for granted. In addition to modern factories, which they expected to see, the Russians delighted in finding 40-year-old machinery chugging away like new. They heard farmers like themselves talk of crop yields, in some cases double their own, saw the distribution systems that get products anywhere in the nation with negligible spoilage, and visited market exchanges where buyers bid against each other for farm products.
 
Dividends of Ownership
 The Russians also heard farmers explain how they had created private trade groups to represent their interests in Washington and cooperatives to expand their financial opportunities.
The result, as officials of the investment company had hoped, has been a heightened conviction that private ownership pays big financial and psychic dividends. "It will be easier to try to convince people to change because now I'm convinced myself," said Lubov Bubnova, the chief agronomist of Emelianova, a farm collective 50 miles northeast of the city of Nizhny Novgorod, formerly known as Gorky, in central Russia.
Like most other farms that are edging toward privatization, Emelianova has technically been converted from a state-owned collective into a venture owned by its employees and the residents of the villages on it. But with no workable regulations in place on the distribution of ownership to individuals, the farm still operates as a collective. And, lacking networks of private suppliers and product processors, it remains a cog in a Government-run agricultural apparatus that routinely loses to spoilage 20 percent or more of the output of various sectors.
 
Six Farms Chosen
 Mrs. Bubnova's farm is one of six that I.F.C. officials, who are based in Nizhny Novgorod, have picked as candidates to lead the way to privatization. The farms range from 4,000 to 15,000 acres and employ 100 to 500 administrators and laborers. The collectives are also the homes for hundreds of retirees, who will receive shares of any land distribution.
Officials of the investment company said the leadership of Nizhny Novgorod in privatizing small retail businesses and the trucking industry, coupled with the progressive attitudes of Boris Nemtsov, the 33-year-old provincial governor, make the region -- which is about the size of Ireland -- the best place to tackle the daunting problem of privatizing agriculture. "If it can't work in Nizhny, it isn't going to work anywhere," said Jeanne Segal, a spokeswoman for the I.F.C. in Washington.
Several of the visitors said they knew they were being shown the brighter side of American agriculture, but expressed confidence that what they had seen was representative of the benefits of giving farmers and private investors direct ownership in their operations.
 
Signs of Contrast
 The telltale signs, they said, were common roadside sights. The farmhouse lawns, they said, contrasted with the generally unkempt residential groups of the cooperative farms. And the large number of pickup trucks on dealer lots and in farmyards suggested that many people owned a class of individually oriented utility vehicles virtually unknown in Russia. Others commented on the lack of drunken workers or the guards who are employed to prevent the property thefts that plague the collectives.
The Russians rarely batted an eye at the technology deployed by the American farmers. They quickly understood a demonstration at the stockyard in St. Paul of a new electronic auction system that allowed hogs to be sold without shipping them to St. Paul or another association yard.
Several of the visitors accepted the invitation to use a keyboard to go through the motions of bidding. And they were more tickled than awed when invited to take top-of-the-line tractors and cultivators at the John Deere dealership in Elbow Lake, Minn., for test drives around the lot.
 
A Web of Cooperation
 What really impressed them was the intricacy of the web of cooperating and competing enterprises that drives the system and its insistent focus on marketing.
Several members of the group stared in fascination at the almost imperceptible bidding motions of buyers at the stockyard auction and wistfully compared it with being forced to sell all their cattle to the nearest state processor without bargaining over price. Worse still, they said, the processor would simply freeze the meat because there was no dependable way to distribute it while it is fresh.
Not everyone has derived the same lessons for Soviet privatization from such sights. Mikhail Goloshev, the deputy director of the Nizhny Novgorod Department of Agriculture, said he thought Russia should struggle less over questions of who owns enterprises and more on how to force them to compete.
 
Disagreement on Emphasis
 And even among those who believed the most vital step was to create private enterprises, there was widespread disagreement over whether what they had seen favored an emphasis on creating a few large farms out of each collective or many small enterprises that would give greater scope for individual initiative.
Those attuned to smaller-scale entrepeneurship were intrigued by their visit to Eichten's Hidden Acres Cheese Farm in Center City, Minn. The Eichtens sold their dairy herd during a Government buyout program in 1986 aimed at cutting milk production and had successfully branched into making specialty cheeses and raising bison for meat.
The debate over the size of the farms was serious and one of several that led to boisterous banter on the bus. But some Russians saw it as a disguised battle over the amount of power that would remain with the traditional administrators and bureaucrats.
But there was also plenty of high spirits and humor, much of it self-deprecating. "In Russia, you have a drink to celebrate any contract," laughed Yevgeny Mikheev, watching the tumult of wheat trades in the pits of the Minneapolis Grain Exchange last week. "These guys never stop."
