HEADLINE: Jobs Data Stagnant for June

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The unemployment rate ticked back up to 7 percent in June as job growth nearly vanished after two months of solid gains, the Labor Department reported today.
The rise in unemployment, from 6.9 percent in May, was accompanied by the disappearance of 53,000 manufacturing jobs. The figures were weaker than anticipated, even allowing for the steady procession of disappointing economic figures in the last few weeks. 
 While economists found a few nuggets of favorable news in the report, a common view was that the business recovery, officially now in its 28th month, has become so enfeebled that the Clinton Administration's budget plan, relying heavily on tax increases, might bring it to a halt.
 
Republican Criticisms
 Bob Dole of Kansas, the leader of the Senate's Republicans, seized on today's report to contend that "the President's massive tax increase continues to haunt working America -- employers are scared to death, so they're simply not hiring."
At the White House, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the top economic adviser to Mr. Clinton, acknowledged the option of what she called "adjusting some of the phasing" of the budget measure to changes in economic conditions. The bill is now before a Senate-House conference.
But Ms. Tyson, after noting that a Republican filibuster had killed a stimulus measure that she said would already be starting to take effect, insisted that the measure's main goals -- deficit reduction and associated low interest rates -- were still the right formula. And while the economic recovery is "modest," she added, nearly a million jobs have been created so far this year, including upward revisions announced today for April and May.
 
Weakness in Manufacturing
 The discouragement among most private economists focused largely on a meager rise of 13,000 in payroll jobs, well under predictions of an increase approaching 150,000 and down sharply from May's robust gain of 215,000. Moderate gains in business, health and educational services and in restaurants and bars were largely offset by the fourth straight sizable drop at factories and by declines in wholesale trade and in stores selling general merchandise.
"What worries me most is the erosion in manufacturing," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley. "You don't want to take that lightly."
Nearly 190,000 factory jobs have disappeared since February, and 1.7 million since January 1989, the figures showed, even as factory output has recently reached new peaks. While this implies higher productivity -- though diminished by the fact that many companies now contract out various nonmanufacturing functions -- it also means a loss in the short run of hefty paychecks that workers could use to buy goods.
Much of the June decline was in transportation, electronic equipment and instruments, reflecting cutbacks in military spending, said William G. Barron Jr., the Deputy Commissioner of Labor Statistics.
Factory hours and overtime also fell slightly in June, though remaining at relatively high levels
Construction jobs edged down 6,000, after posting gains of 36,000 and 55,000 in April and May, respectively, the report also showed.
 
Confirmed by Another Survey
 The department's survey of about 60,000 households -- from which the unemployment rate is derived -- also showed little of the early-spring vigor, though this survey's remarkable May job surge of 857,000 was sustained.
June employment declined by 54,000, a development that combined with a small reduction in the labor force to raise the ranks of the jobless by 50,000, to 8,908,000.
The unemployment rate itself edged up one-tenth of a point, an amount the department considers statistically insignificant. In fact, the reported rise occurred because the complete figure, 6.953, rounded to 7 percent; the unrounded May figure was 6.913. So, while the June increase was the first reported rise in the jobless rate in a year, the change was "really zero," a department official said.
The number of part-time workers who wanted to work full time eased 258,000 in June, to 6,322,000, but this group of "involuntary" part-timers remains extraordinarily large in light of a business expansion that has been under way for more than two years.
After other recessions, the ranks of these workers had generally diminished by 17 percent after 27 months, but this time -- since March 1991 -- there are actually 5 percent more of them.
The number of discouraged workers -- those who have given up looking for jobs because they think they will not find one -- rose 68,000, to 1,202,000, in the department's quarterly tabulation. Since the third quarter of 1991, however, this gauge has been essentially flat.
Among the 11 biggest states for which figures were published today, only Massachusetts, where the unemployment rate eased to 6 percent from 6.7 percent, showed a change of any significance. But a small decline for New Jersey, to 6.9 percent, and a small rise for New York, to 7.8 percent, pointed up a notable shift since April. In that month, New Jersey had a 9.1 percent jobless rate, highest of any large state and 2.1 points above New York's. In June, the New Jersey rate was a shade below the national average.
 
Regional Results Evenly Split
 Regionally, the department reported that the Northeast and Midwest posted declines of one-tenth of a point last month, to 7.1 percent and 6.3 percent, respectively. The rate rose, however, by two-tenths of a point in the South and the West, to 6.6 and 7.9 percent.
While today's results deepened the gloom of the more pessimistic analysts, some thought the data exaggerated the weakness in the economy. This group was inclined to wait for July figures before worrying about an aborted recovery, especially since there are distortions in the labor market at this time of year for which the seasonal adjustment process may not be adequate.
In addition, the department's survey week is always the one that includes the 12th of the month, which fell on a Saturday last month. That put this June's survey so early in the month that it probably failed to capture the movements into and out of the work force of most high school students and teachers.

Companies
The F.C.C. gave television shopping a major windfall, saying cable systems must carry such programs that are broadcast over the air. The decision could force smaller cable systems to drop channels to make room for home shopping. Consumer groups and some Congressmen attacked the ruling. [Page 1.]

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Giuliani's Strategy: Don't Give Dinkins a Target

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
For weeks, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate for mayor, has given speeches ringing with an image of a new New York City, a place transformed by tough decisions, major reforms and fundamental change.
"The next mayor of New York is going to have to smash up the way in which we practice politics and we do business in this city," he announced at the City Club in May. Absent that, he warned, "This city is going to continue to deteriorate economically. It's going to continue to deteriorate financially. It's going to continue to deteriorate morally." 
 Thus far Mr. Giuliani's r4inging rhetoric has not been backed up with many specifics on the issues that will define the mayoral campaign. The image of Mr. Giuliani sitting behind the mayor';s desk is tough but vvague. Quite intentionally his campaign guided by the campaign tactician David Garth has remained as far as it can from the tangles of issues that define the city's course or lack of it.
Instead, following a carefully constructed plan to associate his candidacy with a romantic portrait of New York City on a comeback trail, he has talked of harmony and economic growth while mostly avoiding specifics and stirring resentment against his opponent, Mayor David N. Dinkins.
By ducking the minutiae and sticking with broad brush strokes and good vibes, the campaign reasons, Mr. Giuliani can hit hard while never providing Mayor Dinkins with a target to strike back.
The Dinkins camp has tried to fight back. The Mayor recently described Mr. Giuliani as being in "the candidate protection program" and has tried to press him, and encourage reporters to press him, for specific stands. On one issue, rent control, the Giuliani campaign seemed to take a position, realized it was not particularly popular and quickly shifted ground.
Of course, it is hardly novel for a candidate to strive to avoid being pinned down on issues -- especially controversial ones -- a minute before he or she has to. What is more, the Giuliani camp had counted on a summerlong Democratic primary that would have kept attention focused on Mr. Dinkins and the rivals in his own party. But when City Council President Andrew J. Stein dropped out of the race, all eyes turned immediately to November.
 
Nothing Specific to Criticize
 The flap over rent control seemed to confirm the political wisdom of the Giuliani campaign's larger strategy of avoiding specifics as much as possible this early in the campaign. Taking positions on controversial and divisive issues like homelessness, taxes and the arcana of the budget would only give the press and the public, to say nothing of the Mayor, something specific to criticize.
Since Mr. Dinkins cannot sidestep positions, it leaves him vulnerable while Mr. Giuliani seeks to remain on the high road, speaking of harmony, economic growth and a new way of practicing politics.
In speech after speech, Mr. Giuliani tugs at the city's slow response to the disturbances in Crown Heights in August 1991, the "300,000 jobs lost" in a sustained recession, distressingly low reading and math scores in the schools, a bureaucracy "out of control" and out of proportion to New York's needs, and a catalogue of other ills that he easily recounts but has yet to offer specific ways to solve.
 
A Simple Message
 The message could not be simpler: vote for the "RUDY!" of those red and blue campaign banners and the city will breeze forward toward a future full of hope. Stay with the incumbent and watch the city bled of jobs, economic health, educational excellence, even morality.
Some New Yorkers have been charmed by this feel-good approach to a campaign. Others are already impatient. After one speech on the city's economics, several Wall Street financiers groused that he had mostly avoided specifics and that the few he did introduce were dusted off from his 1989 campaign and lacked sophistication.
But their reactions followed some of the few specifics Mr. Giuliani has offered: a promise to reduce the city's work force by across the board freezes. "Our goal," Mr. Giuliani said on May 20, is to reduce city personnel "by 3 to 5 percent per year for a three- to four-year period."
Other proposals were more vague. Asked about rent control, Mr. Giuliani that day first appeared to circle the issue by talking about the "correlation between the huge amount of property owned by New York City" and the physical condition of the city. He said he would sell some city property to bring about a healthier balance of private and public ownership.
 
'Too Emotional'
 Eventually, he went on to say that he favored removing rent regulations on luxury apartments and those that become vacant. Within a month he would do an about-face, telling reporters in Albany on June 21 that he opposed both. "The administrative burden and complexity of trying to administer a change like that in a fair way would far outweigh the tiny, small percentage of benefit that would be achieved," he said. Earlier he was quoted in Newsday as saying the whole issue was "too emotional" for the mayoral campaign.
His stand on taxes is quite general, too. Earlier this month, he vowed "a reduction of the tax burden on the people of New York City." In a pamphlet distributed by his office, Mr. Giuliani promises to "streamline and where possible, eliminate, the numerous and often capricious taxes, fines and regulations strangling city business."
Nowhere has he delineated, tax by tax, what would go, what would be reduced, what would stay, and how he would make up the lost revenue or what programs he would cut to make up the lost revenue.
He says he will "phase out the commercial rent tax and unincorporated business tax and reduce the hotel occupancy tax, too." But he does not say what programs would be trimmed by the resulting reduction in revenue.
 
Priorities for the Schools
 Schools, too, Mr. Giuliani says, would prosper under his administration. Under his administration, he said last month, the school system's budget of more than $7 billion would be poured into primary educational needs like textbooks and "decent places in which to learn, safe environments."
Sounds fine. But how? "In the trickle-down budgeting that occurs now," Mr. Giuliani said, "after the administrators and the administrators who administer the administrators, and the administrators who watch the administrators who do forms together and then talk about their forms and then make some more work for each other, after they get paid, a little bit of that trickles down to the classroom."
His solution: "first we take care of the needs of the students. Then we take care of the needs of the classroom teachers, and then whatever is left over, that goes to the less important part of the system. That's called setting priorities."
Several reporters have lately taken to calling Mr. Giuliani's run for City Hall a "stealth campaign," invisible but potentially deadly. The fact is, Mr. Giuliani has been out meeting voters for months. What is missing is not his presence, but his programs.
 
The Mayor Responds
 After Mr. Giuliani was caught twirling about on rent control last month, the Mayor finally took him to task.
"This man says to speak about rent regulation is 'too emotional' an issue," Mayor Dinkins said. "But to involve himself in Crown Heights at that rally, to be down at the police rally some time ago, that was all right. What is the thought process of this man who for three and half years couldn't be found, and even now is under a candidate protection program?"
Still, like Walter F. Mondale facing down Gary Hart in 1984, some voters are already starting to ask: "where's the beef?"
Mame Rosenberg, a sales representative for America Works, a for-profit program that tries to find work for people on the welfare rolls, was wearing a Women for Giuliani button June 16 at a gathering of the candidate's Women's Coalition. The button was only half true. She was a woman. But she was not sure that she was for Mr. Giuliani.
Ms. Rosenberg said she she went to the breakfast program simply to see what Mr. Giuliani had to say. Disgruntled with Mayor Dinkins, she had hoped to like the challenger. "I came so I could see for myself," she said. "So far, he hasn't really said anything."

HEADLINE: Grumbling Over GATT

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 2

 BODY:
For 45 years GATT has worked. The 96-page set of basic rules for international commerce designated by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has bolstered a huge increase in international trade.
 At the same time, customs tariffs have been slashed to less than 10 percent in industrialized countries, from an average of 40 percent, encouraging ever- greater exchanges of goods. And the number of nations subscribing to GATT regulations has grown to 111 from 23. 
If the current talks are aimed at lowering tariffs again by about a third, and embracing whole new sectors like agriculture and textiles, why do governments keep balking even when they have repeatedly promised to reach what they themselves call a crucial agreement?
 As leaders of the leading industrial powers prepare to gather in Tokyo next week for what is now an almost ritualistic attempt to advance the Uruguay Round, as the current round of talks is known, these questions have become pressing. More people are questioning whether GATT may have outlived its usefulness.
 "GATT is facing a structural crisis and should simply be abolished," the Gaullist President of the French National Assembly, Philippe Seguin, declared last month. He heads the more nationalist wing of the governing Gaullist Party but is far from a wild extremist in the French political spectrum. Indeed, his views have been echoed in recent weeks -- in much milder form -- by President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, and other senior officials.
 They argue simply that the world has changed. Now that communication is almost instantaneous and technology can easily be shifted, developing countries with cheap labor, little social security and no expensive environmental regulations are sure to take markets and jobs from highly developed countries.
 But the more fundamental problem for GATT is that its most ambitious trade talks since 1948 have coincided with an economic downturn that inevitably fuels protectionist trends.
 A round of trade talks attempting, for the first time, to include services, intellectual property, agriculture and textiles within the basic GATT rules is taking place against a drumbeat of layoffs and slow or nonexistent growth in the developed world.
 In such circumstances, each opening to competition is easily equated with a lost job rather than with the potential lift to economic output -- estimated by economists at $200 billion over a decade.
 So, the argument goes, free trade is not enough. As one senior French official who will be in Tokyo put it, "We can't go on running if we are not running by the same rules."
 In fact, while developing countries, particularly those in Southeast Asia, have been sharply increasing exports in recent years, they have not taken a greater share of the overall trade pie. But stagnation and recession in Europe, America and Japan have clearly changed the overall mood.
 "How do you stop people blaming outside causes for their present deep predicaments?" Etienne Davignon, the chairman of the Belgian conglomerate Societe Generale, asked in an interview. At a time of economic difficulty, he suggested, "we have to find some way between outrageous protectionism and absolute free trade."
 President Clinton has not put the issue quite the same way. But in the face of the economic problems at home, his campaign for open access to the Japanese market, to reduce Japan's trade surplus, amounts to an acknowledgment that free trade alone is not enough.
 
Sees Benefits of Competition
 GATT, however, was not fashioned for such middle ground. While its rules condone measures like quotas and subsidies in exceptional cases -- which until now have included agriculture and textiles -- the Geneva-based body stands squarely behind the view that open and multilateral trade is in the world's best interest.
 "I do not favor the Clinton approach of looking first at surpluses, even Japan's," said Peter Sutherland, the new Director General of GATT. "I believe in competition."
 But the benefits of securing a commitment from Japan to cut its surplus are also far more concrete than the promises of a new GATT agreement. As a result, some GATT officials perceive a worrying drift toward seeking bilateral or regional arrangements, like the North American Free Trade Agreement among Canada, Mexico and the United States, at the expense of the multilateral system.
 It is true that open trade can hurt. The European Community's steel industry is already suffering from cheap steel from the former Soviet bloc. If Ukraine, a breadbasket, gets organized, Western European agriculture could be a victim.
 
Giving and Getting
 A lesson of GATT's 45 years appears to be that the overall benefits outweigh the pain. "Look," said Willem Duisenberg, the governor of the Dutch central bank, "Holland used to be a great producer of textiles and shoes before the European Community was established. Both disappeared as a result of our borders' falling. But we learned new things: services, chemicals, metals. The lesson of open trade is you get something better than what you gave up."
 It is, however, a hard lesson for politicians to embrace at a time of recession. What you get comes after -- sometimes a long time after -- what you give up. That is why a GATT deal has proved elusive, and looks as if it will be again in Tokyo.
 The alternative to a GATT deal could indeed be grim. At GATT headquarters, one telling graphic is prominently displayed. It shows how, between the first and second world wars, international trade stagnated as countries turned inward.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kemper Sets Insurer Sale To St. Paul

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

 BODY:
The Kemper Corporation has agreed to sell its Economy Fire and Casualty Company to the St. Paul Companies for $420 million in cash and other assets as part of its plan to focus on its core financial services and life insurance operations.
About two-thirds of the transaction will be paid in cash and one-third in assets like stocks and bonds distributed from Economy Fire and Casualty's investment portfolio. The St. Paul Companies, a group of property and casualty insurance underwriting and insurance brokerage companies based in St. Paul, said it would finance the deal with internal funds. It also plans to replace the assets distributed from Economy Fire and Casualty's investment portfolio with an "appropriate amount" of assets. 
 After the announcement, which was made late on Thursday, Moody's Investors Service, one of the nation's largest credit and debt rating agencies, said it might lower the St. Paul's senior debt ratings and ratings on four of the company's property-casualty insurance units. About $273 million of debt could be affected, Moody's said.
Kemper, one of the nation's largest financial services companies, and St. Paul said they expect the sale to be closed by the end of the third quarter, pending approval by insurance regulators in Illinois. Kemper is based in Long Grove, Ill.
Economy Fire and Casualty, based in Freeport, Ill., is a large national auto and homeowner insurance underwriter, with $401 million in premiums written in 1992, assets of $733 million and about 1,200 employees. The company has operated through a network of 1,600 independent agents in 22 states.
Last November, Kemper put Economy Fire and Casualty and a small regional property-casualty unit, the Federal Kemper Insurance Company, up for sale, saying it wanted to concentrate on its core businesses, including its Kemper Securities Inc. brokerage, and asset management and life insurance businesses. Federal Kemper Insurance, based in Decatur, Ill., remains for sale, a Kemper spokeswoman said.
The property-casualty companies together had an operating profit of $34.5 million last year, compared with $26.2 million in 1991.
Shares of Kemper closed yesterday at $36.125, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of the St. Paul Companies closed at $80.75, up 12.5 cents, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Corning Wins in Bidding for Lab Company

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 2

 BODY:
National Health Laboratories declined today to sweeten its takeover offer for the Damon Corporation, ending up the loser in a bidding contest with its rival, Corning Inc., which will strengthen its position in the blood-testing industry.
With National Health taking itself out of the competition, Corning said it would begin its $23-a-share offer in the next few days for 16.1 million Damon shares. Damon, based in Needham Heights, Mass., operates 12 labs in the United States and one in Mexico City. 
 Corning's offer is valued at $575 million, which includes assumption of Damon's $168 million in debt and $18 million in fees owed to National Health for terminating the deal.
 
Predicts Trend for Industry
 In an interview, Robert L. Rosen, Damon's chairman, predicted that the deal would be a forerunner of a wave of consolidations in the health-care industry, driven by a demand for lower costs from health-care providers and the Clinton Administration. "Combinations provide the economies of scale and better prices that the Administration wants," Mr. Rosen said. He declined to estimate the potential savings from the merger.
The deal came with a penalty for Mr. Rosen, Damon's largest individual shareholder, and two other directors. The three executives agreed to split their stock profits if National Health's $16-a-share offer, made on June 22, was outbid. As a consequence, Mr. Rosen; the company's treasurer, Donald T. Netter, and a director, John O'Bryan, will owe National Health $3.6 million.
Corning, best known for its glassworks, also operates 40 labs that provide clinical, pharmaceutical and environmental testing and had 1992 sales of $1 billion. A merger with Damon, which had $317 million in revenue, would solidify Corning, based in Corning, N.Y., as the nation's second-largest testing company behind SmithKline Beecham, which has revenue of $1.5 billion.
Corning and Damon labs overlap in 10 markets, and analysts expect most of Damon's operations will be closed within a year. Mr. Rosen, however, scoffed at the prospect of a huge consolidation, and Corning officials declined to comment on changes in operations after the merger.
"Corning didn't buy Damon to revive it," said Damon Brundage, a health-care analyst with Paine Webber. "Corning bought Damon to dismantle it."
Mr. Brundage said National Health could not improve its offer without hurting earnings. He said Allied Clinical Laboratories of Nashville might become a new takeover target for National Health, based in La Jolla, Calif. "Corning probably won't be around to compete," he said.
The profit-sharing pact was apparently part of an agreement between National Health and Mr. Rosen to smoke out a satisfactory offer from Corning, which had been holding talks with Damon for more than a year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Bonneville, Citing Drought, Lifts Power Rate 15.6%

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 2

 BODY:
Announcing details of a rate increase that has been dreaded throughout the Pacific Northwest, the Bonneville Power Administration said today that it would raise rates by 15.6 percent on Oct. 1.
Earlier this spring, Randy Hardy, Bonneville's administrator, warned that the increase might be as high as 24 percent. 
 The agency, which supplies 170 utilities and large industrial companies in the Northwest, says it is facing a financial crisis because of a drought that has reduced output from its hydroelectric projects and cut sales. In addition, it faces expensive requirements to protect endangered fish and must cope with sluggish sales to industries that have suffered because of a poor regional economy.
Bonneville, a Federal agency, sells 50 percent of the power used in the region, which covers all of Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana and parts of other states.
Prodded by protests from rate payers, Mr. Hardy has slashed Bonneville's $2.4 billion budget by half a billion dollars, and he has also begun a program to close offices and reduce the 4,700-member work force. He is also hoping that normal rains return.
 
'Delivered on Our Promise'
 "We're playing the hand we've been dealt," Mr. Hardy said. "We've delivered on our promise to do what we could do to keep the increase as low as possible." The new rate for utilities is 2.68 cents a kilowatt-hour, up from 2.3 cents.
William Drummond, manager of the Public Power Council, which represents 113 utilities, says the rate is nearing the cost of alternative sources of electricity, threatening Bonneville's position as the region's low-cost power wholesaler.
Nine aluminum plants are among the customers hit hardest by the increase. The plants already pay 20 percent more for power than competitors worldwide and the new rate comes at a time when international prices are at record lows because Russian aluminum has been flooding the market.
"The increase will be very painful and will really hurt basic industry, said Steve Waddington, deputy director of Direct Service Industries. The group represents 11 energy-intensive aluminum and chemical plants that came to the region decades ago with low-cost power as the lure. "Some aluminum plants will cut production," he added
Alcoa said earlier this week that it would cut output nationally 25 percent. Bonneville's rate increase was factored into this decision, said Jack Speers, power manager for the company's plant in Wenatchee, Wash., which will trim production by 22,000 tons a year.
Mr. Hardy said Bonneville had taken on many programs at the request of utilities, but might no longer be able to do so. "People say Bonneville is a large punch bowl, and everybody from utilities to fish and wildlife agencies has a straw," he said. "Without change, they will suck us dry. We simply have to pull out the straws."
Ted Hallock, a member of the Northwest Power Planning Council, which plans for future energy needs and restoring fish, said: "It appears Bonneville may not be able to fully fund measures to rebuild salmon runs. We could see more fish populations pushed to the brink of extinction."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Bonneville Power Administration plans to raise rates by 15.6 percent in the Pacific Northwest because of a drought that it said had reduced output from its hydroelectric projects. The McNary Dam on the Columbia River is owned by the utility. (Bonneville Power Administration)

HEADLINE: Muddy Waters, I Presume

BYLINE: By Gary Giddins; Gary Giddins's most recent books are "Faces in the Crowd: Players and Writers," a collection of essays, and "Satchmo," a biography of Louis Armstrong.

 BODY:

THE LAND WHERE THE BLUES BEGAN
By Alan Lomax.
Illustrated. 539 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $25. 
 IN the 1960's I occasionally postured at being Alan Lomax, not by journeying into the Deep South but by approaching Skip James, Mississippi John Hurt, Bukka White and other fabled bluesmen when I was an undergraduate with a tape recorder and a thousand questions. At one session, someone asked the often distracted but ingenious Skip James about the Delta blues singer Robert Johnson. James ruminated in his mournful, high-pitched voice that now that we mentioned it, he hadn't seen his old friend in about 26 or 27 years, leaving us with the jaw-dropping implication that he didn't know Johnson had died -- 26 or 27 years before. He then told us he had taught the younger Robert "32-20 Blues," and played it vigorously as if to confirm ownership.
Musicians like James, who spurred the country blues revival, seemed strangely foreign to many of us avidly credulous white Northerners, attracted chiefly to their music but also to the romantic existentialist myths of the black troubadour. They were representatives of an America we could scarcely imagine. In 1980 Peter Guralnick wrote a keenly observed novel, "Nighthawk Blues," about blues collectors of our generation who did travel south. But perhaps only one white man could tell what it was like combing the backwoods when Son House, David (Honeyboy) Edwards and Muddy Waters were robust young artists and not the patriarchal legends of a later day. Now he has.
Alan Lomax is a nearly ubiquitous figure in American folklore and music. Born in Texas in 1915, he was a protege of his father, the folklorist John A. Lomax, with whom he created the Archive of American Folk Song at the Library of Congress and brought to public attention the baronial giant of the 12-string guitar, Leadbelly. Generations have grown up with his Library of Congress recordings of Leadbelly, Woody Guthrie and Jelly Roll Morton, as well as his book derived from the Morton sessions, "Mister Jelly Roll," one of the most influential and widely quoted books ever written about jazz. That remarkably disparate trio does not figure in "The Land Where the Blues Began," which is concerned primarily with Mr. Lomax's trips through the Mississippi Delta in the 1940's.
It is probably fair to say of Alan Lomax that he is too serious a man to write autobiography and not serious enough to write history. History requires the collation of everyone's research, and Mr. Lomax prefers to mine his own, enlarging on his experiences, as documented on disk or tape, with vivid recollections that dynamically establish the time and place of every encounter. This book makes clear (as his several others did not) that he can be a stunningly evocative writer, conveying the excitement that fueled his wanderings through Coahoma County more than half a century ago.
Mr. Lomax notes that one of his associates, a black folklorist named Lewis Jones -- who is one of the book's somewhat elliptical heroes -- characterized their research "in terms of the three main modes of transport" linking the Delta to the outside world: steamboats, railroads and highways. He then goes on to describe the first:
"Beating the brown belly of the mighty river to froth with their great paddles, filling the sky with black clouds from cathedral-like smokestacks, at night their furnaces breathing dragonlike flames across midnight waters, gliding through the semiwilderness of the Southwest like swift heavenly chariots, loaded down with well-dressed dudes, fancy women, double-jinted roustabouts and new cotton millionaires -- these floating palaces roused the awe of the Delta songsters."
Inevitably, Mr. Lomax provides a couplet by way of a musical amen: "The big Kate Adams headin' down the stream / With her sidewheel knockin' -- 'Good God, I been redeemed.' " Always his recollections lead to and from the musical examples he preserved on 15-minute acetate disks. He captured the call and response of
spirituals, whole sermons and conversations, and countless blues, play songs and work songs. Early on, he asks the reader to listen to some blues records before returning to the text.
At times, Mr. Lomax's adventures in bluesland read like an American version of "Dr. Livingstone, I presume," as when he makes his way through the "broomweed pastures" of Senatobia, Miss., and encounters Blind Sid Hemphill, a drum major with a fife-and-drum outfit whose style shows a direct African influence. Of course, he also encounters hostile natives -- all white, law officers and plantation bosses, one of whom ominously warns Mr. Lomax, "We've been told to be on the lookout for Jap agents," and then threatens to lock him up for prefacing Son House's name with the honorific "Mr." The whole book veers between musical commemoration and outrage at racist barbarism.
But "The Land Where the Blues Began" is also a journey into the folklorist's own heart of darkness. For as disinclined as he is to write about himself, Mr. Lomax is forced to acknowledge his arrogance as a young Government-sponsored missionary: he simply is not ready to handle the horrors of racism and the submissiveness he finds in its victims. After a Delta church service, he notes, "My heart had struck a depth of sorrow and hurt such as I had never imagined."
Mr. Lomax has always been a somewhat regressive defender of old ways and styles. He has mellowed enough to enjoy the accomplishments of such newfangled idioms as gospel, yet he regrets the loss of the improvised spiritual harmonies it displaced. Surprisingly, he finds sexist villainy at the root: "The age-old female religious collective was being replaced by a male-dominated hierarchy."
Mr. Lomax's reluctance to place his own research in the context of the larger historical canvas is more problematic. He does not attempt to trace the origins of songs beyond his own discovery of them (some were pop hits that Mr. Lomax, who disdains most commercial music, would have recognized had he spent more time in front of a radio), and he perpetuates myths long since discounted by other researchers -- including the familiar tale of Bessie Smith dying needlessly because she was refused admission to three hospitals, a story popularized in a play by Edward Albee that Mr. Lomax notes in his bibliography while omitting Chris Albertson's 1972 biography of Smith, which disproved it.
So "The Land Where the Blues Began" is not a comprehensive or always reliable history, but it is something no less valuable -- the firsthand account of a uniquely sympathetic and capable Boswell determined to preserve for all time not only the innovators of the blues but also the vanishing communities that produced them. Mr. Lomax gives us Muddy Waters before and after he traveled to Chicago and became a star; and, though he muses perhaps sentimentally that blacks alone know the secrets of life's pleasures, he gives us Big Bill Broonzy describing with articulate passion the economic and sociological privations of this loamy region where the blues began. In Alan Lomax's discerning reconstructions, such long-ago visits miraculously evade the blurring of time. They give life to a domain most of us can never know, and yet one that summons us with an oddly familiar sensation of reverence and dread.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sid Hemphill, left, and Lucius Smith in 1959. (Alan Lomax/From "The Land Where the Blues Began")

HEADLINE: ENDPAPER/PUBLIC STAGES;
Horror Stories

BYLINE: By Frank Rich

 BODY:
You may already have forgotten The Great Pepsi Scare of 1993. It raged out of control for less than a week, though it did leave whole states and several major news organizations terrorized in its wake.
The facts, if they can be called that, were these. On June 10, an elderly Tacoma, Wash., couple, Earl (Tex) and Mary Triplett, said a syringe had turned up in their can of Diet Pepsi. Within days, dozens of other syringe sightings were reported by Pepsi drinkers -- the very health-conscious drinkers of Diet Pepsi in particular -- in 23 states. Soon all three network evening news programs led with the crisis. Jay Leno's monologue likened President Clinton's inoculation program to "the Pepsi challenge" while Ted Koppel countered with a Pepsi "Nightline." A big-eyed 9-year-old boy in the Bronx who said his gum had been pricked by a hypodermic needle posed with the accused Pepsi bottle in The New York Post. USA Today published a front-page map showing the tainted Pepsi states in red, should readers wish to reroute their vacations. 
 Less than a week after Earl (Tex) and Mary had popped their lid, my local newscast was so obsessed with the story that it offered "team coverage" whose length and depth might persuade channel-hoppers wandering over from the Bulls-Suns game that they had stumbled into a new gulf war. One frantic anchor suggested that Pepsi drinkers search their unopened cans for needle punctures, never realizing that a perforated Pepsi can might be as empty as his head.
There was only one flaw in the frightening Pepsi scenario: the Food and Drug Administration could not confirm even a single report of Pepsi tampering. No one was sick. No one was injured. No one had a plausible theory of how syringes might find their way into soft-drink cans sealed at the rate of 2,000 per minute, let alone at bottling plants as scattered as the red states in the USA Today map. What's more, in a country where taxes are going up but the economy is flat, roughly half the population has a motive for shaking down a fat soft-drink manufacturer in a get-rich-quick hoax. Yet for 72 manic hours, even as one of the Pepsi alarmists was arrested on the Federal charge of making a false tampering claim, the mass media dangled syringes and needles before the public with ominous narration to match.
What drove this horror story? The only scare word left unspoken in the coverage was AIDS. But surely AIDS, with its doomsday specter of an unsanitary needle plunging into the bloodstream, lurked somewhere in the psyches of any copycat fantasists among those reporting the syringes. And surely AIDS was not far from the thoughts of those who flogged the fraud on the air and in print, hoping to titillate the public under the guise of informing it. As the Pepsi story unfolded, there were such bona fide AIDS stories as the publication of Arthur Ashe's memoirs, the death of the actor Ray Sharkey and the grim medical reports from the annual international AIDS conference. But after a decade of plague, the impact of such familiar events has been blunted by numbness and denial. The irrational Pepsi scare gave sensationalists a covert cue to whip up the old mass AIDS hysteria that still festers within America, however repressed, waiting to be tapped at any time. Would this patently bogus story have spun so far out of control if Earl (Tex) and Mary had found mere mouse droppings in their can?
THIS IS A SUMMER OF FEAR, BUT PEOPLE'S true fears rarely rise to the surface, where fake fears stay and can be enjoyed. The same week that the Pepsi scare toyed with what really scares America, the summer's official fount of fright, "Jurassic Park," broke box-office records, drawing crowds with its promise of monster-movie chills as executed by carnivorous DNA-spawned dinosaurs.
Reasonable people can disagree over whether "Jurassic Park" is a worthy successor to "Jaws," "E.T." and the transcendant "Close Encounters of the Third Kind." What is less debatable is Spielberg's genius for giving the public what it wants when it wants it. For all the supposed scariness of "Jurassic Park," it doesn't really scare anyone much except the very young who arrive under the mistaken impression (fostered by the film's long and greedy merchandising arm) that they are about to rendezvous with Barney. The only adults reported to be terrified are executives at Columbia Pictures, who invested zillions in "Last Action Hero," the Schwarzenegger romp that "Jurassic Park" devoured at the box office.
But it is precisely Spielberg's ability to deliver the aura of fright without any actual fright that makes "Jurassic Park" the right movie for the moment. People are panicked enough about real life right now, and they are not looking for movies that might confront them with, say, a lethal communicable virus. About born-again dinosaurs no one need seriously worry.
Forget about the technical brilliance that has gone into this movie's simulation of its Jurassic-age specimens. The real imagination has gone into keeping the dinosaurs' havoc carefree. If Spielberg really wanted to shock the audience, he would have had a T. rex eat an actor with top billing, as Alfred Hitchcock did away with Janet Leigh in the "Psycho" shower scene. But the victims in "Jurassic Park" are such secondary nonentities as a tubby villain (who would have died of a heart attack anyway), a chain smoker (who would have died of lung cancer anyway) and an arrogant, pricey lawyer (who deserves to die anyway). To make sure that no one in the audience will be upset by even the prospect of a major character failing to survive until the final credits, Spielberg cast stars who are less persuasively human than the dinosaurs. In lieu of Harrison Ford, Michelle Pfeiffer and Alec Guinness, he recruited semi-animated performers indistinguishable from the Audio-Animatronic robots who simulate dead Presidents at Disney theme parks.
As many have noted, "Jurassic Park" is itself a theme-park ride. Everyone who takes it knows where the jolts are in advance, and the fun of the experience is to yelp when the anticipated roller-coaster curve at last does arrive, especially since it is powered by the slickest technology a Japanese-owned movie studio can buy. Visible bloodshed is kept to a sanitized minimum, and a viewer never actually sees a dino incisor slice a vein. The predictable, escapist scariness unleashed by pseudo-scientists in "Jurassic Park" is the pause that refreshes for a country on pins and needles about rampaging monsters that so far remain beyond real science's grasp.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 9; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2050 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
The Cinematic Law Firm of Greedy, Vain & Immoral

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
Comfortably ensconced atop his class at Harvard Law School, sexy and clever and cocky to boot, Mitch McDeere can go to any law firm he likes. Instead, seduced by a bloated salary, a shiny new Mercedes, a plush office, the taste of Memphis barbecue and a low-interest mortgage on a ranch house with a big backyard, he opts for the ritzy but obscure firm of Bendini, Lambert & Locke.
Had McDeere, played by Tom Cruise, followed the well-trodden path from Ivy League law school to a real-life law office like Hale & Dorr or Sullivan & Cromwell, he would have quickly been forgotten. In nearly a century of cinema, few film makers have seen movie material in these strait-laced, straitjacketed operations. But in joining the Bendini firm, McDeere joined something else -- the ever-lengthier list of lawyers in American movies. 
 His venue is "The Firm," the new Sydney Pollack film based on John Grisham's best-selling tale of a yuppie lawyer who finds that his place of employment is actually a front for the Mafia. (Another Grisham novel about lawyers, "The Pelican Brief," is in production in New Orleans with Julia Roberts and Denzel Washington, and filming will start soon, once again in Memphis, on Mr. Grisham's legal thriller "The Client.")
Something there is in the American psyche that is fascinated with lawyers, and, not surprisingly, that fascination has frequently found its way onto film. But if lawyers are a constant in American cinema, the character of those lawyers is not. The heroic type immortalized a generation ago by Gregory Peck as Atticus Finch in "To Kill a Mockingbird" has fallen victim to everything from the anti-authoritarianism of the Vietnam era to the lawyer-infested world of Watergate to America's diminished standing in the world economy (for which Dan Quayle blamed the bar) to the growing ubiquitousness, and vulnerability, of lawyers themselves.
As public perceptions of lawyers have changed, so, too has Hollywood's. Indeed, film makers who once idealized lawyers have gleefully joined in the bar-bashing. "What do you call 500 lawyers at the bottom of the ocean?" Danny DeVito asks one of his clients in "The War of the Roses." "An excellent start," he says, answering his own question. "I used to resent jokes like that," Mr. DeVito continues. "Now, I see them as simple truths."
Attitudes like this explain why moviegoers, who once applauded lawyers immortalized by Mr. Peck, James Stewart and Spencer Tracy, now cheer when a Tyrannosaurus rex consumes a cowering lawyer in "Jurassic Park." It explains why Mitch McDeere, foolish and greedy and arrogant as he is, passes as a hero. It explains why California Lawyer magazine, in tracing the evolution of lawyer characters, entitled the article "Atticus Doesn't Live Here Anymore."
It is not hard to understand why lawyers have long been a fit subject for film. As professionals who often hover close to conflict, lawyers are rife with dramatic possibilities; in them, film makers have always found neatly encapsulated examples of nobility and corruption, cowardice and courage. For every valiant lawyer (like Mr. Peck in "To Kill a Mockingbird") there is one who is venal (Walter Matthau in "The Fortune Cookie") or vain (Ron Silver, the ersatz Alan Dershowitz in "Reversal of Fortune") or incompetent (the nameless defense lawyer in "Twelve Angry Men" whose sorry performance clears the way for Henry Fonda's heroics) or ineffectual (Smithers in "Desk Set").
Americans not only admire and loathe their lawyers, they also like laughing at them. Thus, we also find lawyers who are nitpicking or pompous, stuffy or nerdy. All types have been as liberally represented on the tube as on the screen, most particularly on "L.A. Law" but also on recent shows like "Matlock" "Law and Order" "Civil Wars" and "Reasonable Doubts." And, as television's lawyers have degenerated from Perry Mason to Arnie Becker, lawyers in movies have followed suit.
For a time, movie lawyers were largely indistinguishable ethnically, religiously and sexually. But, mirroring the changing demographics of the legal work force, they have gradually been differentiated as Irish (Paul Newman in "The Verdict"), Jewish (Kevin Pollack in "A Few Good Men") or women (Debra Winger in "Legal Eagles," Glenn Close in "Jagged Edge," Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio in "Class Action," Demi Moore in "A Few Good Men").
Black lawyers are less common, though in politically correct Hollywood these days, they seem disproportionately represented on the bench. The bar is not only more diverse but younger, with Tom Cruise (also in "A Few Good Men"), Michael Douglas ("War of the Roses," "Fatal Attraction") and Harrison Ford ("Regarding Harry," "Presumed Innocent") replacing Spencer Tracy ("Judgment at Nuremberg," "Inherit the Wind," "Adam's Rib") as the modern archetype.
Lawyer movies of all eras tend to follow certain conventions. For one thing, they focus on trial lawyers who, though only a small percentage of the bar, offer more vivid possibilities than antitrust lawyers or probate specialists. They include plenty of law books, gavels, ceiling fans, hopelessly truncated and oversimplified trials and surprise witnesses. Opposing counsel -- from George C. Scott in "Anatomy of a Murder" to Joe Mantegna in "Body of Evidence" -- is obnoxious, dishonest or incompetent.
Lawyers at large firms are caricatures from a New Yorker cartoon, smug and porcine or downright sinister. The partners at "The Firm," most notably Oliver Lambert (Hal Holbrook), are positively creepy to everyone but McDeere but no more odious than Ed Concannon (James Mason), the high-priced lawyer battling Frank Galvin (Paul Newman) in "The Verdict." Concannon was Hollywood's image of a fat-cat corporate lawyer: elegant (usually denoted by a bow tie), coldblooded, slightly British, assisted by droves of dronelike underlings who could have been McDeere's Harvard classmates.
True, the movies have always had their share of bad lawyers. When Jack Benny played a loutish lawyer in the otherwise forgettable 1943 film "The Meanest Man in the World," five Connecticut lawyers sued. "There's got to be a law, even for lawyers!" Lana Turner tells Hume Cronyn, who is playing her attorney in "The Postman Always Rings Twice." In "Adam's Rib," the man living across the hall from the husband-and-wife legal team of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn made the same point more amicably. "Lawyers should never marry other lawyers," he declares. "This is called inbreeding, from which comes idiot children and more lawyers." "You lawyers are all the same," one reluctant witness tells Mr. Newman in "The Verdict." "You don't care who you hurt as long as you make a buck. You're a bunch of whores."
But if America has always had a love-hate relationship with its lawyers, the focus, for a time, was on love. In "The Fortune Cookie," Walter Matthau may give short shrift to Lincoln as legal counsel -- "Great President, lousy lawyer," he huffs -- but in many of the finest lawyer movies, the heroes had a Lincolnesque cast: noble, earnest, handsome, plain-spoken, impeccably ethical. They are exemplified by Atticus Finch in "To Kill a Mockingbird" and Paul Biegler, played by James Stewart, in "Anatomy of a Murder." Both love the law so much they don't care if they're paid in collard greens or hickory nuts or not at all. Both represented the unpopular, and both were effective. Biegler got his client off, even though he was probably guilty; Finch lost, but only because he had to battle three centuries of Southern racism.
Both "To Kill a Mockingbird" and "Anatomy of a Murder" date from the late 1950's to the mid-1960's -- the golden age of the genre, as Thomas J. Harris notes in his book "Courtroom's Finest Hour in American Cinema." Such classics as "Witness for the Prosecution," "Compulsion," "Inherit the Wind," "Cape Fear" and "Judgment at Nuremberg" also appeared. Another film buff, Anthony Chase of the Nova Law Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., has explained this efflorescence: The crusading, idealistic lawyer, he contends, was a delayed reaction to the loss of civil liberties during McCarthyism.
Of course, the view of lawyers in these films was hopelessly naive. The lawyer-heroes of yore would no longer sell, and film makers stopped peddling them. Nothing better illustrates the change than the two versions of "Cape Fear," made 30 years apart. In the 1961 edition, Sam Bowden, the lawyer played by Mr. Peck, embodies all the usual virtues. He is Atticus Finch without Jem and Scout. But in Martin Scorsese's 1991 remake, Bowden, now played by Nick Nolte, is unfaithful, unethical and unsympathetic. As if to underline the point, the now-aged Peck once more portrays a lawyer -- this time, a slick, sanctimonious windbag.
Recent films have offered more subtle, complex figures like Mr. Newman's character in "The Verdict," perhaps the most convincing lawyer ever portrayed on film. Lesser examples include Glenn Close in "Jagged Edge" and Willem Dafoe in "Body of Evidence" -- dedicated defense lawyers with an unfortunate propensity to sleep with their sexy clients.
Ron Silver's Alan Dershowitz does not go to bed with Jeremy Iron's Claus von Bulow or commit any other ethical faux pas. "I gotta feel there's some moral or constitutional issue at stake," he says in "Reversal of Fortune." But in his film incarnation, Mr. Dershowitz comes across as arrogant, self-righteous, angry and perpetually overcaffeinated -- due, no doubt, to the coffee mug he nurses in almost every scene. He may be a great lawyer, but he is not a mensch.
Characters like McDeere represent a new wave of lawyer characters, children of the Reagan era, the first generation of young lawyers to be fought over by megafirms promising buckets of money. These lawyers are better educated than their predecessors; both McDeere and Michael Douglas's Oliver Rose in "War of the Roses" went to Harvard Law School. They have forsaken the country for the city, the perilous life of the single practitioner for large hierarchical enterprises, three-piece suits for suspenders and power collars, poor clients for wealthy ones, simple honest pleasures for amoral materialism.
For them, the law is less a calling than a fast track to affluence, and we don't see them practicing much of it. They spend less time in court than they do flattering senior partners or huddled over law books and yellow legal pads, working on matters of little interest to them and even less to moviegoers. Of much greater interest is the toll their work takes on them and their families.
Oliver Rose does not cheat on his wife in "War of the Roses," but given his workaholism, his obsequiousness to clients and superiors, his self-centeredness and soullessness, his marriage founders anyway. "My fee's going up!" he chortles to his long-suffering wife, played by Kathleen Turner, after landing a new client. "Better get me while you can afford me!" So repulsive does he become that when he is hospitalized with what he thinks is a heart attack -- in fact, it is a hernia, suffered while further flattering the coveted client -- she does not bother seeing him. "When I watch you eat, when I see you asleep, when I look at you recently, I just want to smash your face in," Ms. Turner later tells him. And things go downhill from there.
Mitch McDeere's wife, played by Jean Tripplehorn, has nearly as many grievances, and in much shorter a time. Though she is a mere schoolteacher rather than a cum laude graduate of Harvard Law School, she instantly senses that something is wrong with a law firm that monitors its lawyers' marriages and encourages them to procreate. "I don't mind square," she says. "Weird, I mind." But sucked in by the wages, McDeere pours himself into the firm, leaving his wife to cook meals for herself. The plot allows him to muster whatever courage and character he possesses simply to dig himself out of the hole his greed landed him in.
These are lawyer movies only because their characters happen to be lawyers. But as vehicles for demonstrating the hollowness of the 1980's, Mitch McDeere and Oliver Rose need not have been lawyers at all. Charlie Sheen's Bud Fox did it just as well in "Wall Street," and he, for one, didn't have a law degree.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. Parks Retrench After Budget Cuts

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.; JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
IT was one of the busiest days of the year at one of the busiest national parks in the country, but the sign at our planned campground declared: Closed. Because of budget cuts, rangers explained, the camp is not open this year.
We had hoped to establish a comfortable base at the Mathews Arm Campground in Shenandoah National Park, in the Blue Ridge Mountains of Virginia, for a Memorial Day weekend of hiking. Instead, with every open campground in the park full, we had to park at the edge of the park's spectacular Skyline Drive and haul our gear deeper than we had planned into the woods to strike a camp. 
 This was hardly a major inconvenience, but under park rules our back-country bivouac could have no campfire, and our distance from the car made it a bit harder to reach the trails we had picked for our daily excursions along the Appalachian Trail and its many tributaries.
On the trails, we encountered maintenance workers still clearing away trees that had fallen under the weight of ice that had long since melted, and at the Dickey Ridge Visitor Center at the park's northern end there were none of the usual offerings of ranger-led educational programs.
The campground closings, maintenance backlogs and cuts in the highly instructive interpretive programs that we found are symptomatic of a budget squeeze that is hitting the National Park Service hard from coast to coast this year.
The Wilderness Society, after conducting an extensive survey of conditions in many parks, issued a survey in May that reported: "A record number of people are expected to visit the national park system, and while they can look forward to rewarding experiences, they may come back home troubled by what they have seen."
The parks budget was tight to begin with, and has recently become even tighter, say officials of the National Park Service. The defeat in Congress of President Clinton's economic stimulus program cut off an anticipated increase in financing -- and cost many seasonal employees their summer jobs. Bad weather this spring reduced the park coffers further, as did a few unusually expensive rescue efforts.
The net effect is that parks around the country are cutting back on their offerings, and visitors -- whose numbers grew to 273 million in 1992, an increase of 6 million over 1991 -- must pay special attention to planning throughout the summer. That will become even more important in the autumn, because after Labor Day there will be further cutbacks at many parks.
"We ain't getting better," said Duncan Morrow, a spokesman in Washington for the park service.
The Wilderness Society, in its survey of major parks, found dozens of campgrounds closed all summer, visitor center hours cut back, fewer rangers on patrol to protect and assist visitors, fewer lifeguards, fewer guided nature walks, less maintenance of trails, buildings and vehicles, and, in many parks, cuts in scientific research.
At the Cape Hatteras National Seashore, for example, there will be only 150 guided programs a week instead of the usual 250, the Wilderness Society found. At the Canadian border of Glacier National Park in Montana, tours have been eliminated and racks of brochures are offered instead. At Olympic National Park in Washington, where 7 percent of the budget goes to interpretive programs, an amphitheater program that used to draw 120 people nightly will be offered only on weekends.
The National Park Service said at the start of the year that its budget was $34 million short of the $986 million needed to maintain last year's level of service. President Clinton's economic stimulus program would have added $253 million to the budget this year, but it was defeated. Many parks raised their entry and camping fees early this year, usually by a dollar or two, but steeper increases that were sought by the parks have not been approved by Congress.
And at about 50 parks, shortages of rangers have resulted in entrance stations' being unstaffed for part of the day, meaning that many visitors enter without paying, further decreasing park income. Park managers say that can't be helped, since rangers cannot be diverted from safety duties.
On top of the budget woes came bad weather. Spring storms cost the park system $6 million; at Shenandoah, it cost $250,000 just to clear the downed trees from Skyline Drive, the winding road that runs along the ridge line, its views of the famous Shenandoah Valley drawing millions to the park.
Search and rescue costs soared, as well. Several dozen students from a boarding school near Detroit were stranded in Great Smoky Mountains National Park during a March blizzard, and the air and ground search cost $100,000. Other incidents cost hundreds of thousands more, and rescue operations this year are already more than 10 times as high as last year's total.
Yosemite National Park in California, with its four million visitors a year, is a good example of a park that is not able to keep up with demand.
Two campgrounds at the park, at Bridalveil Creek and Yosemite Creek, are closed this summer. They contain nearly 10 percent of the 1,900 family campsites in the park. Another campground, at Hodgdon Meadow, which usually operates all year, did not open until this month.
Heavy snow and budget cuts delayed the clearing of Tioga Road in the park, forcing more visitors into the overburdened Yosemite Valley. As a result, for the first time ever, the park had to shut its gates to traffic for hours at a time on May 22 and 23 and again on Memorial Day, said Bob Clopine, a park spokesman at Yosemite.
While events like these stand out, it is the day-to-day decline in services that is affecting more people.
Across the park system, there have been reductions in the hiring of seasonal employees, including rangers, and that has meant cuts in the interpretive programs that educate visitors to the parks about the natural resources they are seeing.
Law enforcement has also suffered. At Big Bend, a park the size of Rhode Island along the Rio Grande in Texas, there are only eight law-enforcement rangers, and there have been incidents of sniping along the river, perhaps related to drug traffic, the Wilderness Society said. Cuyahoga Valley National Recreation Area, linking Cleveland and Akron, Ohio, has no overnight patrols, and arson has been reported during those hours, the society said.
Although visitors' safety is among the highest priorities, park service officials said some safety measures have been sacrificed. At many locations, like Cape Hatteras National Seashore, lifeguards cannot be provided at all of the beaches. Park visitors are not always well informed about potential dangers; if a ranger doesn't tell you that a black-tailed deer, even one used to humans on its territory, may lash out with its deadly hooves, you might approach too close.
At Glacier National Park, with its considerable population of grizzly bears, some trails have had to be closed because inadequate maintenance poses a danger. "Bears are most likely to take on humans when they are surprised," the Wilderness Society explained in its May report, "and poorly maintained trails generally limit visibility and thus increase the likelihood that a hiker will suddenly encounter a grizzly."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1310 words

HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
Jean Dubuffet, Giving Pleasure Despite Himself

BYLINE: By Michael Kimmelman

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
From beginning to end, the Jean Dubuffet exhibition here at the Hirshhorn Museum is a pleasure to see. Has any other artist strived so hard to seem rude and irascible and yet spread so much pleasure?
It was the central paradox of Dubuffet's career that he both debunked the art establishment more vigorously and received more encomiums from it than probably any European artist of his generation. He made his debut in Paris to fanfare in 1944, his wit and mischievousness apparently proving to be just what that enervated city needed after years of deprivation and humiliation. From then until his death in 1985, at the age of 83, Dubuffet enjoyed the kind of recognition artists mostly dream of. 
 With clocklike regularity, major museums presented exhibitions of his work, beginning in 1960 in Paris and thereafter in New York (1962), Venice (1964), London (1966), Montreal (1969), Chicago (1970), Paris and New York (1973), Berlin (1980), Paris and New York once more (1981). The man whose paintings were often said to represent the very antithesis of the School of Paris became that city's most esteemed artist. When a renovated Jeu de Paume opened there two years ago as a center for contemporary art, it sought to establish its own stature by basking in Dubuffet's, dedicating its inaugural exhibition to his late work.
And now there is this show at the Hirshhorn, through Sept. 12 (it does not travel). With nearly 100 works, it is the most extensive Dubuffet exhibition in the United States in 20 years. Organized by the museum's director, James T. Demetrion, it concentrates on the period from 1943 to 1963, the most fruitful of Dubuffet's artistic life, just before he settled into "L'Hourloupe," the series of paintings and sculptures that was his attempt at a universal kind of public art. He succeeded almost too well. For years, Dubuffet produced the mostly cheerful jigsaw compositions that defined the series, until his art came to seem almost as ubiquitous and predictable as McDonald's. The self-declared anti-establishment man became something of a big business.
But before then, during the years on which this exhibition concentrates, he applied his contentious energy to the creation of one series after another of still surprising audacity.
He was born in 1901 in Le Havre, a port city that had nourished many artists, including Boudin and Braque, but Dubuffet always claimed that the tradition of high art they upheld meant nothing to him. His dream, he once announced with characteristic provocation, was to eliminate all the libraries and museums and erect in the center of every town a statue commemorating Oblivion. "Let us abolish the past and all that comes with it!" he declared.
Dubuffet was hardly the first to say so. But when he said it, he had the momentum of history behind him. It was not coincidental that his career took off at the same time that the writings of Sartre, Camus and Orwell gained widespread attention and that Francis Bacon, Alberto Burri and Lucio Fontana began to make their own marks on the European artistic scene.
Twice Dubuffet made aborted stabs at art; the third try stuck. In 1942 he abandoned his career as a wine merchant to take up painting. Ever the dutiful businessman, and ironist, he sent notes to clients informing them of his "new line of business, pictures." Within months he had completed the first works in this exhibition.
Little wonder they astonished the critics when they were publicly exhibited shortly thereafter. For one thing, Dubuffet's sources, he insisted, were not the reigning masters, like Picasso, but the madmen, derelicts, prisoners, children and marginal figures whose art he had come to admire and began to collect. He called their work Art Brut. For another, his images -- brightly colored and scrawled in an artfully uncouth hand -- were peopled by characters who seemed possessed of a goofy delirium perversely out of place in wartime Paris.
They were gangly pink cows with a caught-in-the-headlights expression, effervescent subway passengers, mustachioed bicyclists and sticklike flaneurs, all with arms akimbo as if dancing some collective jig. They were also smug politicians, like "Le President," and jazz musicians of a magnificent and very endearing silliness.
And they were businessmen at lunch, each in bow tie, each with thick mustache and eyebrows, lined up like understudies for the Last Supper. Dubuffet's gift was to capture the essence of these types, their mores and peccadilloes, with a shrewdness disconcertingly at odds with his deadpan, pseudo-folkish style.
HE WAS CERTAINLY NO genuine naif. A peripatetic intellect,
he numbered among his friends some of the most gifted writers of the day -- Georges Limbour, the poet and critic; Raymond Queneau, the novelist; Armand Salacrou, the playwright -- who often became subjects of his portraits. He undertook a series of such portraits in 1946, fittingly titled "Plus beaux qu'ils croient" ("Handsomer Than They Think").
The paintings, hysterical and amusing and at the same time sharply observed, made use of the sort of materials that soon became a hallmark of Dubuffet's iconoclastic art: pebbles and sand defining eyes, teeth and hair, embedded in gelatinous globs of paint that had the look and consistency of wet concrete. Eventually he came to use concrete itself -- and slag and string and sponges and silver foil and driftwood and, most remarkably, butterfly wings. No artist of the time had a more venturesome and sophisticated approach to materials.
His portraits, and his subsequent series of paintings of female nudes, the "Corps de Dame," were meant to be shocking in their disdain for Western ideals of verisimilitude and beauty. The corpulent and lethargic nudes especially looked as if they had been squashed by steamrollers; they suggest a degree of violence and anger on the part of Dubuffet that is ideal grist for feminist analysis.
But Dubuffet was never as shocking or as radical as he pretended -- and was at first said -- to be. Not only did his art, in fact, build on the achievements of Klee and Miro and other enrollees in the pantheon of high art. It also betrayed a degree of refinement that, particularly with the hindsight of several decades, links it inextricably with those School of Paris artists he professed to abhor.
You can see this in his use of color -- at the time derided as crude and now so clearly the reverse, as in the sparkling hues that seem to bubble up from beneath the muddy surface of "Jazz Band," in the subtly pinkish flesh of "Beautiful Woman With Heavy Breasts" and in the bleeding colors of "The Extravagant Lady." It's also clear in the effulgent color of the "Paris Circus" paintings, which laid the groundwork for "L'Hourloupe" in their dense, compartmentalized compositions and seem suffused with the French capital's exuberance in the economic boom years of the early 1960's.
Dubuffet's refinement can also be sensed in the elegant spareness of the so-called Texturology paintings of 1958, total abstractions that surely owed a debt to the New York School (in 1951, he came to the United States, where his work was immediately embraced). And what could be more fastidious and delicate than his images of figures made out of those butterfly wings?
It takes nothing away from the authenticity of Dubuffet's art to point out that his incendiary rhetoric was one thing and his work another. He may have aspired to the condition of Art Brut, but he remained a Parisian intellectual. This is especially clear when one compares Dubuffet's work with actual Art Brut, or "outsider" art, as it now is called, which has once again become fashionable in this politicized climate of insiders and outsiders. Interest in the work of outsiders lends to this fine Dubuffet show a timeliness. But it needs no such excuse.

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Federal Subsidies;
Fresh Money Cranks Up an Aid Program

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A COUPLE named Vivian and Louis Hunter bought a vacant four-family house on Crotona Avenue in the South Bronx at a city auction in 1988. They planned to renovate it, live in it with their daughter and her children, and rent out what they didn't use themselves. But they could never get the project financed.
They have held it ever since, regularly making payments of $634 a month on the $78,750 purchase price, hoping the situation would change. This year it has. 
 The Hunters are among those who will benefit from a new flow of Federal subsidies known by yet another housing catchword, and an odd misnomer, HOME. It was coined from the term Home Investment Partnerships Program, which suggests that it has something to do with home-ownership assistance.
But in fact it is merely a pot of money usable under the National Affordable Housing Act of 1990 to provide housing aid for low-income people. Subject to certain restrictions, the money can be applied to construction or reconstruction of houses or rentals.
In New York City, it has supplemented the city's own assistance to a variety of programs. In at least one case it has revived a program that was stalled for lack of adequate subsidy assistance.
This is the housing agency's Small Homes Program, intended to help people renovate small privately owned buildings, sometimes bought at city auctions, in low-income neighborhoods. These projects were once financed by the Federal Section 312 program, a victim of 80's budget cuts. Of $75 million in HOME funds committed so far in New York, $2.9 million has gone to the Small Homes Program.
In Brooklyn, Leonard and Frank Baratta will be able to renovate a five-unit building as low-income rentals at 112 Baltic Street, at Hicks Street, in Cobble Hill. And in Crown Heights, Peter J. M. Moore, a Manhattan architect, and his partner Ralph Lewis, a Brooklyn contractor, will be able to start their long-delayed renovation of 255 Albany Avenue, at Sterling Place. They are planning 12 apartments with a ground-floor store.
The Small Homes Program is only a modest user of HOME funds in the many-faceted activities of the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. But all of the benefiting programs have in common a direction toward low- or very-low income people. At least 90 percent of the HOME money used for rentals must assist families with incomes under 60 percent of the areawide median. The median income for a family of four is now $41,700 a year.
This restriction deprives the city of the flexibility it would prefer in using Federal funds to supplement housing efforts. The income limits make it difficult to use the subsidy for mixed-income housing -- the preference in new construction and rehabilitation as well where market conditions would support somewhat higher rents.
IN New York City the preferred income mix in new construction of larger buildings is two-thirds moderate or middle income and one-third low income.
Another shortcoming for New York is that the Federal money cannot be used to finance the social services that are necessary in certain construction projects for residents with special needs. Nor can the money be used to set up a fund for operating assistance to guarantee sufficient income over time if costs rise faster than rent levels. These are perennial problems in high-cost areas with Federal housing programs that are directed to very-low-income people only.
In any event, the HOME money, after a drought in Federal housing funds through most of the 80's, has brought chunks of money to various activities: $19.3 million for building improvements in city-managed tax-foreclosed buildings; $24.4 million for the same in tax-foreclosed buildings under alternate, or noncity, management; $19.4 million to tax-credit low-income housing produced by the Enterprise Foundation and the Local Initiatives Support Corporation; $5.3 million to the small-home rehabilitation projects of the Mutual Housing Association of New York and $3.8 million to the single-room-occupancy loan program.
With more Federal money having been awarded last spring, the city expects to have committed a total of $213 million in HOME funds by the end of fiscal 1994. These funds supplement other Federal housing aid, which is running at about a third the pace of the late 70's and early 80's, when annual budget authorizations were running at $1.5 billion to $2 billion a year. Most of this money is tied to long-term Section 8 or public housing contracts.
THE effects of the Small Home Program are vivid because it brings back to useful life buildings that have been local eyesores, sometimes for 10 to 20 years. And it brings them back at a low enough rent level to provide greater confidence of survival through an economic downturn.
"With H.P.D. financing we can set rents a few dollars lower than if we were calling the shots ourselves," said Mr. Lewis, the East Flatbush contractor who will do the recontruction of 255 Albany Avenue.
With Mr. Moore, the Manhattan architect, he bought five vacant buildings in the 80's and renovated three of them. Mr. Moore said that debt service costs in one eight-family building came to about $25,000 a year. Rents had to average about $600 a month. Although the building's nominal income was $60,000 a year, only 70 percent of rent collections could be depended upon.
"LEGAL expenses were way out of proportion," Mr. Moore said, as efforts were made to evict nonpaying tenants. This is usually a lengthy litigious task in a housing court less sympathetic with an owner's plight than a tenant's.
Under the Small Homes Program, with 1 percent mortgage money from the city, rents will average about $400 a month for a one-bedroom, $500 for a two-bedroom and $600 for a three-bedroom. The builder will try to hold construction costs down to a level that will leave money for a reserve fund after construction. "It should be a $50,000 reserve but it will probably be $25,000," Mr. Moore said.
In fiscal 1993, which ended last Wednesday , 22 loans were committed under the Small Homes Program, to produce 138 housing units at a cost of $7.4 million. About half the properties had been purchased at city auctions, said Carol Corden, the program director, and the rest had been privately held.
In the latter category is the Baratta family's vacant building in Cobble Hill. Anthony Baratta, a lawyer, said his father, Leonard, an accountant, and his brother, Frank, an electrician, bought the building from an owner who had inherited it from an aunt who had lived in it as a one-family house. Bank financing for rehabilitation was unavailable.
UNDER the Small Homes Program the building has obtained $150,000 from the city in a 1 percent loan and a $200,000 Federal grant, repayable after 15 years. City inspectors and engineers decided on the level of reconstruction needed.
And in the Bronx Mrs. Hunter, a home-care attendant, is looking forward to being able to rehabilitate the four-family house at 2026 Crotona Avenue that she has been holding since her 1988 auction purchase. Two daughters and the two young children of one of them live with her and her husband, who works for Coca-Cola Bottling, in a rental on Decatur Avenue.
"We're not rich people," she said. "All these years we've been paying the bills on that house. I'm hoping the city will give us the money to fix it up. But we haven't got a closing date on the loan yet." The housing agency says the closing will come this summer.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Partners in a Crown Heights renovation are (from left) Darnell Coy, Ralph Lewis and Peter J.M. Moore. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)
