HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Rowayton

BYLINE: By ROSALIE R. RADOMSKY

 BODY:
ROWAYTON residents liken their neighborhood to a Norman Rockwell painting and to towns along the Maine coast. Everyone in the community, which has 500 boat slips, 200 moorings and 4 marinas, seems to know everyone else.
"In Rowayton no one minds if you're fancy or if you're not fancy," said Grace W. Lichtenstein, chairman of the three-member elected commission of Norwalk's Sixth Taxing District, which was set up in 1921 by the Connecticut Legislature to allow Rowayton residents to tax themselves to supply services not provided by Norwalk. Those taxes -- the figure was $555,000 last year -- are applied to the parks, beach and library that help give the community a sense of its own identity, as well as to garbage collection and other services. 
 Wendell Livingston considered it a compromise between Maine and New York when she and her husband, Tom, moved into a 1930's Cape Cod six years ago. "There are small yards, but there's so much going on," said Ms. Livingston, who now has a five-year-old son and two-year-old daughter. "It's a wonderful place to raise children."
"A typical lot is 0.3 acres and a half-acre is considered large," said Gail Van Slyck of Van Slyck & LeMoult Realtors.
Its 1,515 houses are a jumble of cottages, Victorians, colonials and Capes. Members of its three housing associations -- Bell Island, Pine Point and Rowayton Beach -- pay dues for extras such as private beaches and roads.
But no house is more than five minutes from Bayley Beach, which all residents can use, free.
Frank E. Raymond's ancestors moved in 10 generations ago. Mr. Raymond, who remembers skating out of Five Mile River onto Long Island Sound during the freeze of 1934, wrote a history, "Rowayton on the Half Shell," published in 1990 for the Historical Society of Rowayton.
A variant of its name -- Rooaton -- appeared in the deed between Chief Runckinheague of the Siwanoy Indians and settlers in 1651, when only a few sustenance farmers and fishermen lived in the area.
Within 20 years Rowayton became part of Middlesex Parish (Darien) and by the start of the 18th century blacksmiths, shoemakers, carpenters and weavers were contributing to its economy. Oystering was important by the 1860's but oysters succumbed early in this century to overharvesting and pollution.
By then, though, Rowayton had become a summer resort. Its drawing card, Roton Point Park, attracted thousands of daytrippers from New York. Over the years they came to hear and see Rudy Vallee, Alice Faye, Glenn Miller and others and to ride the airplane swing and Big Dipper roller coaster. The park closed in 1942.
In 1910, James A. Farrell, who became president of United States Steel Corporation, built an Elizabethan-style mansion, which burned down three years later and was rebuilt in granite. The building now houses Hewitt Associates, actuaries. Since 1966 the Farrell family stables have been the community center and the library, which has 29,261 books, including 500 on boating.
Though waterfront houses go for over a million dollars and flood insurance is expensive, the waterfront is coveted.
"You can sell land along the water by the square inch," said Douglas A. Bora Sr., a retired local realtor, whose backyard is the river facing Darien.
A renovated four-bedroom 1887 Victorian on 0.11 acre on Rocky Point Road has an octagonal tower overlooking the Sound; it is priced at $1.175 million. Inland, a marble-floored three-bedroom 1890 farmhouse on .32 acres along Oakleigh Court is selling for $409,000. A binder was recently put on a 17-year-old three-bedroom raised-ranch on 0.2 acre along Dean Court, near the railway station, which listed for $179,900.
Rowayton's only condominium is a four-unit converted schoolhouse on Thomas Place, a development that also has detached colonial one-families. Except for Hilltop Homes, which has 24 one- and two-bedroom units for the elderly and disabled, there are few rentals.
"Rowayton has the the best of both worlds," said Ralph Sloan, superintendent of Norwalk Public Schools. "It's a charming village and has the diversity of the Norwalk school system with 40 percent minority enrollment."
BRIEN McMAHON HIGH SCHOOL, with an enrollment of 1,042, attracts students from 10 other towns to its Center for Japanese Study Abroad, which sent 51 of its 53 students to Tokyo in May.
The school also offers nine advanced-placement classes for college credit and at least 80 percent of its graduates go on to higher education.
Roton Middle School, with 370 students, focuses on team teaching, and eight eighth-graders from its new Japanese class joined the high school trip to Japan. Its Robert Oliver Planetarium is being renovated. The k-5 Rowayton Elementary School is undergoing a nearly $3 million upgrading and expansion.
"It's a caring, extended family," said Leslie Pattengill, its principal, alluding to parent participation. The school has a fine-arts and performing-arts core curriculum for its 330 pupils and about 200 to 300 parents come in regularly to help out. They also run the annual Rowayton School Carnival to raise funds.
Children also go to private schools in nearby towns. Preschoolers can take advantage of the local Community Cooperative, Five Mile River and United Church Nursery Schools, as well as the Parents Exchange, in which parents take turns watching one another's children. There is also youth soccer and Little League.
Along with having story hours for children 3 and up and lectures for adults, the library doubles as a mini-town hall. Residents buy permits there for the local tennis and paddle tennis associations, apply for Bayley Beach stickers and buy commuter parking lot permits.
During the annual one-day Trash Bash, a rigorous rite of spring, residents clean up the village. The Memorial Day Parade ended this year with a speech by Mr. Bora urging residents to do something about an eyesore -- Winthrop House, a dilapidated single-room-occupany house on Rowayton Avenue. As usual, hot dogs and soda were given away afterward behind the fire station, which houses the 50-member volunteer Rowayton Hose Co. No. 1, and homemade strawberry shortcake was sold in Pinkney Park, where the annual art show was being held.
Pinkney Park, 2.3 acres along the river, is also the site of the Historical Society in Seeley-Dibble-Pinkney House, and other events such as the River Ramble, featuring canoe races, auctions and 25 pairs of lobsters to be raffled-off on July 17. Laid-back summer evenings can be spent on the lawn there, where 10 Sunday concerts are held during the Summer Arts Festivalthrough Labor Day Weekend.
Bayley Beach bustles with summer activity -- basketball and volleyball games, as well as events like tonight's July Fourth bash with a rock band. In August there will be a lobster bake.
There are also three private clubs: Roton Point, Wee Burn (a beach and tennis annex of the Darien country club) and the Rowayton Yacht Club at Hickory Bluff.
The block-long commercial strip along Rowayton Avenue has such conveniences as a barber shop, a hardware store, a grocery, a drugstore and the post office.
ALTHOUGH there are no local movie theaters, residents can choose from many within a 10-minute drive in Norwalk or a 15-minute drive in Westport or New Canaan. Major shopping is done at a Grand Union in Darien and supermarkets along the Post Road in Norwalk.
Fresh fish is available at Rowayton Seafood, which has four tanks holding up to 5,000 pounds of lobster. Its owners want to open a seafood restaurant in an adjacent building, but have met with some opposition over a lack of parking.
Upper Crust Deli, which has homemade specialties, is a popular meeting place for young mothers. Singles tend to hang out at the bar of the 5 Mile River Grille, known for its new American cuisine. And the Rowayton Arts Center is getting ready to open The Back Porch, where free iced tea and cookies will be served two afternoons a week overlooking the Five Mile River.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Five Mile River flows by Roton Point Park. An 1887 Victorian mansion on Rocky Point Road overlooks Long Island Sound. (Photographs by Eddie Hausner for The New York Times)

Government: Norwalk Mayor (Frank Esposito, Republican) and 15-member City Council elected to 2-year terms.
 
On the Fence: Goings-on, from the annual River Ramble to Lobster Bake as well as other events by civic groups and personal greetings are usually posted on a chain-link fence around the old schoolyard on Rowayton Avenue at Witch Lane. Although tag sale notices are taken down, an affair of the heart got by. "Susan will you marry me?" asked an unnamed suitor on a sheet tied to the fence last fall. "Meet me at Pinkney Park at 2 o'clock." A couple of days later a note read: "She's accepted!"

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
Disclosure Now a Key Home-Sales Issue

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
DISCLOSURE is becoming the home-sales issue to reckon with in the 90's. For verification of a property's condition and of the fealty of the broker are increasingly considered vital safeguards against unpleasant surprises following the most important purchase of a lifetime.
Not only buyers and sellers, but a decimated real estate industry find such safeguards desirable. "Competition and litigation are rising while the number of licensed agents has dropped from 36,000 in 1988 to 19,800 today, and inventories are humongous," said Kenneth Smith, coordinator of the University of Connecticut's real estate licensing courses. 
 Unrevealed defects in a house can be dealt with in court, or by local real estate boards, where buyers can file complaints. If after a hearing an agent is found to have violated the National Association of Realtors' code of ethics he can be expelled, losing access to the multiple listings.
"Should the case be forwarded to the state Real Estate Commission he may lose his license," said Chip Kunde, executive director of the Connecticut Association of Realtors in Hartford.
In the absence of state regulations, real estate firms and boards are creating a plethora of individual disclosure forms to deal with today's buyers, who are very different from their free-spending 80's counterparts.
"People are asking more questions," said Adorna Carroll, a New Britain realtor who feels penalties should be imposed for failure to disclose known defects.
"Connecticut has been laissez-faire about disclosure legislation compared with other states," said Dorothy Nowell, director of human resources for William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford. She is organizing a task force of Pitt agents to draw up disclosure policy for the company.
In the legislative session that ended in June a bill to create a standard disclosure form listing all known defects was defeated. It required that sellers and buyers, but not agents, check off the list and sign it. "It's pretty meaningless for a seller to pay an agent a considerable sum and not require him to share some of the responsibility," said Trudy Bird, deputy commissioner of the state's Department of Consumer Protection.
Buyers should be entitled to know everything that the seller and broker know about the condition of a house for sale, including when problems appeared, what repairs were made, what repairs are still necessary, and who is to be held accountable if the furnace blows, the water heater expires, the second-story insulation is missing, or the roof leaks shortly after they move in.
Disclosure, according to Ms. Bird, should also include fee disbursements. "Checks are passed across the table at closings face down to hide how commissions are allocated," she said. "The buyer and seller have the right to see that the commissions they agreed to pay are indeed the commissions paid at the closing."
Laurence Hannafin, director of the consumer agency's real estate division, described how the recession has turned up some misuses of client's funds. For example, a buyer placed a deposit on a house. The agent removed the deposit from an account he kept to pay overdue bills. But the deal fell through and rather than face the consequences of the shortage, the agent disappeared.
Many professionals think that a 1991 regulation requiring that brokers disclose in writing whether they are working for the buyer, seller, or both, should be strengthened by executing the document at the first substantive meeting between broker and buyer, rather than any time before a contract is signed.
Dual agents working for both buyer and seller are controversial but legal, as long as they disclose their position. "When representing both," said Marie Bacoli, a lawyer with the Hartford firm of Robinson & Cole, "you have fiduciary duties to each and you immediately see the conflict when you negotiate price."
INDEPENDENT buyer brokers as opposed to those working within traditional companies are few in numbers. "We are forming a Connecticut Association of Buyer Agents with about 20 members," said Rick Dressler, an education specialist with Westledge Real Estate in Avon. Buyer brokers handle fully 25 percent of the agency's transactions.
Diane Nash, head of the firm, believes that "they are in a better position to advise clients how to structure an offer and negotiate terms that meet his needs -- advice that a seller's broker cannot give, nor can he reveal that the seller would accept a lower price."
Buyer brokers customarily get a retainer of a few hundred dollars that becomes part of the purchase price, and they prefer purchasers who are pre-approved by a lender.
Home inspections are the only tool for unearthing a property's problems, and they are usually paid for by the buyer. But William Raveis, president of the real estate company that bears his name, encourages sellers to pay about $225 for a basic pre-inspection, leaving the report at the house for buyers to see.
"We insist on professional inspection," said Mr. Raveis, "even though the results may be serious enough for the deal to fall through. Buyers can't rely on agents as experts. Most agents don't know copper wire from bx cable." He said he felt that legislated disclosure forms would be helpful in creating a standard for the state's realtors.
"Basic inspections," said Ron Passaro, head of Res-i-tec, a 20- year-old national inspection company in Bethel, "cover interior and exterior construction, utilities and appliances, but not testing of septics and wells, termites, radon and lead testing, buried oil tanks and other specifics."
Hiring one of the 165 home inspection companies in Connecticut can cost from $200 to $1,000, depending on the house and the menu. "The worst kind is the brand new house," said Mr. Passaro. "Older homes show their faults, but you have to look carefully in a new house. There was a lot of shoddy construction in the 80's."
Most reliable companies exceed the minimal standards set by the American Society of Home Inspectors, the industry's professional organization in Washington. "We encourage buyers to walk the house with us," said John Ghent, president of Goldring Home Inspections in Trumbull, "and it's best if the seller is not at home."

HEADLINE: Another Opinion On School Budgets

 BODY:
Regarding the Q. & A. column of June 6, which quoted from an interview with Janet S. Walker, executive director of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association, I am deeply disappointed that you gave so much space to a paid lobbyist with vested interests in maintaining the stutus quo in terms of school budgets. I formed a group in White Plains working to get the vote on the school budget here and in the other 56 small cities in New York State.
In White Plains, we face a 13 percent increase in school taxes after a 10 percent increase last year and a 13 percent increase the year before. Our school taxes are consistently higher than our city taxes. We average a $15,500 per student yearly expenditure when the state average is $7,500 and the national average is $4,000. We have an overpaid, underworked group of teachers who instead of giving extra time for tutoring or counseling negotiate these functions as well as hall duty out of their contracts, and then blame the poor performance of their students in terms of standardized tests and ranking with their peer groups on the diversity of the student population. 
 We have dozens of administrators in the high school who see their main function as disciplinarians instead of mentors or role models. Since I have a thorough knowledge of statistics and possess some plain common sense, I know the state study was not flawed. I applaud the state and Governor Cuomo in their efforts to monitor the excesses in the bureaucracy that Ms. Katz is paid to defend.
I suggest that all people in Westchester concerned with the high cost of educating our youngsters read the report "Nation at Risk" and the Merritt Lindsey Report. The need to defend raising taxes by such school teacher verbiage as micro, macro, mini-macro is nonsense.
The bottom line is that the product you are turning out is not competitive in the real world because the school establishment doesn't live in the real world. Get real -- this is no longer a farm economy -- children need more than 185 days of school and who says throwing good money after bad will provide "quality" education?
 
ROSELYN KATZ
White Plains

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Two Scripts for Talking in Tokyo

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE Japanese love meetings. Just ask anyone who has worked in a Japanese-run office. And they are particularly fond of precisely managed meetings designed to come to a preordained result, which is why they usually thrive at summits.
So months ago they roughed out a script for the Tokyo summit meeting that opens here Tuesday: President Clinton would be welcomed by the unshakable leaders of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, which came to power four decades ago as the symbol of the American alliance. After some tough talk with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa about the trade surplus (some things cannot be avoided), the two would emerge with a "framework" for the next several years of trade talks. There would be talk of progress on the Uruguay Round of global trade talks, and of more aid to Russia. They would agree to call each other Bill and Kiichi. And Japan would go on to serve as host to the rest of the Group of Seven, using the moment (discreetly, of course) to make its case for a permanent seat on the Security Council. 
 But even the Japanese, it turns out, can muck up a good business plan.
Just days before the meeting, the framework had yet to come together, efforts to jump-start the global trade talks had largely failed, and Washington's plan to create a $4 billion fund to privatize Russian business had been shrinking ever since Japan's Foreign Minister called the amount preposterous.
But most important, Bill's new friend Kiichi seemed bound to be out of power in two weeks -- along with the party that always knew better than to jeopardize America's relationship with Japan.
Indeed, because endemic corruption is finally an issue that may unseat Japan's power brokers, Mr. Clinton will be landing in the midst of the wildest election here since Gen. Douglas MacArthur left town at the end of the postwar occupation. Sound trucks will be cruising the streets below his hotel room, candidates blaring their names and waving to a wary electorate -- hardly a dignified backdrop for a summit. "It is a little like the Japanese showing up in Washington to rebuild the relationship a week before a Presidential election," one frustrated summit aide said the other day. "No one would know they were there."
But it will be hard to miss Mr. Clinton -- partly because he is, in a very real way, an undeclared candidate in the July 18 elections here. For years now a key element of American trade strategy toward Japan has been to push the country toward consumers instead of manufacturers, toward imports instead of home-grown goods, toward better housing and shorter working hours. And while no one said it publicly, the same ruling party that America once hailed, and covertly financed, as the party of anti-Communism also became the party of economic protectionism.
Over time the Liberal Democrats represented so many interest groups that the political scene here seemed frozen in the 1950's. Policy was designed to keep prices in Japan high so that companies had the money to attack foreign markets; farmers still wield great clout, even though most are weekend rice-growers whose big harvests are Corollas and computers.
Mr. Clinton's advisers clearly see the elections as a chance to break out of that trap. "I think that the changes now going on in Japan, over the long run, they're going to be good for the Japanese people and good for the American people," Mr. Clinton said Friday. And while professing neutrality in the election, his advisers are making sure he is seen spending some time with men like Ichiro Ozawa, a one-time political fixer for some of Japan's most corrupt politicians who led the defections from the ruling party.
 
A Familiar Platform
 In a new book he conveniently published this week, Mr. Ozawa sometimes sounds like his platform was written on Pennsylvania Avenue. " 'Japanese-style democracy' is no longer able to respond adequately to the changes taking place at home and abroad," he complains. "We can no longer enjoy the luxury of devoting ourselves exclusively to our own economic development as we did during the cold war era." He even speaks of new freedoms for the Japanese, including "freedom from the company," "freedom from overwork" and "freedom from regulation."
Sounds great, but there are reasons to wonder how sincere it all is. Mr. Ozawa and his friends spent decades in the L.D.P. vineyards; he only bolted the party and talked openly about remaking the lives of ordinary Japanese after his mentor was caught with $50 million in political payoffs.
Even if such reform leaders can be taken at face value, in the short run America's troubles with Japan seem bound to worsen. The weakness of politicians here is an invitation for bureaucrats to dig in, protecting big-business constituents. Some think that is why the pre-summit trade talks failed. "In the absence of a strong political vision for the country, each of the bureaucracies will just strengthen its domain," said Minoru Makihara, president of Mitsubishi Corporation.
Japan, of course, has had a vision-thing problem for a long time. The political culture has never encouraged the expression of a national mission or broad ideals; instead, officials here talk about building "relationships" with their most vital allies.
One reason that the Clinton White House and the Japanese have done so much talking past each other is that they have such widely differing agendas. Beneath the argument over how to come up with ways to measure the success of trade agreements, for example, is a Japanese fear that Washington ultimately sees relations only as figures on a balance sheet.
So for Mr. Clinton this week, the object will be how to speed the forces of reform without appearing to take sides in the election. For the Liberal Democrats, the object will be to speed through the summit and bundle Mr. Clinton out of town before he turns their nightmare into something worse.
In fact, the meeting itself seem far from the minds of men like Yoshiro Hayashi, the Japanese Finance Minister. Rather than focus on the summit, he admitted Friday, he spent most of last week twisting the arms of banks and insurance companies, which his ministry regulates, for campaign donations. He seemed a bit shocked when people suggested this was just the kind of ethical lapse that got the Liberal Democrats into such trouble. "Is their any problem in my making such requests to those people?" he asked Japanese reporters. "I am a politician before I am a finance minister."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The leaders of Japan's opposition parties are seeking to form a coalition for the July 18 elections. From left: Keigo Ouchi, Sadao Yamahana, Tsutomu Hata and Koshiro Ishida. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why Uncle Sam Isn't A Better Landlord

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR anyone trying to get a grip on the dimensions of the Federal Government's property-management problems, two related and disturbing events of last month are especially instructive.
In the first, the Department of Housing and Urban Development proved to be to urban development roughly what Dutch elm disease is to elms. Trying, shotgun-style, to boost housing construction, the agency guaranteed private loans for apartment complexes nationwide, then forgot to monitor its investment. The economy soured, the complexes went bust, drug addicts moved in and buildings started to fall apart. Last month HUD said it may hold the bag on $11.9 billion in bad loans. Taxpayers, of course, will foot the bill. 
 That is the first disturbing development. The second is that hardly anyone noticed.
People are used to this sort of thing. Granted, the trackless Federal bureaucracy does some things well, even heroically, with little notice. But on many basic management issues, from offices to parks to military bases to forests, it often seems to have entrusted trillions of dollars in land and assets to civil servants named Moe, Larry and Shemp.
As the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission completed its recommendations last week on closing 31 military posts, Defense Secretary Les Aspin noted that the Pentagon has been under orders for years to shut down 42 other bases, but so far has gotten around to 13. "There are literally thousands of separate actions" required to close a base, he said, "and all too often these actions have not been done concurrently."
At the Interior Department, officials have deferred $2.1 billion in parks maintenance, even though they have hardly begun to tap an obvious revenue source: park users. Visitors' fees cover barely a quarter of the cost of services, and staff shortages leave some fee-collection booths vacant.
At the Resolution Trust Corporation, steward of bankrupt savings-and-loans and their assets, managers decided last year to cut costs by canceling insurance on property seized from thrifts. That was just before Hurricane Andrew roared through Miami and carried away a good chunk of seized property.
The agency has won better reviews lately for its handling of the S & L crisis. But early on it was assailed for letting speculators pick up the better thrifts for mere pocket change, while taxpayers paid for the dogs. Why can't the Government run things right? Two Hoover commissions tried to find out for Truman and Eisenhower in the 1940's and 1950's. Ronald Reagan focused the Grace and Packard commissions on the issue in the 1980's. Now President Clinton has ordered a "national performance review," headed by the Vice President and plowing much the same ground -- but more deeply, of course. Mr. Clinton says this study will not gather dust in some warehouse like past ones.
But the basic question does not really demand such deep thought. In government, as in most areas of endeavor, there is a certain level of ineptitude. The worst Federal mismanagement, however, is not personal but systemic. Ours is a bureaucracy where priorities are determined by the peculiar logic of politics; where the rewards for parsimonious management are a budget or staff cut, not higher profits or a promotion; where success is measured, if it's measured at all, in dollars spent.
Conservatives think government would run better if it were managed like a business. But it isn't a business; it's a monopoly.
"The reason that in the private sector we get spanking new shopping centers and so on, and in the public sector you get HUD, is that the private sector makes a pile of money when everything goes right," said Robert Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington. "In government, that's not supposed to happen. And if it did, everyone would be screaming because it would be unfair competition."
Reformers want to improve government by ending favoritism. But favors are the essence of politics, and they are unlikely to vanish. "Do we lease government lands for cattle grazing at costs below what the private sector would charge? Of course we do," said Paul R. Portney, vice president of Resources for the Future, an environmental think-tank. "Do we know the reason? Sure: soon as we try to raise it up to market levels, senators and congressmen raise the roof."
 
Jobs and Plunder
 Indeed, Mr. Clinton tried this year to raise the dirt-cheap grazing fees and was immediately slapped down by Western Democratic senators.
Similar examples abound. The Interior Department lets miners extract huge amounts of ore from public lands without paying a penny in compensation. Congress could change the 121-year-old law that allows such plunder, but chooses not to.
Similarly, the Forest Service loses scores of millions of dollars annually by selling public timber at prices well below the Government's cost; some in Congress complain, but nothing is done because the practice creates jobs. Last week, Mr. Clinton ordered reduced tree-cutting on Forest Service lands in the Northwest, but only after he also agreed to pony up $1.2 billion in economic aid for the logging region, which includes the home district of the Speaker of the House.
Finally, up-in-arms taxpayers want to root out incompetence. But much of it is generic to a government that exists to serve, not to prosper.
"Federal programs by and large suffer from some very common, fundamental flaws," said a Federal official. "They don't have defined objectives. And where they do have defined objectives, they're input objectives, not outcome."
What's the difference? Take the HUD fiasco, in which managers blindly measured success by inputs -- the number of guaranteed loans issued and the number of apartments built -- instead of by the outcome, whether the apartments were occupied and livable.
The temptation to despair over such regular and profound lapses is great. The Government controls a third of the nation's land area, 1.4 billion acres of ocean floor, 12,000 miles of waterways and enough office space -- 400,000 buildings -- to supplant all the office towers in the country's 10 largest cities. The potential for mismanagement stretches from sea to shining sea.
But while there is certainly room for improvement, no amount of fulmination is likely to produce a clockwork government. The built-in irrationalities will never change, Mr. Portney says. "The real key," he says, "is to weed out the discretionary incompetence."

HEADLINE: Overview of the Term;
The Court's Counterrevolution Comes in Fits and Starts

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMONG the flood of opinions that ended the Supreme Court's term last week, two in particular underscored the complex and contradictory personality of a Court poised on the threshold of change.
On the one hand, the Court strode with surprising unanimity across a new constitutional frontier in a case about Government seizure of assets, announcing a new constitutional right grounded in the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against excessive fines. Having only once before even examined the excessive fines clause, the Court turned it into a potentially powerful brake on the Government's aggressive use of its authority under the drug forfeiture laws. 
 Simultaneously, a decision in a voting rights case plowed familiar and painful ground for the Court, revealing the persistence of deep divisions over how to interpret the constitutional guarantee of equal protection in the context of racial distinctions made for assertedly benign reasons. Five Justices said the Court's precedents made presumptively unconstitutional any oddly shaped legislative district drawn for the sole purpose of increasing minority representation, while the four others drew the opposite conclusion from the same precedents.
Often united -- the Court was unanimous, in result if not always in the rationale, in nearly half its cases this term, far more than in recent years -- the Court nonetheless remains sharply divided in such important areas as religion and civil rights.
Often tentative and incremental in its approach, the Court took some unexpectedly decisive steps this term, as in Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's opinion upholding state laws that provide longer sentences for crimes motivated by bias. The decision was unanimous.
Rulings in two civil rights cases, the voting rights case and a decision making a category of cases under the Federal law against employment discrimination harder for employees to win, showed dramatically the impact of the Justices named to the Court by Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
Four of those Justices -- Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas -- joined Chief Justice Rehnquist to provide 5-to-4 majorities in the two cases, which would almost certainly have been decided differently only a few years ago. Justice Thomas's votes were particularly notable because there is no doubt that Justice Thurgood Marshall, whom Justice Thomas succeeded in 1991, would have been on the other side.
But another decision demonstrated the limits of the Court's counterrevolution. The Court ruled that the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment can make it unconstitutional to confine a nonsmoking prisoner in a cell with a chain-smoker. The decision rejected the Bush Administration's view that this "novel Eighth Amendment claim" was "without merit."
Justice Thomas wrote a dissenting opinion that took issue with 17 years of Supreme Court precedents on unconstitutional prison conditions, arguing that all were based on a broad view of the Eighth Amendment at variance with the framers' original intent. Only Justice Scalia joined the dissent. The vote in the case was 7 to 2.
As Justice Thomas maintained a predictable alliance with Justice Scalia -- the two voted together in more than 80 percent of the non-unanimous cases -- Justice David H. Souter emerged this term as perhaps the Court's least predictable member.
Justice Souter, who like Justice Thomas was named to the Court by President Bush, dissented in the two civil rights cases as well as in a series of criminal-law rulings in which the conservative majority prevailed. Notable among these was a decision refusing to permit a Texas death-row inmate, Leonel Herrera, to bring a belated claim of innocence into Federal court through a petition for a writ of habeas corpus. The vote was 6 to 3, with Justice Souter joining Justices Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens in dissent.
Justice Souter also dissented from a 5-to-4 decision in a double jeopardy case, in which the majority overturned a three-year-old precedent that had broadened the double jeopardy defense. His allies in dissent were Justices Blackmun, Stevens and Byron R. White. And in a church-state case, he dissented from the Chief Justice's 5-to-4 opinion that found no constitutional objection to the government paying for a sign-language interpreter for a deaf parochial school student.
These developments do not necessarily mean that the conservative New Hampshire judge suddenly emerged this year as a liberal; "liberal" has been a highly relative term at the Supreme Court since the retirements of Justice Marshall and Justice William J. Brennan Jr., whom Justice Souter succeeded in 1990.
Rather, Justice Souter's hallmark is a willingness to confront some of the Court's murkiest doctrinal areas, working his way through the contradictions to try at the same time both to make sense of the precedents that apply and to steer clear of those that do not. Through this process, he appears this term to have found a personal voice almost completely free of ideological identity.
For example, in his dissenting opinion in the voting rights case, Justice Souter identified the flaw in Justice O'Connor's majority opinion as a confusion of categories. The majority drew on precedents in the affirmative action and public contracting area; in light of those precedents, it was not hard to deem the bizarre-looking North Carolina Congressional District an unjustifiable racial preference.
Without commenting directly on the affirmative action cases -- on which he may well agree with the conservative majority -- Justice Souter said the analogy was inapt. Unlike the workplace, where a job or contract for one person may leave someone else empty-handed, redistricting does not confer a zero-sum benefit, he said. Everyone can still vote, no matter where the district lines are; the Constitution is offended only by some further action such as an effort to use district lines to dilute a racial group's political power.
Justice Souter's independence made him a frequent dissenter. He dissented in 12 of the 17 cases that were decided by 5-to-4 votes. In 40 cases in which Justice Scalia and Justice Blackmun were on opposite sides, he voted with Justice Scalia in 56 percent and with Justice Blackmun in 44 percent.
The least frequent dissenter was Justice Kennedy, who dissented in only four of the 5-to-4 decision and in five out of 107 decisions over all. The term found Justice Kennedy anchored in the Court's mainstream. For example, he dissented only twice in 30 criminal law decisions.
Presumably the center of gravity will shift with Justice White's retirement and the all but certain confirmation of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg as the first Supreme Court nominee by a Democratic President in 26 years. How great the shift will be is not yet clear; Justice White was in dissent in the civil rights decisions, for example, so his departure does not open those rulings to challenge even assuming Judge Ginsburg shares his displeasure. In other areas in which the Court is often closely divided, including free speech, religion and abortion, Judge Ginsburg is likely to be substantially more liberal than Justice White.
With characteristic wryness, Justice White ended his 31-year Supreme Court career on Monday by expressing the hope that the Court's future opinions would be "clear, crisp" and easy for lower court judges to understand and apply. Whatever new departures are now in store for the Court, fulfilling Justice White's wish is not likely to be one of them.
Following are summaries of some of the Court's major rulings of the term, which began Oct. 5 and ended June 28.
 
Criminal Law
Restrictions on Seizing A Suspect's Property And on Death Penalty Appeals
 For the first time, the Court set a constitutional limit on the Government's power to seize the homes, businesses and other property of criminals and suspects, invoking the Eighth Amendment's prohibition against "excessive fines" clause to hold that a forfeiture can be excessive.
The 9-to-0 ruling in Austin v. U.S., No. 92-6073, left to the lower courts the application of that general principle to specific cases. In this case, a North Dakota man lost his business and mobile home after selling two grams of cocaine to an undercover agent.
An earlier forfeiture case this term, involving a statute rather than the Constitution, had indicated the Court's growing skepticism toward the Government's aggressive use of forfeiture as a tool in the war on drugs. The Court interpreted a Federal drug forfeiture law to provide an exception for "innocent owners" that was considerably broader than the Government's view of that defense. The 6-to-3 vote in U.S. v. A Parcel of Land, No. 91-781, permitted a woman to defend her house against forfeiture on the ground that she did not know the money used to buy the house came from her boyfriend's drug dealing.
In the second Eighth Amendment case, the Court ruled by a vote of 7 to 2 that it may be cruel and unusual punishment to confine a nonsmoking prisoner in a cell with a chain-smoking cellmate. The Eighth Amendment applies to future as well as current harm to prisoners, the Court ruled in Helling v. McKinney, No. 91-1958.
Prisoners fared less well outside the Eighth Amendment area; the Court continued to take a restrictive view of the right of state inmates to seek Federal court review of their convictions or sentences through petitions for writs of habeas corpus. In a Texas death penalty case, the Court ruled 6 to 3 that a belated claim of innocence does not ordinarily entitle a death-row inmate to a new Federal court hearing before being executed.
The inmate, Leonel Herrera, had tried to reopen his case with new evidence 10 years after his conviction for murder. The Supreme Court rejected his argument that the 30-day limit for seeking a new trial under Texas law is unconstitutional. He was executed several months after the Court's ruling in Herrera v. Collins, No. 91-7328. Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the opinion, with Justices Blackmun, Stevens and Souter dissenting.
In another significant habeas corpus defeat for prisoners, the Court ruled 5 to 4 that Federal courts may not overturn a state conviction on the basis of constitutional error unless the prisoner can show that he suffered "actual prejudice" from the error. The decision, Brecht v. Abrahamson, No. 91-7358, had the effect of shifting the burden of proof from the state to the prisoner, because the state previously had the burden of proving that any constitutional error was "harmless beyond a reasonable doubt." Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote the decision, with Justices White, O'Connor, Souter and Blackmun dissenting.
The one habeas corpus decision that was a victory for prisoners did not actually change the law, but rather preserved the status quo. Voting 5 to 4, the Court refused to close off Federal court access for prisoners seeking to challenge their convictions on the ground that they had been interrogated by the police without first receiving their Miranda warning of the right to remain silent.
Justice Souter's majority opinion rejected the view, pressed by the Bush Administration, that prisoners who had already received one "full and fair opportunity" to make a Miranda argument in a state-court appeal should not be able to reargue the question in Federal court. Chief Justice Rehnquist along with Justice Scalia, O'Connor and Thomas dissented in Withrow v. Williams, No. 91-1030.
Overturning a three-year-old precedent that had broadened the definition of double jeopardy, the Court ruled 5 to 4 that a man could be prosecuted for trying to kill his wife after having already been held in criminal contempt for violating a court order not to assault her. Justice Scalia wrote the opinion in U.S. v. Dixon, No. 91-1231, with Justices Souter, White, Stevens and Blackmun dissenting.
The Court ruled unanimously that the police do not need a warrant to seize narcotics that were recognizable by "plain feel" while frisking a suspect for concealed weapons. The decision, Minnesota v. Dickerson, No. 91-2019, created a tactile analogue to the "plain view" doctrine, under which police do not need a warrant to seize clearly visible items.
The Court ruled unanimously that regardless of the evidence, a criminal conviction is invalid if the judge did not instruct the jury properly on finding guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Such a mistake can never be "harmless error," the Court said in Sullivan v. Louisiana, No. 92-5129.
 
Civil Rights
New Hurdles for Black Majority Districts And Job Bias Suits
 With two 5-to-4 decisions, one interpreting the Constitution and the other the Federal law against employment discrimination, the Court forcefully re-entered the civil rights debate.
The Court ruled that legislative districts drawn in "bizarre" shapes and designed to increased black representation can violate the constitutional rights of white voters to equal protection of the law.
The district in question was the 12th Congressional District of North Carolina, a narrow 160-mile long ribbon running through 10 counties along Interstate 85. In her majority opinion in Shaw v. Reno, No. 92-357, Justice O'Connor said the district "resembles the most egregious racial gerrymanders of the past" and that the state must demonstrate a "compelling interest" for having drawn it in disregard of traditional redistricting criteria favoring compact and contiguous districts.
While the decision cast doubt on the fate of a number of new black-majority districts, its full impact is unclear because the Court did not distinguish a "bizarre" district from the merely unusual.
In the employment discrimination case, the Court placed a new legal burden on workers who show that an employer gave a dishonest courtroom explanation for an apparently discriminatory action. In the view of most courts, at that point the worker was entitled to a favorable judgment, even if there was no direct evidence of discrimination.
But the Court ruled in St. Mary's Honor Center v. Hicks, No. 92-602, that the worker may still be required to present direct evidence of the employer's discriminatory intent or to refute theoretical explanations other than the one the employer offered. Justice Scalia wrote the opinion.
In both cases, the dissenters were the same: Justices White, Stevens, Blackmun and Souter.
 
Free Speech
A Hate-Crime Statute With Increased Sentences Is Finally Upheld
 The most important free-speech question of the term was the validity of state hate-crime laws that provide increased sentences for violent crimes motivated by bias. The Court unanimously upheld a Wisconsin law that is similar to those on the books in half the states. Chief Justice Rehnquist's opinion in Wisconsin v. Mitchell, No. 92-515, said that the law was aimed at "conduct unprotected by the First Amendment" rather than the defendant's thoughts or expression.
In a significant ruling on commercial speech, the Court reaffirmed its view that advertising is protected by the First Amendment and held that a city could not automatically bar advertising brochures from newspaper vending machines on public property. Justice Stevens wrote the 6-to-3 opinion in Cincinnati v. Discovery Network, No. 91-1200; the dissenters were Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justices White and Thomas.
In a case raising a question under the Freedom of Information Act rather than the Constitution, the Court unanimously rejected the Justice Department's sweeping assertion that all sources supplying information to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a criminal investigation should be treated as "confidential" and exempt from disclosure. (U.S. v. Landano, No. 91-2054).
 
Abortion
Two Laws Banned, One Stays And Operation Rescue Triumphs Over Federal Judges
 The Court displayed no interest in revisiting or elaborating on its 1992 ruling in Planned Parenthood v. Casey that reaffirmed a constitutional right to abortion. The Justices refused to hear appeals from Louisiana and the territory of Guam, where laws banning most abortion had been declared unconstitutional by lower Federal courts. At the same time, the Court refused to hear a challenge by abortion-rights advocates to a Mississippi law with a 24-hour waiting period, similar to Pennsylvania's waiting period that the Justices upheld in the Casey decision.
By a 6-to-3 vote, the Court removed a tool that judges around the country had used to protect abortion clinics against disruptive protests by Operation Rescue and other anti-abortion groups. The Court ruled in Bray v. Alexandria Women's Health Clinic, No. 90-985, that a Reconstruction-era civil rights law enacted to protect blacks from the Ku Klux Klan did not give Federal judges jurisdiction to issue injunctions against the blockades and mass protests.
Justice Scalia wrote the opinion, from which Justices Stevens, O'Connor and Blackmun dissented. In its next term, the Court will decide whether abortion clinics can sue the organizers of the demonstrations under the Federal racketeering law.
 
Government
The U.S. May Intercept Fleeing Haitians at Sea And Deny Them Asylum
 The Court upheld the Senate's shortcut procedure for conducting impeachment trials of Federal judges, ruling 9 to 0 that the Senate's choice of how to discharge its constitutional duty to "try all impeachments" is not subject to judicial review.
The decision, Nixon v. U.S., No. 91-740, effectively upheld the recent removal of two impeached Federal judges, Walter L. Nixon and Alcee L. Hastings, who is now a Congressman from Florida. For their trials, a special committee of 12 Senators heard witnesses and compiled evidence, tasks that the judges argued had to be done by the Senate as a whole and could not be delegated.
The Court upheld the Bush and Clinton Administrations' policy of intercepting fleeing Haitians at sea and returning them to Haiti without asylum hearings. The 8-to-1 decision, written by Justice Stevens with Justice Blackmun dissenting, rejected arguments that the policy violated Federal immigration law and an international treaty on refugees. (Sale v. Haitian Centers Council, No. 92-344).
 
Courts
When Science Experts Knock, Judges Will Be The Gatekeepers
 In its first ruling on the place of scientific evidence in Federal courtrooms, the Court placed judges firmly in charge of keeping bad science out and letting good science in. The 7-to-2 decision in Daubert v. Merrell Dow, No. 92-102, held that while an expert witness's actual conclusions need not be "generally accepted" in the scientific community, the "methods and procedures" used in reaching those results must be valid. The judge should limit the jury's consideration to testimony or evidence that is "not only relevant, but reliable," Justice Blackmun said for the Court.
The Court had been widely expected to set a new constitutional limit on punitive damages this term. But it declined to do so, instead upholding a $10-million punitive damage award for a $19,000 injury, in a 6-to-3 decision that made little new law. The Court found that the award, while "certainly large," bore enough relationship to the economic stakes involved in the commercial dispute over rights to a West Virginia oil field as not to violate the losing side's right to due process of law. (TXO Production v. Alliance Resources, No. 92-479).
 
Religion
The Standoff Between Church and State Eases at School
 Despite three church-state cases on its docket, the Court made little new law in this area. It ruled 9 to 0 that a Hialeah, Fla. ordinance banning ritual animal sacrifice violated the free-exercise rights of adherents of the Santeria religion, in which animal sacrifice has a central role. The Court found that the ordinance, which was drafted to allow such practices as recreational hunting and kosher slaughter to continue, had the unconstitutional purpose of suppressing religious observance. (Church of the Lukumi Babalu Aye v. City of Hialeah, No. 91-948)
In another 9-to-0 decision, the Court ruled that public school systems that open their schools to after-hours use by community groups must permit religious groups to use the buildings on the same terms. The Court held in Lamb's Chapel v. Center Moriches School District, No. 91-2024, that a religious viewpoint could not constitutionally be excluded from a public forum open to other viewpoints.
The Court ruled 5 to 4 that the Constitution permits using government money to pay for a sign-language interpreter to accompany a deaf child to a parochial school. The child would have been entitled to the interpreter in public school under a Federal law that requires appropriate services for handicapped schoolchildren. The question in Zobrest v. Catalina School District, No. 92-94, was whether providing the service in a parochial school amounted to an unconstitutional establishment of religion.
Chief Justice Rehnquist's majority opinion said that the interpreter was a permissible service aimed at helping the child and not the school. Justices Blackmun, Souter, O'Connor and Stevens dissented.
 
Taxes, Business
Moonlighters' Alert: Deductions for Home Offices Take a Hit
 The Court made it harder than ever for taxpayers to take deductions for the spare rooms they use at home to handle the administrative aspects their businesses.
By an 8-to-1 vote, the Court backed the Internal Revenue Service's view that the question is not whether a home office is legitimate or even necessary, but whether it is the place where the taxpayer's most important professional activities take place. The decision, Commissioner v. Soliman, No. 91-998, refused a deduction claimed by an anesthesiologist who used his home as his only office, while practicing his profession in hospital operating rooms.
The Court redefined its rules on retroactivity, making a four-year-old tax ruling retroactive in a decision that may require 16 states to pay huge refunds to retired Federal workers who did not get a tax break that the states made available to their own retired workers. The Court had ruled in 1989 that the disparity violated a Federal law barring state tax discrimination against Federal employees. As much as $2 billion is at stake in the 7-to-2 decision, Harper v. Virginia, No. 91-794.
The Court ruled that accountants, lawyers and other outside advisers to corrupt companies cannot be sued under the Federal racketeering law unless they actually participated in the operation or management of the client organization. The 7-to-2 ruling, Reves v. Ernst & Young, No. 91-886, shields outside professionals, whose deep pockets make them attractive targets for shareholder lawsuits in securities cases, from the threat of triple damages liability.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Two Scripts for Talking in Tokyo

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JAPAN'S Ambassador to the United States, Takakazu Kuriyama, was at the White House recently to talk about the Clinton Administration's emerging Japan policy. The Clinton team had to be patient in dealing with Japan on trade problems, said the ambassador. The Clintonites responded in effect with two words: "Trade imbalance." Washington should not forget the importance of security and political cooperation with Japan, said the ambassador. The Clintonites responded: "Trade imbalance."
It went on that way for an hour, as the American side tried to hammer home to the Japanese the shift in Japan policy being undertaken by the Clinton Administration. Since World War II United States-Japan policy has been like a three-legged stool: the security relationship, focused on cooperation against the Soviet Union, the political relationship, focused on cooperation to promote democracy around the globe, and the economic relationship, with all of the frictions over trade. 
 For 40 years the solidity of the first two legs tended to compensate for troubles with the economic leg, and kept the relationship balanced. But since the end of the cold war, the political and security legs have lost some strength, and can no longer compensate for the fact that the economic leg is more wobbly than ever: Japan, at $49 billion a year, has run up a total trade surplus with the United States of nearly $500 billion over the last decade. The key question raised by the Clinton approach to Japan is this: Can the relationship really tolerate any longer the pain that might be required to balance the economic leg?
"The basic change," said Winston Lord, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, "is that we are putting an urgent focus on the economic dimension -- not because it is the only dimension we care about, but because it is the one that needs fixing now. We have to focus on it both for its own sake and because, if it is not fixed, over time it could infect the other dimensions of the relationship."
 
A Different Atmosphere
 The culture of Japan policy-making in the Clinton Administration contrasts sharply with the Reagan-Bush years. Reagan-Bush trade negotiators were as tough as any, but the overall tone of that Administration was often milder. In part this was because whenever the trade negotiators wanted to really play hardball, the Pentagon and State Department would try to soften the blows, arguing that Japan's cooperation was needed against Moscow. President Bush, himself, had little interest in the making of Japan policy. Given a choice between discussing arcana like the homologation of auto parts with Tokyo and negotiating arms control with the Soviets, he always chose the latter.
Mr. Clinton, by contrast, is far more interested in discussing the balance of trade than the balance of power, and he looks at Japan not like some giant American aircraft carrier in the Pacific that needs careful tending, but more as an extension of America's domestic economic difficulties that must be confronted. Mr. Clinton's economic advisers do not tell war stories about how they cooperated with the Japanese, shoulder to shoulder, to confront the Soviets in Asia. The scars they show off are from confrontations with Japan in the global marketplace.
"In the old days, an American President would talk to the Japanese and say, 'Here are the security issues, here are the political issues, and, oops, we ran out of time to talk about the economic issues,' " said a top Clinton economic adviser. "No more."
Beyond the new tone, and their quiet effort to devalue the dollar against the yen, the Clinton Administration's Japan policy is focused on opening Japan's markets in a way that can be measured by increases in Japanese imports of foreign manufactured goods. This includes autos, parts, insurance, banking services and general Japanese Government procurements. The United States also wants Japan to reduce its world trade surplus ($107.1 billion last year) from the current 3.3 percent of its gross national product to between 1.5 and 2 percent of G.N.P. In return, Mr. Clinton is promising that America will keep its own markets open to Japan and get its own economic house in order.
So far the talks have gone nowhere, hopes of a deal before this week's economic summit meeting in Tokyo have been dashed, and Japanese diplomats are warning their American counterparts to back off. As one put it: "If the President does not care about the political-security side of the relationship, it will have an adverse effect on the economic relations."
Clinton advisers don't buy that. Said one top trade negotiator: "We're not asking the Japanese to do anything against the interests of their consumers, who will benefit from lower import prices. They think they can wait us out, and they are wrong. Our market is more important to them than theirs is to us. Furthermore, I really don't think that from a security point of view the Japanese are ready to take a lot of risks in their relationship with us. The leverage is on our side; it is just a question of deploying it."
What worries some analysts of the Clinton approach is that it somehow assumes that the trade imbalance with Japan can be repaired by negotiated decisions. Most experts are convinced that the biggest factors affecting the trade imbalance are things like relative saving rates, quality standards and productivity rates that are beyond the control of governments and tend to be based on deep cultural traditions. Japan must lower its trade barriers, to be sure, but even if it removed them all it would still have a huge trade surplus with the United States.
So even under the best of circumstances any change will be incremental and long-term. The trick for Mr. Clinton will be to put enough pressure on the Japanese to open markets where there are real barriers, without generating so much pressure that unrealistic expectations -- or a Japanese backlash -- develop.
Washington has to be careful not to push the Japanese to accelerate their growing links with China and the rest of Asia, leaving the United States more isolated and Japan more independent. The Japanese could also play hardball, and tell Americans in effect: "You want measurable targets? Well, so do we. You bring down your high-school dropout rate, which we think hinders your export capacity, and we will bring down our savings rate."
What we have here is two nations in flux, playing a game of chicken -- with neither one quite sure any more at just which point the other will veer away.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Good Old Bad Old South Africa

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
AMERICA will be extending more than a token of its admiration when it awards Nelson Mandela and President F.W. de Klerk the Liberty Medal this afternoon in a ceremony at Independence Hall in Philadelphia. The medal is intended as an inducement to both men to continue on course toward democracy for South Africa. Put more crudely, the award will be the latest demonstration of America's incurable compulsion to meddle in this country's affairs.
For Americans, South Africa has been the one enduring object of fascination on a continent that rarely commands their attention. From disinvestment and cultural boycotts to "constructive engagement" to the current sugar-lump diplomacy, something about South Africa brings out Americans' missionary impulse. 
 And now that the old South Africa, the last outpost of white supremacy, is giving way to something amazingly ordinary, there is even a whiff of nostalgia in the American reaction.
America's interest here was only in small part self-interest. The policy mills have ground out countless papers assessing South Africa's importance as the guardian of the Cape sea lane, a bulwark against Communism, a source of strategic metals and, now that the country is reopening, a land of business opportunity.
But for most Americans, the lure of South Africa had nothing to do with stopping the Red menace or assuring ample platinum for catalytic converters.
 
Moral Clarity
 It was, literally and figuratively, a black-and-white issue. Here, Americans could refight their own racial battles with a moral clarity America itself did not offer, not in this era of the underclass and affirmative action.
Some Americans looked at South Africa and felt smug, that at least someplace on the planet botched its race relations worse than they did. Others saw an opportunity to make amends for America's own racial history.
"South Africa isn't a country for Americans; it's a metaphor," says John Matisonn, a South African journalist who has worked for the past seven years in American public broadcasting.
America has usually approached South Africa with an exaggerated sense of its own influence.
Andrew Young came here in 1977 as the Carter Administration's delegate to the United Nations convinced that America could push Pretoria into enfranchising blacks. Prime Minister John Vorster called an election six months later and won a landslide victory by campaigning against the meddling of the Carter Administration.
Next up, the Reagan Administration argued that by "constructive engagement" America could make useful allies of the apartheid government without in any sense condoning their practices. Indeed, the Reaganites argued, in some companionable way American values would rub off.
At the same time, Congress, responding to public pressure, preferred the theory that South Africa could be starved or shamed into doing the right thing by the application of trade sanctions.
Academics will debate for decades how much difference these carrots and sticks made, but few dispute that apartheid failed above all from its own stupidity. The notion was that 5 million whites could make 30 million blacks live forever in wretched, make-believe homelands and commute to white South Africa to sell their labor cheap. Mr. Mandela, early on, and Mr. de Klerk, in time, recognized that this defied the laws of demographics, economics and human nature, which is one reason the two men are in Philadelphia today.
As South Africa becomes more normal, so does America's relationship with it. Instead of moralistic scoldings, America now offers helpful hints from the Federalist Papers to help the new constitution-writers. Scores of Americans who might once have shown their disapproval by picketing the South African Embassy are now here serving as peace monitors and voter education specialists.
Andrew Young, now an executive of an Atlanta engineering firm, comes to scout investment opportunities now that sanctions are soon to be abolished. Mr. Mandela is hopping from fund-raising dinner to fund-raising dinner, squeezing corporate fat cats for campaign contributions and touting his country's business climate.
It is enough to make some Americans wistful, this spectacle of South Africa's liberation hero soliciting not their moral indignation, but their cash and tips on organizing focus groups.
One escape is to simply disbelieve the changes that have occurred here, and to deny that Mr. de Klerk is any different from villains preceding him.
Martin Meyerson, the university don who heads the Liberty Medal selection commission, said the award has drawn protests from black clergy, black Pennsylvania legislators and others who denounce Mr. de Klerk as a "fascist" and "murderer."
"They are still fighting the last war," Mr. Meyerson said. "There have not been many battles where good and evil were so clearly delineated."
In Washington, a few lobbyists want to replace economic sanctions with some new form of moral supervision -- a code of conduct, for example, requiring American companies to prove that they will promote blacks and respect labor unions and so on when they open shop in South Africa.
Leaders of the African National Congress find this kind of proposal condescending.
"We don't need a gatekeeper anymore," said Trevor Manuel, chief of the congress's economics department. "The rights and responsibilities of foreign investors are a matter to be codified by a democratic government of South Africa. But I understand the feeling of groups that have made South Africa their life's work."
It is hard to let go, he meant. The old South Africa was such a lovely place to loathe.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Nelson Mandela in New York last week. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Lorenzo's New Flight of Non-Fancy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
HE'S fit, he's rested and he's back. Yes, Frank Lorenzo -- hero to bargain-hunting travelers, Darth Vader to organized labor -- is again launching an airline.
With the major carriers losing pots of money and the unions baying for his blood, conventional wisdom suggests that the man who flew Continental and Eastern Airlines into bankruptcy will not keep his planes aloft for long. 
 But ATX, the working name for the East Coast start-up, is not intended to be a conventional airline. And Mr. Lorenzo is hardly a conventional airline executive.
"Frank loves low fares," explains Alfred Kahn, the Carter Administration economist who presided over the deregulation of the airline industry. What's more, says Mr. Kahn, "Frank hates to lose."
Applications to start airlines are ordinarily rubber-stamped by the Department of Transportation after the applicant shows the wherewithal to pay the bills. But prodded by the A.F.L.-C.I.O., 150 members of Congress signed a letter urging the department to keep Frank Lorenzo grounded. And 15 members of the House, led by Mac Collins of Georgia, are sponsoring "two-time loser" legislation that would bar an owner of two bankrupt airlines from making a third attempt.
The union's case against Mr. Lorenzo does not impress free marketeers. "If he's going to lose his shirt," argues Severin Borenstein, an economist at the University of California at Davis, "that's his problem." And since President Clinton has publicly lamented the attenuation of airline competition, the betting now is that Mr. Lorenzo will get his certificate of operation after a little ritual hazing.
This first hurdle, which Mr. Lorenzo hopes to clear by the fall, is hardly the last. Grand old airlines including Pan Am, Braniff and Eastern have fallen by the wayside. Several others are in bankruptcy or on the edge. Even the Big Three -- American, United and Delta -- have hunkered down for losses. How could little ATX expect to thrive?
The answer, in a phrase: by imitating Southwest Airlines.
The big carriers all operate "hub-and-spoke" route structures, shuttling passengers through central airports for connections to third cities. This has proven amazingly efficient, allowing people to fly almost anywhere and back the same day. But at a price: the systems are burdened by logistic and marketing overhead.
Southwest exploits this. It offers one-class, low-frills service on short, densely trafficked routes, often where airplanes are competing with cars. There are no hot meals or even preassigned seats. But by setting fares far below what hub-and-spoke carriers can afford to charge, Southwest is filling planes and making money.
In fact, many economists say Southwest has kept flying affordable for Westerners. The San Diego-San Francisco route is roughly as long and serves the same size population as the Boston-Washington route. But last year, the airlines on the Western route carried almost twice as many passengers at an average fare of $53 as their Eastern counterparts charged an average of $129.
Mr. Lorenzo plans to start small, serving only Boston and Atlanta from the Baltimore-Washington airport. Most likely USAir and Delta, which now serve these routes respectively, will respond by matching ATX's fares for some seats. But by charging just one-third their unrestricted fares, Mr. Lorenzo expects to create an avalanche of traffic that allows ATX to fill several flights a day without cannibalizing the markets of the majors.
 
Frills Gone

 Competitors on these routes might undercut ATX's fares and increase frequency of service until ATX leaves the market. But Irwin Stelzer, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, thinks that is unlikely in light of the Administration's new vigilance against predatory practices. When Northwest Airlines threatened start-up Reno Air on the Minneapolis-Reno route this spring, antitrusters jawboned Northwest into retreat.
Of course, costs matter as well as revenues. One reason why no one has tried to transplant the Southwest model to the East is that operating costs -- notably labor -- are widely believed to be in a different league. But Bob McAdoo, an analyst for Prudential Securities and the former chief financial officer of Newark-based People Express, offers a comforting perspective.
Southwest pays only slightly lower wages than the industry average, he says; its advantage largely comes from getting more work out of planes and people on their point-to-point route structure.
"When you sit down and really look at the numbers," he concludes, "costs on the East Coast aren't that much higher."
Indeed, Mr. Lorenzo will enjoy one clear cost advantage over Southwest. With airlines mothballing hundreds of planes, the venerable DC-9's and 737's that ATX needs can be leased at Wal-Mart prices.
Plenty could still could go wrong. Labor may convince the public that ATX will inherit Eastern Airlines' maintenance problems. A fumbling start -- late flights, overbooking -- could alienate passengers. ATX may be unable to recreate the image of no-nonsense informality that allows Southwest to keep travelers content with minimal creature comforts.
Whatever his limitations, Mr. Lorenzo is well aware that any airline associated with his name must try harder. And his optimism is infectious: "We will make a very nice Christmas present for the East," he predicts.
