HEADLINE: 7 Rich Nations Expecting Little At Tokyo Talks

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 3

 BODY:
Struggling with slow economic growth, high unemployment and bitter trade disputes, the leaders of the world's seven wealthiest nations will gather here for their annual summit meeting next week amid widespread doubts that they will make much progress in setting the global economy on a more prosperous course.
Negotiations on resolving the remaining differences among the so-called Group of Seven -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada -- are continuing and may yet produce modest agreements on liberalizing the world trading system, pumping new life into the industrial economies and providing financial assistance to Russia. 
 But some economists and government officials say there may be a deeper message in the contentious discussions leading up to this year's gathering, which opens Wednesday in the lavish Akasaka Palace.
 
Group's Unity Is Weakened
 The ambitious form that these annual economic conferences have taken, they say, may have been better suited to the more prosperous and confident 1980's than the current era of economic insecurity. The group's unity of purpose has been frayed by tough domestic problems in each country and politically weakened leaders.
"The tone, the atmosphere, the ideas that are discussed may be far more important than anything specific that comes out of the communique," President Clinton told a group of reporters on Friday, in an apparent attempt to lower expectations. "It is what direction are we going to take the world."
Horst Kohler, a senior German Finance Ministry official involved in preparing the conference, said, "The outlook is sobering."
 
Clinton to Be Scrutinized
 President Clinton's performance will be watched closely, in part because this will be his first summit meeting and in part because he had campaigned on a promise that he would focus more on domestic issues.
His hand will be strengthened by his recent success in advancing his budget deficit-reduction program in Congress, since that is what the other countries have been demanding of the United States for several years. But the tough issues here will present Mr. Clinton with a difficult test in his first overseas trip as President.
Nicholas F. Brady, the Treasury Secretary during the four summit meetings under President George Bush, said some past conferences received more credit than they deserved. The gatherings, he said, can help prevent looming disasters and provide a good forum for an exchange of ideas. But they usually cannot do more than give added impetus to developments that are already taking place, like exchange-rate movements.
"If the stars are already lined up, you can push things ahead in a direction they were already pointed. But if you aren't that lucky, there is a limit to what you can do," Mr. Brady said.
Those limits have been accentuated this year by domestic concerns in each of the seven countries. The industrialized world's economies will expand by just 1.2 percent this year, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the third year of sub-par growth.
 
Strained Relations
 Unemployment remains at a stubbornly high 8.5 percent for the 24 countries that are members of the organization, and it is expected to rise to 8.6 percent next year, a total of 36 million people out of work.
Relations between the countries have also been strained. Japan and the United States have been engaged in bitter negotiations, not over substantive trade problems, but simply over the framework for future trade talks. The European Community is finding its vision of unity tested by the economic problems of its members.
Germany, Europe's economic locomotive, is expected to see its economy contract by 2 percent this year, and is facing continuing violence against immigrants. Indeed, tight national budgets and unemployment are creating social problems in many Group of Seven countries.
In addition, President Clinton and Prime Minister John Major of Britain are struggling against low approval ratings at home that have limited their ability to fashion compromises. Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, who lost a no-confidence motion in Parliament last month, and appears likely to be forced from office after elections in two weeks. As chairman of the summit meeting, he is thus likely to have even less ability than usual to force the parties to reach agreements.
"There are seven ships out at sea, and usually the head of each state remains on the bridge setting their course," said Makoto Utsumi, an economics professor and former top Japanese Finance Ministry official who has been involved in several summit meetings. "But at the moment the captains are all down in the engine rooms."
 
Some Meetings Make History
 The Presidents and Prime Ministers of the leading industrial countries have met each year since 1974 to share ideas, set the global agenda and tackle world economic problems. Some meetings have made history, like the one on July 18, 1991, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev, then President of the Soviet Union, joined the group's leaders in London and asked for financial assistance. Others, like the Paris conference of 1989, which focused on stemming trade in narcotics and the laundering of illegal drug profits, made less of an impact.
This year, the leaders need to conclude negotiations on the long-stalled guidelines for a more open world trading system, to stimulate their faltering economies and to help finance Russia's transformation into a market economy. There is also likely to be some agreement on a plan to reduce the debt of the world's poorest developing nations, officials said.
There will also be discussion of critical political issues. The conference will try to achieve a common position on halting the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina and on whether to condemn Iran over accusations that it supporting terrorism, commits human rights abuses and is trying to build arsenals of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
But the signs of discord on the economic issues have been conspicuous. For instance, France has said it will refuse to free its agriculture markets as long as the United States threatens to increase duties on steel imports. Prime Minister Edouard Balladur called last-ditch attempts to work out a trade deal "rather stupid," and added, "There will be no accord on market access in Tokyo."
 
GATT Talks Threatened
 This attitude threatens completion of what is called the Uruguay Round of negotiations to rejuvenate the trading system under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Each of the past three summit meetings promised that the talks would be concluded by the end of the years in which they were held.
Japan has rebuffed calls that it cut taxes and increase Government spending to stimulate its anemic economy, which is expected to grow only about 1 percent in 1993. A stronger economy would reduce Japan's huge trade surplus -- expected to reach $160 billion this year -- and lift other economies.
Japanese officials have refused to take such steps, saying the two stimulus packages they have announced in the last year are enough.

HEADLINE: Boom in Boating Crowds the Summer Sea

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 3

 BODY:
It was high noon last Saturday and weekend drivers who only hours before had jammed the New Jersey Turnpike or Garden State Parkway were hopping out of cars and into boats.
"They operate their vessels the way they drive their cars, only with less knowledge and skill," said Michael Yannuzzi, the New Jersey Marine Police officer at the helm of a 40-foot patrol boat cutting slowly along the Manasquan River near Point Pleasant. 
 Ahead loomed an armada of pleasure craft. Fat ocean-going cabin cruisers plowed up a huge wake, leaving crabbers in 12-foot boats fighting to keep from capsizing. Two high-performance craft with bows like knives engaged in the waterborne equivalent of a drag race as sailboat skippers -- with terror and anger on their faces -- angled out of their paths.
 
Many Potential Dangers
 All the while Jet Skis, Waverunners and other high-powered personal watercraft darted about.
"The wonder of it all is why more people aren't killed," muttered Sgt. Erich Herkloz, a state trooper who commands a Marine Police station. It is a comment shared across the region and the nation as America's 20 million pleasure craft take to waters that are increasingly congested.
But despite the potential dangers, pleasure boating is largely an unregulated pastime that invites freedom from the cares of landlocked lives. No states require licenses for adults to operate boats and only some states require children to have boating safety certificates. In many states, law enforcement is fragmented between several agencies with only a handful of marine officers assigned to patrol long stretches of water.
Prosperity in the 1980's helped increase the number of powerful boats once considered too costly for most Americans. Summer weekends bring the boats out in undisciplined swarms along the Jersey Shore, Long Island Sound and other waterways, raising concerns about safety and noise.
In New Jersey, as in most states, no boat speed limits are imposed unless posted to reduce wakes at marinas or in very narrow channels. High-powered racing boats thunder across shallow rivers and bays at speeds not tolerated for automobiles on land.
"There are very few quiet places near the water," said Nelson Potter, director of the marine and recreational vehicle department of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.
But safety is the main issue that worries Mr. Potter and other experts who say that most of the region's recreational boaters have had no formal training in boat operation and many do not possess even rudimentary information on safety rules.
 
Number of Deaths Is Low
 Yet despite the growing congestion, the number of deaths from pleasure boating is low, compared to the number of highway deaths. In fact boating deaths have declined steadily for a quarter-century, dropping from 1,418 in 1970 to 1,360 in 1980 and 816 in 1992, a period in which the Coast Guard estimates that the number of pleasure boats jumped from 7.4 million to 20 million. But the drop is mostly in the category of drownings after falls off boats or sinkings.
A category that has climbed is the number of deaths and serious injuries from vessel collisions, according to the Coast Guard. In 1970 boats ramming one another caused 55 deaths and 232 injuries requiring hospitalization; by last year the figures were 79 and 1,369.
Connecticut just became the first state in the nation to pass a law requiring a certain level of boating proficiency. Under the law, by 1997 all operators of motor boats must demonstrate knowledge of boat operation by taking a safety course or a test. Delaware, Maryland and Vermont recently passed similar laws, but they are not as far reaching.
 
Public Support for Licensing
 Some states, like New Jersey and New York, require minors to be certified to operate power boats, but Mr. Potter and other safety experts said lobbyists for boat manufacturers have blocked bills seeking to make adult education mandatory.
And although studies have shown that the public supports licensing of recreational boaters it faces resistance nearly everywhere, said William Gossard, program manager for recreational boating safety in the National Transportation and Safety Board.
"We see licensing coming but it is being fought by 30 percent of the boaters who want no rules at all and the groups that are owned by the boating industry," Mr. Gossard said.
"Licensing is a nasty word to many people," said Capt. William Gronikowsky, supervisor of New Jersey's Marine Police. "There is an outcry for us to take more action against reckless individuals who say no one can tell them how to run their own boats. But it's very frustrating that we don't have the enforcement tools, like the threat of suspending an operating license."
 
Personal Craft Popular
 But even responsible boat owners resist further regulation.
"We strongly support programs to phase in mandatory boating education for all owners and operators," said Michael Sciulla, vice president of governmental affairs for BOAT/U.S., an association of 450,000 boat owners. "But we do not believe that paying the state for a license is going to significantly improve a rather remarkable safety record."
Drownings in bathtubs and pools claimed nearly as many lives last year as boating accidents did, Mr. Sciulla said.
One category that causes particular concern among boating safety experts is personal watercraft, like Jet Skis, which represented 25 percent of all power boat sales in 1992 and now number more than 350,000.
"They're a lot of fun, like motorcycles, but out on the water if you wipe out you don't get hurt," said Thomas Riley, 25, a truck driver from Philadelphia who rented a Jet Ski for three hours at Seaside Heights.
Not all landings are soft. While personal watercraft represent only 1 of every 60 power craft in America, they are involved in one-third of all collisions that result in serious injury.
Another concern of boating experts is the fragmented responsibility for law enforcement. New Jersey is the only state in the region that has a State Police bureau responsible for boat safety and enforcement. In New York the Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation regulates policy through the Department of Environmental Protection, with conservation officers sharing enforcement with local authorities like the Harbor Patrol of the New York City Police Department, the Marine Bureau of the Nassau County Police Department and the police in towns on Long Island.
 
A Push for Boating Standards
 This spring, the National Transportation Safety Board urged the states to enact uniform pleasure-boating standards to reduce the number and severity of accidents. It recommended the mandatory use of life jackets or similar equipment for children, tougher laws on alcohol consumption while operating a boat and adult boat safety education.
The extent of alcohol use in recreational boating "cannot be adequately documented," the safety board said, because states vary on the compilation of information. In a study of fatalities the board estimated that "at least 37 percent" of boat operators involved in fatal accidents have some alcohol in their systems.
The issue attracted widespread attention three months ago when two Cleveland Indians pitchers, Steve Olin and Tim Crews, were killed when their 18-foot boat hit a dock on a lake near Orlando, Fla. Investigators later determined that Mr. Crews, the driver, was legally intoxicated.
New Jersey and Connecticut have no requirements about life jackets for children; New York requires children under 12 to wear them on boats less than 26 feet long. New York recently joined New Jersey in adopting a requirement that boat operators consent to alcohol impairment tests or face loss of boating privileges. Connecticut has no such requirement.
But no matter what laws are in place, officials say that resources for enforcement are so small that violations usually go unnoticed. The Coast Guard, whose chief mission is search and rescue, works closely with the states within the three-mile continental limits and tidal areas, and Federal money augments state patrol expenditures in lean economic times.
In New Jersey, budget constraints have cut the Marine Police to 150 officers, who patrol the state's lakes and waterways, including 127 miles of Atlantic coastline and 1,750 miles of interior tidal shoreline. The officers are also responsible for pollution control and anti-narcotics policing. "We just don't have the manpower to cover our beat," said Sergeant Herkloz.
 
Few Patrols
 Federal money earmarked for overtime pay will help beef up patrols this summer, said Captain Gronikowsky, the Marine Police supervisor in Trenton. But last weekend, on a beautiful day that produced heavy boat traffic, only one 20-foot patrol boat with two officers was on duty between Shark River in Monmouth County and Island Beach State Park in Ocean County.
The same goes for some areas of New York State, Mr. Potter said. "Whole stretches of the Hudson River are not covered," he said.

HEADLINE: A Roof for All, Made of Rulings and Red Tape

SERIES: Search for Shelter -- New York and Its Homeless/First of three articles.

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
They shout out sad stories in rush-hour subways. They beg for money outside bank machines. They dig through the trash. They talk to the air.
The homeless remain an indelible fact of New York City life. Thousands still live on the streets. And since Mayor David N. Dinkins took office four years ago, the number of homeless families in city shelters has swelled from 3,700 to 5,600. Mr. Dinkins himself faces contempt of court charges for leaving hundreds of these families to sleep for days at a time on chairs in dingy, smoky city offices, where gaunt men with AIDS huddle next to squalling babies and exhausted mothers. 
 Some of the current crisis is of the Dinkins administration's own making, researchers and advocates for the homeless say, but its ability to swiftly change the city's troubled shelter system, which dwarfs that of any other American city in its scale, expense and comprehensiveness, has also been limited by decisions made years before Mr. Dinkins became Mayor.
The tale of the city's response to homelessness -- which now costs over a half a billion dollars a year -- began more than a decade ago when a young lawyer who had never even tried a case sued the city for the right to shelter.
The outcome of that suit, and others like it filed on behalf of women and families, set off a dizzying shelter buildup and entangled the city in a confounding problem as difficult to control as wildfire and as hard to predict as human nature.
When Mr. Dinkins took office four years ago, he spoke of lofty goals, promising sweeping changes in the city's treatment of the homeless. But in trying to remake the city's shelter system he had to grapple with a number of immovables. The past haunts the present in the unconditional right to shelter enshrined in legal agreements, state regulation and ingrained bureaucratic practice -- a right more far-reaching than that offered by any other American city.
There are no limits on how long people live in the system, nor can they be required to do chores or to join self-help programs. Even a resident who sets a fire, attacks someone or uses drugs in a shelter can only be suspended for a week, city officials say.
For years, the city has relied on large, institutional buildings and commercial hotels for shelters, places often condemned as costly warehouses. But providing something more humane is no easy thing. The city is often boxed in by not-in-my-backyard resistance to new, improved shelters.
It also must contend with the state's longstanding practice of emptying its mental hospitals without creating enough group homes, which has left thousands of disturbed people to fend for themselves on the streets and in the shelters.
Leading state legislators are now pushing for a landmark bill requiring that most of the savings from reducing hospitalization be reinvested in community services, but Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, faced with budget pressures, has not agreed to the proposal.
The plight of the mentally ill is just one aspect of homelessness that the Mayor cannot control.
"It's not simple," he said recently.
The city's vast shelter system of more than 100 hospitals, armories, schools, prisons, factories, hotels and apartments is a unique jerry-built contraption that grew helter-skelter over the last decade, shaped by legal battles, flawed compromises, grass roots fears of the homeless, political expedience and quirky twists of fate.
It has taken New York more than a decade to build its behemoth of a shelter system. All say it will take years more to send it lumbering in a new direction that helps the homeless attain self-sufficiency.
 
The Policy
 1979 Lawsuit Opened Doors
 Since the inception of New York's remarkable open-door policy, spending on homeless programs has exploded from less than $10 million in the early 1980's to more than $500 million this year. On average the city spends $36,000 a year to shelter a family. The Federal Government pays half the cost and the state and city split the rest. The city and state share the cost of shelter for a single person -- $15,000 a year. That is what it costs to run the shelters, including paying for staff, supplies, utilities and building maintenance.
Most cities refused to create an entitlement and instead relied on charitable and nonprofit groups to provide shelter on a catch-as-catch can basis. "When I was doing my field work and said I was from New York," said Diane Baillargeon, who is completing a book on homeless policies in 10 American cities, "people raised their eyebrows and told me, 'We don't want to make those mistakes.' "
Even cities that had similarly open-ended policies pulled back by decade's end. In Washington D.C., voters repealed the right to shelter. In Philadelphia, advocates for the homeless themselves abandoned the battle for shelter. What the homeless really need, said Stephen Gold, a lawyer who represented the homeless there, is housing and treatment for alcoholism, addiction and mental illness.
"Shelters stink," Mr. Gold said. "You don't want a right to stuff that stinks."
But New York City has not backed away from the right to shelter because of the city's strong liberal tradition and the shrewd band of young advocates whose legal battle for shelter has never let up.
 
No Challenge Planned
 No one in city government is talking about challenging the right to shelter, though city lawyers say it has never been definitively established under the state constitution. If the city decided to back away from the obligation, it would have to go back to court to set aside a 1981 consent decree for single men and it would have to litigate the issue for families, city lawyers say.
It was a young, green Wall Street lawyer who started it all in 1979 when he sued the city for the right to shelter for men. Robert Hayes, just 26 years old, had begged time from his firm and burrowed into the library stacks, looking for leverage to improve the lot of panhandlers he met on the streets. He found a passage in the state constitution that called for "the aid, care and support of the needy." New York is one of just a handful of states with such a broadly worded social commitment in its constitution.
He also found a ready audience in a state Supreme Court Judge, Richard Wallach, elected to the bench from the Upper West Side. Mr. Wallach recalled reading George Orwell's "Down and Out in Paris and London" from his Harvard College days. The image of Depression-era hobos tramping through England stayed with him. He felt no civilized society should allow such misery.
He pressured the city to settle. Mr. Hayes wanted small shelters and housing. But Mayor Edward I. Koch resisted providing more than basic shelter in large settings.
"I believe there are minimums below which nobody should be permitted to fall," Mr. Koch said recently. "But after that, this country is so big, so wonderful and filled with opportunities, after that you have to earn it."
In August 1981, the city and Mr. Hayes signed a consent decree, called "Callahan" after one of its plaintiffs, a hard-drinking, out-of-work short-order cook, that made New York the first city in the nation to guarantee each homeless man the bare necessities of shelter: a mattress, a pillow, clean sheets, soap, a roof over his head.
Koch regards his approval of the decree as one of his biggest mistakes. He handed the advocates a club they used to beat up on the city in court and in the press, he said.
Judge Wallach, who keeps a sketch of Mr. Hayes arguing before him hanging behind his desk, said of the decree: "It was uncharted sea. Of course it wasn't the ideal approach. But ideals and what's practically available are not the same. You've got to see it in light of the limited powers of the judiciary."
And Mr. Hayes, who helped found the Coalition for the Homeless, acknowledges its mixed results. "Have the shelters bred dependency?" he asked. "Absolutely. Have shelters saved lives? Definitely."
 
The Shelters
 Vast Armories And Seedy Hotels
 The suit -- which Mr. Koch addressed by sending thousands of homeless into barracks-style shelters and hotels -- created a huge bureaucracy and began a massive build-up that has proved difficult to undo.
The Dinkins Administration has made progress in opening more apartment-style shelters for families, but not enough to end use of hotels. Nor has it been able to close down the armories and other large shelters for individuals, though some of them have fewer residents.
The city faces one constant practical problem: no one wants a shelter in their neighborhood. The Koch Administration got around this by turning armories into shelters in the dead of night, busing in as many as 1,000 men to sleep on one vast drill floor.
With homeless families it chose a different tack, sending many into seedy, garish parts of midtown, where landlords willingly accepted troubled families in exchange for $2,000 -- about seven times the state's rental grant -- or more a month for a single dilapidated room.
The decision about the kind of shelter to offer was not made only out of political expedience. Mr. Koch believed the homeless were only entitled to minimal quarters, not better quarters than the working poor trying to make it without government aid.
Advocates continued to press for shelter as part of a calculated strategy that expanded the very system they so often condemned. Mr. Hayes believed the terrible conditions in shelters would embarrass the city into giving the homeless permanent apartments. To win public sympathy, advocates oversimplified homelessness.
"There was a discussion that went on among us all," said Marsha A. Martin, who served on the board of the Coalition for the Homeless. "Do you market it as a problem of shelter, or do you tell people about alcoholism, drug addiction, mental illness, concerns about child abuse?"
The problem was "marketed" as soluble with the simple provision of housing. In one television report, Mr. Hayes walked through Harlem saying the solution to homelessness was simple: "In three words, housing, housing, housing."
Meanwhile, the whirlwind of economic and social problems that caused so many to seek shelter only gained strength. Poverty deepened. The mentally ill went untended. Cocaine, as cheap rocks of crack, moved into the ghetto. AIDS was not far behind.
The number of people sheltered by the city has grown from 2,000 in 1980 to 24,000 now, the population of a small town.
 
The Regulations
 Further Demands But No Solutions
 As new shelters proliferated, so too did state regulations about how they should be run. City policy has been driven not so much by a coherent strategy for combatting homelessness as by the drive to open more beds and satisfy the rules, say city officials past and present.
The 1983 regulation that has most bedeviled the Dinkins administration says shelter "be provided immediately" to families.
It is no small irony that the state social services commissioner who approved that regulation is now a city official who faces contempt of court charges for failing to carry it out. Cesar Perales, Deputy Mayor for Human Services, has found his own orders impossible to follow.
Mr. Perales now says he did not mean to penalize the city for failing to place someone who applied for shelter at 11 P.M. by 8 the next morning. Instead, he said, he was thinking of other counties that had callouslyrefused to shelter people promptly.
His explanations only inflame former Mayor Koch. "Now, of course, he doesn't want any of these rules," Mr. Koch said. "That is why I have a minimum regard for Cesar Perales. When he was in the catbird seat he made our lives miserable."
City officials say they are also haunted by state policies that have fueled the homeless problem. The state has released tens of thousands of mental patients from hospitals in recent decades because of the advent of mood-leveling drugs and patient's rights suits, but never developed anywhere nearly enough group homes to care for them in communities. Many of these disturbed people have ended up on city streets.
And the state has only raised the monthly rental grant for families on welfare twice since 1975, making it hard for many to keep or get housing on their own. Governor Cuomo says the state cannot afford to increase the grant -- $286 a month for a family of three -- even though he has admitted it is not enough to pay for a garage, much less an apartment, in the city.
 
The Quandary
 Some See Lure To Enter Shelters
 When Mr. Dinkins came into office the city had already started providing permanent housing -- mostly rehabilitated apartments -- to homeless families, under the largest program of its kind in the country.
The program has given the city a way to get tens of thousands of families out of shelters, but Mr. Dinkins now believes it has had a pushmi-pullyu effect, also drawing many doubled-up families into the shelters as they looked for better housing.
The tricky job of balancing the number of people who come into shelter and the number who leave will be at the heart of any mayor's efforts to control the size of the shelter system.
Oddly, the city's housing effort, started in the mid-1980's, was not the result of some grand visionary plan. To the contrary, the city's effort to develop and rehabilitate thousands of permanent apartments for homeless families -- ultimately spending hundreds of millions of dollars -- was set in motion by an accident of fate: Wayne A. Stanton was watching television on a Sunday evening in 1986.
Mr. Stanton, soon to be the Reagan Administration official in charge of welfare programs, was sitting in his favorite leather chair in his living room when he tuned into 60 Minutes.
The episode, "Heartbreak Hotel," was about New York City "paying luxury rates for squalid, vermin-infested rooms in hotels." A tearful mother displayed her filthy room. (Mayor Koch remarked sarcastically, "We don't pay for maid service.)
But what really got Mr. Stanton's attention was this: the Federal Government had for years paid half the city's tab for putting thousands of families in the hotels -- about $70 million a year.
"I was horrified," he said recently. "I thought, 'My God, my department is paying for that?' "
 
30-Day Limit
 The next year, Mr. Stanton announced that the Government would stop paying for hotel stays of more than 30 days, even though many families had lived in these places a year or more. Congress delayed the cutoff, but the threat remained.
Mr. Koch said he felt he had no choice but to get families out of the hotels -- and the only way he could see to do it was to move them into permanent apartments. He personally thought that giving the homeless priority for housing was bad city policy.
And he warned that the city's ill-housed residents would pour into shelters in search of a permanent home. "If you build them, they will come," he said.
Despite his reservations, Mr. Koch felt compelled to mobilize the city's fractured bureaucracies to come up with thousands of apartments. With more homeless entering the shelter system, the city could not afford to lose the Federal millions, he said.
By the time, he left office the city had more than halved the number of families in welfare hotels, to about 1,500. But as Mr. Koch predicted, the housing did not end the crisis -- and still has not.
Koch visited a formerly homeless family in 1988 and described how well they lived in an op-ed piece for The New York Times. The mother and her children watched a large TV, with remote control and VCR, in a "tastefully furnished" living room.
 
Picking and Choosing
 He asked the woman why her family had spent years in welfare hotels. She told him she had turned down 19 apartments the city offered her until she found one to her liking. It galled Koch that she had been finicky when working poor families never had a chance at those apartments.
"Something has gone wrong," he wrote, "when people on public assistance have more choices than people who are making it on their own."
The advocates rolled their eyes at the hard-hearted Mayor. But two years later, when they came to power with Mr. Dinkins, they ran headlong into the same cul-de-sacs as their despised adversary.
Next: The Dinkins administration's path from idealism to pragmatism.

HEADLINE: Muted Reaction in District That Court Opposed

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C. July 2

 BODY:
From its vantage point, the Supreme Court defined the racial politics of North Carolina's 12th District, redrawn to elect a black member of Congress, in dire terms, likening it to "political apartheid." But those who live and work in the long and skinny district in the Carolina Piedmont view the issue in far more muted terms.
From the pungent-smelling tobacco warehouses to the rusty textile mills, people of both races joke about their amoeba-shaped district, which follows Interstate 85 linking predominantly black neighborhoods of Charlotte, Winston-Salem, Greensboro and Durham. What is termed "racial gerrymandering" in Washington, they call "the ketchup spill" here. 
 "Times have changed," said Renee Jarrett, a freshman at Johnson C. Smith University, a black college in Charlotte. "Whites are more likely to vote for blacks now, although the new district makes it less likely minorities will sit on their butts and not vote."
In an unscientific series of interviews with more than 30 citizens around the district, the fault lines seemed fluid or ambivalent. Some blacks broke with civil rights advocates by expressing discomfort with the concept of drawing political boundaries along racial lines.
 
Some Urban Unity
 And many whites, who make up more than 40 percent of the district, said they felt well served by their representative, Melvin Watt, a 47-year-old Democrat who is the first black to represent the region in Congress in this century. A few said that Mr. Watt actually reflected their views better than their former white representatives, who were attuned to rural areas.
Autrey Van Pelt, a 61-year-old clerk in the Gastonia city hall, who voted against Mr. Watt last November, said she was distressed by the notion of rezoning to favor blacks. Nevertheless, she said, "I don't feel like I'm less represented." Saying she had come to see the freshman Congressman in a new light, she added, "I can still vote and voice the way I feel."
But such reactions here may not be typical of those in more than a dozen other districts around the country, where minority representatives potentially face similar challenges from white voters claiming discrimination.
The textile centers of the North Carolina Piedmont have long been an oasis of relative racial harmony. Settled by Scottish and Irish farmers, the Piedmont was a Republican area that opposed secession during the Civil War. Many neighborhoods are integrated, and Charlotte twice elected a black mayor in the 1980's even though a majority of its population is white.
 
No Pressing Concern
 Though the High Court's ruling promises to be in court for months, there has yet to be any audible protest.
"It's not a matter of life and death," said Herbert L. White, managing editor of The Charlotte Post, an influential black newspaper. "There has been no discernible increase in racial tension."
The Post, a weekly, postponed for a week an article on the legal issues of the case, preferring to devote the immediate issue to opportunities for black businessmen if Charlotte attracts a professional football franchise.
Mr. White's editorial decision reflects a widely expressed attitude that seems to place a higher priority on economic issues than on racial considerations in the district.
To be sure, many blacks say they are proud of Mr. Watt, 47, who grew up in a tin-roofed shack without electricity. A few said they were more likely to turn to a black than a white Congressman for help. Still, some blacks say they still need an advantage at the ballot box to assure the election of representatives who share their concerns.
Linda Ramsey, a 41-year-old nurse's assistant, said, "I'm not a racist but I personally relate better to blacks." Visiting Mr. Watt's Charlotte office in appreciation for his help in seeking a Navy transfer closer to home for her son, she added, "We do need a black man to represent us because he knows where we're coming from."
 
Some Voice Complaints
 Some whites expressed misgivings that their choice at the ballot box now appears to be narrowed to only black candidates.
At the Carolina Steel Plant in Greensboro, where groups of blacks and whites sit at separate tables in the sweltering cinderblock mess hall, Gene Hurley called the reapportioned district "a lot of bunk."
The 55-year-old crane operator, munching potato chips on his dinner break, added: "It's violating the white voters' rights. That's democracy: you do it to them before they do it to you."
While getting a shave at the Spindle Center barber shop in Gastonia early Thursday morning, Charles Henderson, a 63-year-old retired telephone installer who is white, said: "There's a Dad Jim drunk that laid out the district because of the way it's shaped and what they tried to accomplish. As an old country boy, I say we had a pretty good system before this."
Virtually all residents of both races appear aware of the Supreme Court decision, which requires a lower court to reassess the complaints of five white litigants who claim the district's linking of otherwise distinct communities constitutes a racial quota system.
 
Contrast of Tones
 But few expressions of concern here, even by the harshest critics of the district's odd appearance or the Supreme Court's decision, echoed the sharp words in the Court's 5-to-4 decision.
In her majority opinion, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor thundered against "political apartheid," and suggested that "the North Carolina plan resembles the most egregious racial gerrymanders of the past."
In response, Mr. Watt called the decision "intellectually dishonest." He added, "The notion that a black Representative can't represent white folks is ridiculous."
The 12th district was created in 1991 because North Carolina had not had a black Representative since 1900. After the North Carolina Legislature created one minority district, the Justice Department ordered that a second be created to offer blacks representation in proportion to their 22 percent of the state population.
The case now goes to a special panel at Federal District Court in Raleigh. The state is expected to argue that there is a "compelling state interest" underlying the strange shape of the district: that urban dwellers as well as blacks deserve representation of their own in predominantly rural North Carolina.
Whatever the lower court's decision, the matter is likely to go back to the Supreme Court.
But more often than not, blacks and whites in this overwhelmingly Democratic district expressed their opinions about Mr. Watt and redistricting in economic, not racial terms.
If Mr. Watt's district is redrawn and he suddenly faces a serious challenge at the polls, he should think about taking up smoking. He is roundly unpopular at the sprawling R. J. Reynolds cigarette plant dotted with little plaques that say, "Thank you for smoking."
Inside the factory, speaking over the din of forklifts transporting freshly packed Winstons, Steven Floyd, a 39-year-old black machinist, said Mr. Watt would have to join other North Carolina representatives in fighting proposals to increase cigarette taxes to gain his support in the next election.
"I can live with the new district," he added, "but I wish they didn't have to create a district to have a black representative."

HEADLINE: Vermont Debates Value of Saving a Rural Image

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHREWSBURY, Vt.

 BODY:
Marjorie Pierce sat on the porch of her 158-year-old general store, gazing upon her garden of blue lupines, the lush meadow and the Green Mountains against the evening sky.
"It doesn't look endangered from here," said Miss Pierce, a former high school French teacher who celebrated her 90th birthday in May at the Town Hall with several hundred neighbors, including Senator James M. Jeffords. 
 But the view from Miss Pierce's hilltop store in Shrewsbury (population 1,800) is not the only window into Vermont. In June, the National Trust for Historic Preservation designated the state as one of America's 11 most "endangered historic places," the first time an entire state made the list.
The distinction -- although a symbolic one with no legal weight -- has fueled the debate over a fundamental question here: should Vermont be quaint forever? Or should it open the way to unpredictable development?
Can Vermont allow Wal-Mart to cross its borders and still be the mythic Vermont of small towns and gentle mountains? For now, Vermont, Hawaii and Alaska are the only states without a branch of the discount chain from Bentonville, Ark.
 
State With Identity Crisis
 To meander from the Vermont Book Shop in Middlebury to the old red brick City Hall in Rutland to the W. E. Pierce Country Store in Shrewsbury is to see a state with an identity crisis. To many people here, Vermont has been under siege for years, and these days, more cows can be found on T-shirts than in the pastures.
Miss Pierce sees the changes every time she gets into her 1966 Volkswagen and drives to Rutland (population 18,000), 10 miles away, to buy groceries at the Price Chopper. "They're talking about putting a mall just outside Rutland," she said. "I'm worried that there's too much development coming in, and that will bring a change in our life style."
That mall, along with Wal-Mart's plans to build two huge stores in Vermont, had much to do with the preservation group's decision to put this state on its list.
 
Change of Character
 "It clearly could change the nature and character of Vermont if they succeed in putting in these malls," said Richard Moe, the president of the nonprofit trust, adding that he had fallen in love with Vermont as a student at Williams College, just across the border in Massachusetts.
But character has not been paying the bills in Rutland. Mayor Jeffrey Wennberg says he appreciates the small-town charm of Vermont as much as any out-of-towner, or flatlander as they are called here. "I got married in Woodstock because the backgrounds are great," he said. "Woodstock is Hollywood's image of Vermont."
And it sells. Woodstock has a manicured village green, a covered bridge, antiques stores and $100-a-night bed and breakfasts where New Yorkers dream on four-poster beds with Laura Ashley sheets. Tourism is the state's third-largest revenue producer, after manufacturing and services.
Still, Woodstock is not Rutland.
Rutland is the shuttered stores of a once-vibrant downtown, and the General Electric jet-engine-parts plant, which has cut 500 of its 1,600 jobs since 1991. Rutland is people who buy Wilcox ice cream because it is cheaper than the Ben & Jerry's made in Waterbury by two millionaires from New York, and it is people who have to drive 55 miles to Glen Falls, N.Y., to buy a washing machine at Sears.
After a six-year battle with environmentalists, Mayor Wennberg hopes ground will be broken this summer on a $40 million shopping mall in Rutland that will include Sears, Kmart, J. C. Penney's and perhaps a Gap. "Even Vermonters need to shop," said the Mayor, a Republican who was recently elected to his fourth term.
More important, he said, the mall will mean 800 jobs, though they will be mostly part-time and will not pay anywhere near the $15 an hour General Electric pays.
 
Environmental Vanguard
 A lot of people were surprised that one of the country's most environmentally progressive states -- it was the first to ban billboards and the second to enact a bottle-deposit law -- ended up on the trust's 1993 list.
With a flair for the dramatic, Mr. Wennberg one day in June unrolled a 50-foot-long computer printout across the lawn of City Hall. It detailed the maze of state environmental regulations that the developer had to negotiate to win approval for its mall.
"Our regulations are beyond Byzantine," he said. Although he acknowledged that those regulations have helped keep Vermont relatively unspoiled, he and others say economic growth has been severely inhibited.
Miss Pierce, for one, misses the money she and her 79-year-old brother, Gordon, used to make pumping gas. The red pump their father put in at the general store around 1923 became a museum piece three years ago when state inspectors ruled that the gas tank had to be replaced by an environmentally correct, double-lined model. "We estimated it would have cost more than $15,000," she said. "And neither of us is going to live long enough to make that back."
Coincidental to the preservation group's ominous report, a poll made public in June by the Becker Institute of Massachusetts, a market-research organization in Sudbury, Mass., showed a drastic shift in Vermonters' attitudes toward the environment, with 54 percent of those surveyed ranking economic development as their top priority, while 40 percent put the environment first. Several years ago, the poll found that 58 percent of Vermonters listed strict environmental protection as their top priority, with only 35 percent listing economic development as a "very high" priority.
 
Preservation Too Costly
 "We can't afford to turn this into a social game preserve for the elite," Mayor Wennberg said, talking of the competition for economic development with states like New Hampshire.
But New Hampshire, with its condominium explosion, is just what many people here do not want Vermont to become. Noel Perrin, a writer who commutes by electric car from his home in Thetford Center, Vt., to his job as a professor of environmental studies at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., remarked, "New Hampshire is not on the endangered list because New Hampshire's already gone."
Still, Vermont is not a museum. Things change. Dike Blair plans to sell the legendary 45-year-old Vermont Book Shop in Middlebury, which Mr. Blair's friend, Robert Frost, patronized. The buyer, Mr. Blair said, is a lawyer from New Jersey "who has decided he wants to live in Vermont."
And in Woodstock, 88-year-old Larry Angwin was auctioning off the contents of his three-bedroom house: the beds, the china plates with painted roses -- and the Aug. 19, 1950 cover of the Saturday Evening Post, a Norman Rockwell illustration of a man in bed smoking a cigar and playing solitaire.
It was a picture of Larry Angwin 43 years ago. "I posed for him," said Mr. Angwin. "He paid me $5 by check. I never should have cashed it." This time around, the auctioneer bought the cover for $5.
The image of Vermont has a way of swallowing the reality. Across the brook from Mr. Angwin's house is a Victorian inn where a harpist plays during cocktails. And in May, when Mr. Angwin moved to a senior-citizen residence in Woodstock, the urban refugees who own the inn bought his house.

HEADLINE: China's Peasantry Takes Measure of Its Prosperity

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PAN SHI, China

 BODY:
Ignoring a light drizzle, the women emerged from their houses carrying small plates of potatoes, goose livers and pickled cucumbers, and placed them on tables clustered outside a shiny white three-story house.
The focus of attention was a tiny boy bundled up like a bushy red ball and cradled in the arms of his new mother. He had just turned one month old, a magic age in the hardscrabble Chinese countryside, traditionally signifying that a baby is likely to survive, and nearly a hundred peasants had come with gifts of little red packets bulging with money. 
 "He's the first son," said Mai Shunjing, the scrawny grandfather, as he let out a smile filled with broken teeth and big aspirations. "This is an important day for our family."
Half a dozen years ago, there would have been a similar celebration, but without the food, the money or the wine. Life has overwhelmingly improved over the last six years, even the last six months, for the 440 people in Pan Shi, a village in a land of rich, rolling rice paddies in southern China's Guangdong Province.
 
Well Off and Typical
 Pan Shi (pronounced pahn sher) is a bit wealthier than the average Chinese village, but customs and conditions here are still fairly indicative of how China's 900 million peasants -- three-quarters of the nation's population and nearly 17 percent of the world's -- go through life.
The great issues that absorb residents of Beijing, and through them catch the attention of the West, are of subdued interest here. The peasants seem little interested in challenging the Government on freedom of expression, for instance, preferring to put their energies into defying Government limits on having children.
They do not seem intrigued by macroeconomic questions, like whether China's economy now trails only that of the United States and Japan, but rather by such mundane matters as whether they will be able to afford running water instead of having to fetch water from a well.
Yet even here, the peasants feel vulnerable to what happens 1,000 miles away in the capital. The Communist Party's policies may change tomorrow. Or some official may arbitrarily decide to ruin one family or another.
"Our life is so much better now than before, but in China, you never can tell what the Government will do," said a young entrepreneur who runs a factory in another village. "I don't know how long this economic policy will last. So whenever I get the chance, I'm going abroad. Life is stable in America."
 
Knowing When to Clam Up
 While they may not know much about politics, the peasants here in Pan Shi know enough to clam up when the topic comes up. As the festivities for his grandson continued over a 10-dish banquet by the porch, Mr. Mai turned sheepish when asked what he thought about the growing gaps between the rich and the poor.
He managed a faint smile before mumbling something about there being no gaps at all. Immediately, however, his son came to his rescue, and Mr. Mai slipped away.
"We don't talk politics in this house," said Jinsheng, his 29-year-old elder son. "My father has suffered too much in his life, from the Cultural Revolution, from this and that movement.
"He is old and afraid. I don't want anything to happen to him again because of politics. I have to protect my father. If it weren't for him, I wouldn't be here today."
 
Politics Is Passive
 For most villagers, politics is not an interactive process but a passive one. A new political movement means that they must change the slogans on the village walls, or -- worse yet -- attend silly meetings instead of working the fields.
To be sure, the Government now holds elections for village chief, but only one person runs. That is partly because villagers cannot quite imagine a political race, and partly because it is no longer a very attractive position.
"Most people don't want to do that kind of work," said Chen Qiumei, a 33-year-old woman with two children, both boys. "The Government wants you to do a lot of work that offends other people."
A few others echoed her view. In a place where much of life is lived outside, there are few secrets. The village leaders often have take sides with one villager over another.
 
Spying for Family Planning
 The worst part is reporting on mothers who get pregnant for a second, third or fourth time. The village chief risks being regarded as a traitor for turning in his friends.
Mai Ruiqian, a 46-year-old sturdy fellow with a rounding stomach, became the new Mayor this year. He is a member of the Mai clan that dominates the village: nearly all men are named Mai, and only their wives, who came from other villages, have other surnames. It is common in China for a village to be made up of a single clan, and many villages are known only by the surname of the people who live there: the Mai Village, the Wu Village, and so on.
One sign that the job is not as enviable as it was in the past is that the last chief declined to run for a second term. Still, Mayor Mai says he has found a way around the difficulty of picking on his neighbors: He leaves the troublesome tasks to his superiors in the township government a few miles away.
"The township sends its family planning people here," Mr. Mai said, expressing relief that he does not have to worry much about it. "They have the family planning rosters."
 
A Phone but No One to Call
 Mr. Mai enjoys a few perks, like lunching in the township with officials nearly every day. But there are problems: arranging for water for crops and for more electricity to meet the growing demands of modernization. In a small triumph, the village also got a public phone recently; the only problem is that since few peasants have a phone, there is no one to call.
The phone, however, is a sign that the peasants are pretty well off in Pan Shi. Indeed, in addition to the public phone, two families have their own phones -- not including the Mayor.
Being moderately well off, in Pan Shi's case, means that peasants here earn an average of about $175 per person per year, instead of the national average for peasants of about $125. The figure may be a bit misleading because the peasants grow most of their food themselves and have few expenses.
Another reason they are doing well is that people throughout this region called Taishan have many relatives in Hong Kong, the United States and Canada. Taishanese is still a common dialect in Chinatowns in the United States, although in the last few decades it has been partly eclipsed by Cantonese and, more recently, Mandarin.
The gates to Pan Shi itself are a reminder of the overseas connection, having been built with money sent home from migrants abroad and carrying a tablet with the names of dozens of contributors.
 
Plastic for the Crops
 Still, it was only when someone here introduced a new farming technique -- protecting the vegetable crops with plastic covers -- that life for everyone seemed to get better. The plastic serves to keep moisture in the soil and protect the vegetables from freezing, and the practice has since become widespread throughout China.
Mai Caidong, 26, is among the new entrepreneurs who are branching in new directions. Not content simply to spend her days wading in the rice paddies or bending over the cabbages, she is taking advantage of opportunities to go into business.
Up at 3:30 A.M., she and her husband roar off on their motorcycle to the Taishan city center every day to sell fruit and vegetables, a business that brings them about $2,600 a year. Last year, they saved $1,700 of that in the bank, although Ms. Mai recently diversified her assets by investing some of that in a gold necklace from Hong Kong and other jewelry.
"They let us go into private enterprise, and most people don't feel bad if they stay behind in the village," said Ms. Mai, sitting in her clean, spacious living room. "Of course, my husband wants to go to Guangzhou and set up a rice shop."

HEADLINE: 3 More Victims of Serial Killer Are Identified

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., July 3

 BODY:
Two women who have been missing since 1991 and a third whose body was found on Monday were identified today by state police here as victims of a serial killer who the police say confessed to slaying 17 women.
The women came from varied backgrounds, with police saying that one was a methadone user who frequented Allen Street in Manhattan, a common haunt for prostitutes, while another was an unemployed accountant who lived at home with her family in Suffolk County. 
 But all of them, the police believe, were strangled over the last two years by Joel Rifkin, 34, an unemployed landscaper who appears to be the most prolific serial killer in New York history.
Mr. Rifkin, of East Meadow, was arrested on Monday morning after New York State Police discovered a woman's body in the back of his truck. Later that day, the police said he confessed to killing 17 women and dumping their bodies throughout the region, from Putnam County to the eastern tip of Long Island. Since then, law-enforcement officials have been trying to check his claims.
 
Link to 13 Killings
 This evening, the police said, they had identified the woman whose body was found in the back of Mr. Rifkin's truck as Tiffany Bresciani, 22, of Manhattan. She apparently was last seen on Allen Street around June 24. Several women there earlier in the week said she was a fixture on the street and was well-liked by the other women there.
The bodies of the other women, Lorraine Orvieto, 29, of Stony Brook, L.I., and Mary Ellen DeLuca, 22, of Valley Stream, L.I., were discovered more than a year ago in Brooklyn and Orange County, respectively. But they remained unidentified until this week. With today's announcement, troopers here in the State Police Barracks L said they had linked Mr. Rifkin to 13 killings and identified seven victims.
Both Ms. Orvieto's and Ms. DeLuca's families had reported to police that their daughters were missing almost two years ago.
"Why did it take this long to find out?" asked Florence Orvieto, Lorraine's mother, in a telephone interview this afternoon, choking back tears. For the last two years, she said, she had been saving Christmas presents for her daughter, who disappeared in December 1991. "I was waiting for her to come home," she said.
On Friday, the police called Mrs. Orvieto and told her that her daughter's body was found last July 11 in a 55-gallon oil drum in Coney Island Creek near Cropsey Avenue in Brooklyn. A cause of death has yet to be determined, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the New York City Medical Examiner.
Also on Friday, the police notified the DeLuca family that their daughter's body had been found in Cornwall, in Orange County, in October 1991, one month after she had been reported missing. The cause of death was not available today.
According to the police, the identities of both women were confirmed through dental records.
The police said that Lorraine Orvieto was petite, like many of the other victims, just under 5 feet tall and about 100 pounds. And as with the others whom Mr. Rifkin is accused of killing, a memento found in his room -- in this case, a driver's license -- helped police to discover the apparent connection to Ms. Ovierto's death.

HEADLINE: Base Closings Less Painful Than Feared

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
It was a disaster waiting to happen. For a region already mired deep in recession, the Government's plan to aggressively shut down military bases seemed certain to shower more economic distress on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
But by Friday, when President Clinton said he would support the recommendations of a Presidential commission to close 35 major bases across the nation, and sharply scale back others, some of the gloom in the New York region had begun to lift. 
 Compared with several states -- particularly California, Florida and Virginia -- job losses from the base closings in the New York region would be modest. And where the region's military installations are to close, on Staten Island and near New York's border with Canada, experts say there are promising alternatives in private development and business activity.
To be sure, the political storm has yet to subside. In a region whose three states routinely engage in fierce competition for jobs, New York has emerged a clear loser.
In New York City, Mayor David N. Dinkins condemned the base closing recommendations as an example of "homestate favoritism." He charged that New York State bases were unfairly targeted in favor of those in New Jersey because of the influence of James A. Courter, the former New Jersey congressman who presided over the panel, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission.
Others in New York may feel the heat of political embarrassment. One is Representative Susan Molinari, the Congresswoman from Staten Island, which is losing one of the Navy's most modern installations. Another is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who angered many last week by blaming the state's losses on bickering between local officials in Plattsburgh and Rome, where Air Force bases are to close or to be scaled back.
But amid the exchange of recriminations, many people say the region fared better than they expected.
"The mood here has been awfully bad for a long time, but maybe now things are turning around," said Mark Wolman, a building contractor in Waterford, Conn., one of the thousands of business people across the region whose prosperity is closely tied to the military.
His company is situated near one of the biggest, and most unexpected winners -- the Navy submarine base at New London. The plan backed by President Clinton not only reverses the Pentagon's recommendation to close the base, it expands base operations with additional training facilities and $100 million in construction by civilian contractors.
 
Mix of Gains and Losses
 Elsewhere in the region, there is a mix of gains and losses. McGuire Air Force Base in central New Jersey had been among the Pentagon's targets for closing; instead, under the President's plan, it would be expanded.
Some of the bad news was as much of a surprise as the good. In northern New York State, Plattsburgh Air Force Base, recommended as a survivor by the Pentagon, is to close under the commission plan, eliminating 2,850 jobs. Operations at Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome are to be sharply cut back.
But experts say that, in contrast to many bases elsewhere -- isolated outposts in deserts and remote rural areas -- those in the New York region have long been considered attractive locations for nonmilitary development. And some business people and economists maintain that "defense conversion" may as well get started now instead of later in the decade.
"We have a realistic opportunity to come out bigger and better and stronger," said Mark Barie, a business consultant and president of the Chamber of Commerce in Plattsburgh. The reason: Plattsurgh is close to the Canadian border, and might, like other cities nearby, attract several Canadian companies to the offices, distribution facilities and real estate to be vacated by the Air Force.
 
'Plenty of Negotiating Room'
 In Rome, officials say they might try to lure European aircraft manufacturers to the vacated areas of Griffiss Air Force Base.
"We are left with a tremendous amount of industrial capacity, and plenty of negotiating room," said Fred Tillman, a stockbroker in Rome, where the Griffiss work force, now 6,400 people, is to be reduced to 1,500.
The base closure commission's plan calls for the B-52 bombers now stationed at Griffiss to be sent elsewhere. All that would remain of the base is the Rome Laboratories, an intelligence research center.
Mr. Tillman, a retired Air Force colonel and former commander of the base, said the plan leaves ample opportunity for converting the vast B-52 hangars on the base, its maintenance shops and other facilities to civilian use.
"We can market these facilities around the world," he said, adding that potential buyers include commercial aircraft manufacturers in Europe who are seeking a United States base of operations.
 
Moving the Coast Guard
 In New York City, where the Navy's Staten Island Homeport is to close, the economic advisors to Mayor Dinkins say they might try to persuade the Coast Guard to move to the abandoned installation from Governors Island, freeing that strikingly scenic piece of New York Harbor real estate for a park, new housing or other development.
The idea was raised at a news conference last week by Representative Molinari, the Staten Island Republican, who said that a group would try to meet with the Transportation Secretary, Federico F. Pena, later this month. The Coast Guard is part of the Transportation Department, and the plan would involve moving nine cutters and 2,800 Coast Guard and civilian employees.
Another suggestion, from Representative Jerrold Nadler, a Manhattan Democrat whose district includes Governors Island, would make the Homeport part of a larger container shipping port on Staten Island and in Brooklyn.
 
Connecticut Benefits Most
 It is Connecticut that stands to benefit most, not only by the commission's recommendation to retain and expand the New London submarine facility, but by other welcome reversals in its huge aerospace and military industries in recent weeks.
"We know that defense is a declining industry, and it will continue to decline," said William A. McEachern, an economist at the University of Connecticut. "But it is refreshing to have some good news to talk about."
Federal studies show that 6.5 percent of Connecticut's civilian work force depends on defense contracts for its livelihood. By that measure, the state follows only Alaska, Hawaii and Virginia in its economic ties to the military.
In late June, the state was spared huge cuts by one of its largest aerospace concerns, Pratt & Whitney, which is shifting the focus of its jet engine manufacturing from the military to commercial aircraft.
With a promise of huge tax incentives from the state, Pratt & Whitney on June 23 won deep wage and work rule concessions from its biggest union and agreed not to shut down its biggest jet engine plant, in East Hartford. The agreement averted the loss of 2,000 jobs, which the company had said it would move to other plants in Maine and Georgia.
 
Good News in Groton
 Another corporate centerpiece in Connecticut, still reliant on military spending, is the Electric Boat division of General Dynamics Corporation, which manufactures submarines for the Navy in Groton. The company has cut its work force deeply over the last five years.
But over the last month, strong evidence has surfaced in Washington that the company's submarine yards in Groton will not be abandoned by the Navy. Electric Boat officials said last week that they had been informed by the Pentagon that their company was the leading contender for a contract to assemble the only new submarine the Navy plans to acquire in the next five years.
If the contract is won by General Dynamics, it would mean that the company would be well positioned to bid on a future generation of Navy submarines, which the Pentagon plans to begin ordering in 1998.
Even amid the good news for Connecticut, analysts cautioned that the state's reliance on military contracts will continue to make it vulnerable to economic setbacks, because further reductions in defense spending are expected for a decade or more. Indeed, Congress will required to review the nation's inventory of bases again in 1995 and make more cuts.
The recommendations endorsed by the President "are a plus" for the region, said Gary L. Ciminero, chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group, a bank holding company with operations in New York and Connecticut.
"But we are swimming upstream," he added. "The question remains how long it will take for the basic minuses of our dependence on the military to catch up with us, and we see more shrinkage."

HEADLINE: Race and the Workplace

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The article contributed (perhaps unwittingly) to the feelings of hostility and resentment on the part of white males against African-Americans, women and other groups whose economic opportunities have been historically limited because of racism, sexism and other isms that seek to legitimize hatred and bigotry. 
 The article states in part: "Efforts by companies to hire more minorities and women, often at the expense of white males . . . " (emphasis added). This characterization of societal attempts at ensuring equal opportunities is in itself a perpetuation of damaging stereotypes. It presupposes that whatever job or career opportunities exist are the province of white males and that anyone else who is placed in these jobs is encroaching on a property right of white males.
 
ROSALYN L. WILCOTS
Washington, June 21

HEADLINE: When Getting There Isn't Half the Fun

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER

 BODY:
MORE vacationers will be traveling on Connecticut's highways and back roads this summer than last, but with construction scheduled or already in progress on most of the state's major highways, how will motorists get from one place to another?
 "Very slowly. Cautiously," said an engineer with the State Transportation Department, Thomas Mangan. 
Automobile travel, which will account for 82 percent of all summer vacation trips nationwide, is expected to increase 6 percent from last year, according to the American Automobile Association. And Connecticut will undoubtedly reflect the national trend, said a spokeswoman for the Connecticut club, Annette Cormany.
 
Not Merely a Place to Pass Through
 Now that Connecticut is being promoted as a destination for tourists --rather than merely a place to pass through on the way to Massachusetts and Rhode Island -- groups like the Mystic Coast and Country Travel and Leisure Council have been meeting with transportation officials and legislators to stress the need to keep highways open during peak travel times and to schedule construction during the off season, said the council's director, Lou Camerota.
 The Transportation Department has assured the council that whenever possible, road work will be done outside rush hours and other periods of heavy traffic.
 "It's an educational issue that we're facing now," Mr. Camerota said. "Granted there are job contracts let out that we had no influence over. But for the future, we just want to sensitize the department to work with tourism. Whenever possible, the department has to be responsible to the economy." The Transportation Department notifies newspapers and radio stations before construction jobs are begun so that drivers can plan alternate routes, Mr. Mangan said.
 The list of improvements being undertaken this summer on both Interstate highways and state roads is lengthy. On Interstate 95 between Greenwich and Branford, for example, about 25 projects -- from bridge replacement to installation of lighting and noise barriers -- will be going on through November, said a department engineer, Paul Breen.
 The new Baldwin Bridge in Old Saybrook, which was opened in late May, should relieve weekend traffic along the shoreline. But additional work -- removal of sections of temporary roadway -- may cause minor disruptions throughout the summer, said a supervising engineer, Nicholas Rutherford.
 Work on the Gold Star Memorial Bridge over the Thames River in New London is expected to cause some weekend congestion, Mr. Rutherford added. "Based on what we have seen in the past, I would envision on Friday nights and Sunday nights some backups in New London because of the reduction in lanes on the bridge."
 Two projects involving resurfacing and safety improvements are planned on Interstate 395 between Exit 87, near Plainfield, and the Massachusetts state line. While the work is not expected to affect weekend travel, Mr. Rutherford said, there may be only one lane open in each direction for as much as a mile on weekdays. Interstate 395 is used to bypass New London on the way to Boston, Maine and northern shore points in Massachusetts.
 Most of Route 8 and Interstate 84 will be under repair, said another engineer, Peter Curcio. Travelers from New York State frequently take Interstate 84 to Boston or the Rhode Island beaches, and Route 8 is a major north-south road that extends from Bridgeport into Massachusetts.
 
Back Roads Vs. Highways
 Motorists who shun the major highways in favor of the more scenic back roads may meet up with construction on any of 28 to 30 bridges in towns from Ansonia and Avon to Canaan and Kent. Seven of the projects are on Route 7, which originates in Norwalk and extends north into Massachusetts and Vermont.
 "I have worked for the state for 31 years. We built a lot of roads but didn't do much to repair what was there. It has got to be done. Unfortunately, everything is being done at one time now," Mr. Curcio said.
 Officials of the Transportation Department listed other projects as well.
 * In Hartford, work on the interchange south of Interstate 91 and Interstate 84 near Founders Bridge. The project involves lowering the southbound lanes of Interstate 91 and rebuilding the bridge, which spans the Connecticut River.
 * Rebuilding the interchange at Interstate 91 and Route 3.
 * Building an interchange at Interstate 84 and Route 291 in the Manchester area.
 * Building a platform over Interstate 84 between Trumbull and Main Streets in downtown Hartford.
 * Repairing and resurfacing on Interstate 84 from Tolland to Union.
 * Repairing and resurfacing on Interstate 384 from East Hartford to Bolton.
 * Repairing roads and bridges on Interstate 91 from the south end of Hartford to Wethersfield.
 In addition, pavement markings, generally one- or two-day jobs in each location, will be done on most of the state's roads.
 Mr. Mangan said the Transportation Department tries to send out notice of road projects two weeks before the starting date. "That has softened a lot of the complaints," he said.
 Travel counselors in the Connecticut motor club's office in Branford said they, too, are given information about construction sites on the state roads and mark those places on the routes they map out for their clients. They also try not to send traffic through small towns, said Constance Chieppo, the office manager. "There are little-town folks who don't want 90 million people going through their town."
 
Three-Day Trips
 Mrs. Chieppo said people are staying at home and taking two- or three-day tours rather than longer trips. "We're going to see a lot more motor traffic than last year."
 Whether to sit in a line of traffic at a construction site or head for one of the back roads is a matter of choice, Mrs. Chieppo added, and travel counselors leave the final decision up to their clients. "Some people don't mind sitting in traffic. Sometimes you're better off doing that than going on a two-lane highway where the traffic is stop-and-go."
 Edward Dombroskas, director of the tourism division of the State Department of Economic Development, said his office has worked out a communications system with transportation officials and local groups promoting tourism so that problems concerning travel are resolved quickly. Some road work will be done at night rather than during the day and, depending on the type of project, work hours may be split to keep roads open during heavy traffic.
 Meanwhile, Mrs. Hoffman said Mystic will attract tourists in spite of the orange cones and Jersey barriers on the highway. "We will wind up with the same number of visitors. They just might be more frazzled."
