HEADLINE: Focus: Seattle;
Transforming a Rundown Lake Shoreline

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
HIGH-TECH and research companies are transforming a neglected industrial area on the southern shores of a 6,718-acre lake a mile north of the downtown into a desirable workplace.
One of them, the fast-growing ZymoGenetics, planning to expand its biomedical research, is spending $25 million to restore the landmark Lake Union Steam Plant, Seattle City Light's first powerhouse, which produced electricity until 1983. 
 Bruce Carter, the company's president, said he had chosen the Lake Union area so he could collaborate easily with scientists at the University of Washington and the downtown medical community.
ZymoGenetics was founded in 1981 by university faculty members. Its parent company, Novo Nordisk, the Copenhagen pharmaceutical giant, depends on its subsidiary for research that will lead to developing such products as genetically engineered insulin.
"We have someone from the university in our facilities every day," said Dr. Carter. "It's important that we be close by."
The university, homes and houseboats line Lake Union's northern shore and Portage Bay, part of the lake's seven-mile perimeter. A few blocks east is Interstate 5; to the west, mansions and condominiums perch high above the shoreline on the steep slopes of Queen Anne Hill. Just beyond the lake's west shore the landmark Space Needle caps the skyline overlooking ferries plying Puget Sound.
Until recently, locating on the southern shore of Lake Union would have been unthinkable. The lake view was blocked by large moored ships. Factories sprawled along the water, among them a large cement plant that sent plumes of dust into the air and dumped slurry into the water. In the early 80's dilapidated buildings were everywhere.
"The place was a mess," said Richard Wagner, an architect who was one of the first to see the lake's potential. "The old-time businesses, including an asphalt plant and glass factory, were dying or outgrowing the area."
But in the mid-80's the ships began finding other moorings, factories pulled up stakes and developers moved in, tearing down dilapidated buildings.
Mr. Wagner has since built the Center for Wooden Boats, which rents turn-of-the-century wooden sailing boats to tourists.
Restaurants were among the first wave of new businesses to come in in the last 10 years. Bill Schwartz, president of Schwartz Brothers Restaurants, has opened three, including two in Chandlers Cove, a retail development that now occupies the cement factory land.
"We own 16 restaurants and I think Lake Union is our best location in Seattle today," he said. "It's close to the downtown, parking and the freeway."
Inn Ventures Inc. of Seattle was attracted by the restaurants and in 1991 opened a Marriott Residence Inn. "Building a residential hotel on a lake is like having a mini-resort in the middle of the downtown," said Denise Books, regional manager for Inn Ventures.
ZymoGenetics, now in the university district about four blocks northeast of Lake Union, was one of the companies Marriott was targeting. "We go after the high-tech companies because visiting scientists will need a place to stay while working on projects for two to three months," Mrs. Books said.
Companies then started to expand by the lake. Cellular One opened its headquarters nearby and a Seattle software company, Walker Richer & Quinn, is moving in soon.
MR. CARTER was searching for a Lake Union site when a developer, William Justen, of the local Koll Company, took him to see the powerhouse, which Mr. Justen had bought in 1991 and had planned to convert into a $21-million condominium. A lack of financing forced him to abandon that plan.
Mr. Carter was immediately interested. "It was desolate, with its ornate windows broken out," he said. "Yet with its interior support columns it looked like a European cathedral at the end of World War II. I saw that it could be transformed."
The 90-foot-long, 316-foot-wide building is a designated landmark, so architectural restoration, by Daly & Associates of Seattle, will follow guidelines of the Seattle Landmark Preservation Board. Koll, which still owns the land, is directing the development.
Interior design, by NBBJ Architects of Seattle, will put lab areas and offices for scientists along the lakeside walls of the building to take advantage of sweeping water views. When work is completed in 1994, the five-story building will have 113,000 square feet of usable space, plus basement parking for 190 cars.
Another reason for the interest of ZymoGenetics in the site was that the $83-million, 300,000-square-foot Fred Hutchison Cancer Research Center was being built just down the block by a joint venture of Koll Construction and Baugh Construction of Seattle; the first phase is complete and it eventually will occupy 10 acres embracing 42 separate parcels that Mr. Justen had amassed for Koll.
The cancer center was growing rapidly and occupied 12 scattered buildings, most in a medical-complex area on the eastern edge of downtown. Karen Lane, the senior vice president of development for the cancer center, said, "We have close connections with Swedish Hospital downtown and the university and wanted a place in between. Our researchers needed to be in one building where they can interact."
City Councilman Jim Street, who played a key role in helping ZymoGenetics get the zoning changed from industrial to industrial/ commercial -- to provide for research and development -- said he believed that it and Fred Hutchison would be the anchors to attract other biotech companies to the south lake area. Selling industrial expansion in the south lake area to local residents was not easy. But after several public meetings -- and ZymoGenetic's promise to build a floating public walkway and dock suitable for kayaks and canoes -- opposition abated and the project moved forward.
On a recent "wharf rat's boat tour" of the lake, Paul Marlow, an associate at the Wooden Boat Center, said it was apparent that marinas were popping up as part of the new development.
"New moorage is important to many people who do not want to see traditional marine business disappear," said Mr. Marlow. The restaurants and new property owners are adding berths for yachts to the ends of their properties to defray costs and to provide badly needed space for boats.
SOME traditional uses will continue, too. The Lake Union Dry Dock, next to ZymoGenetics's property, still repairs ships. Nearby, large fishing vessels are at anchor, waiting for the season to resume in mid-July. And a fleet of ancient mothballed tugs -- whose owner, worried that they'll be used by a competitor, won't sell -- is berthed there.
Another proposed development, Seattle Commons, now in the conceptual stage, is sparking interest in the area. The Commons, to be built by the city, would be an 85-acre greenbelt stretching the dozen blocks between Lake Union and the northern end of the downtown in a three-block-wide swath. A community plan is in the works that would flank the park with residential, office and commercial projects to be built by many developers.
Joel Horn, the project director, said the idea was "to create an urban village where people could live, play and walk or bicycle to work and not need cars." Many of the companies are expected to be biomedical and high-tech.
Parking lots occupy about 45 percent of this space today and low-rise warehouses and stores account for the rest. The Commons is starting to acquire parcels through a $20-million "seed money" loan from Paul Allen, one of the founders of Microsoft, based in nearby Redmond, that will be repaid by the city. Says Mr. Horn, "we've been buying up land like crazy at low prices."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Transforming the Shore of a Seattle Lake

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
High-tech and research companies are transforming a neglected industrial area on the southern shores of a 6,718-acre lake a mile north of the downtown into a desirable workplace.
One of them, the fast-growing ZymoGenetics, planning to expand its biomedical research, is spending $25 million to restore the landmark Lake Union Steam Plant, Seattle City Light's first powerhouse, which produced electricity until 1983. 
 Bruce Carter, the company's president, said he had chosen the Lake Union area so he could collaborate easily with scientists at the University of Washington and the downtown medical community.
ZymoGenetics was founded in 1981 by university faculty members. Its parent company, Novo Nordisk, the Copenhagen pharmaceutical giant, depends on its subsidiary for research that will lead to developing such products as genetically engineered insulin.
"We have someone from the university in our facilities every day," said Dr. Carter. "It's important that we be close by."
The university, homes and houseboats line Lake Union's northern shore and Portage Bay, part of the lake's seven-mile perimeter. A few blocks east is Interstate 5; to the west, mansions and condominiums perch high above the shoreline on the steep slopes of Queen Anne Hill. Just beyond the lake's west shore the landmark Space Needle caps the skyline overlooking ferries plying Puget Sound.
Until recently, locating on the southern shore of Lake Union would have been unthinkable. The lake view was blocked by large moored ships. Factories sprawled along the water, among them a large cement plant that sent plumes of dust into the air and dumped slurry into the water. In the early 80's dilapidated buildings were everywhere.
"The place was a mess," said Richard Wagner, an architect who was one of the first to see the lake's potential. "The old-time businesses, including an asphalt plant and glass factory, were dying or outgrowing the area."
But in the mid-80's the ships began finding other moorings, factories pulled up stakes and developers moved in, tearing down dilapidated buildings.
Mr. Wagner has since built the Center for Wooden Boats, which rents turn-of-the-century wooden sailing boats to tourists.
Restaurants were among the first wave of new businesses to come in in the last 10 years. Bill Schwartz, president of Schwartz Brothers Restaurants, has opened three, including two in Chandlers Cove, a retail development that now occupies the cement factory land.
"We own 16 restaurants and I think Lake Union is our best location in Seattle today," he said. "It's close to the downtown, parking and the freeway."

Our researchers needed to be in one building where they can interact."

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1587 words

HEADLINE: New Rochelle's Fear: Sidetracked by Amtrak

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE

 BODY:
AS Amtrak proceeds with plans to develop its Northeast Corridor for high-speed service between New York City and Boston, officials here fear that plans to revitalize the city's struggling downtown may get sidetracked in the name of progress.
For Amtrak, the stop at the busy station here, which it shares with Metro-North Commuter Railroad, has become a scheduling nightmare, a bottleneck at which trains meet frequent delays and Amtrak engineers often have to negotiate complicated track crossovers with Metro-North before continuing to the next destination. 
 Amtrak -- a private corporation that gets about 20 percent of its budget from the Federal Government and is under a Congressional mandate to operate the country's intercity rail passenger service -- wants to build a new station at Nardozzi Place, about two miles away in the southwest section of the city.
 
Trip of Under Three Hours Sought
 The railroad hopes to triple the number of trains it runs between New York and Boston and shorten the time for the express run. Its eventual goal is to reduce the express trip from four hours to less than three, and it hopes to achieve the time reduction with a series of measures.
Those measures include electrifying the system from New Haven to Boston and reconfiguring tracks in New Haven and New Rochelle. That would in turn allow the use of high-speed trains.
An important element of Amtrak's Northeast Corridor High-Speed Rail Improvement Project for its New York-to-Boston run is shaving time off the stop at New Rochelle.
The railroad's plans, however, may not be in the city's best interests, at least the way Mayor Timothy C. Idoni sees it. "Amtrak may be trying to save two or three minutes," he said, "but we're trying to save a city."
The proposal to reroute Amtrak traffic would divert travelers and therefore spending power -- what some city planners call "a critical mass of bodies" -- away from the downtown business district.
A city that has lost several large department stores -- Macy's last year and Bloomingdale's and Arnold Constable in the 1970's -- and has seen its major business district fall into decline as a result, must now call a halt to the exodus of "revenue-generating enterprises," the Mayor said.
The Appropriations Committee of the United States House of Representatives last week directed Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, to find a way to update the current station to meet its growing needs rather than move elsewhere.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, a member of the Appropriations Committee and a Democrat from New York's 18th District, which includes New Rochelle, said: "If they move, it's going to be another blow for New Rochelle. We're not asking Amtrak to do the impossible. We're just saying, slow down and think this through."
Planners here have described New Rochelle as a typical "Main Street, U.S.A.," a downtown area of city streets with small and medium-size retail stores that lost out in recent years to the development of larger regional shopping centers.
 
Business Siphoned Off
 "What cities faced across the country, especially during the recession, happened in New Rochelle also," said Joseph G. Madonna, the city's Commissioner of Development. "Now we're trying hard to make a comeback."
In Westchester, a number of major department stores have located in White Plains, where plans are underway to expand several shopping malls and bring in yet more department stores. Also, many discount outlets and smaller chain stores are situated in strip malls along Central Park Avenue, which cuts a north-to-south swath through the center of the county from White Plains to Yonkers. Both types of shopping areas have drawn business away from older city centers.
In New Rochelle, at the downtown mall where Macy's was the key anchor, the number of retail stores has dropped from 64 to 50 since Macy's left last summer, and the merchants who are still there "are struggling along" to stay in business, Mayor Idoni said.
Now a proposal by a developer to build a multiplex movie theater and an ice-skating rink there and bring in a Bradlee's department store where Macy's once was could turn that around, the Mayor said.
 
Haven From Terrorists
 Also, the city is negotiating with Unicef to place its headquarters on Huguenot Street, also in the downtown area. If New Rochelle's proposal is accepted, the United Nations would build a 440,000-square-foot office building for Unicef. There has been discussion, too, of plans to locate an international conference center and other United Nations agencies here.
In light of the discovery last month of terrorist plans to bomb United Nations headquarters in New York, along with other buildings, Mayor Idoni suggested that a new high-security building outside of Manhattan, but still within a 25-minute train commute, would be an advantage to the agency. Unicef is expected to choose between plans offered by New Rochelle and New York City by late summer.
Also, city officials said that a New York City developer is considering a two-acre parcel of land near the proposed Unicef site for an apartment building that could house United Nations workers.
Mr. Madonna explained that city leaders here are attempting to put together a number of revitalization projects for this city of 67,265 residents. "Hopefully," the Commissioner said, "we're on the verge of some major development breakthroughs."
 
Convenience a Factor
 Anticipating increased parking needs, the city has proposed building a 1,000-space garage next to the Depot Place station with spaces set aside for Amtrak riders. Construction of the garage would be paid for with a combination of Federal, private and local funds. A bus depot and centralized taxi stand would be situated there also, making the Depot Place location what planners call an "intermodal station."
In addition to the city, Metro-North representatives say they, too, have a vested interest in keeping Amtrak where it is.
"The whole idea is to make everything as convenient as possible for the traveler," said Daniel Brucker, a spokesman for Metro-North, which is a division of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a public corporation run by the state. "We call it seamless mass transportation. It keeps passengers using trains and thinking trains because everything is accessible and interconnected."
But Amtrak officials are frustrated by the current setup at the train station here, explaining that two of its tracks from Pennsylvania Station converge with four Metro-North tracks from Grand Central Terminal, and Amtrak trains are restricted to a speed limit of 15 miles an hour at the interlocking point. Also, Amtrak trains bound for New York must cross three sets of Metro-North tracks before getting on their southbound line.
 
Planning for the Year 2030
 Amtrak, which operates passenger service in 45 states and covers 25,000 route miles, wants to build its own station on land it owns on Nardozzi Place and increase the number of its trains that travel through New Rochelle each day from 30 to 68. It also hopes to more than double the number of riders getting on or off at New Rochelle on the New York-to-Boston run to 170,000 from 80,000.
"We're not just looking at the year 2010," said David J. Carol, project director for Amtrak's high-speed rail improvement program. "We're trying to plan for the year 2030 and beyond."
The program calls for construction of a $60 million flyover, a bridge that would elevate Amtrak's tracks above Metro-North's in New Rochelle and allow passengers to board and disembark at the Nardozzi Place station.
For those 500 Amtrak passengers a day who are projected to get on or off at Nardozzi Place, the rail company cites the convenience of shopping at the new location, where the Home Depot -- a building supply and home-improvement chain -- intends to build a 164,000-square-foot retail outlet and garden center and where a shoppers'-club store may be locating.
 
'Very Little Interchange'
 But New Rochelle leaders, among them Mr. Madonna, dispute that argument. "Who would take the train to buy a sink or lumber?" he said. "That's the kind of store one drives to."
Opponents of Amtrak's plan also say that Westchester travelers bound for Washington or Philadelphia would no longer have the convenience of boarding a Metro-North train in Rye, for example, and switching to an Amtrak train in New Rochelle. They would have to take the Metro-North train to Grand Central Terminal and then take the subway or a bus or a taxi to Pennsylvania Station to pick up an Amtrak train.
But R. Clifford Black, director of public affairs for Amtrak, said that New Rochelle is considered an area of "very little interchange," with only 1 percent of the 80,000 passengers a year who get on or off the Amtrak line at that stop actually transferring to other trains.
Upgrading the current station at Depot Place would entail separating some tracks and constructing a center island to be shared by Metro-North and Amtrak.
Both plans, upgrading Depot Place or building a new station, would cost $66 million, Amtrak officials estimated.
Ms. Lowey said that the Appropriations Committee has directed Amtrak and Metro-North "to work together to find a solution that meets New Rochelle's needs while expanding Amtrak's service."
Amtrak and Metro-North have agreed to report back to the Appropriations Committee in August on their conclusions about using the present station.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Passengers, left, boarding an Amtrak train at the New Rochelle station, above. In an effort to reduce the time a train is stopped at a station, Amtrak is considering moving to a new location in the city where it would not have to share tracks with Metro-North trains. (Photographs by Susan Harris for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Broad Strokes Revive Interest in Whales

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
SPERM whales made New London famous 150 years ago. Sailing vessels returned to the southeastern Connecticut port on a regular basis, their holds filled with oil that had been rendered from the behemoths of the sea. Now, city officials are hoping that sperm whales will make the city famous again, but in a different way.
 The environmental artist known simply as Wyland will be in New London from Tuesday to next Monday to paint a mural on the 220-by-25-foot-wall of a building that faces Eugene O'Neill Drive. The stop in New London is part of his four-month tour of the East Coast to paint whaling walls, as these depictions of cetaceans are known. His tour will take in 17 cities in 16 states. Florida will be the only state to get two of the walls, one in Sarasota and one in Key West. 
The artist's whaling walls -- there will be 50 around the world by the time the summer's tour is finished -- show various species of whales and dolphins painted life-size with an airbrush. Wyland works from 8 A.M. until dusk, and finishes them in a week.
 
'Like a Science Project'
 "By painting them life size, you really get your audience to appreciate them," Wyland said. "The kids go up and measure themselves against the whales, and really get them into perspective. It's like a science project for a lot of these kids."
 In every city where he paints, children congregate around his project, peppering him with questions about marine mammals and his painting techniques. People are often amazed he can finish his murals, which always take up thousands of square feet, because he takes time out to answer the youngsters' questions.
 "They know so much about marine sciences already, it's amazing," Wyland said. "And that's what we need, to encourage that kind of study, because the better they understand the oceans the more they're going to be committed to saving them."
 In New London Wyland will paint his life-size mural on the wall of the American Discount Store, at the corner of Eugene O'Neill Drive and State Street, one of the busiest intersections in the city.
 
Official State Animal
 "It's not the largest wall on the tour, but it's large enough to do some sperm whales, which is appropriate since it's the official state animal," said Wyland, who 36 years ago was born Robert Thomas Wyland, but had his name legally changed to just Wyland.
 Ezra E. Shalam, one of the principals of American Discount Stores, said he was a bit wary when he was approached by city officials about allowing someone to paint an environmental art mural on his building. Then he saw a video of Wyland's work, and a folder of his paintings. "After I saw that, I was convinced. His work is outstanding, incredible," Mr. Shalam said. "We believe in downtown New London, and we're delighted to be part of this."
 Wyland said he chose New London at the request of Dr. Robbins Barstow of Wethersfield, director emeritus of the Cetacean Society International. Dr. Barstow was one of the chief lobbyists to name the sperm whale as the state animal in 1972, despite an early lead by advocates of the white-tailed deer.
 Dr. Barstow said he and his wife were in Hawaii in 1988 and saw a humpback whale mural Wyland had done. "At that time, it was the largest mural in the world," Dr. Barstow said. "We were tremendously impressed."
 
Symbol of Transition
 Dr. Barstow said in 1989, while attending the meeting of the International Whaling Commission in San Diego, he ran into Wyland again. The artist was part of a crowd of protestors outside the meeting, and Dr. Barstow asked him to come to Connecticut. When he found out about the East Coast tour he called New London officials and put into motion plans to get the mural painted in that city. "We're trying to symbolize the transition from whale killing to whale watching and whale conservation," Dr. Barstow said.
 "New London used to be known as the whaling city," he said. "More ships went out of New London in the 1840s looking for whales than any other port except New Bedford. And there were more whaling millionaires in New London than in any other city in the country."
 
Maritime Theme Festival
 New London officials are pleased that Wyland has chosen that city for one of his murals, particularly because Wyland's visit will take place the same time as Sail Fest, the city's annual maritime theme festival.
 The economic development coordinator for New London, Philip N. Biondo, said that as many as 250,000 people visit the city during Sail Fest, and he hopes the number will increase this year because of the mural. "It can't be anything but positive in terms of bringing people to New London," he said, "and hopefully, they'll come to see the whaling wall and stay to see the rest of the city. We need to do more to emphasize our maritime heritage,"
 New London public works crews will clean the wall, and apply some sealer and primer donated by local companies. The Holiday Inn, Radisson and Lighthouse Inn in New London have all offered rooms to Wyland and his entourage. Other businesses are offering anything else the crew will need. "A lot of the downtown merchants are very excited about it," Mr. Biondo said. "It'll help bring people in, but it will also make the downtown more beautiful, and it will foster more environmental awareness."
 
'New Artistic Dimension'
 "It's going to add a whole new artistic dimension to the downtown, and extend what the city is trying to do in terms of promoting New London's maritime heritage," said Michael H. Lamperelli, director of the Marine Commerce and Development Commission, which works to promote New London.
 During Sail Fest the city will also have a 62-foot painting of Prince William Sound on loan from the Governor of Alaska, and other environmental and maritime art, Mr. Lamperelli said. But the whaling mural will be the centerpiece of the display, he noted, and it should last for many years -- one of ocean waves painted a few hundred feet away has lasted since the mid-1970s, he said.
 "More than anything it's going to create an uplifted image for the downtown," Mr. Lamperelli said. "It's beginning to look more like a historic port, with the work the city has done like putting the utilities underground and installing some old-fashioned street lamps, and this is going to advance that."
 Mr. Lamperelli said also during Sail Fest, the city will have a living history program including a whaling sailor from Mystic Seaport, at the Nathan Hale Schoolhouse, which is on State Street within sight of where the wall will be painted.
 
Today's Thinking
 "Things change," Mr. Lamperelli said. "The whaling trade in New London was never intended to hurt the whales. People thought the supply was endless. Our area has been very environmentally conscious, doing what it can to clean up the Thames River and clean up Long Island Sound. I think having the whaling wall in New London is very much in line with today's thinking."
 Wyland agreed that there is no irony in the fact that one of his walls, which are dedicated to preservation and protection of whales, will be in a city once renowned for killing whales.
 "The present is different," Wyland said. "People are interested in saving the whales today. At that time there was a lot of whaling, because they were seen as a product. Today they're a thing of beauty that is worthy of protection."
 Wyland noted that he did four whaling walls in Japan, where boats are still whaling in the name of research. His first wall there was in 1987 on a wall visible from Tokyo Bay, and now boats are embarking from the bay on whale-watching excursions, and people are starting to talk about eliminating whaling.
 "It's a small movement, but it's happening," Wyland said. "If we just keep reinforcing that the whales are important as living creatures, even the older people will get it."
 "There's probably more money now in whale watching than there ever was in whaling," he added.
 Wyland said his first view of whales came in 1971, when he saw them migrating off California. Wyland attended art classes at Motown's Center for Creative Studies from 1975 to 1979, and found his niche in the early 1980s when he began painting the animals that so impressed him.
 Today Wyland and his galleries employ 200 people, and his paintings can sell for more than $100,000. But he gives the murals to the cities where he paints them, and many people say they are his finest work. People who have seen his walls often comment on how lifelike the creatures look, particularly their eyes, which seem to have the depth and soul of real whales.
 
Capturing the Spirit
 "I try to capture the spirit of the animal," Wyland said. "If people see the beauty in nature, they'll work hard to preserve it."
 Wyland said while Dr. Barstow encouraged him to choose New London for his Connecticut mural, his first meeting with New London officials convinced him that it should be there.
 "There's extraordinary support wherever I go, and it keeps me real pumped up," Wyland said. "But there's no other city on the tour that's more enthusiastic than New London. If I have that kind of support and commitment, I'm going to do it."

SECTION: Section 5; Page 19; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1298 words

HEADLINE: Traveling Close, Very Close, to Home

BYLINE: By SUZANNE BERNE; SUZANNE BERNE writes often about travel.

 BODY:
THE first time I realized that it was possible to travel at home, I was 6 years old and standing in the linen closet of a rented house on Cape Cod. It was an old drafty house by a bay, full of camphor-smelling eaves and corners and unexpected doorways, and one foggy afternoon I slunk about the shadowy upstairs picturing myself in the Black Forest. My grandfather had been to the Black Forest, and from his description I envisioned a mossy, Grimm's-fairy-tale sort of place, not so different from the dark upper hall with its peeling fern-colored wallpaper. That afternoon it had taken me an hour to reach the linen closet, which served as a remote Bavarian castle, and by the time I finally arrived after hiking through the hallway I was worn out. When my mother found me recovering by the pillowcases a few minutes later she asked what I'd been doing, and I told her: "Traveling." She seemed to accept this statement at face value and, from that moment on, so did I.
What I discovered from those foggy afternoons was that home can be a wide and varied place, and that a person may be a seasoned traveler without necessarily leaving the backyard. While some believe traveling means going far away -- imagining that a trip to Bangkok is travel while a trip to the park is not -- others recognize that travel, like relaxation, is mostly a state of mind. The wanderer wanders wherever he is. Naturally, the inverse must also be true. Just as some people can't relax, some cannot travel, no matter where they find themselves. Look at the commuter who drives 75 miles a day, then says he hasn't gone anywhere in months. Or the business person who flies to Rome and then never leaves her hotel. And what about the delicate soul who ventures forth only when the weather is clement, the accommodations posh, the sights acclaimed -- is this travel, or resting away from home? 
 Travel, in my opinion, is one part locomotion and three parts the desire for discovery. It should set the mind going. Which is why a stroll around the block can be as invigorating a journey for the determined discoverer as a junket around the globe. To know one place well is to travel deeply, continuously. To know one place altogether is impossible; it can take a lifetime, after all, to navigate an acre if you proceed inch by inch. Not that most of us will ever roam that closely, but the opportunity is there. Consider Emily Dickinson, who rarely left her house and yet traveled so extensively inside of it that critics are still retracing her footsteps. A poem about one of her adventures begins:
 
 I started early, took my dog,
 And visited the sea;
 The mermaids in the basement
 Came out to look at me.
Dickinson is, perhaps, an extremist, the domestic equivalent of Marco Polo. Yet one doesn't have to be a recluse to voyage at home. While he lived at Walden Pond, Henry David Thoreau treated his visits to nearby Concord Village as if they were brief sojourns on the Continent. "It was very pleasant," he notes, "when I stayed late in town, to launch myself into the night, especially if it was dark and tempestuous, and set sail from some bright village parlor . . . for my snug harbor in the woods." He called the scatter of ponds around Concord "my lake country," and there he wandered, viewing the flora and fauna, keeping a record of strange sights, his Grand Tour on the banks of Walden. One afternoon he might watch ants battle by his woodpile, emerging as shaken and excited as any foreign war correspondent; the next he might sit by the railroad tracks, sniffing the cinder-struck air, musing on the vagaries of international commerce based on a whiff of salt fish. "I have traveled much in Concord," he observed, and it's hard to think of anyone who has ventured farther.
Some of the most stirring travel accounts I've ever read, in fact, have been written by people who stayed right at home. Aldo Leopold's "A Sand County Almanac," his description of 12 months on a Wisconsin sand farm, treats each season as its own location, with its own particular attractions, citizenry and customs. He pays special attention to the trees he encounters on his rambles, and reports the startling news that, "There is much small-talk and neighborhood gossip among pines," surely as intriguing a bit of information as anything in Frommer's.
A quarter of a century later, Annie Dillard describes her exploration of one "rather tamed valley" in Virginia with a gusto that makes Lewis and Clark seem timid. "It's all a matter of keeping my eyes open," she writes in "Pilgrim at Tinker Creek." And so she turns a morning's saunter into a trek, with starlings, frogs and praying mantis egg cases crowding her rural landscape like so many exotic acquaintances. "I would like to know grasses and sedges -- and care," reflects Dillard. "Then my least journey into the world would be a field trip." Once while crouching on a log she became so bedazzled by a spot of Tinker Creek that she fell in.
Keeping one's eyes open, occasionally falling in astonishment into a creek or a gutter, obliges one to recall that adventure happens in small places as well as large. "I explore the neighborhood," declares Annie Dillard, with the same passion Columbus must have felt when coming upon the New World. At heart, an expedition is no more than a trip undertaken to see or do something -- and what that something is usually matters less than the spirit in which the trip is made. Which is not to say that journeys to France and Peru and the Grand Canyon aren't wonderful, or that everyone should stay at home all the time. Only that where one lives should be treated with the same inquisitiveness as anywhere one might go.
IN my own case, although I no longer travel by way of linen closets, I do wander locally for most of my excitement. This has a bit to do with economic considerations, but even more to do with my conviction that if a second look reveals more than the first, then a daily look will reveal something new every time. So I take the same route on my afternoon walks, examining the houses I pass with clinical interest, noting a new garage door here, a bed of pansies there, admiring a weathervane, trying my best to comprehend the inhabitants through their domiciles much as de Tocqueville sought to comprehend America through its politics. To hear another language, I traipse down to the Armenian markets not far from my house and listen to the clerks yell over vat-sized bowls of olives. When I am feeling especially venturesome, I climb into the car and drive to a nearby meadow that has a few wild animals, a sketchy stream and a cool fringe of oak forest. These are places I have come to love partly because they are familiar, but mostly because I've learned to see them in detail.
Of course, noting detail enlivens travel afar as well as at home. Last summer, I visited friends on Deer Isle, a chip of an island off the coast of northern Maine. Half swallowed by pine trees, their cottage perched on a rocky spur overlooking a scatter of smaller islands and beyond, the sea. At night we sat on their porch, watching the sun set over the water, feeling those black pines close in behind us, admiring and dreading the moment when the sun slipped past the brim of the world and left us alone in the dark. On those nights I couldn't help thinking of earlier residents in this lonely place, especially the fishermen's wives. So often solitary, an ocean at their doorsteps, trees at their backs, those women must have braced for the evenings, watching the same light vanishing. How far they must have traveled. Because it seems to me, finally, that travel truly lies in yearning, the outward gaze that lends one the hope that anything may still happen, that there is so much yet to see.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1741 words

HEADLINE: The 43% President

BYLINE: By Alan Brinkley; Alan Brinkley is a professor of American history at Columbia University. He is the author, most recently, of "The Unfinished Nation: A Concise History of the American People."

 BODY:
BILL CLINTON'S political fortunes have fluctuated as wildly and rapidly as those of any President in recent history. In the 1992 Presidential campaign, he seemed one of the most impressive politicians of his time. By the end of his first four months in office, he was being widely dismissed as an inept and rudderless leader. Now, after weeks of careful repositioning, he appears slowly to be regaining the public's ear. How do we explain such radical swings in public perception? Is the President himself responsible for the roller-coaster-like character of his Presidency so far? Or has he been the victim -- and at times beneficiary -- of events beyond his control?
The new Administration has, to be sure, made its share of early mistakes. But the speed with which many of them seem to have been forgotten suggests that they received more attention than they deserved -- and more attention than the similar early missteps of most of Clinton's predecessors. What has made the President's first months so rocky has been less his own performance, which includes real achievements as well as failures, than the character of the contemporary political environment. 
 Perhaps no President of the 20th century has entered office facing a more difficult combination of pressures. On the one hand, Clinton carries an exceptional burden of diverse and incompatible expectations. He is the first Democratic President in a dozen years, the first President since Lyndon Johnson committed to a significant expansion of Government's social and economic responsibilities. Liberal Democrats have greeted him with a rapture born of 12 (many would say 25) years in the political wilderness. African Americans, feminists, gay men and lesbians, environmentalists, intellectuals and artists and many other groups who considered the Reagan and Bush Administrations their enemy expect something close to a millennial change now that a sympathetic Democrat is in office. Centrist and conservative Democrats expect Clinton to rescue the party from its liberal wing and recast it in their own image.
Virtually everyone expects solutions to the problems of the economy, health care, the welfare system and many other troubled areas of American life; but there is no consensus, even among Democrats, on what those solutions should be -- or even on whether any solutions are available. Clinton may have increased the burden of these contradictory expectations with his lavish campaign promises and his well-known eagerness to please everyone. But there is no way he could have escaped it altogether.
At the same time, Clinton has entered office with extraordinary political weaknesses, which have made it almost inevitable that he will fail at much of what he set out to do. He was elected with 43 percent of the popular vote, the smallest winning percentage in 80 years -- a frail mandate indeed for the bold programs he has promised. In the absence of the cold war, there are no evident foreign policy issues around which he can easily rally popular support and derive political strength -- as his abortive Bosnia initiative demonstrated. He must, instead, fight it out on the domestic front, where consensus is much more difficult to create.
That means, among other things, fighting it out with Congress, which does not seem to be in a cooperative mood. Clinton has encountered an unusually implacable Republican opposition. His economic program attracted not a single Republican vote in the House. Senate Republicans unanimously supported the filibuster that killed Clinton's modest economic stimulus package. Bob Dole now talks of the filibuster as if it were a normal tool of minority party opposition, and he has made it clear that he plans to use it often. In fact, a filibuster orchestrated by party leadership (as opposed to mavericks or regional minorities) is virtually unprecedented.
Without any likely Republican support on the most important elements of his agenda, Clinton must rely on virtual unanimity among Congressional Democrats, who are themselves deeply divided. The Democratic majorities in both houses are small and -- in the Senate -- diminishing. Members with moderate to conservative views hold the balance of power, as the President's excruciatingly narrow Senate victory on his budget bill last month makes clear. Nor can Clinton expect much help from his party's Congressional leaders, who are so accustomed to being in opposition that they seem to have lost the will -- and the means -- to help him succeed. Clinton's much-vaunted "move to the center" is not, in other words, simply a public relations gambit. It is at least in part a recognition of the realities of Congressional politics.
There is a larger obstacle to Clinton's hopes as well: the legacy of nearly three decades of social, economic and ideological disappointment, a legacy of political frustration and popular cynicism symbolized for the moment by the irritatingly persistent popularity of Ross Perot. The last liberal President with an activist agenda comparable to Clinton's was Lyndon Johnson, who entered office before the height of the Vietnam War, before the racial climate soured, before Watergate, before the energy crisis, before the erosion of the economy -- before all the events that have left the public and -- of more immediate importance, perhaps -- the news media with a skeptical, adversarial view of politics in general and the Presidency in particular. That Clinton is himself a representative of the "60's generation," the generation most decisively affected by these events (and the generation currently dominating the media), has exaggerated both the expectations he has generated and the disappointment he creates when he seems not to fulfill them.
Mistakes and miscalculations that would have attracted little attention 30 years ago -- the travel office imbroglio, the California haircut, even the Lani Guinier embarrassment -- now become major issues, seized upon by journalists as evidence of Clinton's indecisiveness. One can understand the frustration among those in the White House who see what they consider their most important initiatives consistently obscured by fleeting controversies. But while the news media are certainly to blame for some of the President's political problems, they did not create and cannot alone dispel the popular cynicism that is their real basis. Clinton's complaining about the nature of the press in this skeptical, post-modern age is, as Fred Barnes wrote recently in The New Republic, "like someone complaining about the weather. He's railing against the way the world works."
Many of Clinton's admirers hoped and expected that he would become a domestic dynamo who would break through the gridlock and fulfill the dreams of a generation. He would be a Franklin D. Roosevelt or a Lyndon Johnson, the kind of President the political scientist Clinton Rossiter celebrated nearly 40 years ago in his book "The American Presidency" as "a kind of magnificent lion, who can roam freely and do great deeds so long as he does not try to break loose from his broad reservation. . . . There is virtually no limit to what the President can do if he does it for democratic ends and through democratic means."
But the political world in which Clinton must live has very little in common with those F.D.R. and L.B.J. inhabited. A more appropriate analogy for this President would be Harry Truman, whose tenuous popularity and fragile (or nonexistent) Democratic majorities in Congress frustrated almost all his important domestic initiatives; or John F. Kennedy, who like Clinton received less than 50 percent of the vote in 1960, who like Clinton had no reliable Congressional majorities and who through most of his brief Presidency had consistently to trim or abandon his most expansive domestic goals. Clinton may, in other words, face the kind of world that the British writer Godfrey Hodgson described in his 1980 book "All Things to All Men: The False Promise of the Modern American Presidency" when he wrote: "Never has any one office had so much power as the President of the United States possesses. Never has so powerful a leader been so impotent to do what he wants to do, what he is pledged to do, what he is expected to do and what he knows he must do."
Great Presidents are products not just of their own talents and ambitions, but of the circumstances they inherit. Theodore Roosevelt complained frequently that his times had denied him the greatness to which he aspired and of which he considered himself capable. "A man has to take advantage of his opportunities," he said in 1910 after leaving office, "but the opportunities have to come. If there is not the war, you don't get the great general; if there is not the great occasion, you don't get the great statesman; if Lincoln had lived in times of peace, no one would know his name now." The great disappointment of Roosevelt's life was that World War I came after he had left office, that, as he saw it, Woodrow Wilson and not he had the real opportunity for greatness.
Bill Clinton may some day have a similar lament, not presumably about the absence of a war but about the absence of great political opportunities. And yet Presidents also have at least some capacity to change the circumstances in which they govern -- to alter the public conversation to permit discussion of ideas that were once impermissible, to build a mandate where none exists, to persuade wavering legislators (and wavering voters) that small steps forward are better than none -- and that small steps now can lead to bigger ones later on. That was one of Theodore Roosevelt's most important achievements, even if it was one he did not himself always fully recognize; it was also, in the end, the principal legacy of John F. Kennedy. It is an opportunity that remains open to President Clinton. He probably cannot do all he and his most exuberant supporters had hoped. But if he manages to restore at least some realism to national fiscal policy (as he has already begun to do), to construct even a modest program of national health insurance and to revive a modicum of popular confidence in the ability of Government to perform, he will deserve credit for some historic achievements.
To succeed, he will need to adjust to things as they are without giving up patient efforts to change them. He will also need those who wish him well to give him a chance.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Me-First Scramble To Find Screen Gems

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

 BODY:
A cadre of young, globe-trotting movie executives charged with knowing every nonstudio film being made around the world is transforming the way these movies are bought for distribution.
No longer are these executives waiting for Cannes or Berlin or Toronto or other major film festivals to screen the best of international cinema at the same time as all the other independent distributors, then making their offers in their own time. In today's cutthroat global film economy, where financing dollars are scarce and releasing costs astronomical -- and where only a handful of independent releases succeed in North America each year -- getting to the right movie first has become the key to survival. 
 "By the time I got to Cannes, I'd already seen 25 movies," said Mark Ordesky, vice president of acquisition and co-production at New Line Cinema ("Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles"). And by the time he got to Cannes in May, his company had already acquired the Taviani brothers' "Fiorile" in Rome. Fine Line Features, a New Line division, announced the acquisition at Cannes even as more cautious competitors were still waiting to see how it would fare with critics.
New Line's toughest competitor right now is Miramax Films, which not only released "The Crying Game," with an American box-office gross of more than $62 million to date, but also the recent art-house hits "Enchanted April" and "Like Water for Chocolate." The co-chairmen of Miramax, the brothers Harvey and Bob Weinstein, are paying higher prices for more screen gems than any of their rivals.
Before Cannes this year, Miramax, which was purchased by Disney in the spring, had already landed both eventual winners of the coveted Palme D'Or: "The Piano," a New Zealand period drama starring Holly Hunter, Sam Neill and Harvey Keitel, and the lush Chinese epic "Farewell to My Concubine."
To get "The Piano," Harvey Weinstein used his connections to arrange a screening in Paris in the winter. Miramax promptly bought the film for more than $3 million.
"Everyone went ballistic" at being shut out of the process, said Bingham Ray, a partner at October Films ("Un Coeur en Hiver"). "That's what you deal with. Everyone tries to jockey for position. Good relationships can pay off with an early screening ahead of the competition."
Marcie Bloom, co-president at Sony Classics ("Howards End," "Orlando"), agreed: "The business is all about relationships. You have to stay alert and attentive to anything that might be helpful in any way. You have to be open to possibilities when films are emerging from literally anywhere on the globe."
And, said Bobby Rock, senior vice president of acquisitions for Triton Pictures ("American Heart"), "You have to have a good back and a good pair of arms to carry your bags, and be able to watch a movie on six hours of sleep."
Like most of his colleagues, Mr. Rock screens 7 to 10 movies or videotapes a week and attends seven or eight film festivals a year, during which he sees three to five movies a day. But it's getting riskier for the smaller companies like Triton that lack lavish travel budgets to wait to see a movie at a huge festival like Cannes: The film may not be available by the time they get there.
"More films are bought earlier, so there is less completed product available," said Betsy Stanbock, director of acquisitions for the Samuel Goldwyn Company. "We have to hustle that much harder."
Still, "Cannes is the triple triathlon for acquisitions executives," said Zanne Devine, vice president of Universal Pictures, who seeks films for the studio as well as for the new independent distributor Gramercy Pictures, which is owned by Universal and Polygram. "I'm looking for lightning in a bottle: a movie that will light my hair on fire."
Staying alive in this pack isn't easy. After seeing "Tous les Matins du Monde," starring Gerard Depardieu, at the Berlin Film Festival last year, Jeff Lipsky of October Films wanted to buy it. So his partner, Mr. Ray, had to screen it right away. He flew to Montreal, where the film was playing without English subtitles, and persuaded a local friend to translate. The next day, the partners made their offer, and "Tous les Matins" has grossed more than $3 million in the United States, a sizable sum for a foreign-language film.
While getting there first is the acquisitions executive's priority, even more important is judging market value. Although Howard Cohen, vice president of acquisitions for Goldwyn, flew to Hong Kong to see "Farewell to My Concubine" before anyone else, Goldwyn ultimately passed in favor of another Asian film, "The Wedding Banquet," which it bought after the Berlin Film Festival.
It remains to be seen whether he or Miramax made the right call.
Many potential hits are not obvious. While sex has usually been an easy sell, many distributors have overlooked the strong appeal of food in films. "Tampopo," "Babette's Feast," "My Dinner with Andre" and "Eating" have been joined by "Like Water for Chocolate," which created very little heat at Cannes last year but is now a hit.
Everyone saw "Like Water for Chocolate" in the same screening room, says Trea Hoving, senior vice president of acquisitions of Miramax. But Miramax saw in it some of the same elements as in its Oscar-winning Italian hit "Cinema Paradiso," the highest-grossing foreign-language film in the last decade. And Miramax was willing to work with the director, Alfonso Arau, to recut the film for the American market, shortening it by 10 minutes. The movie has grossed more than $10 million in the United States.
"You're always trying to stay a jump ahead of the taste of the public," Ms. Stanbock of Goldwyn said. "You just have to listen to your heart."

HEADLINE: Foreigners Frame America

GRAPHIC: Photos: For another perspective on the Independence Day weekend, the Op-Ed page asked six foreign photographers to comment on one of their images that expresses a telling aspect of America. Bastienne Schmidt, a German, lives in Brooklyn. Ana Aslan is a New York correspondent for a newspaper in her native Argentina. Tomas Muscionico, a Swiss, covered the Clinton campaign and is now working in Bosnia. Kent Klich, a Swede who studied photograpy in New York, is the author of "The Book of Beth," about a drug-addicted Danish woman. Eniac Martinez, a Mexican, has been following the migration of Mixtec Indians to Mexico City and California in pursuit of better economic conditions and their return to their native Oaxaca. Pierre Perrin, who is French, has documented the lives of people living near the Mississippi River.
 -- FRED RITCHIN, co-editor of "Mexico Through Foreign Eyes."
The only guns I ever saw while growing up were in Wild West movies. Coming to America, I see that the Wild West has moved from the movie theater to the front page: A 6-year-old carries a gun in the classroom, a Japanese teen-ager dies because a man asks him to "freeze" and the boy does not understand. Perhaps the 6-year-old saw too many movies and the Japanese teen-ager saw too few.
 -- Bastienne Schmidt. Left: Teen-age girls from West Virginia at a rifle competition. Camp Perry, Ohio, 1992.
American society is a battleground. Everybody feels they have the right to be themselves, but all the time they have to assert that they have that right. Sometimes, happy occasions, such as a New Year celebration, give the impression that a war has taken place, while watching a war on television can be a cause for celebration.
-- Ana Aslan. Left: Chinese New Year, Chinatown, New York City, 1991.
There is no other country where people so cherish the ability to look like famous people. I could spend the rest of my life photographing look-alike contests as well as ugly baby contests, conventions of twins. Although these are fascinating events, there is a sense of desperation and emptiness in a society that places such a high regard on looking like someone else.
-- Tomas Muscionico. Left: Ernest Hemingway look-alike festival, Key West, Fla., July 1991.
The guards and the inmates were talking to each other about my taking this picture, and I was amazed to hear how similar their attitudes were. Living in the same world, they use the same words -- heavy with desperation and violence, very much on edge. There are places in the U.S. that do not seem to change very much.
-- Pierre Perrin. Left: Prisoners and guard at Louisiana State Penitentiary, Angola, La., May 1992.
 I have always been fascinated by World War II. My father was a concentration camp survivor. The Americans helped liberate a Europe that was slaughtering itself. Once again, this time in Bosnia, Europe cannot handle its own problems and is waiting for the U.S. to act. Nothing seems to have changed.
 -- Kent Klich. Above: Veterans Day, New York City, 1981.
 Emigration affects young people differently than it does parents. The Mixtec children in the U.S. are more familiar with Halloween than with the Day of the Dead as celebrated in Mexico. Rituals quickly disappear or are mixed with newer customs.
 -- Eniac Martinez. Left: Halloween in Gilroy, Calif., 1989.

HEADLINE: New Budget Looks a Lot Like 1990's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Oct. 2, 1990, editorial on the 1990 budget deal stated: "The budget agreement between Congressional leaders and the Bush Administration cuts defense too little. It increases energy taxes too little. It taxes rich families too little. Even so, the coarse compromise would cut the deficit by half a trillion dollars in five years. . . . The best part of the package is what it will not do. It won't throw the economy into recession." 
 I can only imagine the additional increase in the deficit (it rose more than $700 billion) and the depth of the 1990-91 recession if the 1990 budget deal raised taxes to your satisfaction.
The October 1990 Wall Street Journal editorial pages predicted the explosion in the deficit, as well as the recession, as they are doing again.
"Demagoguery on Taxes" (editorial, June 25) again denounces the Reagan years. Why not admit that the defense budgets by the end of the Reagan Administration were not at historically high levels, and the 1983 and 1986 "deficit reduction" bills he signed, which represented huge tax increases, did not curtail the appetite of Congress for growing spending on nondefense appropriations?
Is it not true that the Federal budget deficit declined in real, as well as nominal terms, during President Reagan's second term? Did Federal revenue not increase despite lower tax rates? Didn't median family net worth and incomes rise through 1989?
Can you produce an analysis pointing to empirical data that supports your contention that a repeat of the 1990 budget deal will reduce our deficit and avoid another recession?
The architects of the 1993 tax bill are the identical players to those of the 1990 budget. The members of Congress simply blamed President Bush for a tax and spend bill they drafted.
Now they, and you, repeat the process and the self-congratulation. Who will the Democrats in Congress point to in the 1994-95 recession? Will you lament that the "rich" weren't taxed enough?
 
STEVEN L. EBER
Coral Gables, Fla., June 25, 1993
 
The writer is an investment adviser.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Making Gains Among Hispanic Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 1

 BODY:
The photographs of Robert F. Kennedy posing with Cesar Chavez during a hunger strike three decades ago are no longer living room fixtures in the barrios here. "Viva Bush" placards were popular last year. Now, some Hispanic households proudly display photos of Richard Riordan, this city's new Republican Mayor, who won a surprisingly large portion of the Hispanic vote.
Hispanic voters have historically been in the Democratic camp, and most still are. But they are not the reliable Democrats they once were. They are increasingly less willing to cast votes for an all-Democratic ticket. Hispanic support for Republican candidates in recent elections here and in Texas suggest that some of these voters are slowly, yet unmistakably, changing sides. 
 The Hispanic population in the United States is relatively young and makes up one of the largest pools of potential voters. So the Republican Party is aggressively courting middle-class Hispanic Americans with a message of family values, law and order and opposition to abortion.
 
Lapse by Democrats
 "They're getting a bigger share of the vote and I'm extremely concerned," said Domingo A. Garcia, the Mayor pro tem of Dallas, who heads the Democratic National Committee's Hispanic caucus. "The Democratic Party has not done a good job of reaching out to the growing Latino population in the United States. The Republicans are filling the vacuum and are building coalitions, appealing to issues like family values that have wide appeal in our community."
By seeking alliances with Hispanic voters, Republicans hope to gain an edge in close races and are threatening the Democratic Party's tradition of building powerful ethnic coalitions.
While Cuban-Americans, spurred by strong sentiments against Fidel Castro and Communism, have long tended to vote Republican, an interest in Republican politics is spreading to other Hispanic voters who had been considered part of the Democratic constituency.
In contrast, blacks continue to vote overwhelmingly Democratic and show no signs of switching parties. Asian-Americans are not quite as lock step in their support for Democrats, but they generally vote with that party. And in large pivotal states, Hispanic residents make up a far larger percentage of the pool of prospective voters than do Asians.
In the mayoral race in New York this year, Republicans are running highly visible voter-registration drives in some Hispanic neighborhoods. Herman Badillo, the city's first Puerto Rican-born member of Congress, dropped out of the mayoral race to run for comptroller on a ticket with Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is challenging Mayor David N. Dinkins, under the Republican and Liberal Party labels. Mr. Giuliani is seeking to attract support from the Hispanic and Jewish voters who voted for the Democratic Mayor in 1989.
The most recent example of Republican appeal to Hispanic voters was the election last month of Mayor Riordan. Though he did not win a majority of the Hispanic vote, Mr. Riordan made significant inroads, drawing 43 percent, as against 57 percent for his Democratic opponent, Michael Woo, according to a Los Angeles Times poll. By contrast, Mr. Riordan's share of the black vote was only 14 percent.
"Woo should have gotten 70 percent," said Richard Martinez, regional director of the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project. "It was his to lose. He didn't talk to the Latino community. Most campaign managers don't see the growth of Latino voters; they believe that the Latino vote is apathetic. They're nuts. We outregistered Anglos and blacks last year."
In Texas, three days before the election in Los Angeles, Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Republican candidate, was elected Senator in a landslide in which she carried heavily Hispanic South Texas, 60 percent to 40 percent. While the Democratic incumbent, Bob Krueger, still carried most of the Hispanic vote statewide, Mrs. Hutchison's support demonstrates the potential for what Texas Republican leaders contend is a new winning coalition of urban Republicans, rural conservatives and Hispanic Americans.
Although Democrats still won a majority of the Hispanic vote in the Texas and Los Angeles races, Republican support from those voters was significant. It at least partly reflected that Republicans were far more aggressive than Democrats in running Spanish-language advertising campaigns and phone banks to get Hispanic voters to the polls.
"We're not the enemy like we used to be 20 years ago," said Tirso del Junco, a Cuban-American who heads the California Republican Party. "The Hispanic community identified with Mr. Riordan on jobs and economics and family. There is a notion out there that Hispanics are interested in social issues and that's it. I suggest that's not the case."
Even as more Hispanics voters back Republican candidates, Hispanic politics is still dominated by Democrats. But that, too, shows signs of shifting.
"Latinos are no longer to be taken for granted as being in one corner or another," said Gaddi H. Vasquez, the Republican Supervisor of heavily conservative Orange County south of Los Angeles, whom his party is grooming for statewide office.
Texas has been the most successful breeding ground recently for Hispanic Republicans. Pete Nieto, who was recently elected a Texas State Representative as a Democrat, announced last month that he was switching to the Republican Party. In a statement, he said the lessons of his parents of "hard work, self reliance and family values" were shared by Republicans.
 
For the Next Election
 With Mr. Nieto when he made the announcement was Representative Henry Bonilla of San Antonio, who last year became the first Hispanic Republican elected to Congress from Texas.
In many states, Republicans are hoping to make even greater inroads next year in state and local elections by recruiting Hispanic candidates and getting Hispanic voters to the polls. Looking ahead to the 1996 Presidential race, several important battlegrounds, including California, Florida, Illinois, New York and Texas, have large numbers of Hispanic residents.
In Los Angeles, the potential Hispanic political clout is clearly illustrated on a wall map at the offices of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials in East Los Angeles. In bright orange and yellow colors, the map dispels the notion that Hispanic residents are concentrated only in East Los Angeles, and shows they are spread throughout five neighboring counties, including the San Fernando Valley and the Republican bastion of Orange County.
"That's where the voters are," said Harry P. Pachon, the national director of the group, pointing to the map. "If you're in the Republican Party hierarchy, you ask yourself: 'Will the blacks vote for us?' "
 
'Not Set in Concrete'
 Though Mr. Pachon said the Republicans had largely given up on the black vote, he said they know that "the Latino vote is not set in concrete."
Indeed, a 1992 poll by the Southwest Voter Research Institute showed that in Texas the Republicans have made sharp inroads among Hispanic voters. In California, the poll found that increasing numbers of Hispanic voters are dropping party affiliations and identifying themselves as independents -- but, as the recent mayoral election shows, are willing to vote Republican.
By the end of 1994, more than three million former illegal immigrants, mostly natives of Mexico, will complete a five-year waiting period to be eligible for naturalization. More than half of these people live in California. The Republican Party has recognized the potential faster than the Democrats, and usually dispatches party representatives to naturalization ceremonies.
Although the Republicans have concentrated on well-to-do Hispanic business owners, the party has also sought to portray itself to minorities as inclusive and progressive.
To tap the full potential of the Hispanic vote, both parties have to reverse the low turnouts by Hispanic voters. In the Los Angeles mayoral race, Hispanic voters accounted for only 10 percent of the total.
Peter Skerry, a political scientist and author of "Mexican Americans: The Ambivalent Minority" (The Free Press, 1993), is skeptical of the prospects for a significant shifts in Hispanic voting pattern. Fundamentally, he said, the Hispanic electorate is a "working, lower-middle class kind of vote that's interested in the same economic issues as Democrats."
And Mr. Skerry said Cuban-Americans, who among Hispanics have been the most ardent Republicans, had discouraged others.
"There's intense animosity between Mexican-Americans and the Cuban-Republicans, who got there first and contributed a lot of money to the party," he said. "They're not eager to open the ranks to what they call Johnny-come-latelys."
But Mr. Garcia, the head of the Democratic Hispanic Caucus, said he was so worried about the Republicans that he took his concerns to David Wilhelm, the chairman of Democratic National Committee, and officials at the White House. "So far," he said, "the pleas have fallen on deaf ears. An organized strategy still has not been developed."
But Mr. Wilhelm said he was confident that the Democrats could hold on to the 62 percent of Hispanic voters who said they backed Bill Clinton last year.
"The key with Hispanic voters is the same as it is with voters generally," he said. "If we deliver on economic change, if we pass health-care reform, we will have spoken to those Hispanic voters in a very clear and compelling way."

HEADLINE: Restoring Stability to Haiti Is Seen as the Next Big Test

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 4

 BODY:
Now that an agreement has finally been signed to restore Haiti's first elected President to power on Oct. 30, diplomats say they face a more critical test: building a viable economy and political stability in a desperately poor country with virtually no tradition of compromise.
The tortuous talks in New York that culminated in the signing of the accord on Saturday by the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide and the military leader who overthrew him in September 1991, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, exposed the fractious nature of Haiti's politics and the skills and limits of its foreign partners. 
 Equally difficult hurdles will emerge as early as next week, when representatives of Father Aristide are to meet with political parties represented in the Haitian Parliament, perhaps in Washington, for political consultations aimed at forming a new government of the President's choosing.
Father Aristide, a liberal priest elected in December 1990 with strong support from Haiti's poor, was overthrown by the army after what many analysts viewed as an unnecessary fight with his own natural allies in the Parliament. That power struggle left him with few friends beyond a government of untested intimates and a population thirsty for the redemption he had promised.
 
A Test of Skills
 Beginning next week, Father Aristide must test his skills of consultation and coalition building in selecting a prime minister who must be perceived by the nation not as a crony, but as an independent personality who can reassure all Haitians that the country can overcome its divisiveness.
Speculation has centered on Robert Malval, a Haitian businessman who told a reporter several weeks ago that he could not support Father Aristide as President if he retained the chaotic and insular pattern of governing of his first seven months in office. Last week Mr. Malval was a leading member of Father Aristide's negotiating team in New York.
But before Father Aristide can install a new Government, the country's political parties must come up with a formula for purging the Parliament of members who won office in an election on Jan. 18 denounced by many governments and by most Haitians as a sham.
To maintain the pressure for those two actions, the settlement crafted by United Nations mediators calls for maintaining an international oil embargo against Haiti and a freeze on the assets of supporters of the 1991 coup against Father Aristide.
 
An Accord With Teeth
 "We assume they will all be pulling in the same direction," a senior diplomat involved in the settlement said of the Haitian parties who are to take part in the coming talks.
Dante Caputo, the United Nations mediator who has shuttled for months between Father Aristide and General Cedras, emphasized that the accord was intended to have teeth.
"We are not going through all the trouble we've been through for one day of victory," Mr. Caputo said last week during the arduous talks at Governors Island in New York harbor. "To be considered a success, this has to be something lasting."
Father Aristide signed the settlement just before 11 P.M. Saturday, nearly 12 hours after General Cedras did so. One of the snags that delayed the President's signing was his request for United Nations assurances that his supporters and others would enjoy freedom of expression in Haiti during the consultations leading to his return.
Aides to Father Aristide have asked for television coverage in Haiti of any political meetings held during this period.
 
Vast Economic Program
 The selection of a new government by Father Aristide, once ratified by the Parliament, will also set in motion a huge program for economic recovery that diplomats say is of vital political importance as well.
The international package, valued at more than $1 billion by President Clinton, will focus on the quick creation of 30,000 or more jobs in areas like sanitation, road building and well digging to improve conditions in a country that was already the hemisphere's poorest when it began its 21-month crisis. International sanctions have only made conditions more wretched.
Since February, teams of international experts coordinated by the United Nations Development Program have repeatedly visited the Haitian capital and countryside to study Haiti's needs and lay the ground for a quick start in the event that a settlement is reached.
When Father Aristide's Government took office in February 1991 it enjoyed strong popular support and had the good will of international donors, who pledged $350 million in aid. But ultimately it managed to get almost no development programs.
 
Infusion of Foreign Experts
 To help Father Aristide avoid repeating that destabilizing debacle, the emerging economic strategy involves a strong infusion of foreign experts who are to pass along expertise to a renovated civil service and help speed up its work.
The military is also scheduled for major change. The accords, like Haiti's 1986 Constitution, call for the separation of the police from the armed forces. To help accomplish this, the United Nations will send hundreds of experts with expertise in police work and military affairs to Haiti, most of them drawn from French-speaking countries.
Senior Clinton Administration officials say the United States would prefer to allow other nations to fulfill that role, but will send troops to Haiti, if requested, to help support the process.
In the meantime, American military involvement is expected to be limited to experts from groups like the Army Corps of Engineers, which can help the Haitian military, now concentrated in and around the capital, move to new bases to be sprinkled throughout the countryside.
A major element of the country's reconstruction plan hinges on permanently removing soldiers from politics and involving them in rebuilding and in long-neglected, traditional duties like border patrols.
The international police and military cooperation with Haiti, a strategy contested at various points in the negotiations by supporters of the President and by army officers, must be discussed and approved by Haiti's political parties and Parliament.
The accords call for the President to name a new army commander shortly before his return who would replace General Cedras. Father Aristide said in a recent interview that the commander would be chosen according to military rules of promotion. That commander will then name a new staff to replace the military high command that the President holds responsible for the coup and the violence that followed.
One of the reasons for the delay in Father Aristide's signature on Saturday was dismay and confusion among his aides over the meaning of the required "retirement" of those officers under the terms of the settlement.
Father Aristide's delegation had wanted those officers to be banished from the army altogether, but the final agreement allows for their reassignment to positions outside the high command. Diplomats say General Cedras himself will leave the army.
The reversal of fortunes for General Cedras completes a circle in his relations with Father Aristide. On the morning of his inauguration in 1991, the new President surprised many by dismissing much of the senior officer corps and naming General Cedras, who had overseen the country's peaceful elections, as the new commander.
A critical turn in Haiti's fortunes came with the swearing-in of President Clinton in January. Embarrassed by his own inaugural about-face on a campaign promise to change the way Haitian refugees were treated after being intercepted on the high seas, Mr. Clinton set out to press for the restoration of Haitian democracy and return the country's leftist young leader to power.
The linchpin of the strategy, devised soon after Mr. Clinton took office, was a partnership with the United Nations. After dispelling doubts that lingered from the Bush Administration about the strength of Washington's commitment to the goal of restoring democracy in Haiti, the United Nations mediator for that country became a regular sight in Washington.
The diplomatic triumph on Saturday, in which General Cedras and Father Aristide each signed an agreement that promised to restore the President by Oct. 30, was a victory for both men.
But in the deliberate pattern that has held throughout the six-month partnership between Washington and the United Nations mediator, it was Mr. Caputo, a former Argentine Foreign Minister, who emerged from the shadows of diplomacy as the visible actor.
Their intention, carefully respected, was that American muscle be held in reserve -- always visible, but deployed as little as possible to make a United Nations diplomatic offensive successful. This was necessary for two reasons, diplomats said: Haiti's long psychological ties to Washington, reinforced by American intervention, had become destructive; and with crises sprouting around the world, Washington was anxious to develop effective joint strategies for dealing with them.

International

An election two weeks from today seems certain to end nearly four decades of rule by the Liberal Democrats. And the President, as he prepared to leave Washington, made it clear that he hoped the political turmoil would produce a Japanese Government more willing to open its markets. [1.] 
 The Administration is planning to use the economic meeting to announce the successful conclusion of talks among European allies and Japan on providing aid to Russia for economic reforms. [4.]
