HEADLINE: Security Official Guides U.S. Aims at Conference

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Every Wednesday, three men gather around the conference table in a spacious corner office in the West Wing of the White House to share sandwiches and talk. Their conversation is anything but casual, for they are the backbone of President Clinton's foreign policy team.
W. Anthony Lake, the President's national security adviser, Les Aspin, the Secretary of Defense, and Warren Christopher, the Secretary of State, are the people who have drafted the President's speeches and policy statements as Mr. Clinton prepares to go to Tokyo this week to meet with the leaders of the world's wealthiest nations. They have spent weeks in close negotiations with representatives from the other countries, trying to resolve differences over economic policies and aid to Russia. 
 Mr. Lake will be at the President's side as he travels to Tokyo for his most extensive foray to date on the world stage. And when the leaders of the so-called Group of Seven issue their communiques in Tokyo, much of the direction will have been determined in advance by Mr. Lake and a staff of strategists and technocrats.
The advisers place a premium on collegiality, secrecy, efficiency and finding a Clinton-like consensus on every issue. In planning for the economic conference in Tokyo, Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen has also taken part, as have Robert E. Rubin, the head of the new National Economic Council, and his deputy, W. Bowman Cutter.
 
Lake Spearheads Asia Trip
 But because Mr. Rubin has a significantly smaller staff and a mandate that focuses on domestic issues, Mr. Lake's shop has driven much of the preparations for the Asia trip.
"As we look at this week, we have a new President going to Asia -- a new Asia. It really becomes increasingly clear that we ought to use this as an opportunity to talk more broadly about the United States as a Pacific power and the emerging economic and security relationships with the United States and Asia," said a national security official, who insisted on anonymity.
The summit meeting will inevitably push Mr. Lake closer to the public view. But the national security adviser and his own team, members of the White House national security staff, generally leave the public stage to Cabinet members like Mr. Aspin and Mr. Christopher, in part to avoid the sort of turf warfare that has often marred foreign-policy making.
"I really wanted to avoid becoming the guard-all shield between the President and the rest of the foreign policy community, but at the same time make sure he wasn't being buried in all kinds of different memos and meetings," Mr. Lake said in an interview. "That's not what the President wants in any case."
The feuds between William P. Rogers and Henry A. Kissinger under Richard Nixon, and Zbigniew Brzezinski and Cyrus R. Vance under Jimmy Carter are now remembered almost as much as the achievements. Even James A. Baker 3d and Brent Scowcroft, who worked as Secretary of State and national security adviser for George Bush, had their tense moments.
 
Determined to Avoid Tension
 "I think Tony and I and Les are determined that we'll not have a repeat of the tensions that existed in previous administrations," said Mr. Christopher, who worked with Mr. Lake at the State Department during the Carter years.
"If that falls apart," another adviser added, "you get the Vance-Brzezinski, the Kissinger-Rogers vehemence, and everybody loses."
Some of Mr. Lake's supporters, concerned that like some of his predecessors he is ceding the political credit for American policy advances to Mr. Christopher, have begun quietly campaigning to raise his visibility just a bit. But Mr. Lake has generally eschewed television and most other opportunities to publicize his role.
"The more you do, especially in a job like this, outside, the more the others are going to start feel you're threatening them," said a White House official. "And it actually diminishes your power, and it actually undercuts the President."
 
Mixed View on Growing Pains
 When the national security advisers boast at all, it is to point out that -- in their view, at least -- the President's foreign policy operation has suffered few of the growing pains that have occurred on the domestic and communications side of the White House.
This ignores the Administration's biggest foreign policy stumble to date, its abortive effort to force allied action in Bosnia. Mr. Lake, officials concede, has been at the center of that crisis as well.
And critics say the foreign policy brain trust also mirrors some of Mr. Clinton's own weaknesses. To some members of Congress and people in the foreign policy community, the collegiality of the President's advisers comes across as mushiness, their secrecy as stubbornness and their passion for efficiency as a maddening inability to see the forest for the trees.
 
Praise and Criticism for Lake
 Mr. Lake is the most frequent target for both the praise and the complaints that emerge about the President's foreign policy office. Low-key, bespectacled and possessed of a dry wit, he does not fit the mold of previous national security advisers, most of whom have been drawn from the military. A career Foreign Service officer who served in Vietnam and later opposed the war, Mr. Lake's appearance suggests an academic background and he has indeed been a professor at Mount Holyoke College.
The White House foreign policy team is so circumspect that even members of Congress with security clearance have trouble forming opinions about its efficiency.
"I suspect he's very much overworked," Representative Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is the chairman of the House Foreign Relations Committee, said of Mr. Lake. "That means it's tough for him to get to an issue unless it's urgent."
Harsher critics suggest that the President's foreign policy advisers are too reactive and have not taken on enough of an advocacy role.
"I'm being careful," said Representative Dave McCurdy, a Democrat from Oklahoma and member of the Armed Services Committee, who was asked to assess the early work of the President's policy advisers. "A lot of it depends on State and Defense and how forceful they are in the kinds of roles they hold."
 
'A Very Low-Key Manager'
 Of Mr. Lake, he added: "I haven't figured out what kind of role he has. If he's a manager, he's a very low-key manager."
But Mr. Lake's low profile has cost him in credibility in a political environment where invisibility is often equated with powerlessness.
"What I think they miss is his toughness," said George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to the President. "I think it's too easy to think: Vietnam, professor, laid-back and funny equals not tough. And that's just flat-out wrong."
Administration officials said that before last weekend's missile strike against Iraq, Mr. Lake urged the President to take aggressive action after concluding that Iraq was responsible for hatching an assassination plot aimed at President Bush. Mr. Lake's handprints, they said, were also to be found in Mr. Clinton's aggressive defense of aid for Russia before and since the Vancouver summit meeting.
The downside of that analysis, of course, is that Mr. Lake has also been central in forming the failed Administration policy on Bosnia. Mr. Clinton's oratory seemed muscular during the election campaign, but Washington's policy has appeared feckless after European allies rejected Mr. Christopher's pitch to lift the arms embargo on the Bosnian Muslims and consider limited air strikes against Serbian nationalists.
But if it is true that Mr. Lake is the man at Mr. Clinton's elbow when it comes to setting foreign policy, what of Warren Christopher, the courtly Secretary of State?
Although he insists he is not a gatekeeper, Mr. Lake has designed a system that makes him the hub of the wheel.
 
More Than One Voice
 "The principal spokesman for foreign policy should be the Secretary of State," one White House official said. "It gets confusing when there is more than one voice out there. But there's no question who's driving foreign policy in terms of the decision-making process." That would be Mr. Lake.
"There's more than enough room," Mr. Christopher said in an interview. "A properly functioning national security adviser only enhances the position of the Secretary of State."
When all of the President's foreign policy advisers gathered around the long table in the Roosevelt Room at the White House for a series of briefings for the Tokyo summit conference last week, Mr. Lake led the discussions.
But as the President sets out his vision of Asia policy this week, some say it will have come not a moment too soon.
"We have been lax in setting out goals for the international community," said Michael Mandlebaum, a former Clinton foreign policy adviser who directs the East-West Project of the Council on Foreign Relations. "But just setting them out would not mean we could achieve them. Because there are problems that no other American President has had to deal with that Bill Clinton will have to deal with."

HEADLINE: Mandela and de Klerk Receive Liberty Medal in Philadelphia

BYLINE: By LARRY OLMSTEAD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, July 4

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela and President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa joined President Clinton at the birthplace of American democracy today, capping a day of pointed remarks on the distance each nation must travel to guarantee the fruits of freedom to all their citizens.
Mr. de Klerk and Mr. Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, were given the Liberty Medal in a ceremony at Independence Hall. 
 Mr. Mandela shook hands cordially with Mr. de Klerk, yet recalled the observation of Frederick Douglass in marking the holiday 141 years ago during the era of slavery that, "This Fourth of July is yours, not mine."
Quoting from Langston Hughes's poem, "Harlem," Mr. Mandela said that for millions in the United States and elsewhere, amid problems of drug abuse, homelessness and violence, the promise of liberty was "but a dream deferred."
 
Sharing Justice and Prosperity
 As South Africans negotiate a transition into rule by the black majority, he said, the great challenge would be to insure "that no one in our country shall in the future complain that justice and prosperity are not shared by them."
Mr. Clinton, Mr. de Klerk and the leader of the African National Congress spoke in front of more than 2,000 invited guests and thousands of others who jammed the mall in which sits the pavilion that houses the Liberty Bell.
Amid controversy over the appropriateness of awarding the medal to Mr. de Klerk, he and Mr. Mandela had a sharp exchange at a news conference preceding the ceremony in which the anti-apartheid leader stated, "We don't regard Mr. de Klerk as the President of South Africa." Mr. Mandela said that people of color, 85 percent of the nation's population, had no say in the election of Mr. de Klerk.
 
Protest Against de Klerk
 The crowd included several hundred protesters who chanted during Mr. Mandela's speech, "Mandela yes, de Klerk, no." But they were some 300 yards from the podium and caused minimal disruption, and Mr. de Klerk's speech was applauded politely.
The awards, conferred by the civic group We the People 2000, carried a $100,000 cash prize that the two leaders split. The Liberty Medal and the cash award were established by Philadelphia-area business and civic leaders in 1988 to heighten recognition of the nation's founding principles.
 
Money Raised for A.N.C.
 During an earlier appearance at a North Philadelphia church, Mr. Mandela got more than $30,000 in pledges for his organization in what became an impromptu telethon headed by former Representative William H. Gray 3d, the church's pastor.
"It would seem strange to some people that . . . we who have been fighters for liberation are together with the captains of apartheid," Mr. Mandela said.
But it would also strike many as strange that America's Founding Fathers "permitted the institution of slavery to continue."
 
'I Tremble for My Country
 Mr. Clinton, warmly received on his nation's birthday, said, "Even after 217 years, no one can say we've gotten it all right yet." He recalled how Thomas Jefferson, referring to slavery, wrote: "I tremble for my country when I reflect that God is just."
Mr. Clinton promised United States economic and technical assistance as South Africa continues it democratization process. He said he would raise the topic of international assistance at next week's economic summit in Tokyo.
Earlier Sunday, at the news conference, Mr. de Klerk took exception to comments made the past few days by Mr. Mandela that the South African President was "irrelevant" to the timing to the lifting of sanctions.
 
Call for End to Sanctions
 "Nothing and nobody is irrelevant when it comes to the issue of sanctions," Mr. de Klerk said.
Mr. Mandela said he was worried about Mr. de Klerk's assurances in view of a recent controversy in South Africa over the President's decision to override an independent panel and place some of his own choices on the board that controls South African television and radio.
Noting that the prerequisite for the lifting of sanctions was the successful creation of an interim governing council, Mr. Mandela said: "We want to make sure that before we lift sanctions, nobody, including Mr. de Klerk, will have the authority to change the members of that council."

HEADLINE: Results of Study on Pesticide Encourage Effort to Cut Use

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
With the release last week of a five-year study of agricultural chemicals and how they affect children, it appears that there is momentum for a major change in Federal policy on pesticides.
Just before the release of the report, from the National Academy of Sciences, came the announcement by three Federal agencies, which in the past had often clashed on the subject, that they would now work together to try to reduce the use of pesticides. That, in turn, came a few months after the Supreme Court strictly interpreted a law on food additives, forcing Congress to act on pesticide policy. 
 Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat and head of the Agriculture Committee, said a few days ago that "the whole atmosphere is worlds different than when I requested the report" five years ago. "It comes at a time when we may actually be able to enact some of the changes suggested."
 
Regulating Pesticides
 The study released last week detailed how the Government should regulate pesticides. It also faulted the Government's method of calculating the level of pesticides on food that is safe. And it found that other sources of pesticide contamination -- for instance, chemicals used on lawns -- have not been considered when total pesticide exposure is calculated.
The study found that infants and young children might be uniquely sensitive to pesticides on food. They consume more than 60 times the amount of fruits as adults for their body weight, and so tend to get higher doses of the pesticides used on fruits early in life.
Senator Leahy said the Clinton Administration was ready to reverse the policy of recent decades and try to reduce the amount of pesticides used by American farmers whenever possible. Alternative ways to control pests, like using beneficial insects to control them or enriching the soil to makes plants more resistant to pests, may become Federal policy.
 
In a Year, Perhaps a Law
 Because of the President's support, the Senator said, Congress might pass a bill within the next year or so, something he and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, have tried to do without success for several years. With the threat of a Presidential veto gone, he said, lawmakers "will be willing to negotiate."
The report said the three Federal agencies that control the amount of pesticides that is permitted on food -- the Agriculture Department, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Food and Drug Administration -- had outmoded policies that make it possible for children to get the same pesticide from several different sources and end up eating amounts of it that are unsafe.
The Government now considers the amount of a pesticide "average persons" might ingest. William Jordan, deputy director of policy for the E.P.A. Pesticide Office, said the agency had looked at the diets of several groups, classified by age, race or geography.
But the academy said that computer data now made it possible to do things like look at children's pesticide consumption in their first five years.
The report also said that each new pesticide was tested before it is approved by the Government for use in foods. But these risk calculations have not taken into account the fact that people may get pesticides from many sources besides food, like contaminated drinking water or golf courses treated with chemicals.
Thus, said Dr. Philip Landrigan, chairman of the committee that wrote the pesticide report, "Pesticides applied in legal amounts on the farm, and present in legal amounts on food, can still lead to unsafe amounts."
Both Government and industry had years ago allowed some products on the market if they had what was called "negligible" amounts of carcinogens. That could mean, for example, that a person would not run a risk of cancer higher than one in a million over an entire lifetime.
 
Ending the Risk
 Two bills in Congress, one offered by Democrats and one by Republicans, have one thing in common, something industry has sought for years. Both bills would require the E.P.A. to calculate risks and permit pesticides and other additives on the market if they pose only a "negligible risk."
In the Democratic offering, the Kennedy-Waxman bill, an acceptable "negligible risk" would cover a pesticide that would cause a person no more than a one in a million chance of suffering a harmful effect over the course of a lifetime. Thus, a trace amount of a carcinogen might not force a chemical off the market.
The two bills differ in that the Republican bill asks the E.P.A. to weigh the economic benefit of having a pesticide on the market against its health risks.

HEADLINE: High School Lasts Longer Than 4 Years for Many Students

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN

 BODY:
Judith Aguilar is 18 years old and graduated from high school after only four years. In her midtown Manhattan school, Park West High, that achievement alone places her among the elite.
Veronica Lopez is 17 and desperate to complete her senior year. Just over a week ago she marched with her class to the strains of "Pomp and Circumstance," but when the graduates picked up their diplomas last Monday, Miss Lopez stayed home. To graduate, she still must pass three courses, including an economics class she has already failed twice. 
 Victor Osbourne, 22, has been a high school graduate for one week. He does not like to talk much about his high school years, except to say this: "For anybody who wants to achieve their goal, the impossible is possible."
 
Huge Obstacles
 Possible, maybe, but for a large portion of New York City students, getting through high school is a daunting task. Besieged by family demands, burdened by the need to work, discouraged or simply disinterested, thousands of students came years late to their graduation ceremonies, if at all. Many of those who graduated did so despite huge handicaps and were driven by the desire to build better lives for themselves.
"I'm having a tough time now and if I don't go to college, it's going to keep on for the rest of my life," Miss Lopez said. "With a high school diploma you don't do anything. You got to go to college."
In many ways, Park West on West 50th Street reflects the face of the New York City school system as the academic year ends. Less than 32 percent of the ninth graders who entered in 1988 had graduated by 1992, a little worse than the citywide average of 38.7 percent.
Nearly 16 percent were listed as having dropped out -- matching the citywide average -- while 37 percent remained in school. Some, like Mr. Osbourne, will take six or seven years to graduate.
"Some people will make the statement that 'Look how horrible it is they are spending all that time in high school,' " said the Park West Principal, Richard A. Ross. "Would we rather that they spend four years and drop out? Our job is to help them have a better life."
 
An Array of Student Problems
 Despite the statements that departing Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has made recently about the declining dropout rate, Park West and its students offer a vivid explanation of why, across the city, only 57 percent of the students receive a diploma, even after seven years.
Park West's student body is predominantly Hispanic, increasingly immigrant and largely poor. The school's five counselors and one social worker contend with an array of student problems, from pregnancy to housing, from drug abuse to violence.
Many students, discouraged by poverty and tempted by the world outside the classroom that seems to offer more immediate rewards, do not value academic success, said Renee Pollack, an assistant principal.
"In many instances it has no relation to what they need to do in their life or to what they do during the day," she said. "Very often I see kids once or twice a month when they come in to get a bus pass. Then I'm not going to see them for another month."
 
Conflicting Demands
 Even students who value education and want desperately to graduate can get sidetracked by the demands of family and work. Three-quarters of Park West's students live below the poverty level. For many, working is not an option, it is a necessity.
The students say that too much work means they fall behind in class. Falling behind in class means they fail and must retake the class.
Several Park West students said they had reached their senior year only to find out they lacked enough credits in some subjects and were oversupplied in others. The problem seems to be acute among students who transferred from other countries and who say they were never told what they needed to graduate.
Noreen Connell, executive director of the Educational Priorities Panel, a group that advocates improvements in public education from the student's point of view, said such bewilderment is not uncommon. Ms. Connell said her group had been urging the school system to send yearly reports to parents showing the student's progress toward graduation.
"It is especially important to empower the parent, so that the parent knows even if the kid doesn't care," she said.
Ms. Pollack said students are given the graduation requirements during school orientation and meet frequently with grade advisers.
"I tell kids all the time, 'You need this, this and this,' and they still say, 'You never told me,' " Ms. Pollack said. "It's part of their being kids."
 
'Not Going to Just Give Up'
 Some students said they had no trouble finding out which credits they needed to graduate. Judith Aguilar plotted her high school career like a chess match, and won in four years.
"Instinct, it was all instinct," she said. "I made sure I got to see the grade adviser. I made sure I completed my credits and got through. I made sure I was going to pass."
Voted most intelligent and most likely to succeed by her classmates, Miss Aguilar will enroll at Hunter College in Manhattan this fall.
"I don't know what I will study, but I will do it successfully," she said. "I'm not going to just give up."
 
Four Years of Drifting
 It never occurred to Victor Osbourne to give up, either, not through more than six years of high school. He drifted through the first four, cutting classes in an attempt to fit in, often failing and still not finding many friends, he said. "I tried to be just like everybody else," he said.
He dropped out once, after a fight with another student, but after a few months found his way back to Park West. He wandered away again this spring while helping his family pack for a move to Florida. At one point his parents were called in to discuss the possibility of Mr. Osbourne working toward a general equivalency diploma. But his parents would have none of it, and neither would Mr. Osbourne.
"Oh no, they wanted the diploma," said his favorite teacher, Grace Walsh. "He wanted it."
On Monday he went back to Park West to pick up his diploma and thank Ms. Walsh for her help. "She stuck by me," he said. "She inspired me to read more. She's my hero."
 
Hopes for Better Future
 Veronica Lopez has dreamed of college and a better life since she and her mother came to New York from the Dominican Republic. They get by on the money Miss Lopez makes at a fast-food restaurant, and the money her mother earns as a sample-maker for a factory.
Miss Lopez used to work at a convenience store from 3 P.M. until midnight, five days a week, for $165 take-home pay. When she realized she would not graduate on time and the strain became too much, she quit.
This summer Miss Lopez will take two math classes and an economics class in an effort to get her diploma. She has twice failed the economics class, but hopes that with a different teacher, she will do better.
If all goes well this summer, she plans to apply to La Guardia Community College for the January term. Eventually she hopes to go into the travel and tourism business.
"I cannot be like this, working for $4.25 an hour for the rest of my life," she said. "I want to be somebody."

HEADLINE: Ready to Put Theories Into Action, Secretary Finds Ideas Are Not Allies

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
Not many Cabinet secretaries arrive in town with a billing like that of Robert B. Reich when he showed up to take over the Department of Labor.
A friend of the President for 25 years, author of many Clinton campaign promises and a force behind some of the liveliest economic policy debates of the last decade, Mr. Reich (pronounced reish) was leaving Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government, where he taught political economics, to come into Government and do nothing less than reorganize labor and industry using the theories he conceived in academia. 
But after five months he has found that theorizing is the easy part.
 
Assembling Committees
 Mr. Reich is still pursuing his big ideas: remaking the American workplace, ending the hostility between workers and management and producing millions of better-skilled workers for new high-paying jobs.
In the manner of an academic, he is assembling committees to work on these things. He has created a Commission on the Future of Worker-Management Relations, with 8 of its 10 members from universities and a chairman, 78-year-old John T. Dunlop, Secretary of Labor under President Gerald R. Ford, with a long record of settling labor-management disputes.
And any day now, his aides say, he will announce the formation of a new agency, the Office of the American Workplace, which, like the commission, will focus on ways to encourage cooperation between workers and management.
But some people say Mr. Reich may not fully grasp the realities of Government.
"What a disaster!" said Audrey Freedman, a labor economist who is a director of Manpower, the big temporary-help company. "What does the Secretary of Labor have to do with how individual companies deal with their workers? Really!"
 
Fallen Campaign Promises
 Certainly, Mr. Reich's impact on policy has so far been less than his advance billing suggested. His ideas have collided with the reality of a budget deficit, skeptics in Congress, special interests and the slow-turning wheels of bureaucracy.
Already, the ground is littered with fallen campaign promises, including one to require Federal contractors to give young poor people after-school and summer jobs and another to require businesses to spend 1.5 percent of their payrolls on training. The promise to raise the $4.25 minimum wage has been postponed for at least a year.
The Clinton Administration's $16.3 billion economic stimulus plan, written in part by Mr. Reich, was rejected by Congress; the only piece that survived that vote was an extension of unemployment benefits.
Mr. Reich's other big proposal in the stimulus plan, a $1 billion expansion of this year's Federal summer jobs program, has been chopped to $220 million.
And as the 1994 budget makes its way through Congress, Mr. Reich seems unlikely to get more than a third of the $1.5 billion he sought for job training for those who permanently lose jobs in shrinking industries, a program near to his heart because it is intended to put people on pathways to his "high performance" workplace.
 
'Keeping Himself Focused'
 To pay for a richer job training program Mr. Reich faced the same difficult choices other secretaries do. He proposed to cut back the number of investigators enforcing the child labor, anti-discrimination, mine safety and minimum wage laws. He promptly ran into flak from Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat from Iowa who has a big voice in the Labor Department budget.
Mr. Reich, 47, can hardly be stuck with all the blame for his early stumbles. Throughout the Administration, many bright ideas have withered while the White House, to wring a budget out of Congress, has reduced its proposed tax increases and cut more spending. And reviving the economy and creating good jobs are not simple tasks.
"People are more in the attack mode on him than seems justified," said Jerry J. Jasinowski, who as president of the National Association of Manufacturers is often at odds with Mr. Reich. "He's done a pretty good job dealing with conflicting crosscurrents. He's keeping himself focused in an unfocused Administration."
In his own workplace, the Department of Labor, Mr. Reich has been trying out his ideas. As part of Vice President Al Gore's Administration-wide program to shrink bureaucracy, he has established a "reinventing Government" team of union officers, top career staff members and political appointees to review the department's budget and its promotion, training and purchasing policies.
Mr. Reich has made numerous crowd-pleasing gestures. He invited the whole Washington staff to his swearing-in, closed the lush executive dining room and ordered that the intimidating double doors to his second-floor suite be kept open.
Mr. Reich has clearly lifted the spirits of the department's 17,900 workers. "It's a very different day here," said Linda Copening, head of the local of the American Federation of Government Employees that represents Labor Department workers in Washington. "He seems to be practicing what he's preaching."
Mr. Reich is also popular with the press, making light of his scholarship ("My books, once you put them down, you can't pick them up") and his 4-foot-11-inch height ("See. They've already cut me off at the knees"). His agenda for a week in May shows he logged six-and-one-half hours talking to reporters, a half-hour more than he spent with business people, labor leaders and members of Congress combined.
In the struggle over the budget, Mr. Reich has lost some internal disputes with the Administration's more rigorous deficit-cutters, particularly the budget director, Leon E. Panetta. But more than any of his predecessors, Mr. Reich is extending his reach far beyond the confines of his own department.
Mr. Reich's relationship with the labor unions, traditionally an important ally for Democratic administrations, is still being tested.
He has pleased unions by loading his senior staff with at least 10 recruits from organized labor. But unions are miffed by his retreat on the minimum wage and his support of the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico and Canada. And they doubt that he will lobby hard to keep an expected Senate Republican filibuster from stopping legislation to prevent companies from, in effect, dismissing workers who go on strike.
The biggest conflict with unions is still brewing. A large faction opposes Mr. Reich's notion of labor-management cooperation, an idea at the center of his philosophy. Through his workplace commission, Mr. Reich hopes to rewrite labor laws to encourage formation of labor-management committees.
At some companies, such committees are already at work without Federal goading. "I told him these things are happening because labor and management understand they have to happen, not because of any Government-run thing," said Representative Bill Goodling, Republican of Pennsylvania. He said the Government should not mandate something that was happening voluntarily.
 
'Workers Need a Voice'
 Many unions fear that Mr. Reich's committees could become a new avenue for industry to banish unions.
"The one danger I see with Reich," said Edward J. Carlough, president of the sheet metal workers union, "is that there may be a tendency to say, 'Let's establish labor-management cooperation committees all over the place.' But that can't happen in a nonunion atmosphere. It simply can't happen."
Mr. Reich expects his commission to modify the labor laws so unions could still have a place, though he said he would not require a role for them.
"The issue for me is worker voice," Mr. Reich said. "Workers need a voice at the workplace. I'm flexible about where that voice comes from or how it's expressed."
In the past, Mr. Reich has demonstrated that his grand ideas are not necessarily fixed ideas. A decade ago, Mr. Reich and a Rhodes-scholar classmate, Ira Magaziner, argued that the Government could help the economy grow by picking the companies and technologies most likely to thrive in world competition and favoring them with development aid.
Conservatives and moderate Democrats chafed at the notion of a Government that could outsmart the marketplace in selecting winners and losers among companies and industries. And when Mr. Reich saw his notions of industrial policy put to a real test, he reconsidered.
In "The Resurgent Liberal," a 1991 collection of essays, he criticized an ambitious economic development plan that Mr. Magaziner, now senior adviser to Hillary Rodham Clinton on health care, devised for Rhode Island in 1983. But Rhode Island voters rejected it 4 to 1.
"Industrial policy is fine so long as it builds on current policies and institutions," Mr. Reich wrote. "But wrap it in an elaborate plan and assign it to a 'strategic commission' comprised of big shots, and you can stuff it."
As Labor Secretary, Mr. Reich has devised a variation on his old notion of industrial policy: Government, not the industries themselves, would pick the skills it believes people need for emerging industries in the marketplace and help train the workers for those industries.
World economic leadership, Mr. Reich wrote two years ago in his book "The Work of Nations," required crews of "symbolic analysts" -- scientists, engineers, lawyers, managers, physicians, writers and others who identify and solve problems, by, as he puts it in his academic jargon "manipulating symbols."
Some people think these theories are no more realistic than the old ones about picking winners in industry. How, they ask, can the Government presume to know what skills the as-yet unknown new industries will need?
"There's a real fallacy in some universities and some parts of government that 'we are knowledgeable and we know what's best for business.' " said Jack Faris, president of the National Federation of Independent Business, an association of 610,000 small businesses.
Mr. Reich says that once people have the right skills the demand for those skills will appear.
"There's no finite number of good jobs out there," he said. "Look at the history of economic development since the Industrial Revolution. Technological change does not reduce the number of jobs."

(Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Vacationing by Car Makes Its Comeback at Full Speed

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
With gasoline cheap and plentiful, and expected to stay that way through the summer, Americans who put off trips during the economic doldrums of the last few years are hitting the road again.
The American Automobile Association, based on a survey of 1,500 drivers, predicted last week that travel during the Fourth of July weekend would be up 4 percent from the holiday weekend in 1992, with 30 million Americans planning to make trips of 100 miles or more. 
 Most will pump their own gas at self-serve stations and hunt for bargains at motels. Few said they were worried about the prospect of a gas tax of 4 cents to 5 cents a gallon, which seems likely if the tax bill now before Congress is passed.
Indeed, driving is widely seen as economical, compared with flying. The discount fares offered by the airlines are not as steep as they were during a fare war last summer, when ticket prices were slashed by as much as 50 percent. As a result, the number of people traveling by airplane is expected to decline 8 percent from 1992, the survey said.
"There is a new breed of traveler," said Jerry Cheske, the director of public relations for the automobile association. "They shop for vacations much like they shop for a TV or stereo."
Among those who are opting to travel by car is Bill Gardner. He paused a couple of days ago with his wife, Trina, and their three children at a service area on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, while en route to Ocean City, N.J., for a family reunion. They live in Western Springs, Ill., a Chicago suburb.
"It's a lot cheaper than going by plane," he said of the two-day trip in his Plymouth Voyager. The cost of gas is lower than in past years, he has found, and there are bargains at many of the motel chains along the way -- several had rates of $38 for a room, breakfast included.
Perhaps as a result, the automobile association survey found that more people planned to stay in motels this year: 43 percent, up from 37 percent a year ago. Only a quarter said they planned to stay with relatives, down from a third last year.
Few drivers seemed worried about the growing dependence of the United States on foreign oil, which is at an all-time high. About half the oil consumed in the United States in recent months has been from foreign sources.
 
Use of Imported Oil Up

 
 The dependence on imported oil has jumped this year, with consumption of foreign oil up 7.2 percent in May over the corresponding month last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute, a trade group based in Washington. Of total consumption of 17.1 million barrels a day, imports made up an average of 8.4 million barrels in May. Imports accounted for 49.1 percent of the oil consumed in May, up from 47.6 percent in May of last year.
Many motorists interviewed said that obeying the 55-mile-per-hour speed limit would be dangerous because the general flow of traffic is faster. Faster speeds mean greater gasoline consumption, and greater fuel costs.
Despite consuming extra gas at the faster speeds, motorists still look for bargains when they can find them. And bargains abound, enough of them to more than offset the costs of the proposed gasoline tax.
Nationally, the average price for self-serve regular unleaded gas was $1.12 a gallon last week, down 6.1 cents from a year ago, according to the automobile association. The average price of a gallon of gas in New York State was 5 cents less than it was a year ago, despite a 3-cent rise over the last two months because of high demand.
Prices are approaching the low levels that prevailed before the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq in August 1990. After that they took a huge jump. Recession and higher gas prices kept many travelers at home for the Fourth of July weekend in 1991.
One effect of lower gasoline prices seems to be a return to the free-wheeling speeds of earlier years. Mr. Gardner, like most motorists, said he no longer observed the 55 m.p.h. limit, even though there are reminders everywhere, like the signs in Pennsylvania that emphasize the speed limit is "still 55."
Mr. Gardner said the speed limit was unsafe because the general flow of traffic is 60 to 65 m.p.h. and there are the risks of being tailgated by impatient drivers.
Indeed, during a recent drive on the Pennsylvania Turnpike, a steady stream of cars traveling 60 to 65 m.p.h. passed several speed traps without any offenders being stopped.
Tom Culpepper, the manager of safety for the automobile association, said most states had adopted a 65 m.p.h. limit on roads in rural areas, an option allowed by Congress, which adopted the 55 m.p.h. limit to conserve gas during the early 1970's.
A side effect of the lower speed limit was a drop in the rate and severity of collisions, resulting in a decline in highway deaths and injuries for a time. But as gas prices have fallen, the average speed has been rising. Most drivers travel about 65 to 70 m.p.h. on the Interstate highways, Mr. Culpepper said. He said studies have differed on whether the higher speeds had led to an increase in deaths and injuries.
"The motoring public has decided that 55 miles an hour is not a reasonable speed," Mr. Culpepper added. "Historically the public has always responded to unreasonable highway traffic control by simply ignoring it."
Many drivers also appeared to ignore the anticipated bite of the proposed gas tax. Trilby Lundberg, the publisher of the Lundberg Newsletter, which covers the gasoline industry, said the impact of the tax on gas may have little effect at the pump.
Indeed, most drivers said in interviews that they were not worried about the proposed tax. Adding a few cents to the tax, Ms. Lundberg said, would not prove very costly for most Americans -- about $30 to $40 a year for the average family.
 
Demand for Gasoline Up
 Demand for gasoline has risen as drivers in some parts of the country have begun to shake off the recession. Gas sales were up 2 percent last year from the year before, and in May sales were up 1.2 percent over May of last year, according to the American Petroleum Institute.
Drivers kept costs down during the recession by using cheaper, lower grades of gasoline and pumping it themselves. About 95 percent of the gas sold now is at self-serve pumps.
The effects of the recession, however, have kept some families cautious. At the Thomas A. Edison rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike a couple of days ago, Gerald Goodlin, an auto parts salesman from Bellmore, L.I., said his family would like to make a trip to Florida later this summer but were reluctant because of the cost.
Other drivers had planned their trips far ahead and were determined to make long trips anyway.
Frank McCormack, a Canadian whose motor home was packed with his wife, June, their three children and his mother-in-law, Bertha, had started a vacation from their home on Prince Edward Island and had stopped in New York. Their destination is Vancouver, British Columbia, but they had decided to go the long way around, by way of Nashville.
"We've always wanted to see the States," Mr. McCormack said while getting gas at a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike. He said he had been pleasantly surprised by the low gas prices in the United States compared with those in Canada -- which are roughly $2 a gallon -- especially since his mobile home got about 12 miles to the gallon.
Which route did they plan to follow after they visit Nashville? "We're just going to go down the highway," he said with a gleam in his eye.

HEADLINE: U.S. TO ANNOUNCE NEW RUSSIAN PLAN

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is planning to use the economic meeting in Tokyo this week to announce the successful conclusion of talks among European allies and Japan on providing new aid to Russia for economic reforms.
The $500 million that the allies have agreed to provide includes a $125 million commitment from the United States, $120 million from Japan and $80 million from Germany, Administration officials said. 
 Mr. Clinton has been personally telephoning world leaders in a last-ditch effort to assemble an aid package that could be announced this week. On Saturday morning, he won the German commitment after talking to Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
The balance of the contributions is expected to come from Britain, Italy, France and Canada, whose leaders will all be present at this week's meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations. With the addition of $1.5 billion in aid from the World Bank, officials hope the entire package will reach $2 billion.
 
Clinton Had Sought $4 Billion
 In April, President Clinton, who has been leading the charge for providing international financial help to support President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, asked for $4 billion in international assistance. The money was to be used to help Russia transfer state assets to private control and restructure businesses that had never functioned in a capitalist economy.
But the chances for obtaining that amount of aid faded late last month when Japanese leaders expressed doubts about the plan and Foreign Minister Kabun Muto dismissed such levels as "preposterous." Administration officials have also begun conceding that it is a difficult task to demand that leaders who are weak at home -- as is the case with most of those who will be at the Tokyo conference -- push for a rapid expansion of foreign aid.
"If a leader's popularity and political power falls below a certain threshold, you can't bring them to agree on the time of day," one White House official said.
Administration officials have already begun looking for a way to present the more modest amount as the best choice.
 
Measuring the Pace of Aid
 "Part of what we have to do here is strike a balance between quick and smart," said one senior official involved in the Russia aid plan. "If you push the money out there too fast, it's hard to monitor, hard to make sure it reaches the people it's intended to reach."
Mr. Clinton has been pushing hard for the aid to support Mr. Yeltsin's reform efforts and has demanded frequent updates from his staff on the pace with which the United States has been keeping the commitments it made to the Russian leader during a meeting in Vancouver in April.
When the plan was unveiled in April, the United States agreed to contribute $500 million if the other nations would contribute $1.5 billion and another $2 billion was forthcoming from other international lending agencies.
Even though that amount has now been scaled back sharply, Mr. Clinton is still prepared to present the agreement to provide $500 million as evidence that the United States is following through on its Vancouver commitment.
Last week, the International Monetary Fund approved a $1.5 billion loan to Russia for 1993 after Treasury Secretary Lloyd M. Bentsen scolded the fund for being to slow to provide the money.

HEADLINE: When Saving Navy Money Costs Jobs

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
When Terry Melan ponders his prospects for surviving the military cuts that will cost him his job at the Charleston Naval Shipyard, he thinks of the last disaster to hit the South Carolina city. It does not brighten his mood.
"They talk about defense conversion, and I think about FEMA," said Mr. Melan, a 39-year-old boiler plate equipment mechanic, referring to the Federal Emergency Management Agency's widely criticized performance after Hurricane Hugo tore Charleston apart in 1989. "My personal opinion is we've been sold down the river." 
 On Friday, President Clinton announced a $5 billion plan to help communities cope with the military's plan to close 129 bases, including 35 major bases like the one in Charleston, and expanding or shrinking 27 others. Mr. Clinton has approved the plan, and Congress is now considering it. Approval is expected because of the lure of saving an expected $3.1 billion in military spending annually after the year 2000.
Nowhere are the immediate costs of a smaller military more stark and the knotty issues of converting from a military-based economy more daunting than in Charleston, where the Navy employs five times as many people as the next largest employer.
 
When 1 in 5 Jobs Vanish
 When the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission voted to close the Charleston Naval Shipyard and Charleston Naval Station, it was a decision that local officials say will cost 26,380 direct military and civilian jobs and about an equal number of nonmilitary jobs that depend on the base. That accounts for about 1 in 5 jobs in the three-county Charleston area, a higher percentage than anyplace else in the United States.
The commission voted to spare Charleston's Naval Hospital and to expand the Naval Electronics Support Center, known as Navelex, adding 2,700 well-paying technology jobs to what will be a 6,000-worker research center.
The outcome will be an almost $2 billion blow to the local economy and the dismantling of what was the largest employer at one site in South Carolina. The state gained national attention last year by luring a new BMW automobile plant that could bring 10,000 jobs to Spartanburg, across the state. Officials estimate the losses in Charleston will be five times the gains from BMW.
"This is a staggering blow, because it's not simply this event in itself," said Kent Bosworth, president of the Bosworth Group, a Charleston marketing firm. "It's the aftermath of Hugo, a flat economy and now this. I think there is not a business that will be untouched."
 
Wounding the Working Class
 Still, the bulk of the impact will not be seen in the Charleston of pastel townhouses, horse-drawn carriages and cobblestone streets that lure tourists. Instead, it will be felt in the working-class neighborhoods of sprawling apartment complexes, trailer parks and neat cottages with weathered fishing boats out front in towns like North Charleston, Hanahan and Goose Creek that live and die with the 2,800-acre naval base, whose roots go back to 1901.
As much as the laid-off workers, the dozens of business that rely on the base will feel the blow of its closing.
"A lot of them won't survive; we know that," said John M. Settle, who this week took over as president of the Charleston Trident Chamber of Commerce. "But our primary short-term goal is to keep consumer confidence up and to show there are ways to help business and industry relocate in the area. We need to convince people this is not going to put us in a depression."
For business people near the base -- like Ron Coley, who runs North Area Transmission, which was started by his grandfather 45 years ago; Sammie Douan at B& S Gun Shop, or Johnny Thigpen at Johnny's restaurant and bar -- it will take some convincing.
"Our property values have dropped to the point where it's not even salable," Mr. Coley said. "At one time, this was the place to be. Now it's really worthless."
 
Good Plan, Bad Timing
 The mechanic, Mr. Melan, said that the President's proposals to cushion the blow were largely a step in the right direction, but that given the severity of the dislocation in Charleston he was skeptical how helpful they would be. And he said some of the recommendations, like a push to expedite base closings so communities could make use of the properties, could hurt workers by cutting down the time their jobs would continue. Charleston officials have already begun mobilizing along the lines of Mr. Clinton's proposal.
"It's good something is being done," Mr. Melan said. "But until we actually see whether it works, I'm not going to put much stock in it."
To some experts, the change in Charleston highlights the most vexing and dangerous byproduct of shrinking the military in a sluggish economy: it is taking away good-paying blue-collar industrial jobs at precisely the time the economy is failing to produce them. Officials say the $30,000-a-year, blue-collar jobs at the base pay about twice as much as the average job in the area.
"Given the end of the cold war, it would be foolish to maintain the military of the size we had, but I just question whether or not we can afford the peace," said J. Michael Morgan, chairman of the economics and finance department at the College of Charleston. "I just don't know where our shipyard workers, who are highly skilled, are going to find jobs."
Charleston officials are lobbying for other government jobs, seeking to have the shutdown stretched over as long a time as possible, lining up economic assistance and job-training programs and trying to woo new businesses.
 
Fishing for New Employers
 State and area leaders led by Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. and Mayor Joseph Riley of Charleston have set up a 37-member commission to coordinate economic development efforts. Mr. Riley said he had already been in contact with one group about a possible private shipbuilding and ship repair operation.
But industry officials say the American shipbuilding business is already facing a depression because of the military cuts and foreign competition subsidized by governments in places like Japan and South Korea.
Charleston officials say that shipbuilding is only one option and that the new high-tech Navelex jobs are more likely to be a central part of a redevelopment strategy in their city. And there is ample reason for long-range optimism about Charleston.
The area's growing tourism, retirement, medical and educational sectors have thus far cushioned the area from smaller, but still substantial, military reductions. Military and related jobs in Charleston have fallen by 9,723 or 21.4 percent since 1989, but total employment has grown by 6.7 percent.
With its combination of rich history, lovely architecture and deep-water industrial amenities, Charleston is hardly a dying town. In fact, the city, which has survived hurricanes, a major earthquake, the Civil War and the rise and fall of other industries, provides ample precedent for surviving hard times.
 
The Silver Lining?

 And most experts agree the current traumas will force the area, which once depended on the military for 60 percent of its economy, to diversify in a way it should have decades ago.
"Twenty years from now, we'll probably say this was the best thing that ever happened to us," said Mr. Settle, "but that won't help those who've lost their jobs in the meantime."
Some say it was a mistake not to plan years ago for a conversion to peacetime uses of military installations.
"Our union was talking about economic conversion 10 years ago, but the Reagan and Bush Administrations wouldn't hear of it; they didn't think we needed it," said Jim Davidson, a 49-year-old marine machinist at the naval shipyard. "Look what's happening now."
But both because of its losses and its strengths, Mr. Riley said, Charleston will be a good test of how traumatic the military cuts will be.
"This is a good, strong community," he said. "We're going to need some help, but we're committed to making this a positive thing. This is a good test market for us to show it can work."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks To Resume

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 4

 BODY:
The United States and Japan will resume negotiations on a new comprehensive trade agreement, officials said today, brightening the outlook for President Clinton's meeting this week with the Prime Minister of Japan, Kiichi Miyazawa.
The Clinton Administration has decided that a Japanese compromise proposal, delivered to Washington on Friday, is substantive enough to merit further discussion, according to officials familiar with the negotiations. 
 American negotiators are expected to arrive in Tokyo late Monday night to resume talks that broke off last week in a deadlock. The sticking point was American insistence on setting numerical goals to measure Japan's progress in opening its markets and reducing its trade surplus.
It is still unclear whether an agreement on the so-called economic framework can be reached this week, the original deadline set by the President and the Prime Minister. Certainly, it will be difficult to forge an accord by Tuesday, when the two leaders will meet privately on the eve of the summit conference of the Group of Seven industrial nations.
 
 
Out of the Shadow
 Yet the revival of the negotiations removes a cloud that would have darkened the meeting of the heads of the world's two largest economies. At the very least, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Miyazawa will be able to announce that progress is being made.
There is some speculation in Tokyo that the two leaders may even be able to announce a bare-bones framework, with details to be worked out later. But an incomplete accord would seem to be against the wishes of Mr. Clinton, who has been pushing, aides have said, for a good agreement rather than a quick one.
When Mr. Clinton and Mr. Miyazawa met in Washington in April, they agreed to forge a new framework covering economic relations between the two countries by the time they met again in Tokyo for the Group of Seven conference, which begins on Wednesday. But last week, the United States-Japan talks here broke off when Japan refused to agree to trade benchmarks, saying such measures violate the principles of free trade.
 On Friday, Mr. Miyazawa sent a letter to Mr. Clinton proposing a compromise. The Prime Minister, having lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament last month that is likely to cost him his job, is eager to have a smooth meeting with Mr. Clinton.
As a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said on Friday, insisting on anonymity, "If the Prime Minister who agreed to set up the framework can't work out its details, then the next Prime Minister will find it even more difficult to do so."
By putting his personal stamp on the compromise, Mr. Miyazawa has raised the political ante, making it difficult for the American side to decline to come back to Tokyo for negotiations, even if only as a courtesy. But the resumption of talks does not necessarily mean the United States is enthusiastic about Japan's proposal, said a United States official in Washington, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
In its compromise proposal, Japan said it would be willing to establish quantitative or qualitative indexes to measure progress in opening markets or changing its economic structure, although it still would not agree to set targets in advance. For instance, Japan might agree to measure the share of its market held by foreign products in a particular industry but would not set a goal for what that market share should be.
Depending on the exact wording, this proposal might help close the gap with the United States.
 
Refusal to Set Goals
 Japan also said it would agree to take steps to reduce its trade surplus, though it would refuse to set goals for this as well. This offer seems to fall well short of the American request that Japan agree to cut its current- account surplus to 1 and 2 percent of its economic output over the next three years or so, down from more than 3 percent now.
The two nations are seeking a framework that will cover more specific negotiations in the coming months and years.
These negotiations will aim at increasing Japan's markets for particular products, like automobile parts, and for bringing about structural changes in Japan's economy, like deregulating industries. Reduction of the United States budget deficit and American trade barriers are also expected to be subjects of discussion.
The framework is expected to require a consultative committee of officials from both countries to meet regularly to monitor progress. The framework will also call for periodic meetings of the President and the Prime Minister.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Bentsen Criticizes Japan
 WASHINGTON, July 4 (By Bloomberg Business News) -- Japanese officials who recently complained that the Clinton Administration practices managed trade are themselves masters of that trade policy, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today.
His comments, made on the ABC News program "This Week With David Brinkley," came as he and President Clinton prepared to meet with officials of Japan and other industrial nations in the summit meeting, which begins in Tokyo on Wednesday.
"It's amazing for the Japanese, of all people, to talk about how they're against managed trade," Mr. Bentsen said. "They've done a very effective job of that."

HEADLINE: Giveaways a Cottage Industry in Maine

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me.

 BODY:
Arthur Leach is $11,000 poorer since he sponsored an unsuccessful contest last year to "give away" his waterfront house to the best essayist.
But that has not stopped him from starting another contest, only now he wants to give away the house for a song -- in fact, a jingle of 41 words or less. 
 In Maine, where a sluggish economy has undermined housing prices and driven would-be sellers to unconventional methods to retrieve the money invested in their homes, real estate giveaway contests are becoming almost as common as the tourists who enter them.
Unable to find buyers through more conventional methods, more and more property owners are sponsoring contests in which they try to collect their asking prices by amassing hundreds or thousands of individual entry fees, in some cases up to $250.
 
Innkeepers' Success Story
 The catalyst for the recent interest in contests was the success in May of two innkeepers, Bil and Susie Mosca of Center Lovell, Me., who gave away their country inn through an essay contest that cost $100 to enter. The Moscas' contest attracted 7,000 entrants, but since they were only asking $500,000 for the inn, they are returning the last 2,000 entries.
Since then, the Maine Attorney General's Office has received 3 to 10 calls a day from people interested in running similar contests, said Wayne Moss, an Assistant Attorney General. The contests are legal in Maine if they are "games of skill" rather than gambling.
Mr. Moss said he had discouraged people from sponsoring the contests, warning them of the potential expense and telling them about the Maine residents who had sponsored similar contests that failed.
 
A $31,000 Investment
 In his well-publicized contests, for example, Mr. Leach invested $31,000 in postage, advertising and a toll-free telephone number, which Mr. Leach and his wife, Shirley, staffed themselves. The winner was to be the essayist who wrote most eloquently about why it would be wonderful to live by the ocean in Kennebunkport. But the first contest, which cost $99 to enter, failed to attract half of the 3,500 entrants needed to cover Mr. Leach's investment of nearly $350,000 in the house.
Undaunted, Mr. Leach restructured the contest, giving back the entry fees of those who requested it and offering others the chance to enter a new contest in which the prize would be the cash left after he paid part of his expenses. Ultimately, he recovered $20,000 of his $31,000 investment and awarded a cash prize of $42,000 to a woman in Wellesley, Mass.
Now Mr. Leach is back in the contest business, riding around this oceanside resort town in a two-toned pickup truck with a sign advertising: "Win a Custom House." He still has faith that 7,000 people will send $50 and write a jingle for the chance to win his three-bedroom house. So far, 1,000 people have responded, sending in jingles on the topic: "Why I Would Love to Live on the Coast of Maine." The deadline is Oct. 1.
Noting that there were many second-time entrants, Mr. Leach said he believed that the first contest had helped build his credibility. Local professionals were the judges, as they will be for his current contest.
Joanne Skinner of Acton, Mass., a retired Congressional aide who participated in the Leaches' essay contest, is one of many who has an eye on their house. The two-story gray-shingle house is tucked away on a dead-end street a few miles from the summer home of former President George Bush. She recently returned to Kennebunkport to "gather material" for her jingle.
Mr. Leach, a real estate developer at a time when work is scarce, and his wife, a former bank manager who works at a boat repair shop, bought the house in 1988 as an investment. But like many other people who bought real estate in southern Maine in the late 1980's, the Leaches cannot hope to recoup their money on the conventional market.
Mr. Leach said he had bought the house "at the peak. I paid too much for it, and then the bottom fell out." He hopes that unloading the house through the contest will produce a smaller loss than selling in the current market.
But the couple has already had to dip into savings to pay off home equity loans and other debts, Mrs. Leach said. Noting that her parents had lost a pharmacy in the Depression, she said, "We should have heeded what our parents had known."
If all else fails, Mr. Leach said, he may make a business out of advising others on how to run giveaway contests.

HEADLINE: Ice Cream Brings Call Of Foul Play

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WALLKILL, N.Y., July 2

 BODY:
What started out as a campaign gimmick -- the distribution of discount coupons for Dairy Queen treats -- has turned into a criminal investigation.
For some Democrats here, the episode, which has naturally been labeled "Ice Cream-Gate," is providing the sort of tasty summer fare the name connotes. For others, it's another setback in their party's efforts to gain strength in Republican-dominated Orange County. 
 Peter Panse, a 42-year-old high school art teacher who is running for Town Supervisor here, handed out campaign leaflets containing coupons for discounts on ice cream, frozen yogurt and soft drinks at a Dairy Queen in neighboring Middletown. Next to the coupons, a brief message trumpets Mr. Panse as the candidate of honest government, saying, "So help yourself to delicious savings from Dairy Queen -- and vote yourself a brighter future in the Democratic primary."
 
Inquiry by District Attorney
 The Orange County District Attorney, Francis D. Phillips, is investigating whether Mr. Panse offered the coupons in an attempt to induce voters to sign petitions for him.
Mr. Panse said he had given the coupons to everyone he approached, whether or not they signed.
If found guilty of violating the state election law, Mr. Panse could face up to a year in jail and a fine of $1,000, Mr. Phillips said. If some of Mr. Panse's petitions are invalidated, forms that Mr. Panse and supporters carried for seven other county and town candidates could also be thrown out, said David Flanagan, spokesman for the New York State Board of Elections.
Mr. Phillips said he expects his investigation to be completed around the July 15 filing deadline for the Sept. 14 primary.
One of Mr. Panse's opponents for the Democratic nomination, Nina DeSocio, wrote a letter of protest to the county Board of Elections, which forwarded the complaint to Mr. Phillips. "The Democrats have had a very hard time establishing the Democratic Party as a viable presence in Orange County," she wrote. "To have this destroyed cannot be allowed."
 
Still Seeking Signatures
 Shirley Jensen, the county's Republican election commissioner, said she has never heard of a complaint like this in her 13 years on the job. "I just wonder why a person running in one town would have coupons for a business in another town," she said.
Mr. Panse, who said he wanted to promote small businesses, said the Town of Wallkill and the city of Middletown are "linked economically and socially." His stepdaughter Claudine Rietsch, a graduate student at Baruch College and treasurer of the Orange County Democratic Party, has worked on and off at the Dairy Queen since high school.
Mr. Pansesaid the controversy has helped his campaign by giving him greater name recognition. He and his wife, Susan Rietsch-Panse, the chairwoman of the Wallkill Democratic Committee, have started a new quest for the 189 signatures necessary to get on the ballot. This time, they're leaving the coupons home.
"It's ridiculous that these people are really suggesting that signatures or votes could be purchased for as little as two dollars," Mr. Panse said.
 
'Mockery of Our Election'
 Joseph DeStefano, chairman of the Orange County Democratic Party, likened the coupons to the pens and combs that candidates hand out.
The difference, Ms. DeSocio said, a 44-year-old freelance accountant, is that the coupons have "a redeemable value."
"He's making a mockery of our election," she said.
The third Democratic candidate in the race is the incumbent, Bill Cummings, who has been Town Supervisor for two years. His view: Mr. Panse "should just say, 'Hey, I made a mistake,' and move on from there."
Mr. DeStefano said he is worried the inquiry will hurt the party's chances in November against the Republican candidate, Howard Mills. There are 4,360 registered Republicans and 3,726 Democrats in Wallkill, a town of roughly 23,000 people about 60 miles northeast of New York City.
"This is something that doesn't belong in a district attorney's office," Mr. DeStefano said. "There are so many problems in this county they should focus on, like drugs and crime, and let the politicians play politics."
 
All Smiles at Dairy Queen
 If the controversy has caused headaches for the county Democratic Party, it has been a bonanza for the Dairy Queen owner, Michael D'Ascheberg.
Mr. D'Ascheberg, who says he does not support Mr. Panse, has redeemed more than 100 coupons. He said that Mr. Panse had paid the cost of printing the coupons and that the store had supplied the ice cream.
"I've had orders from as far away as Tuxedo and Greenwood Lake," he said. "People call up and say: 'We didn't realize there's a Dairy Queen in the area. We're going to buy our cakes from you from now on.'
"If people think this will put a candidate over the top, tell President Clinton, Ross Perot and the Republican challenger to come to Middletown and see me."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Uproar on TV Violence Frustrates the Networks

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
Despite the criticism of broadcast networks heard in Congressional hearings during the last several weeks, and the campaigns by interest groups to censor programming deemed too violent for young viewers, there is strong evidence that network series are less violent now than in decades.
Executives of ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox Broadcasting say the shows that people are most upset about are not even on the networks but on cable or independent stations. Still, the executives realize that they are the ones on the political hot seat, and they are concerned that their business will be significantly hurt. 
 Several network executives called the Congressional hearings into violence on television ill-informed, unsophisticated and motivated by the chance to make political gains against an easy target, network television.
Specifically, they emphasized that singling out network programming as excessively violent was unfair. "It is completely frustrating because there has been such a significant reduction in violence on network shows," said Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment. "There hasn't been this little violence on the network in decades."
 
Fewer Crime Dramas
 The evidence suggests that Mr. Littlefield is right. Ten years ago, the prime-time schedules of ABC, CBS and NBC -- Fox did not exist then -- included at least 16 shows that could be labeled "crime dramas." Among the shows heavy on gunplay and fisticuffs were "T. J. Hooker," "Matt Houston," "Chips" and "Magnum P.I."
Twenty years ago, there were 20 crime, spy and cowboy dramas, including such memorably macho entries as "Streets of San Francisco," "The Rookies," "Mod Squad," and "Hawaii Five-O."
The past television season had just a smattering of crime-oriented shows, including "Law and Order," "Homicide" and "The Hat Squad." But the first two were almost entirely about police procedures, not about street chases and fistfights.
Far and away the most common shows on network television today are sitcoms. One reason action series have largely disappeared is economic reality: the networks know they cannot match the spectacular displays of action and violence now available in expensive "Rambo"- and "Terminator"-type films. So they have moved away from that genre.
The network executives tried to make this case during the Congressional hearings, pointing out that the most graphic violence on television takes place either on cable channels, where even the goriest films run uncensored, or on independent channels (like WPIX and WWOR in New York), which also have less stringent standards for violent content.
One fact weakens the networks' arguments: the recent proliferation of made-for-TV films based on lurid real-life stories. Several of those films turned up in May, during the intense ratings competition known as a sweeps month. "The timing of the May movies was singularly bad," said Howard Stringer, president of the CBS Broadcast Group.
Faced with the threat of legislation that might hurt their business even more, the networks felt obliged to respond. They agreed last week to precede programs that are particularly violent with an announcement to parents that says so.
Some network executives fear that the announcement -- "Due to some violent content, parental discretion advised" -- will only drive away nervous advertisers. A warning label "has the potential to cost us up to $20 million next fall," Mr. Stringer said.
Richard J. Glosman, the chairman of Creative Media, a company that buys television time for advertisers, said, "A warning label is probably going to make squeamish advertisers even more squeamish."
 
The Network Dilemma
 Mr. Stringer said increased advertiser skittishness would worsen a perennial problem for the networks in their competition with cable: all network revenue comes from advertising, while cable networks make money in two ways, from advertising and from fees paid by subscribers.
The network executives who believe they were scapegoated said some members of Congress who criticized them did not seem to understand the difference between network and other forms of television.
Some executives said it was apparent that the politicians watched very little television. One executive said that despite long interview sessions with network officials, some committee staff members never understood the difference between the stations that a network owns and its affiliates, which are owned by other companies.
David Westin, the senior vice president of Capital Cities Communications, parent of ABC, said, "We were certainly struck by the lack of sophistication about the difference between network television and cable television and local television."
Senator Paul Simon, the Illinois Democrat who headed the Senate committee looking into television violence, disputed the accusation. He said his staff had come to "understand the field" before the hearings were held.
"I'm not suggesting they are any worse than cable," Mr. Simon said of the networks. "But to say there has been a drastic reduction in violence, I think the May sweeps give you a good idea that that's not true."
 
Amy, Amy, Amy
 Indeed, the networks showed movies in May like "Murder in the Heartland," about a serial killer, and other films based on true-crime stories. Last winter, three networks showed movies based on the Amy Fisher case on Long Island.
These movies do well in the ratings and can also cost less to produce because they do not require writers to devise original stories. These movies are also easier to promote because they have notoriety built in.
Mr. Simon said, "The evidence is overwhelming that television adds to violence in our society," a point he said was supported by network executives, including Mr. Stringer and Mr. Littlefield, in the news conference held last week to announce the parental advisory. Mr. Simon also said it was fair to single out the networks because "they reach the largest audience and they are culprits."
Network executives did not deny that they had economic incentives to oppose further concessions on violence. Foremost is the fear that viewers who enjoy action-oriented shows will simply abandon network television.
Mr. Littlefield gave an example of how viewers might look elsewhere for excitement. He noted a recent decision at his network not to buy the broadcast rights to the movie "Falling Down," which starred Michael Douglas as an ordinary urban resident who, caught in one too many traffic jams, goes on a violent rampage.
"We screened it," Mr. Littlefield said. "And we knew right away it would never appear on our network. So we passed on it."
He added, "We also know that independent stations will buy it, will run it uncut -- and will clobber us."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Network executives say their programming is less violent. NBC, for instance, said it declined to bid for the film "Falling Down," starring Michael Douglas, above, as an urban resident who goes on a rampage. (Warner Bros. Inc.)
