HEADLINE: Easy Prey for a Violent Criminal;
Prostitutes View Murder as Just One Occupational Hazard

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
The 23-year-old prostitute, who says her name is Margie, walked the stroll off Allen Street in lower Manhattan in a baggy black halter top and baggier jeans, eyeing every passing car.
She said she had seen Joel Rifkin, who the police say is New York's latest serial killer, circling the neighborhood in his white pickup, soliciting prostitutes. She even knew a few women who had dated him. But she didn't want to talk about it. Or even hear of it. 
 "Don't talk to me about no serial killer," she said wearily. It was late, after 1 A.M., and she needed money for a cocaine fix. "I don't want to hear any more bad news about the Life. I've been working six years. It's bad enough."
In the week since Mr. Rifkin, an unemployed gardener from East Meadow, L.I., confessed to killing 17 women he said were prostitutes, women like Margie have been forced to confront, or ignore, the reality that so many women disappeared without attracting notice.
Many prefer to ignore it. Even as the authorities were sorting out Mr. Rifkin's murderous stories, prostitutes were going about their business throughout the city, in force, as usual. For them, serial killers are just another occupational hazard. Violence is the nature of the beast. And working girls, as prostitutes like to be called, often disappear, never to be heard from again.
 
Violent Crimes and Unexplained Disappearances
 Outside the world of prostitution, Mr. Rifkin has underscored what is obvious to those within -- that prostitutes, anonymous and reviled by society, are the criminal's easiest targets. In recent interviews with a dozen prostitutes in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, every woman recounted instances in which she was beaten, robbed, raped or stabbed. They all said they knew someone who had been murdered or someone who had disappeared.
"One sicko isn't going to stop girls from working," said a 27-year-old woman standing with her pimp in front of a no-name hotel on 25th Street and Lexington Avenue. Like most of the other women interviewed, she did not want to talk much about Mr. Rifkin. "There are a lot of sick men out there," she said. "Most of them are sick, in fact."
In fact, they are seldom shocked when the quiet, polite man-next-door is exposed as a violent criminal. The meek accountant who does your taxes could be the same man who likes to beat prostitutes bloody, they say, and the upstanding judge who goes to church every Sunday could be the "date" who buys a couple of working girls for rough sex every Tuesday and Thursday. Prostitutes follow a credo: expect the worst.
They often get it.
 
Crimes Are Seldom Reported
 But driven by the demands of drugs or pimps that keep them hustling long hours, and their fear of the police, most prostitutes say working girls never take the time to report crimes against them. And they seldom report the disappearance of an acquaintance on the streets.
"I don't think we watch out for each other as much as we should," said a 28-year-old woman who identified herself as D. She works the Queens side of the Queensboro Bridge and has noticed that another prostitute has been missing for about eight weeks, she said.
"I'm worried about her," she said. "But sometimes a girl moves, or she gets arrested."
On the stroll, in a desolate warehouse area where most of the working girls are drug addicts, D. has been raped, she said, eight or nine times. She said she had told the police about a pack of 40 to 50 boys from nearby projects who like to chase and rape prostitutes. But the police said they deserved it, she said bitterly.
 
'They Almost Caught Me'
 "About four or five years ago, they almost caught me," she said of the pack of boys. "I was screaming down the street and cars were passing as if it were all right." Another prostitute, who was in a cab with a date, let her in the car just as the pack was almost upon her, she added.
To survive, prostitutes say they have to follow their instincts when it comes to choosing their clients, or dates. Men dressed in business suits and driving new cars are considered safer than men in pickup trucks and vans. And a car that spends too much time circling the area prostitutes stroll is often considered suspicious.
"You can tell by the way someone talks to you, or looks," said the woman in front the hotel at 25th Street and Lexington. "But you never can tell." She remembered one time she agreed to let a date take her from Manhattan to his house on Long Island. "He was a short, fat guy with glasses," she said. When they got to his house, he put his hand over her mouth and said he was going to rape her. "I started screaming and I kicked out his window and ran," she said.
In recent months, she added, prostitutes in the neighborhood became the target of a man who would lure the women into his car, smash their heads with a brick hidden in a paper bag, then slash their throats. "He didn't kill anyone, but he came close," she said.
 
'I Don't Want to Be Out Here'
 The last time she was almost killed, Zulma, a 34-year-old heroin addict who strolls the streets under the elevated tracks in Morris Park in the Bronx, vowed never to get into a car with a date she considered suspicious. The date who stabbed her had pierced her abdomen and scarred her legs. But when she needs a fix, she sometimes breaks her vow. "I don't want to be out here, taking all this abuse," she said, adding quietly, "I used to be pretty."
Prostitutes who are pimped are often abused by the men who are paid supposedly to protect them. "The girls are completely loyal to the pimps; they never turn them in," said Lieutenant John Gilchrist of the Public Morals Division of the Manhattan South Precinct.
But outreach workers and the police say that crack addicts who have turned to prostitution to support their habit are the most vulnerable on the streets, since they tend to jump in the first car that stops for them.
"The women we see are resourceless," said Allannah Thomas, a project manager for the Foundation for Research on Sexually Transmitted Diseases, which distributes condoms, conducts H.I.V. testing and provides other outreach services to prostitutes throughout New York City.
"The women are hurt by dates, by their personal partners and in the course of drug transactions. A lot of times people come up to us and ask us to dress wounds."
 
'You Never Really Know'
 Ricardo Ayala, an outreach worker for the foundation, said that in the two years since he began driving the foundation's van, distributing condoms and testing women for H.I.V., he has noticed that many women simply disappear.
"Sometimes the girls tell us about the ones that disappear," he said. "They tell us this woman moved, this one died, this one was killed. But you never really know."
On Thursday night, the van cut short its rounds in a warehouse district in Long Island City because two men who prey on prostitutes, robbing and raping them at knifepoint, had scared the working girls away.
"These guys intimidated the women; they've all left," said Mr. Ayala. "You see, they tell us about these things that happen to them -- getting raped and stabbed and robbed, but no one ever does anything to help them."
Lisa, who has been a prostitute for about five years to support a drug habit and strolls the Allen Street area, has learned the warning signs of a violent date through trial and error.
 
Almost Killed
 "The first couple of years, I got raped so many times it stopped bothering me," she said early Friday morning, as she stood against an apartment house waiting for her boyfriend to bring her drugs. Once, she said, a man almost strangled her. He became violent after she tried to jump from his car when he demanded his money back because he had failed to reach an orgasm.
By the time she starting seeing Mr. Rifkin circle the neighborhood, she said, she had honed her street smarts. She remembered he seemed nervous, and she said she does not get in a car with a man who seems nervous.
The woman on 25th Street and Lexington, who has been working the streets for 10 years, said most experienced working girls know how to use their heels and nails as weapons. A small woman, under 5 feet tall and 100 pounds, she keeps her nails, painted bright pink, two inches long. Her shoes, pink strappy sandals, have four-inch heels.
"These go a long way," she said, lifting her leg to show her heels. "You have to be prepared to kill somebody or be killed."

HEADLINE: Asia and Italy Are Fruitful For Investors

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The Government is collapsing and the economy stalling, but the Japanese stock market is doing just fine. The Japanese recovery, evident on the stock exchange floor but absent elsewhere, continued in the second quarter, far outpacing the returns from most of the world's other leading markets in the second quarter.
American investors in other international markets found that currency losses aggravated weak performances by most major European markets, leaving French stocks at the bottom in dollar terms and German stocks not much better. The best returns among the 24 leading world markets came in Italy, where elections and investigations of political corruption have brought hopes of political changes. 
 In regional terms, East Asian markets seemed to offer the best returns for Americans. Investors in Japan gained almost equally from higher stock prices and a stronger yen. Stocks advanced 9.5 percent in terms of the yen, and 17.9 percent in dollars, as the Japanese currency reached record highs.
 
'Starved for Growth'
 Asia's emerging markets, including Hong Kong, Singapore and Malaysia, had double-digit advances: in their own currencies and in dollars.
"The world is starved for growth," said Steven Nagourney, the chief global strategist at Lehman Brothers. "The prospects for growth remain greatest in the Far East."
Hong Kong has also gained from reduced tensions between Britain and China. The falling value of the currency in China, where many Hong Kong companies have partnerships and plants, has caused Hong Kong stocks to retreat from their highs.
American stocks were off just a fraction of a percent during the quarter, with the advantage of low interest rates offset by slow economic growth.
Strategists said the prospects would continue to be better abroad, especially for those who could handle volatile currencies.
 
Hedging Risks
 As economies in Europe continue to stagger, said David C. Roche, a global strategist at Morgan Stanley, governments are likely to cut interest rates. Stocks would then rise, but currencies would plummet, so American investors should hedge their risks. "Nobody in their right mind wants to own a European currency," he said.
The recent splintering of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party amid scandal and a slowing economy caused stocks there to give up only a slice of their gains. The Government has embarked on huge spending programs and prodded financial institutions to pour money into stocks.

HEADLINE: Haitian General Begins a Selling Job;
Haitians in U.S. Hopeful

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Haitian immigrants in New York spoke with great caution about the latest sign that democracy would be restored to their homeland. But in the end, there was more hope than misgiving in their voices.
Haitians around the city went about their normal routines yesterday, gathering in churches, barber shops and restaurants, where they eagerly exchanged news from back home. 
 There was no great celebration, only the crossing of fingers by those huddled over newspaper reports and hopeful prayers including those of a Haitian congregation in Flatbush, Brooklyn.
 
'Wait and See'
 "People are skeptical," said the Rev. Rollin Darbouze, the pastor of Holy Cross Church at 2530 Church Avenue in Brooklyn, which for years has provided food and lodging to refugees from Haiti. "Things can change in an instant, and then we're back where we started. That's why we have to wait and see."
On a day when Americans were celebrating their nation's independence, many immigrants recalled the price their compatriots in Haiti had paid under the military leaders who ousted President Aristide.
They spoke of their homeland's abject poverty, brutal political repression and hunger, wondering among themselves about the wisdom of an accord that would allow the military to remain in place until President Aristide returned, and possibly afterward.
"There is great reason to be concerned," said Jean Mercius, 39, the owner of a clothing store on Flatbush Avenue. "The problem is that the crime organization -- those who brought the coup -- are still in town."
Mr. Mercius, whose father helped organize support for Father Aristide's election in 1990, added, "These people still have much political and economic influence, and it will be very hard for them to go away."

HEADLINE: Keep the Aid Flowing to Russia

 BODY:
Economic reform in Russia is alive and surprisingly well. Finally, the West is taking notice and moving to provide real help. Last week the International Monetary Fund handed Russia $1.5 billion. The World Bank has approved a mammoth $660 million loan to develop Russia's oil industry, and dispersed hundreds of millions to pay for medicine and other needed imports.
President Clinton deserves credit for persuading his allies to aid Russia. He pressured the I.M.F. to provide money before Russia could complete key reforms; he orchestrated the West's offer of a $28 billion package in April and pushed a $2.5 billion bilateral aid bill through the House. 
 This week when leaders from the seven leading industrialized nations meet at the economic summit in Tokyo, they're expected to approve Mr. Clinton's plan to create a fund to help privatize Russian firms. These are worthy ways to help Russia build a market-based economy and reel a former foe firmly into the Western orbit.
Prices in Russia rose an astonishing 2,000 percent in 1992. Russia was on the verge of hyperinflation created by irresponsible monetary and fiscal policies. But after victory in the April referendum, President Boris Yeltsin gained a measure of control. His Government has begun to cut back spending by raising energy prices and reducing subsidies to state-owned enterprises. And the central bank has raised interest rates and pledged to pull back on explosive increases in the money supply.
These policies aren't yet tough enough -- which is why the I.M.F. had previously refused to release aid. But Mr. Yeltsin complained that without aid to ease the pain, he couldn't overcome opposition to tighter fiscal and monetary policies. The United States agreed, urging the monetary fund to provide aid on the basis of the steps Mr. Yeltsin has already taken and those his Government has pledged for the future. Last week, the I.M.F. signed on.
The Yeltsin Government's most spectacular economic achievement to date has been the rapid privatization of thousands of state enterprises. But merely turning firms over to private owners doesn't accomplish very much. For those firms to prosper, they need cash to buy modern equipment and technical help. To that end, Mr. Clinton proposed an innovative solution: the West would create a $4 billion fund to provide equity in newly privatized firms. But Japan and other allies shamefully balked at the cost.
Mr. Clinton has lobbied hard to get the allies to commit at least $2 billion to start the privatization fund; this week he's expected to prevail. The Western leaders meeting in Tokyo also need to reaffirm the $28 billion pledge they made in the spring. Mr. Clinton's next task is to convince the Senate to follow the lead of the House and pass his bilateral aid package. These measures taken together could keep Russian reforms on a roll.
Western leaders will address other issues in Tokyo: completing the all-important Uruguay Round of international trade talks and coordinating recovery from worldwide recession. But agreement on these issues is probably beyond reach.
Agreement on aid to Russia, however, is possible. At previous summits, Mr. Yeltsin heard lots of dandy promises from the West. He's now kept his end of the bargain. What he needs to see, when he visits the summit on Friday, is cash. His success is vital to the security of the West, as well as to the lives of ordinary Russians.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
'We Hold (Some) Truths . . .'

 BODY:
Americans deem it self-evident that men and women everywhere are created equal, with the same universal right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness, just as the Declaration of Independence says. But third-world countries like Indonesia say otherwise, claiming that human rights vary in place and time, and that enforcement is "the competence and responsibility of each government."
Decoded, that seems to say that human rights are what local police say they are -- which is ridiculous and reprehensible. Yet having proclaimed universal principles, Americans once indulged in the same shameless reasoning. Americans not only permitted slavery at home, but with bolder effrontery resisted an international effort to end the slave trade at sea. 
 This self-critical note is certainly not amiss on a weekend of noisy self-congratulation.
After the final defeat of Napoleon, the victorious European allies gathered at the Congress of Vienna in 1815 to negotiate an enduring settlement. One item on a crowded agenda was the slave trade. The British Foreign Secretary, Lord Castlereagh, worked diligently to win approval of a declaration calling for total abolition of "a commerce so odious and so strongly condemned by the laws of religion and nature."
It was perhaps the first multinational attempt to end a human rights crime. Sanctions were proposed, and a "watching committee" instituted to monitor compliance. But the United States, while paying lip service to the cause, failed to enforce, or let Britain enforce, maritime measures against slavers.
The Vienna declaration came after decades of ineffective attempts by individual nations, beginning with Denmark in 1792, to abolish slave trading. By 1807, the British Parliament called for total suppression, and a year later, the U.S. Congress adopted similar legislation. Nevertheless, the trade flourished. Finally, at Vienna, Britain pressed for an international right of visit and search on the high seas, with the Royal Navy serving as policeman.
Castlereagh then sought American agreement on a mutual but limited right of search, but was informed by a U.S. diplomat that this was not adaptable to U.S. institutions. So began an argument that lasted for decades over suppressing the slave trade. Not until 1842 did the two countries approve a compromise treaty giving joint English and American squadrons a right to search.
The result was summarized by the distinguished maritime historian Samuel Eliot Morison:
"Laws of the U.S. and of almost every Western nation declared the African slave trade to be piracy, punishable by death; but prior to the Lincoln Administration, no American citizen was executed for the offense. Laws against it either were not enforced, or were so construed that traffic in human flesh was protected by the American flag.
"The British Navy was the only force seriously trying to suppress the trade; but successive administrations, faithful to the obsolete issue of visit and search, refused permission to the British to search American vessels. A slave ship only had to raise the 'proud banner of freedom' to evade search and escape."
In self-exculpation, some Americans discerned a hidden motive. Britain had slaves enough in the West Indies, they pointed out, and could afford high moral ground. Besides, by weakening America's slave-based economy, Britain could dump on European markets stockpiles of colonial goods accumulated during a long war with France.
Doubtless self-interest played its part in Britain, as it did in America's evasion of suppression measures. But if economic changes underlay abolition of the slave trade, that does not diminish the great work of humanitarians. In the words of the British scholar Basil Davidson, no apologist for colonialism, "It was thanks to them that abolition came in the first years of the 19th century and not later, perhaps much later."
Yet in this struggle, Americans sat on their hands, sniped at British motives and let their flag cloak a criminal traffic. The U.S. position then was as morally indefensible as Indonesia's today. -- KARL E. MEYER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Election Campaign In Japan Shadows the Summit Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 4

 BODY:
This week was supposed to be the crowning moment in Kiichi Miyazawa's political life: a chance for Japan's urbane, English-speaking Prime Minister to welcome the leaders of the industrialized world -- and Boris N. Yeltsin -- to an economic powerhouse that he helped to rebuild from rubble.
But Mr. Miyazawa could not spare the time this morning to review the giant briefing books for the summit meeting or inspect the work of the 36,000 police officers who have turned Tokyo into a barricaded camp. 
 Instead, he was standing atop a truck at 10:30 A.M. in one of the city's busiest intersections, wearing pristine white gloves and a giant white flower in his lapel, pleading with Sunday shoppers not to make the most historic week of his leadership one of the last.
 
The Elections Are Coming!
 Only two days before a parade of prime ministers and presidents arrive for the Group of Seven summit meeting, the talks could hardly be further from the minds of Japan's leaders.
Two weeks from today the nation faces an election that seems certain to end nearly four decades of rule by the Liberal Democratic Party. And as the leadership tries to stop a hemorrhage of support, the summit meeting has become something of an annoyance.
To many, President Clinton has become a downright hazard to their hold on office. As he prepared to leave Washington, Mr. Clinton made clear that he hoped the political turmoil in Japan would produce a government more willing to open its markets and a leadership that included "consumer advocates."
While too little time has passed for such comments to resound here in Tokyo, they seemed to put Mr. Clinton squarely on the side of the new opposition parties and the 57 defectors from the Liberal Democrats who have wiped out Mr. Miyazawa's majority in Parliament and forced the July 18 election. Campaigning began today.
 
Trying to Keep Profile Low
 A senior Administration official said the President's remarks, reported Saturday in The Washington Post, were observations, not expressions of advocacy. "He was reflecting on long-term trends in Japan that put greater emphasis on the consumer and the demands especially of younger Japanese for improvement of their standard of living," the official said.
But while American officials here say the President would try to stay neutral, the United States Embassy hustled over the weekend to arrange for President Clinton to meet the leaders of the new opposition parties.
The President will be lucky if he finds many of Japan's leaders in town. Most are on the hustings, mindful that they have only 14 days to save their jobs. Mr. Miyazawa seemed to set the tone when he spent the morning warning voters of the disasters that could befall their country if the Liberal Democrats, who have ruled since 1955, are turned out of office.
 
Accentuating the Negative
 "At a time of crisis, we need a firm party in charge of political power, steering the country," he told the early morning shoppers. The defectors from the party, he warned, are forming an "unprincipled alliance" with the Socialists.
Indeed, the Liberal Democrats' strategy appears to be to run a thoroughly negative campaign, portraying its challengers as unfit to direct the world's second-largest economy and ignoring the rampant corruption that led to the party's disgrace.
But opposition leaders like Morihiro Hosokawa, the head of the Japan New Party, which is expected to gain 40 or so seats, argues, "This is the election with a clear point -- whether to say sayonara to one-party rule."
Statistically it would be almost impossible for the Liberal Democrats to win the 256 seats they need to control the lower house of Parliament.
 
Who Is to Be in Charge?
 The question is whether a new coalition government will be led by the Liberal Democrats, or whether the opposition groups can overcome their many differences and build a coalition that excludes the party.
Mr. Miyazawa's efforts today to acknowledge that "political reform is the voice of the people" have not been helped by two prominent members of his Cabinet. Finance Minister Yoshihiro Hayashi and Construction Minister Kishiro Nakamura apparently never got the word that when the main campaign issue is influence-peddling, you are supposed to be against it.
Over the last week or so, both men approached top executives of companies they regulate -- banks and construction concerns -- and asked them for campaign contributions. This is entirely legal, as long as the companies do not exceed the certain limits.
 
Well, Semi-reform, Anyway
 Even though the Miyazawa Government is claiming that it will finally cut the collusive tie between money and politics, the two ministers seemed startled that anyone saw a problem with raising money from companies that depend on them for favors.
As the campaign kicked off and the security net around the capital tightened, it became clear to the 29 million people in Greater Tokyo that this would be an excellent time to leave.
Those daring to drive to the city center were being pulled over and asked politely to open their car trunks and explain their business. Subway stations have been covered with posters saying "Remember the summit seven years ago? We ask for your cooperation this time, again." In Japanese terms, "cooperation" is a nice way of suggesting that you get out of the way.
Already the roadblocks have prompted complaints, mostly from lawyers who say they impinge on personal liberty. But the annoyance arose partly because the police have been so conspicuous recently: similar security surrounded the royal wedding in June, and the roadblocks set up then were never really dismantled.
Divers are also patrolling the waters near Haneda Airport, and plainclothes police have been practicing mock assaults on the baroque state guest house, on the grounds of Akasaka Palace. (Their favorite new gizmo is a triumph of James Bond sleekness and Japanese ingenuity: an ordinary-looking lectern equipped with a desk-top that springs up into a bulletproof shield at the first sign of trouble.)
 
Bombs Left, Pickets Right
 Police officials say they face two threats to an orderly summit meeting -- from Japan's radical left and from its well-financed right.
It was the leftists who rained homemade rockets near the Akasaka Palace during the last summit meeting here, in 1986. The police say they recently found evidence that the group, the Chukakuha, has been developing a rocket with greater range.
The rightists are stirring more excitement this time because of the expected arrival of Mr. Yeltsin. The Russian President has been allowed to bring 60 bodyguards because, apparently, the memories are fresh of an attack in 1891 against Czar Nicholas II. During a visit to Japan as a crown prince, he was slashed with a sword while touring Kyoto.
The right wing's favorite cause is the return of four islands in the Kuriles that the Soviet Union seized in the closing days of World War II.
In ordinary times the police would simply ban the rightists' elaborate sound trucks from around the Russian Embassy. But the law specifically prohibits limits on campaigning by election candidates, and the rightists are fielding several.

EXPLOSION IN SEOUL
 SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, July 5 (AP) -- An explosion today rocked the Seoul hotel where President Clinton is scheduled to stay this week, injuring three workers and forcing the evacuation of 600 guests, the police said. They ruled out the possibility of a bomb.
The blast occurred in the boiler room in the basement of the Hyatt Regency Hotel about 6:40 A.M. The exact cause was unknown, the police said.
A White House spokesman, Jeff Eller, said there was "no evidence that it was any kind of explosive device."
Mr. Clinton is to stay at the hotel Saturday and Sunday after a three-day summit meeting in Tokyo.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Making Gains Among Hispanic Voters

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 1

 BODY:
The photographs of Robert F. Kennedy posing with Cesar Chavez during a hunger strike three decades ago are no longer living room fixtures in the barrios here. "Viva Bush" placards were popular last year. Now, some Hispanic households proudly display photos of Richard Riordan, this city's new Republican Mayor, who won a surprisingly large portion of the Hispanic vote.
Hispanic voters have historically been in the Democratic camp, and most still are. But they are not the reliable Democrats they once were. They are increasingly less willing to cast votes for an all-Democratic ticket. Hispanic support for Republican candidates in recent elections here and in Texas suggest that some of these voters are slowly, yet unmistakably, changing sides. 
 The Hispanic population in the United States is relatively young and makes up one of the largest pools of potential voters. So the Republican Party is aggressively courting middle-class Hispanic Americans with a message of family values, law and order and opposition to abortion.
 
Lapse by Democrats
 "They're getting a bigger share of the vote and I'm extremely concerned," said Domingo A. Garcia, the Mayor pro tem of Dallas, who heads the Democratic National Committee's Hispanic caucus. "The Democratic Party has not done a good job of reaching out to the growing Latino population in the United States. The Republicans are filling the vacuum and are building coalitions, appealing to issues like family values that have wide appeal in our community."
By seeking alliances with Hispanic voters, Republicans hope to gain an edge in close races and are threatening the Democratic Party's tradition of building powerful ethnic coalitions.
While Cuban-Americans, spurred by strong sentiments against Fidel Castro and Communism, have long tended to vote Republican, an interest in Republican politics is spreading to other Hispanic voters who had been considered part of the Democratic constituency.
In contrast, blacks continue to vote overwhelmingly Democratic and show no signs of switching parties. Asian-Americans are not quite as lock step in their support for Democrats, but they generally vote with that party. And in large pivotal states, Hispanic residents make up a far larger percentage of the pool of prospective voters than do Asians.
In the mayoral race in New York this year, Republicans are running highly visible voter-registration drives in some Hispanic neighborhoods. Herman Badillo, the city's first Puerto Rican-born member of Congress, dropped out of the mayoral race to run for comptroller on a ticket with Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is challenging Mayor David N. Dinkins, under the Republican and Liberal Party labels. Mr. Giuliani is seeking to attract support from the Hispanic and Jewish voters who voted for the Democratic Mayor in 1989.
The most recent example of Republican appeal to Hispanic voters was the election last month of Mayor Riordan. Though he did not win a majority of the Hispanic vote, Mr. Riordan made significant inroads, drawing 43 percent, as against 57 percent for his Democratic opponent, Michael Woo, according to a Los Angeles Times poll. By contrast, Mr. Riordan's share of the black vote was only 14 percent.
"Woo should have gotten 70 percent," said Richard Martinez, regional director of the Southwest Voter Registration Education Project. "It was his to lose. He didn't talk to the Latino community. Most campaign managers don't see the growth of Latino voters; they believe that the Latino vote is apathetic. They're nuts. We outregistered Anglos and blacks last year."
In Texas, three days before the election in Los Angeles, Kay Bailey Hutchison, the Republican candidate, was elected Senator in a landslide in which she carried heavily Hispanic South Texas, 60 percent to 40 percent. While the Democratic incumbent, Bob Krueger, still carried most of the Hispanic vote statewide, Mrs. Hutchison's support demonstrates the potential for what Texas Republican leaders contend is a new winning coalition of urban Republicans, rural conservatives and Hispanic Americans.
Although Democrats still won a majority of the Hispanic vote in the Texas and Los Angeles races, Republican support from those voters was significant. It at least partly reflected that Republicans were far more aggressive than Democrats in running Spanish-language advertising campaigns and phone banks to get Hispanic voters to the polls.
"We're not the enemy like we used to be 20 years ago," said Tirso del Junco, a Cuban-American who heads the California Republican Party. "The Hispanic community identified with Mr. Riordan on jobs and economics and family. There is a notion out there that Hispanics are interested in social issues and that's it. I suggest that's not the case."
Even as more Hispanics voters back Republican candidates, Hispanic politics is still dominated by Democrats. But that, too, shows signs of shifting.
"Latinos are no longer to be taken for granted as being in one corner or another," said Gaddi H. Vasquez, the Republican Supervisor of heavily conservative Orange County south of Los Angeles, whom his party is grooming for statewide office.
Texas has been the most successful breeding ground recently for Hispanic Republicans. Pete Nieto, who was recently elected a Texas State Representative as a Democrat, announced last month that he was switching to the Republican Party. In a statement, he said the lessons of his parents of "hard work, self reliance and family values" were shared by Republicans.
 
For the Next Election
 With Mr. Nieto when he made the announcement was Representative Henry Bonilla of San Antonio, who last year became the first Hispanic Republican elected to Congress from Texas.
In many states, Republicans are hoping to make even greater inroads next year in state and local elections by recruiting Hispanic candidates and getting Hispanic voters to the polls. Looking ahead to the 1996 Presidential race, several important battlegrounds, including California, Florida, Illinois, New York and Texas, have large numbers of Hispanic residents.
In Los Angeles, the potential Hispanic political clout is clearly illustrated on a wall map at the offices of the National Association of Latino Elected and Appointed Officials in East Los Angeles. In bright orange and yellow colors, the map dispels the notion that Hispanic residents are concentrated only in East Los Angeles, and shows they are spread throughout five neighboring counties, including the San Fernando Valley and the Republican bastion of Orange County.
"That's where the voters are," said Harry P. Pachon, the national director of the group, pointing to the map. "If you're in the Republican Party hierarchy, you ask yourself: 'Will the blacks vote for us?' "
 
'Not Set in Concrete'
 Though Mr. Pachon said the Republicans had largely given up on the black vote, he said they know that "the Latino vote is not set in concrete."
Indeed, a 1992 poll by the Southwest Voter Research Institute showed that in Texas the Republicans have made sharp inroads among Hispanic voters. In California, the poll found that increasing numbers of Hispanic voters are dropping party affiliations and identifying themselves as independents -- but, as the recent mayoral election shows, are willing to vote Republican.
By the end of 1994, more than three million former illegal immigrants, mostly natives of Mexico, will complete a five-year waiting period to be eligible for naturalization. More than half of these people live in California. The Republican Party has recognized the potential faster than the Democrats, and usually dispatches party representatives to naturalization ceremonies.
Although the Republicans have concentrated on well-to-do Hispanic business owners, the party has also sought to portray itself to minorities as inclusive and progressive.
To tap the full potential of the Hispanic vote, both parties have to reverse the low turnouts by Hispanic voters. In the Los Angeles mayoral race, Hispanic voters accounted for only 10 percent of the total.
Peter Skerry, a political scientist and author of "Mexican Americans: The Ambivalent Minority" (The Free Press, 1993), is skeptical of the prospects for a significant shifts in Hispanic voting pattern. Fundamentally, he said, the Hispanic electorate is a "working, lower-middle class kind of vote that's interested in the same economic issues as Democrats."
And Mr. Skerry said Cuban-Americans, who among Hispanics have been the most ardent Republicans, had discouraged others.
"There's intense animosity between Mexican-Americans and the Cuban-Republicans, who got there first and contributed a lot of money to the party," he said. "They're not eager to open the ranks to what they call Johnny-come-latelys."
But Mr. Garcia, the head of the Democratic Hispanic Caucus, said he was so worried about the Republicans that he took his concerns to David Wilhelm, the chairman of Democratic National Committee, and officials at the White House. "So far," he said, "the pleas have fallen on deaf ears. An organized strategy still has not been developed."
But Mr. Wilhelm said he was confident that the Democrats could hold on to the 62 percent of Hispanic voters who said they backed Bill Clinton last year.
"The key with Hispanic voters is the same as it is with voters generally," he said. "If we deliver on economic change, if we pass health-care reform, we will have spoken to those Hispanic voters in a very clear and compelling way."
 Because of an editing error stemming from the error in the chart, the article incorrectly described the political trend among Hispanic Texans. The Republicans did not make "sharp inroads."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 16, 1993, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A chart on July 5 with an article analyzing Hispanic voting patterns reversed the percentage of Hispanic voters in Texas who identified themselves as Republicans with those who identified themselves as independents. The share of Hispanic voters there who identified themselves as Republican was 9 percent in 1988, 9 percent in 1990 and 7 percent in 1992. Those who identified themselves as independent were 15 percent in 1988, 12 percent in 1990 and 27 percent in 1992.

HEADLINE: Legislators and Cuomo Agree on New Smoking Restrictions

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 5

 BODY:
Negotiators for the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo reached agreement today on a bill that would expand restrictions on smoking by prohibiting smoking in schools and limiting it in workplace lounges and cafeterias to separate, enclosed rooms.
The bill also would ban smoking in general hospitals, child-care centers, public institutions and treatment centers for children, ticketing and boarding areas of public transportation terminals, indoor zoos and some food stores. It also would ban the sale of individual cigarettes out of their packages, which include warnings about the health hazards of smoking. 
 But the chairman of the Senate health committee, Senator Michael J. Tully, a Republican of Roslyn Heights, L.I., said he could not guarantee that the bill would make it to the floor of his house for a vote.
Mr. Tully, the sponsor of the legislation, put its chances of success at only "60-40." He said the Senate's Republican leadership was encountering fierce resistance from tobacco lobbyists and might kill the bill.
 
No Deal Yet
 "We have not agreed to pass a bill," said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, a Republican from Oyster Bay, L.I. "It is being looked at."
Aides to Speaker Saul Weprin, a Democrat from Queens, said the Democratic-majority Assembly was prepared to pass the legislation, and aides to Mr. Cuomo said he supported it.
With the Legislature seemingly prepared to leave town by Wednesday or Thursday -- members had been scheduled to leave on June 25 -- lawmakers, the Governor and their aides were still hoping for last-minute deals on a wide array of major bills.
As is often the case in the final frenzy of the legislative session, bills that had lingered on life support for days edged toward death. Others that had been declared dead were resuscitated.
Late this afternoon, for instance, Senate and Assembly leaders declared defeat in their efforts to refashion the state's hospital financing system, meaning lawmakers would have to return to Albany in the fall to deal with the issue. The negotiators conceded that they had failed to forge an agreement with Mr. Cuomo on how much money to pump into the state's hospital system.
 
Deadlock on Hospital Aid
 By manipulating the state's regulation of reimbursement rates for Medicaid and private insurers, the Senate Republicans proposed to give the hospitals $180 million a year above the amount they will receive for inflation. The Assembly Democrats proposed $142 million. Mr. Cuomo, who first suggested a cut in hospital spending, had raised his ante to $100 million, and expressed openness about going even higher, said Michael J. Dowling, the Governor's director of health, education and human services. That is where the bargaining deadlocked.
"It seems best in my judgment to simply set this aside now and engage in continuing three-way conversations," said the Assembly majority leader, James R. Tallon Jr., a Binghamton Democrat and a key participant in the hospital talks. "This takes a little bit more time."
Mr. Tully, the Senate's lead negotiator, said, "I'd say that's true."
But by early evening, Assembly aides said there were new signs of life, largely because Mr. Cuomo had hinted that he might put a new, more generous offer on the table. "Nothing is dead until we're out of here," said one Assembly aide, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Mr. Cuomo held an early-evening news conference aimed at keeping hope alive. He said there was still a chance to forge agreements on hospital financing, a dedicated fund for environmental purposes and state assistance for building a new hockey arena in Buffalo and new minor-league baseball parks around the state. The Governor coyly suggested that he would pull some dollars out of his sleeve, but provided no details.
"It's realistic to believe all these bills can be done and I would be surprised if they didn't agree after they've been briefed," Mr. Cuomo said, referring to the legislative leaders.
 
Billboard Measure Passes
 In other action in the Capitol, the Senate gave final approval to a measure that would allow the owners of billboards erected on state property to request permission to cut down trees and other vegetation that block the view of the signs from state roadways. The bill was approved by the Assembly on Sunday.
The legislation was supported as a necessity by New York's outdoor advertising industry. But it was denounced by environmental lobbyists, who view it as a reversal of the state's tradition of restricting billboards on scenic corridors.
Legislative negotiators, meanwhile, had yet to translate their agreement to end rent regulations on high-priced apartments into legislative language. And they were still discussing bills involving banking regulations, medical malpractice insurance, low-level radioactive waste storage and mental health financing.
Aides to legislative leaders said they were close to an agreement that would bring New York State into compliance with the Federal Clean Air Act. But negotiators were trying to decide whether to exempt two New York City-operated garbage incinerators in Brooklyn from tough new pollution regulations.
The antismoking measure, if passed, would continue a five-year effort by the state to place burdens of cost and convenience on New York smokers. The Legislature and Mr. Cuomo raised cigarette taxes this year by 17 cents a pack to 56 cents, one of the highest levels in the country. It was the third increase in five years.
The state also has banned smoking in public places and restricted it to special sections of offices and restaurants. Last year, the Governor and Legislature strengthened penalties against vendors who sell cigarettes to minors, banned cigarette vending machines from establishments frequented by children, and banned free distribution of cigarettes on street corners.
Antismoking forces in the Legislature were buoyed this year by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's finding that tobacco smoke causes lung cancer in nonsmokers.

 BODY:

International
U.S. institutional investors are unlikely to reinvest in South Africa immediately, even if Nelson Mandela calls for an end to international sanctions. It could take months if not years to gain the needed approvals from state legislatures and city councils, many of which are in recess. [Page D1.]
The European Community will continue to press Japan to curb its $150 billion trade surplus, more than a fifth of which is with Western Europe. But differences between the U.S. and Europe over how to address the trade problem will keep them from presenting a united front at the summit meeting in Tokyo this week. [A6.] 
 President Clinton softened his hard line on Tokyo, putting a positive construction on the relations between the U.S. and Japan that had been missing in recent discussions. [A6.] Nearly two-thirds of the Japanese polled described their country's relations with the U.S. as "unfriendly." [A1.]
India's Government has opened the door to Westerners. But as the repercussions of a political payoff scandal continue to spread, its recent announcements favorable to business are being seen as an effort by officials to save themselves as much they are an effort to encourage economic change. [D1.]
China's trade deficit more than doubled in May and June. Imports have soared as consumers and governments have gone on a spending binge. A new austerity program is in the works. [D9.]
 Police officials in London have sealed off most roads into the financial district, in an effort to head off further terrorist attacks, and are closely monitoring all remaining traffic. [A3.]
 
The Economy
Temporary workers are being used in manufacturing jobs, and in such numbers that the Labor Department no longer knows how many people actually work in American factories. Their growing presence means that manufacturing will probably not offer much help in solving the country's employment problem. [A1.]
 Foreigners are invading America by the tens of millions. The invaders are tourists, a record 46.5 million of whom are expected this year. They are likely to spend $76.9 billion. [D1.]
 
Companies
PNC Bank Corporation plans to grow by buying other banks. The Pittsburgh-based company has sent its regional executives out to flirt with local banks and try to convince them to sell out. [D1.]
A new chairman and chief executive takes over today at Western Digital. The company is engaged in a price war with the other makers of computer disk drives. [D3.]

Markets
The dollar moved higher against most currencies in overseas trading; markets were closed in the U.S. Stock prices slipped in London and Tokyo. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
A meeting today of the Federal Open Market Committee is expected to result in an agreement by Fed officials to hold short-term rates stable. Credit Markets. [D1.]
No matter which party wins Japan's elections, the effect on Japanese businesses is likely to be slight, analysts say. Foreign investors may be overreacting by bailing out of the Tokyo market now. Market Place. [D6.]
The advertising industry's typically frantic pace of personnel changes intensified last week with changes at Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Groupe Bull to Cut 6,500 Jobs

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PARIS, July 5

 BODY:
Groupe Bull, the French state-controlled computer company, said today that it would cut its work force by 6,500 jobs worldwide by the end of next year.
The company, which owns Zenith Data Systems in the United States, has a total work force of 35,200. The job cuts, which follow a previous program that reduced the work force by 27 percent between 1990 and 1992, include 3,000 positions whose elimination had already been set for this year. 
A senior Bull executive told reporters that the reductions were part of a wider cost-cutting plan at the company, which has been losing money. The goal is to break even in 1995.
 
Cost-Cutting Accelerated
"These reductions form part of the acceleration of our effort to reduce costs," Bull's personnel director, Herve Hannebique, said.
Of the 6,500 total job cuts, 2,500 would be in France. It was unclear whether any jobs would be lost at Zenith Data Systems, which is based in Buffalo Grove, Ill. No one was answering telephones at Zenith Data today.
Mr. Hannebique said costs would also be cut in property, purchasing and information systems. In property alone, the company expects to save $87 million.
Bull reported a loss of 4.72 billion francs, or roughly $821.4 million, for 1992, a year when it had originally hoped to break even before interest costs and taxes.
But the economy was weaker than expected in its main markets, and earnings for the whole computer industry have suffered from increasing competition.

HEADLINE: Investors' Quandary On Pretoria

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Many United States institutional investors are not expected to begin immediately reinvesting in South Africa, even if Nelson Mandela calls for an end to international sanctions.
Executives of pension funds and endowments expressed excitement about the prospects of investing again in companies that do business with South Africa but said it could take months if not years to gain approval to put their money back in the troubled nation. 
 While government and pension fund officials have said that they will take their cue to abandon sanctions from Mr. Mandela, the head of the African National Congress, most must also gain the approval of state legislatures and city councils, many of which are in recess and may not convene again for months.
 
Doubts About Change
 Moreover, some legislative bodies and pension funds have expressed doubt that fundamental change has taken place in South Africa and thus are unlikely to rescind divestment policies until free elections are held.
"A lot of institutional investors will probably wait until there's a new constitution and elections before jumping back into South Africa, because once you return there's no turning around," said William Moses, senior policy analyst for the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based group.
"Investors have told us that they don't want to be criticized for acting too quickly or prematurely," he said. "They don't want to be the first one to take action. They want to be second in going back to South Africa so they can better assess the situation and maintain their integrity."
 
A.N.C. Sets Conditions
 Before it calls for abolishing sanctions, the A.N.C. has said the South African Government must meet certain conditions. The most important, it said, was setting a date for free elections. On Friday, black and white political leaders meeting in Johannesburg agreed that the nation would conduct its first general election under universal suffrage next April 27.
But Mr. Mandela, visiting the United States, has pulled away from his earlier position on lifting sanctions, saying that more progress was needed on establishing an interim government that would run the country until the elections.
Mayor David N. Dinkins has said that at Mr. Mandela's request, he is prepared to ask the City Council and New York City's pension systems to end current sanctions on doing business in South Africa, except those that apply to munitions and weapons-making companies. Those would be retained until the South African military and police forces were brought under the control of the people, Mr. Dinkins said.
Business executives have been pressing Mr. Dinkins to lift the sanctions, which prohibit the city from contracting with companies that do business in South Africa. New York is one of more than 166 state and local governments that have maintained sanctions despite the lifting of Federal embargoes by the Bush Administration.
But Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, a trustee of the city's pension funds, has said sanctions should not be lifted until there was one-person, one-vote representation in South Africa. The city, which controls $43 billion in pension funds, has avoided investing in companies doing business in South Africa.
 
No Rush to Return
 Jarrod Wilcox, director of international investments for Battery March Financial Management, which oversees $5 billion in pension funds, said he saw no need to rush back into South Africa because he believed the country would face economic and political turmoil after the elections, and this would create huge investment risks.
"Those who act quickly could be hurt because of the turmoil and disruptions that will follow," Mr. Wilcox said. "The real values in South Africa won't emerge for at least a couple of years." When it does resume investing, Battery March will probably place about $20 million to $30 million in South African companies, Mr. Wilcox said, citing gold mining as an attractive industry.
 
Ban's Removal Sought
 Still, some pension managers and investors are eager to get divestment bans lifted and are anticipating a flurry of activity in many of the stocks of companies that do business in South Africa but have been listed as hands off.
Jose Arau, principal investment officer for the $25 billion California Public Employees Pension Fund, which is subject to the state's 1986 divestment act, said he hoped that Mr. Mandela's visit to the United States would encourage legislators to move quickly to lift the ban.
Without a repeal, the portfolio would be subject to a new round of divestment, Mr. Arau said. Since President George Bush lifted sanctions and companies began returning to South Africa, the fund has put 10 American companies and 10 foreign companies in which it has investments back on a divestiture list.
"We have always been opposed to divestment because we felt it would reduce our return," Mr. Arau said.The policy has cost the portfolio an estimated $600 million in lost returns, he said.
Many colleges and universities, which faced student demonstrations in the 1980's over South Africa, agreed to sell all or part of their holdings in companies with links to that country and are unlikely to reverse those policies soon. Many college officials say they would rather wait for tangible changes in South Africa before reversing divestment policies.

HEADLINE: Still Radical After All These Years;
At 74, William Kunstler Defends Clients Most Lawyers Avoid

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
William Moses Kunstler stood last week in one of his favorite places, the well of a courtroom. Before business began he chatted amicably with the judge, the court clerk, the stenographer, the security guards, the press. Of everything and everyone around him that Brooklyn morning, only the words behind the bench, from Aristotle, were uncongenial.
"Good law must necessarily mean good order," they declare. 
 For more than three decades now, while other lawyers of his ilk have died out or burned out or straightened out or sold out, Mr. Kunstler has challenged Aristotle's aphorism. Loudly and abrasively but increasingly effectively, he has defended the kinds of clients most people loathe and most lawyers avoid.
On Wednesday -- a birthday he shared with the late Judge Julius Hoffman, with whom he tangled so memorably during the Chicago Seven trial -- Mr. Kunstler will be 74 years old, old enough to be a relic, a curiosity, a walking anachronism.
While the familiar glasses are still atop his head, Mr. Kunstler's face has grown craggier, his voice raspier, his unkempt hair whiter and wispier. But thanks to three Islamic clients, he is more visible, more venerated, more vilified than ever. As he writes the front end of his autobiography -- to be called "Loose Cannon" -- he is still gathering material for the back.
The three clients are El Sayyid A. Nosair, whom Mr. Kunstler helped clear of charges that he assassinated Rabbi Meir Kahane; Mr. Nosair's cousin, Ibrahim A. Elgabrowny, a suspect in the World Trade Center bombing, and Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, whom the Federal Bureau of Investigation has called the ringleader of the plot to bomb the United Nations and other targets.
Mr. Kunstler is accustomed to abuse, but nothing like what he has received recently. The catcalls accumulate on his answering machine, which regularly records obscenities or death threats. A man calls repeatedly and burps. "That's for your Arab clients," he says. A woman shrieks: "Your name should be 'Monster,' not 'Kunstler.' Other criticism comes in person -- the pedestrian who yells at him on the street, the fellow diner who says he should be shot -- for Mr. Kunstler is arguably the most recognizable lawyer in America.
During the Nosair trial, members of the Jewish Defense Organization broke the windows of his Greenwich Village town house with paint pellets. Last Tuesday, armed with placards, they were back again, accusing him of being a self-hating Jew and chanting, "Not one night of sleep till William Kunstler is off the street!"
 
Letters of Apology
 Shortly before the picketing began, Mr. Kunstler placed letters of apology under every doorstep on the block. "I hope you will bear the inconvenience with the fortitude that the Framers expected all of us to exhibit when strident voices were raised against anyone or any cause," he wrote. "So please forgive me and remember that, just like a trip to the dentist, it will feel so good when the J.D.O. is finished."
There are several lawyers representing defendants accused in the World Trade Center and bomb plot cases. But as the most famous and quotable among them, Mr. Kunstler has assumed a disproportionately important role. A man sustained by controversy and cacophony, whose mood rises with the number of decibels he generates and noses he tweaks, is having another heyday. "I'm more loved and more hated than I ever was," he said.
 
Famous Clients
 Most of Mr. Kunstler's famous clients, including Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Daniel Berrigan, Lenny Bruce, Stokely Carmichael, and various members of the Attica uprising, Chicago Seven and Black Panthers, were exceedingly unpopular in their day, but they had their followings. But Mr. Kunstler has also represented clients without constituencies.
There was Larry Davis, the drug dealer charged with murdering four drug dealers and shooting six policemen. There was Darrell Cabey, one of the four men whom Bernhard Goetz shot on the I.R.T., Yusef Salaam, convicted of raping the Central Park jogger, and Kevin McKiever, charged with stabbing a former Rockette as she walked her dog on the Upper West Side. All are black and, he contends, victims of American racism.
Whatever their pedigree, Mr. Kunstler contends, his clients have a common gene: all are pariahs, invariably with the heavy hand of Government on their shoulder.
"The battleground has become tougher and the clients less palatable to the general community," he said. "It was one thing to get an injunction allowing Martin Luther King to speak. Now it's Arabs accused of trying to blow up the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels, and Larry Davis shooting cops in the Bronx."
 
Less Fearsome, More Famous
 Mr. Kunstler maintains, however, that the compliments exceed the criticism. He has learned there are benefits to senior citizenship besides half-price subway rides -- that if even the most politically unpalatable person hangs around long enough, he can graduate from middle-aged enfant terrible to elder statesman.
Many judges now find him more avuncular and endearing than menacing. Jurors who might once have feared him now ask him for his autograph, even in midtrial. His new-found rapport with them has helped Mr. Kunstler, a lawyer historically faulted for placing theatrics over substance, reach new professional peaks, most notably, in clearing both Mr. Nosair and Mr. Davis of the most serious charges they faced.
He has even become a favorite of filmmakers. The day before the picketers arrived at his home, he and one of his two teen-age daughters were in lower Manhattan, appearing as extras alongside Al Pacino in "Carlito's Way," a film directed by Brian De Palma. Earlier, Mr. Kunstler could be seen as a judge in "Malcolm X" and as a lawyer in "The Doors."
Mr. Kunstler said that the bulk of his salary, which he placed around $100,000 a year, comes from lectures and speaking engagements rather than legal fees. He selects his clients, he said, for reasons of principle rather than of economics. His Islamic clients, he said, are not paying him at all. Mr. Kunstler's methodology practically begs purists and critics to scour for inconsistencies, and in recent years, Mr. Kunstler has given them plenty of ammunition.
He once declared, for instance, that he only represented those he loved. The statement, he now says, was hyperbolic; he concedes that some of his recent clients are anything but lovable. He still maintains that he would not represent Klansmen, Nazis or other right-wing groups. But he is defending Moslem fundamentalists whose politics many of his allies find equally odious, leading to charges that what really ties his clientele together is their publicity value.
"One of the criticisms of me is, 'You're a showboat,' 'You're a publicity-seeker,' and to some extent that has the ring of truth," he said. "I enjoy the spotlight, as most humans do, but it's not my whole raison d'etre. My purpose is to keep the state from becoming all-domineering, all powerful. And that's never changed."
There are few leftists left to find fault with Mr. Kunstler's deviations, and those who do, do so very mildly. "Bill is too courageous and too good a lawyer and done too many good things for me to fault him for something he really believes is the right thing to do," said Michael Ratner of the Center for Constitutional Rights.
 
Numerous Epiphanies
 Others, like Alan M. Dershowitz of Harvard Law School, are less forgiving. "He's locked himself into an imposssible position by first claiming that he represents only those he loves or whose politics he supports, then defending people who want to murder Jews randomly on 47th Street," he said. "He can't have it both ways. Does he love these guys?"
Mr. Kunstler is in fact a man of numerous incarnations and epiphanies. The youthful version was a well-heeled romantic, who studied French and wrote love sonnets at Yale, collected in a book called "Our Pleasant Vices." Then came the conventional Kunstler, who settled in the suburbs, fathered two daughters, quietly practiced law, and wrote books with titles like "The Law of Accidents" and "Corporate Tax Summary."
Kunstler the civil libertarian and disciple of Gandhi followed his first epiphany, experienced while defending Freedom Riders in the early 1960's. Epiphany No. 2 occurred during the Chicago Seven trial, from which Mr. Kunstler emerged very nearly as radical and outrageous as his clients. His journey is documented on the walls of his office. A basement lair on Gay Street filled with law books, tattered oriental rugs, and the smell of cats, it was once a stop on the underground railroad.
 
No Ethnic Identity Remains
 As usual, the phone rings continually. Two calls concern a panel discussion on "Zealous Advocacy and the Courts' Need to Preserve Order," in which Mr. Kunstler is scheduled to take part. It seems that two of the judges have withdrawn upon learning of Mr. Kunstler's participation. "Why don't you ask Kevin Duffy?" Mr. Kunstler asked his caller, referring to a Federal judge in Manhattan. "I just moved to impeach him at the House Judiciary Committee, but it might be worth it."
Mr. Kunstler was raised a Jew but no longer considers himself one. He said the charges of self-hatred and betrayal leveled against him "go in one ear and out the other," though he noted that many clients, including Jack Ruby, Abbie Hoffman, and Morton Sobell, a defendant in the Rosenberg spy case, were Jewish.
Mr. Kunstler said he attended seders every year -- "We've doctored up the Haggadah to eliminate sexism" -- but goes to other ceremonies, too. "I go to Catholic churches and Sikh temples and native American ceremonies," he said. "I go to mosques. I have a Koran here."
 
'It Never Stops'
 He married two Jewish women, and at least some of his four grandchildren -- he is not sure how many -- consider themselves Jews. His two youngest daughters, aged 15 and 16, do not. "They're more interested in Act Up and AIDS causes," he said.
Many writers have tried psychoanalyzing Mr. Kunstler, a process Mr. Kunstler has never undergone. "Christ said, 'Know thyself,' but it's impossible," he said. "It's the hardest thing in the world."
Mr. Kunstler's father, a doctor, died at the age of 81 while heading for a house call, and his son wants a similar end. So far, history has been obliging. The kinds of clients and causes he likes just keep on coming. "I get so utterly bored not having a case to look forward to," he said. "I always wondered what would happen if it just stopped, and I thought I would put a bullet in my head. But it never stops. It simply never stops."

HEADLINE: America, a Great Place to Visit

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The largest invasion of foreigners in American history is unfolding across the United States, welcomed almost everywhere. The invaders are tourists, a record 46.5 million of whom are expected this year, and they should spend about $76.9 billion while here -- another record.
The estimates come from the United States Travel Data Center, a Washington-based nonprofit organization. And for the first time, according to the Commerce Department, the total number of overseas visitors to the United States -- an estimated 19.5 million from every part of the world except North America -- will exceed the total visitors from Canada, and by a sizable margin of one million. 
 The result is not only a huge multicultural interchange; it is also an economic bonanza at a time that the Travel Industry Association predicts domestic travel will be flat for the rest of the decade. Last week the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand said that almost one of every 10 hotels rooms in the United States each night is rented to a visitor from overseas and it projected that that figure would be almost one in seven by 1995.
Even bad news -- the murders of tourists in Miami and the terrorist bombing of the World Trade Center in New York -- has not stemmed the flow. While foreigners may have changed itineraries to avoid what they consider trouble spots, travel industry officials say, they are not staying away from the United States.
 
Strength of Foreign Currency
 The size of the influx is driven in part by the strength of the Japanese yen, the British pound, the German mark and other foreign currencies relative to the dollar, making the United States an inexpensive destination.
Visitors are also responding to the growing numbers of promotions in their countries from American tour operators, airlines and hotels. Individual states and cities are also opening sales and tourist offices abroad. The Nashville airport and the Memphis and Nashville convention and visitors bureaus, for example, recently joined the privately owned Opryland Hotel in Nashville and Graceland, Elvis Presley's home in Memphis, in opening a London office to attract British tourists.
All this effort has been paying dividends for several years. The number of foreign visitors has exceeded the previous year's total each year since the late 1980's, and a further gain is being projected for next year as well.
Many foreign visitors need little urging, however. They are here on return trips, intent on catching up on what they missed.
"The last time we were here, we drove 5,000 miles in three weeks, but we didn't get to the West," said Roberta Smithies of London, speaking recently from Buffalo Bill's Museum in North Platte, Neb. This time she and a friend are spending most of their three weeks in Nebraska, Arizona, New Mexico and Texas. "We saw all the John Wayne movies, and when people ask why we came here, we tell them: when you think of America, you think of the West."
In recent days many Italian tourists have been visiting Niagara Falls, and Spanish tourists have panned for gold in Dahlonega, Ga., a tiny town near the Appalachian Trail. Tourists from as far away as Malaysia recently turned up at Graceland, while tourists from more than 30 countries have journeyed to Hope, Ark., to see the boyhood homes of President Clinton.
"For some reason," Paul G. Henley, Hope's director of tourism, said, "the Japanese have no interest in going to the cemetery where his father's buried. They just want to see the two houses where the President lived."
The biggest contingent of foreigners for any three-month period is expected to arrive this summer, but from New England to Washington State, foreign visitors are helping to extend tourist seasons during other times of the year as well.
"The last few years we've seen more foreign tourists in the winter than we ever have," said Jane Gillespie, sales director of Grand Canyon National Park Lodges. Even in summer, overseas visitors account for more than one-third of guests at the lodges, where rooms must be booked months in advance.
Similarly, while Miami is not usually considered by Americans as a summer vacation spot, it is for increasing numbers of tourists from Russia and Ukraine.
"We have two seasons here in Florida: hot and really hot," said Alexey N. Mesiatsev, the executive vice president of Rahim Tours of Lake Worth, Fla., which brings in many tourists from the former Soviet republics. "But the hotter the better for our tour members -- especially the ones from Siberia."
 
Cultural Sensitivities
 To attract foreign tourists, hotels and restaurants are becoming more cosmopolitan. Restaurants are changing not only the languages in which restaurant menus are written but also the cuisine they serve. Many hotels have bilingual desk clerks, and some offer telephone lines solely for providing assistance in foreign languages. Most print fire instructions and other emergency procedures in more than one language.
Staff members at the New Orleans Hilton Riverside wear lapel pins with flags signifying the foreign languages they speak, and room clerks there are careful not to book Japanese guests into rooms on either the fourth or ninth floors -- the former because the Japanese pronunciation of the number "four" is similar to the word "death," and nine is similar to the word "pain."
Theme parks and attractions, like Parrot Jungle and Gardens in Miami, routinely print brochures in several languages, while the new international terminal at O'Hare Airport in Chicago has signs in 17 languages as diverse as Arabic and Chinese, advising passengers of delays or telling them to have passports ready.
Gray Line tours from Manhattan to Niagara Falls are offered with guides who speak French, German, Italian, Spanish and Japanese. And New York -- where foreigners make up 22 percent of the city's 25 million visitors and where visitors spend $1.6 billion a year just shopping -- is filled with stores that cater specifically to tourists from Central and South America.
 
Spending More
 Overseas visitors spend six times more per capita in this country than American tourists spend, according to the United States Travel and Tourism Administration. Their average stay of slightly less than three weeks is almost five times longer than the average domestic vacation.
Corinne Leseur, a Frenchwoman currently touring the United States with her aunt and two cousins, fits the profile of the average foreign visitor. In her three-week visit she is driving a rental car from Louisiana to Miami. "America is a dream come true," she declared recently, after visiting New Orleans's French Quarter.
Ms. Leseur, who works in a pharmaceutical laboratory, lives on Reunion, a tiny island to the east of Madagascar in the south Indian Ocean. It is a long way to come for a vacation, she acknowledged, "but it's something we dreamed of for more than a year."
The 3.7 million visitors from Japan spent the most here last year, an estimated $13.8 billion -- $10 billion more than American visitors spent in Japan. Almost four million Japanese are expected this year, and travel industry officials say a lackluster economy at home does not seem to have curtailed their free-spending ways abroad.
Many Japanese tourists travel on the Delta Queen or Mississippi Queen, the paddlewheel steamboats that ply the Mississippi and several other inland rivers. "They read Mark Twain, so the river trip seems to embody what they envision America should be," Terry Westerfield, a spokeswoman for the Delta Queen Steamboat Company, said.
Los Angeles continues to suffer a drop-off in Japanese and other Asian visitors because of last year's riots.
"This year looks better than last year, when nobody wanted to come here because of the riot, but the number of visitors is still lower than we expected," said Shigemi Kitta, tour operations director of Alfa Tour in Los Angeles. Alfa is one of several small airlines that fly Japanese tourists on one-day roundtrips to the Grand Canyon from Los Angeles.
 
Promoting Florida to Germans
 Several Florida cities sent tourist officials to Germany to try to overcome the negative impact of the murder of a German tourist in Miami, and, for whatever reason, more German tourists are visiting Fort Lauderdale than ever -- possibly in part at the expense of Miami.
"We went from 5 charter flights a week from Germany last year to 11 this year," Francine Mason, a spokeswoman for Fort Lauderdale's tourist bureau, said. "About 41,000 of our one million visitors this summer will be from Germany." Also, 37,000 are expected from Scandinavia.
Foreign visitors are also flooding into New York, where a total of 15 suspects have been arrested in connection with the World Trade Center bombing, which killed six people, and what officials say was a plot to bomb the United Nations and other city sites.
"Terrorism can have harmful effects on international travel," Marshall Murdaugh, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, said. "But we honestly have not seen any concern expressed by international or domestic tour operators, and I'm sure it's because the suspects were apprehended so quickly."

HEADLINE: The Hook: No Ladder A Cherry Orchard Is Easy Pickings

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIVINGSTON, N.Y., June 30

 BODY:
Kneeling on the ground, Norma Saddlewire picked ripe, dark-red cherries as fast as she could from branches just pruned from heavily laden sweet cherry trees.
Nearby, her friend Joyce Nethaway stood plucking cherries from a dwarf tree not more than 10 feet high. 
 Here in the orchards of the 300-acre Fix Brothers farm in western Columbia County, Robert and William Fix have made it possible for customers to pick cherries without leaving the ground.
"It makes it easy for everybody," said Robert Fix's wife, Joan, who noted that eliminating ladders also reduced the possibility of accidents and lawsuits.
One of her three sons, Robert Jr., walked through the orchard, using a ladder and pruning saw to cut high branches and lay them before a steady stream of customers. He explained that pruning during the fruiting season did not harm the trees, nor did it eliminate the need for major pruning routinely done in the winter and spring.
The sweet cherry season started in late June, the beginning of the annual fruit harvest in the Hudson Valley and the rest of New York State, where growing, picking and processing fruit are a major economic enterprise.
 
$200 Million Industry
 "The industry is not only important because it brings in $200 million a year, but it is also responsible for a lot of jobs, both seasonally and permanent, as well as providing us with a lot of good eating," said Richard T. McGuire, the State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets.
Russell Bartolotta Sr., who operates the Klein's Kill Fruit Farm near here, said the cherry crop was good this year. "They are coming in plentiful and sweet," he said. "The flavor is delicious."
In New York, Niagara County is the leading producer of sweet cherries. Columbia and Ulster Counties are major producers in the Hudson Valley. In Columbia County, in one small area near the Hudson River here, eight orchards attract thousands of pick-it-yourselfers during the harvest season.
"We have people coming from all over, from New York City, Long Island, New Jersey," said Mrs. Fix.
Mrs. Saddlemire and Mrs. Nethaway drove 80 miles from Schoharie, just west of Albany, to pick cherries. In less than half an hour, each filled three four-quart cartons with 20 pounds of fruit.
"I'm going to eat some and freeze the others," Mrs. Saddlemire said.
Under a spreading cherry tree, Mrs. Fix stood behind a scale weighing the cherries, which cost $1 a pound.
In supermarkets now, Bing cherries from Washington, Oregon and California are selling for 98 cents to $1.59 a pound.
 
No Fear of Pesticides
 None of a dozen pickers interviewed here indicated any concern about possible danger from pesticides despite the recent report this week by the National Academy of Science that chemical residues on fruit were potentially dangerous.
"I blame the news media for the scare stories on the pesticide dangers," Mrs. Saddlemire said.
William Fix, one of the partners in the farm, said few customers asked about pesticides.
"We spray with fungicides and insecticides six or seven times a year," he said. "If we didn't use pesticides, we would not have any people here because there wouldn't be any fruit. It would be eaten by worms, covered by scab, damaged by every insect you could think of."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The sweet cherry season is well under way, and at the Fix Brothers farm in western Columbia County, N.Y., do-it-yourself harvesters are plucking them at bargain rates. Pruning eliminates the need for ladders. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)
