HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Expected to Hold Line on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
After nine months of predicting changes in Federal Reserve monetary policy that never occurred, investors and traders in the credit markets expect today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee will result in an agreement by Fed officials to hold short-term rates stable.
A decision by the committee to maintain rates would modify its assessment in May, when Fed officials voted to hold rates stable for the immediate future but hinted strongly at their willingness to raise rates if inflation worsened. Explanations of any shift may be forthcoming next Tuesday, when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to present the central bank's views on the economy and monetary policy to Congress. 
 Mr. Greenspan's testimony, which is required twice a year, is likely to include something for everybody.
Bond investors will be assured that the Fed wants low inflation and will stand ready to raise interest rates if that goal is threatened. Congress, meanwhile, will be assured that the Fed will do all it can to keep the economy growing by maintaining low interest rates.
It is a familiar tightrope for Mr. Greenspan, but one that may be fraught with more than the usual difficulty. Because the budget package now being negotiated in Congress promises a combination of higher taxes and reduced spending that can dampen economic growth, many in the credit markets wonder how much pressure the Fed may feel to compensate and help the economy by keeping interest rates low or perhaps even by pushing them lower.
"With the budget package, we now have an economic policy that is good for the bond market, but bad for the economy," said Charles Smith, a bond manager at T. Rowe Price, a Baltimore-based mutual fund company. While he expects the economy to suffer from the tax package, he does not expect the Fed to try a pre-emptive strike. "I expect they will take a neutral posture and wait to see more data," he said.
 
 
Current Policy Is Working
 Some analysts conclude that no change by the Fed is likely because its policy has been working so well. Banks and businesses are awash in cash, so reducing short-term rates from levels that are already the lowest in 30 years would not appear to provide much additional benefit. With Treasury bond yields dropping to a 20-year low of about 6.66 percent last week from 7.75 percent in November, Fed officials may feel unwilling to change a policy that appears to be convincing investors that inflation will remain benign.
"If Greenspan came to Congress, declared a victory over inflation and lowered interest rates, it would surely be popular with Congress and maybe even some parts of Wall Street," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Chemical Bank. But there is no assurance that the inflation-wary bond market would follow the Fed's lead to lower interest rates, he said. "And it's certain that lower rates would not be popular in retirement communities," where low interest rates have reduced incomes, he said.
Raising interest rates -- or strongly hinting they would be raised -- is unlikely, analysts said, because the June data due this week are expected to show a continuation of the low inflation reported for May and because the economy remains sluggish. Last week's weak economic data, culminating in a report showing a meager rise of 13,000 jobs on payrolls in June, have led many economists to reduce their forecasts for second-quarter growth after inflation to 2 percent or less.
 
 
A Dangerous Message
 Mr. Kellner noted that if the Fed adjusted its policy to allow higher interest rates as the economy grows and credit demands increase, "it would be a quite normal development in the economy and would not choke off future growth." But an attempt by Mr. Greenspan to deliver that message is dangerous, he said, "because the Fed is working with a populist President and some members of Congress who would dearly love to curb the Fed's independence."
With the Fed facing such choices, Lawrence N. Leuzzi, a managing director in the New York office of S. G. Warburg & Company, a securities firm, expects that Mr. Greenspan may appease some critics by agreeing to release minutes of Open Market Committee meetings soon after the meetings are completed.
Wayne D. Lyski, senior vice president at Alliance Capital Management, a New York investment adviser, noted that economic growth of about 2 percent would probably not cause the Fed to lower short-term rates. But a decline to 1 percent growth may bring lower rates, he said, even if it means abandoning the principle of keeping key short term-rates equal to or above inflation.
Even if the Fed's policy is unchanged, recent history shows there is plenty of room for interest rates to fluctuate. Since September, when the Fed began pegging monetary policy to maintain a 3 percent rate in the Federal funds market, interest rates on three-month bills have ranged from a low of 2.67 percent at an auction in early October to a high of 3.29 percent in early December to 2.94 percent on Friday. Two-year Treasury notes, which closed on Friday at 3.91 percent, have been as high as 4.83 percent in early December and as low as 3.66 percent in early October.
Long-term Treasury bonds, which closed on Friday with a yield of 6.66 percent, the lowest in about 20 years, were as high as 7.76 percent last November and 7.05 percent as recently as early April of this year.

HEADLINE: Fears Rise Over Wastes Burned in Cement Kilns

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALPENA, Mich.

 BODY:
From industrial plants across the Great Lakes region, tanker trucks and railroad cars haul thousands of gallons of hazardous wastes to this city on Lake Huron, emptying their cargo at the nation's largest cement-making factory where it is burned as fuel.
Almost 10 years ago, with the intent of reducing pollution and conserving resources, Congress amended the nation's hazardous-waste law specifically to encourage recycling such wastes as fuel in cement kilns. About 25 of the roughly 110 American cement plants, many owned by foreign multinational corporations, then installed new piping and other equipment and began being paid to burn hundreds of millions of gallons of hazardous waste each year. 
 First, the lawmakers banned the burial of most raw chemical wastes, making incineration an attractive alternative. Then they decided that cement makers who recycled hazardous wastes as fuel would not have to operate under the same strict standards that applied to commercial toxic waste incinerators. Finally, Congress determined that kiln dust, unlike ash from the toxic-waste incinerators, was not hazardous and did not need to be dumped in special landfills at a cost of more than $1,000 a ton.
But the exemptions for cement makers that were written into the Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act in 1984 are now stirring resentment and fear in rural America. In almost every one of the small cities and towns where hazardous wastes are burned for profit in cement kilns, shrill battles over potential risks to health and safety have become common.
 
New Policy Questions
 Critics of the incineration say the battles are emblematic of a new problem in environmental policy and especially the management of hazardous chemicals: that laws meant to lower risks to health and nature may instead be increasing them.
Cement makers, on the other hand, contend that the technology is safe and the policy sound, and they say they are collecting data to prove it.
Prompted by such a fundamental disagreement, Michigan and other states are investigating what sort of chemical byproducts cement kilns are releasing into the air, water and land. Although Michigan does not yet have enough data to determine if the Alpena plant poses a major risk, the state has found numerous violations of law.
Such close scrutiny of Alpena's hulking cement plant is a recent phenomenon. Since 1906, when the plant was built on a 2,500-acre site, its concrete buildings and towering smokestacks rarely attracted the attention of state inspectors even though they were the most recognizable works of man in a landscape dominated by the blue-gray waters of Thunder Bay and the green expanse of hardwood forests. Generations of men and women have worked at the plant, and it still provides more than 300 jobs and one in every six property tax dollars collected by this city of 12,000 people.
 
Fines and Tighter Rules
 But a community environmental group that started two years ago, the Huron Environmental Activist League, looked into the plant, raised questions about safety and helped prod the state into more aggressive enforcement of the law.
Michigan officials say they have notified the owner, the Lafarge Corporation, that it faces a $150,000 fine for violating air-quality rules and that it will have to establish an environmental monitoring program more extensive than at virtually any other plant in the state.
The state is also studying how Lafarge should dispose of 1,200 tons of dust produced daily by the kilns that is now dumped in the plant's limestone quarry. The dust contains lead, a toxic heavy metal, that state officials say is worrisome but that company executives contend is harmless in its current form. The state is also studying the dust for the presence of dioxin and other toxic substances.
"I remember back in the mid-1980's when this started, people thought cement kilns were the best place for burning hazardous wastes," said JoAnne Merrick, a compliance and enforcement official at the Michigan Department of Natural Resources in Lansing. "The temperatures were high. The wastes could be use as fuel and stayed in the kilns long enough to be thoroughly destroyed. It sounded like a panacea.
"Our mission now is to develop the data to find out whether the public's concerns are real or not."
 
E.P.A. Weighs In
 Last month, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency joined the fray. The agency's administrator, Carol M. Browner, announced a more aggressive plan to oversee the burning of hazardous wastes, especially in cement kilns.
In December, an E.P.A. review found that cement kilns and other industrial boilers using hazardous wastes as fuel were regularly violating Federal law. The agency found that more than half the plants were not adequately analyzing or controlling the wastes they were burning.
Until Ms. Browner's policy change, "cement kilns were often operating without adequate oversight," said Sylvia K. Lowrance, director of the Office of Solid Waste at the agency. "That will no longer be the case."
Turning a mixture of limestone and shale into cement requires heating kilns to 2,700 degrees Fahrenheit to bind the raw materials into rock hard nuggets called "clinker." That is then ground and mixed with gypsum to form cement.
Most of the enormous amount of energy required for the process is supplied by coal, but companies continually experiment with alternatives to lower costs. The favorite alternative fuels in the last decade have been paint thinners, waste oils, spent solvents and other petrochemical byproducts.
The environmental agency says five million tons of hazardous waste are burned each year in the United States. Though it is not known how much of the total is burned by cement kilns, Lafarge and its waste-management subsidiary, Systech Environmental Corporation, burned 80 million gallons of hazardous waste in 1992, or 320,000 tons, at six cement plants across the country. Of that, almost 13 million gallons weighing 52,000 tons were burned in two of the five kilns at Alpena.
To executives of Lafarge, the American subsidiary of Paris-based Lafarge Coppee, burning hazardous wastes is a useful marriage of economic and environmental goals. They said in interviews here that using hazardous wastes as fuel earned the company an average of $100 a ton and saved it the cost of normal fuel, reducing the need to strip mine miles of land for coal.
 
Companies Praise Procedure
 Moreover, the company says incinerating wastes in cement kilns represents the safest technology yet developed for destroying dangerous chemical compounds and protecting the environment.
"Our tests of air emissions, our analysis of the cement kiln dust, and our tests of the process prove to us that burning this waste as fuel effectively destroys the hazardous components," said Jim Daniel, the plant's production manager.
To members of the Huron Environmental Activist League, the burning of hazardous wastes at the Lafarge plant is a looming threat. They blame air and water pollution from the Lafarge plant for causing respiratory illnesses, birth defects and other health disorders, though state environmental and health officials say there is no evidence to confirm such claims.
Nonetheless, in an act that angered elected leaders, the critics put up a billboard in early June at the edge of town warning tourists that they were entering a region where hazardous wastes were burned.
"Lafarge says they've done the testing," said John Pruden, an artist from nearby Ossineke who is a leader of the environmental group. "They really haven't."
Caught in the middle of this battle is the state, which nearly two years ago began inspecting the plant frequently. Michigan is now requiring Lafarge to test air and water around the plant more thoroughly.
"Our intent," said Richard D. Alexander, an air-quality specialist in the state Department of Natural Resources, "was to make the Alpena plant the most closely monitored cement kiln in the country."

HEADLINE: Floods Force Corps of Engineers Into Balancing Act on Mississippi

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROCK ISLAND, Ill. July 5

 BODY:
As the rain fell again today, S. K. Nanda, the chief hydrologist at the Army Corps of Engineers district office here, punched the keyboards at a bank of computers and choreographed a watery balancing act involving three giant Iowa reservoirs along two Mississippi tributaries that weeks ago had filled to capacity.
From this command post just a few feet from where the Mississippi River was cresting at levels not seen since 1965, and never seen in July, Mr. Nanda was making water management decisions unlike any others he has faced in his 25-year career here. 
 Allowing the three reservoirs to fill much more could threaten the dams that hold them. But emptying them as fast as they were filling would cause the waters to rise more in the Des Moines and Iowa Rivers. That could not only put Hills, Iowa, and other towns downstream of the control dams in peril of flooding, but would also add more water to the Mississippi and cause the flood to top the levees and inundate Hannibal and other Missouri towns south of here.
Thus, Mr. Nanda ordered his dam keepers in Iowa to take just about the only action they could: open the flood gates, emergency conduits and spillways, but not to the maximum amount. "We deal with nature and technology on a daily basis," he said. "We try to make an exact science out of inexact nature."
The decisions made here today with the three reservoirs 100 or more miles away are a microcosm of what occurs every day in a mammoth plumbing system the Government designed and built this century to control the flow of the Mississippi and its largest tributaries.
Over the last 65 years, the United States spent billions of dollars to build roughly 300 dams and reservoirs, construct thousand of miles of levees and flood walls and operate countless pumping stations to regulate water draining from parts of 35 states, an area covering 1.25 million square miles, or more than a third of nation. Along with the construction of the Interstate highways, the Mississippi flood control project is one of the most enterprising civil engineering projects ever devised. Its primary purpose is to rein in a wandering river and keep it confined to a rigid man-made channel.
Some have called the project a supreme act of human arrogance, and today it is easy to see why. The Mississippi continued to bound past its banks and to flood towns along 400 miles from southern Minnesota to Missouri. But what is just as clear is that after decades of hemming in one of the world's great river systems, a supreme act of nature, like weeks of heavy rain in places that elude storage reservoirs, can overwhelm the project.
And that, said Mr. Nanda and his engineering colleague, William Koellner, is precisely what happened to cause this flood. Mr. Koellner, the chief of water control here, said that beginning on June 11, a foot of rain fell in southern Minnesota and lesser amounts fell in northern Iowa. Four days later, 11 more inches fell in roughly the same area. Both storms also moved east and dumped near-record rains on Wisconsin.
 
Much Rain Missed Reservoirs
 Most of the water found its way to the Minnesota River, a Mississippi tributary southwest of St. Paul, but not in any place where the Government had built storage reservoirs. On the east side of the Mississippi, the same sequence occurred in Wisconsin, on the Black and Wisconsin Rivers.
The only part of the downpours that was captured was what fell in Iowa. That drained into the three reservoirs formed by the Saylorville and Red Rock dams on the Des Moines River and the Coralville dam on the Iowa River.
At the Army Corps of Engineers district headquarters here, the two engineers and their staffs monitored banks of computers to analyze rainfall patterns, stream depths and river flows. It did not take Mr. Koellner long to predict that all that water pouring into the Mississippi, and moving downstream at 70 miles a day or so, would be trouble.
In mid-June he said the Mississippi would crest at Davenport, Iowa, across the river from here, at 18.5 feet, about four feet below the record of 1965. But then the weather front that caused the heavy rain stalled over Iowa and Minnesota. More rain fell, and June became the wettest in this region since record-keeping began in 1878, he said.
Today, with the river nearing the 1965 level, water has swamped Davenport's river front. And the only hope Mr. Koellner can offer property owners and city officials is that his gauges 50 miles upstream show the Mississippi's level falling.
In the meantime, the towns on the Des Moines and Iowa Rivers have been more fortunate. The reservoirs have prevented those tributaries from catastrophic flooding, and will continue to do so unless extraordinary amounts of rain continue to fall, Mr. Koellner said. And many of those towns are also protected by concrete flood walls and earthen levees.
Along the Mississippi, the Government built almost 500 miles of levees north of St. Louis to protect farms and towns. How well they work is evident in this old river port city.
The flood wall that protects Rock Island has kept all but the lowest-lying areas here dry. Across the river, Davenport residents chose to preserve their river views and not have any protections built; their waterfront neighborhoods and business districts have now been ruined by water.
In response to the flooding President Clinton toured the area this weekend and pledged a $1.2 billion package of flood-relief assistance.
 
History of Forcing Path
 For all but the last flash of time in its long existence, the Mississippi has determined its own boundaries. During periods of high water, it broke its bank and the energy of floods was dissipated as the water spread across tens of thousands of square miles of uninhabited bottom lands. In the 20th century, Americans by the millions drew up to the river's banks, developing the bottom lands for farms and towns. In 1927, a flood killed 214 people and caused $237 million in damage in the lower Mississippi Valley.
A year later, Congress passed the first Mississippi River flood control act, a law that sought no modern-day balancing of environmental and economic goals. The lawmakers directed the Corps of Engineers to confine the river to a prescribed channel. Some 300 flood control dams were built on the river's tributaries.
The nearly 550 miles of river from Hannibal to St. Paul, where most of the flooding has occurred, is managed by two Corps districts. Along with the Rock Island district's three Iowa dams, the Army Corps district office in St. Paul manages 16 flood-control dams.
Over the last few days, experts with the corps noted with some measure of disappointment that the rains fell where nothing made by man could catch them.
"All of this is within certain powers," said Joseph Raoul, the chief of hydrologics and hydrology for the corps's division office in Chicago. "There is nothing that could have been done that has not been done to handle this."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Finding Ways to House All Vexes Leaders at Every Level

SERIES: Search for Shelter: New York and Its Homeless -- Last of three articles.

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
President Clinton signed a little-noticed executive order in May directing his Administration to come up with a "single coordinated Federal plan for breaking the cycle of homelessness." There was no ceremony that day, no soaring oratory, no Presidential photo-op at a homeless shelter.
The order itself was as modest as the circumstances of its signing, emblematic of the lowered expectations of what government can do for the poorest of its poor. The President instructed the 17 Federal agencies involved with homelessness to come up with a strategy in nine months, but promised no new money to carry it out. 
 Mr. Clinton's retooling of homeless policies, however limited in scope, is likely to be strongly influenced by New York City's painful experience with this most visible and vexing manifestation of poverty. Two significant figures developing the new plan, Andrew Cuomo and Marsha A. Martin, were also key players in shaping the homeless policies of Mayor David N. Dinkins's administration.
Whatever Washington comes up with, city officials will themselves be moving forward with the revamping of the city's shelter system that Mr. Cuomo masterminded and that Ms. Martin was carrying out. At its heart, the new effort seeks to shift the city's ponderous shelter system toward the use of small residences for the homeless, run by private nonprofit groups, that address such problems as drug abuse and mental illness.
The city's handling of the homeless is also likely to surface as an important issue in the city's mayoral campaign. A recent New York Times/WCBS-TV poll found that New Yorkers ranked homelessness second only to crime as the problem they most want the next mayor to concentrate on.
Mayor Dinkins, unable to fulfill many of the promises he made on the issue in his last campaign, will have to defend the record of a system that provides services costing $500 million a year but that many believe has failed to lead people toward productive lives. His rival, the Republican-Liberal candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, would not talk about the issue for this article and has yet to reveal how, or even whether, he will approach the issue in any detail.
Mr. Cuomo and Ms. Martin say that the new Federal plan will follow many of the recommendations made by the commission Mr. Cuomo headed for Mr. Dinkins, encouraging cities to move away from simply offering rudimentary emergency shelter to a more sophisticated system of assessing the particular needs of each homeless person, placing people in small, specialized programs and then moving them, once they are ready, into permanent housing. The experts call this "a continuum of care."
 
'A Testing Ground'
 "What we've gone through here in New York is a good testing ground for the nation," said Ms. Martin, who became executive director of the Federal Interagency Council on the Homeless on June 14.
But Ms. Martin and Mr. Cuomo acknowledge that there are limits to what the Federal Government can do if financing remains at the level established during the Bush Administration. Mr. Cuomo, assistant secretary for community planning and development at the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, annually administers almost $1 billion in Federal programs for the homeless -- not big money when measured against the $500 million that New York City alone spends sheltering the homeless each year.
And without an infusion of money, many of the homeless will remain urban vagabonds, researchers and officials say. For example, the New York State Office of Mental Health estimates that it would cost close to half a billion dollars just to develop and operate housing with special services for the 10,000 homeless mentally ill people in New York -- and that does not count the needs of the other 49 states. Nor does it address the problems of homeless families, drug addicts, alcoholics and assorted other categories of down-on-their-luck poor people.
"Obviously, the ultimate solution lies in additional resources for housing, services, job training, jobs," Mr. Cuomo said. "It's always a question of money, but it's not only a question of money. That's what we learned in New York. The Cuomo Commission was premised on the fact of no new money. So we had to get smarter, more creative."
 
City Hall
A Thorny Issue For the Mayor
The issue in this year's mayoral campaign is likely to center on just that question: Which candidate can run a more humane, effective shelter system with the same or less money?
The public's firsthand experience with the problem makes homelessness a potentially potent issue. It is an inescapable fact of life, even for middle- and upper-class New Yorkers who can send their children to private schools, take taxis and live in doorman buildings. "It's scary and depressing at the same time," said Ester Fuchs, director of the urban affairs program at Barnard College.
Like his predecessor Edward I. Koch, Mr. Dinkins has discovered that the politics of homelessness are unkind to incumbents. The public wants a mayor who will fix the problem. As a candidate in the last election, Mr. Dinkins promised to close the armories, empty the welfare hotels and provide more housing for the homeless. The issue helped to define him as the candidate of compassion, in contrast to Mr. Koch, whose blunt talk about the homeless had come to sound more cruel than candid.
But this year, the question for Mr. Dinkins is not how much he cares, but how much he has accomplished. He is vulnerable because the city still uses the armories and hotels he himself abhors -- and because the homeless are still so visible on the streets. A majority of the New Yorkers polled last month said they disapproved of his handling of the issue.
"David Dinkins is a decent man," said Douglas H. Lasdon, executive director of the Legal Action Center for the Homeless, voicing an oft-repeated criticism, "but he is not a doer."
But Mr. Dinkins contended in a recent interview that his administration deserves credit for developing the approach to homelessness that his former advisers are now carrying to Washington. "We've demonstrated compassion and concern," he said. "We haven't walked away from the problem. We've tried to implement the Cuomo Commission recommendations."
Mr. Dinkins said that the issue is so important to him that his battle for a new agency dedicated to the homeless, one of the central recommendations of the mayoral commission, held up his acrimonious budget negotiations with the City Council last month. Ultimately, he won approval for the agency, though the Council forced him to cut the amount of new city money to finance it. "I knew it was vital, and I wasn't going to yield on that," Mr. Dinkins said.
 
What Would Giuliani Do?
 Talking about Mr. Giuliani's refusal to discuss his views on homelessness, part of his broader strategy to avoid specific positions on a range of issues, Mr. Dinkins said his opponent is evading "a knotty problem. He doesn't have a solution or a plan."
On the stump Mr. Giuliani has spoken only in generalities about homelessness, mentioning it as one of many urban problems that will be alleviated by building a healthier economy and privatizing city-run services.
He clearly intends to appropriate some of the Cuomo Commission's ideas. Though he made no comment himself, his spokesman, Ken Frydman, said, "Instead of being in the business of operating homeless shelters, Rudy feels the city should support nonprofit organizations that can do it better, like Help." Help stands for Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, a nonprofit group founded by Mr. Cuomo that runs apartment-style shelters for families.
And Mr. Giuliani is alert to the issue's political possibilities. He has met with Mr. Cuomo and advocates for the homeless. Mary Brosnahan, executive director of the Coalition for the Homeless, said she told him and his staff during a briefing that he had "a perfect opportunity to seize on the discrepancy between Dinkins's rhetoric and reality."
"They all nodded," she said. "They were taking notes like mad."
When he ran for mayor four years ago, Mr. Giuliani said in answer to a questionnaire from the coalition that he favored closing armory shelters and investing in permanent housing and small shelters offering social services.
"I was very comfortable with him," said Robert M. Hayes, a founder of the coalition who is now practicing law in Portland, Me. "He was a good Catholic schoolboy with whom I could relate. His positions were not materially different than Dinkins's. The question was who would carry them out better. The Mayor has been a disappointment. Giuliani remains untested."
Whoever wins the election will have to contend with the City Council, which is increasingly exerting its influence on the issue. Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone was one of the most enthusiastic backers of Mr. Cuomo's ideas, but the Dinkins administration found him thorny to deal with. Mr. Vallone felt the administration's original proposal for a new homeless agency was too costly and could turn into just another layer of bureaucracy.
He insisted on the Council's right to vote the agency out of existence in two years, which insures the Council a continuing say in city policy. Mr. Vallone says the Council will continue pressuring the mayor, whoever he may be, to get the homeless out of hotels and armories and to turn to nonprofit groups to run shelters. But some leaders of nonprofits worry that the Council, with its newfound power on this issue, may succumb to not-in-my-backyard pressures and try to block new shelters from opening in city neighborhoods.
 
Albany and Washington
Too Many Ideas, Little Money
On the state level, the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are engaged in a political battle over financing of community care for the mentally ill that has profound implications for the homeless mentally ill. Since the 1950's, the state has been emptying its mental hospitals -- a process that continues to this day and that saves the state millions in patient costs. But wholesale deinstitutionalization has caused homelessness among the mentally ill, advocates say.
Senate and Assembly negotiators last week announced their support for a landmark bill that would require the state to pour most of the savings from further shrinkage of mental hospitals -- as much as $42 million a year -- into group homes, local clinical care and other community-based services that the homeless need.
But Governor Cuomo, struggling to balance the budget, opposes the proposal. It remains to be seen whether a compromise can be worked out.
The courts may force the state to spend huge additional sums on an issue related to homelessness among families. Judge Karla Moskowitz presided over a three-month trial last year on whether the state should be required to increase the monthly rental subsidy to 289,000 families on welfare in New York City. Her ruling could cost the city and state hundreds of millions of dollars in higher welfare payments.
Advocates for the homeless and some city officials contend that the inadequacy of the monthly rental grant, $286 a month for a family of three, causes homelessness among families who cannot afford housing.
Absent legislative action or court mandates, the only real source of new money is the Federal Government. But the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which has administered the principal Federal programs for the homeless, has deep financial troubles of its own. It was recently disclosed that HUD expects to lose as much as $11.9 billion as apartment building owners default on Government-insured mortgages.
It is still possible that there may be new money for services important to the homeless through a Federal health plan, yet to be unveiled. A Clinton Administration advisory group had advocated universal access to drug treatment and mental-health care.
 
A Clinton Retreat?
 But with Mr. Clinton focused on his budget and deficit-reduction package and worried that he has been perceived as too liberal, the Administration seems likely to scale back this sweeping, potentially costly proposal.
"The sands have been shifting," said Herbert Kleber, executive vice president of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse in New York City. "I was optimistic that mental health and substance abuse would be covered like diabetes and a broken leg. But they're backing away like crazy."
The Clinton Administration faces a problem not unlike that of the Dinkins administration. It has more big ideas than it has money to carry them out. Ms. Martin, who will be coordinating development of the new Federal plan ordered by Mr. Clinton, talked during her last week on the job here about the limits of the city's efforts to help the homeless, but she could also have been talking about the constraints on Federal policy.
"People refuse to deal with the fact that people are poor," she said. "We cannot solve the crisis of poverty in New York City where 1.1 million people are on welfare. We're going through a budget crisis now. We're making very tough choices. We have committed ourselves to organizing the resources we have in a more effective, efficient fashion. That's good policy, good government and probably good politics."
In November, the voters will decide whether she's right.

HEADLINE: Temporary Workers Are on the Increase In Nation's Factories

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Temporary workers, those Americans recruited by companies like Manpower Inc. and rented to corporate clients, have become a familiar sight in many offices. Now "temps" are being used in manufacturing jobs, too, and in such numbers that the Labor Department no longer knows how many people actually work in American factories. Their growing presence means that manufacturing will probably not offer much help in solving the country's employment problem.
In the past, manufacturers have been among the first to make the economy bloom after a recession. As orders turned up, they hired new employees or recalled old ones. But in an economy that has surged and faltered several times since 1990, temporary workers have provided insurance against the next falter: people who can be brought in or laid off far more easily than regular employees.
 
'Worst-Case Approach'
 "Many manufacturers are taking a worst-case approach," said Ray Marcy, the chief executive of Interim Services Inc., a leader in recruiting and renting temporary workers. "Companies have surges in orders so they need help, but they don't want to hire. And with unemployment at 6.5 to 7 percent, it gives us a pool of talented people whom we can recruit inexpensively for our clients." 
 With the rise of this new class of inexpensive temporary manufacturing worker -- even at such stalwarts as I.B.M., General Electric, Motorola and Johnson & Johnson -- a de facto two-tier wage system is emerging at hundreds of manufacturing sites. It is a system in which temporary workers average $2 to $3 an hour less in wages than the permanent employees who work beside them. Many temps are sufficiently educated and skilled to learn a factory job quickly, even a complex one. But even they command only entry-level pay, which is rarely more than $9 an hour, the Labor Department says.
Some in the temporary-worker industry contend that their presence helps the United States hold jobs.
"The temps, in effect, are earning wages that are competitive with worker pay in other countries," said Bruce Steinberg, a spokesman for the National Association of Temporary Services. If the manufacturers could not find a way to get workers at this lower tier, he said, "then a significant part of manufacturing might be transferred outside our borders."
Nike Inc.'s high-tech distribution center in Memphis, while unlikely to be moved abroad, illustrates the economics that push manufacturers into using temporary workers. Sneakers arrive in bulk from many factories and are repackaged for shipment to retailers. Nearly 120 permanent employees, each earning at least $13 an hour in wages and benefits, work with 60 to 225 temporaries, the number varying with the level of activity.
Norrell Services, based in Atlanta, recruits the temps, trains some to drive forklift trucks and rents them to Nike. It collects up to $8.50 an hour for each worker. That covers $6.50 in wages and a $2 fee to Norrell -- the total cost still being well below that of a regular employee. Neither Norrell nor Nike pays for health insurance for the workers, but Norrell covers their worker's compensation and Social Security.
"We think of the core employees as team leaders," said Austin Martin, a Nike executive in Memphis. "They do the same jobs as the temps, give them direction and make sure the work is done right."
 
 
A Count Too Low
 Temps have been present in manufacturing for years; at Nike's Memphis office they were first used in the 1980's. But with the practice growing rapidly, the Labor Department acknowledges that its total count of 17.8 million workers in manufacturing in June is clearly too low, perhaps by several hundred thousand workers.
A survey of companies that supply temporary workers -- sponsored by their trade group, the National Association of Temporary Services -- showed that the companies provided an average of 348,000 temps a day to manufacturers late last year. That was up from a daily average of 224,000 early in 1992.
They represented more than one-fifth of the temporary workers recruited and hired out late last year by temporary-help companies. But none have been counted as manufacturing workers in the Labor Department's monthly tallies of employed people. The reason is that the companies that supply temporary workers -- Manpower, Kelley Services, Interim, Norrell and more than 1,000 others -- are classified as service-sector companies. So the people they deal with show up in the Government's employment data as service-sector employees, not manufacturing workers.
The survey by the Association of Temporary Services, completed last month, was undertaken partly as advertisement: its member companies are increasingly marketing their skills at supplying temporary workers to manufacturers. But the survey also provided the best measure yet of how this trend has grown.
 
 
Not the Whole Story
 Even that study, however, may not tell the whole story. By one estimate, provided by companies that "lease" whole groups of workers to manufacturers, an additional 75,000 people are hidden away in the Labor Department's statistics, untallied as factory workers. That would bring the total of uncounted manufacturing workers to 425,000.
Manufacturing is one of the economy's best sources of relatively high-wage jobs. But the number of workers has been held down as companies have introduced automation and as some production has moved to other countries. The recession took another slice out of this high-wage job pool; so, there is much interest in how many of these jobs return as the recovery progresses.
So far none have. Quite the contrary, the Labor Department says employment in manufacturing has shrunk by 664,000 since the recession officially ended 27 months ago. But if the estimated 425,000 extra temporary workers were included, the decline would be only about 230,000. This, in turn, would raise questions about the gains in efficiency and productivity that American manufacturers are reported to have achieved in recent years.
The Labor Department measures productivity by adding all the goods that the manufacturing sector produces. That total is divided by the number of hours worked by all the people in manufacturing, to find out how much each produced per hour. Production has remained steady in recent years, so as manpower has declined by 664,000 people, each remaining worker had to produce more to sustain the output. And the Labor Department reported that productivity rose sharply.
 
'We Don't Know'
 But if the decline in manufacturing workers was not so great -- if there were more workers than the department had counted -- the productivity gains would be smaller than previously calculated. Edwin Dean, the productivity expert at the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, acknowledges as much. "It appears that we are underestimating the growth in hours worked and overestimating the growth in productivity," Mr. Dean said. "It could be by a trivial amount. We don't know."
In any case, Mitchell Fromstein, chairman of Manpower, says the surge in temporary factory workers encourages a shift in strategy among manufacturers. "What they used to do is produce for inventory or storage, as well as immediate demand, and that kept a factory going with a steady work force," Mr. Fromstein said. "Now they want to produce only when there is demand."
To accommodate their clients, the temporary-help companies often train recruits, mostly for relatively easy tasks, like operating a forklift truck or soldering a computer board or operating a specific machine.
"There are a lot of jobs in manufacturing that don't require all that much training, and that is the real point," said Harvey Maslin, president of Western Temporary Services. "You can train people in a week or two, and they are just as efficient as someone who has been there 10 or 15 years."
That sort of reasoning runs counter to the Clinton Administration's view that the nation's manufacturers, to be competitive, must invest heavily in permanent employees. A well-paid worker, this thesis goes, is worth the pay if he or she becomes skilled and experienced in many tasks and, out of loyalty to the company, constantly seeks new efficiencies.
 
 
'False Dawns'
 "Businesses have been burned by false dawns in this weak economy, and flexibility is critically important to them," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said in an interview. "But the use of temporary workers will prove to be a false economy for many American companies."
Maybe. Right now, however, thousands of manufacturers, large and small, use temporary workers, along with overtime for existing employees, as the two primary means of getting work done without having to hire new employees.
Many companies find temps useful in other ways as well. Motorola brings in temporary workers not only as a buffer against a downturn but also to screen people who might, if they work well, be offered jobs in the future. The company's Land Mobile Products operation, which manufactures control panels and other equipment for mobile radio communication, has 125 temps at its Illinois plant. Most have been there for six months, helping the company meet a "bubble" in demand.
"We have told these 125 people that at points in time, when we can increase staff, we would review them and those that qualify might be offered jobs," said London Newton, the division's employment manager.
The hope of making the transition from temporary worker to permanent employee undoubtedly is an important motivator, many experts say. But often the temps are not looking for permanent jobs.
Paul Anderson, 45, of Highland Park, N.J., is one. With degrees in psychology and statistics, Mr. Anderson quit a job with the State of New Jersey in 1990 and struck out on his own as a consultant.
He is still a consultant, but in the evenings. The weak economy left him with only $25,000 in consulting income last year, Mr. Anderson said. So he signed on with Western Temporary Services and that company has rented him to several companies, including Sundoor Brands, which mixes and bottles apple juice and Hawaiian punch in Dayton, N.J.
Mr. Anderson operated assembly line machines, earning $7 an hour alongside regular employees getting more than $10 an hour. "It would bother me if I did not have my nighttime consulting work; I can't get by on $7 an hour," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Europe Out of Step on Japan Trade

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 5

 BODY:
Like the United States, the European Community will continue to press Japan at this week's summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial democracies to curb its $150 billion annual worldwide trade surplus, more than a fifth of which is with Western Europe.
But differences between the United States and Europe over how to address the trade problem will keep them from presenting Japan with a united front on the issue, government officials and analysts said, diluting their message and perhaps weakening their negotiating positions. 
 Despite ending initial negotiations with Japan last Monday without making significant progress, the Clinton Administration is sticking by its insistence that Tokyo accept specific targets for increased imports of goods and services from the United States as the best way of achieving measurable success in reducing the trade gap. A third of Japan's surplus comes from its trade with the United States.
 
Quota Deals Opposed
 The European Community, however, has made clear that it objects to such a "managed trade" approach, primarily out of fear than any specific quotas assigned by Japan to goods from the United States would reduce opportunities for European exporters.
Instead, the community will push a program to review with Japan, company by company if necessary, the reasons why European exporters have difficulty getting access to the Japanese market. Based on the results of the reviews, the community would then propose specific changes to remove the impediments and create more free-market competition, officials said.
Top community officials, including Sir Leon Brittan, the trade negotiator, and Hans van den Broek, the foreign affairs minister, will meet in Tokyo with a Japanese delegation led by Yoshiro Mori, the trade and industry minister, on Tuesday. The next day the leaders of the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada will open their summit meeting in the Japanese capital.
 
'A Different Style'
 "We don't reject the idea of putting maximum pressure on Japan to reduce its surplus as a percentage of G.D.P.," one European trade official said in Brussels. "We agree with the U.S. on the aim, and we haven't openly criticized the U.S. measures. But we have a different style in our approach to cutting the current-account surplus."
Japanese officials have sought in recent weeks to isolate the United States in its efforts to impose numerical targets on its imports to Japan by portraying the Clinton Administration's approach as counter to the principles of free trade. But it is self-interest rather than ideology that appears to have driven the wedge between the United States and Europe over the issue.
"If the Japanese markets are opened, European business will have to fight for its share," said Keith Richardson, the secretary general of the European Roundtable, an association of leading business executives based in Brussels. "But one hopes there are no special arrangements between the U.S. and Japan that might be done at Europe's expense."
Economists and trade analysts said Europe and the United States, although united in the general goal of inducing Tokyo to reduce its trade surplus, also remained reluctant comrades because of their own deep trade disputes over issues like agricultural subsidies and access to government contracts.
"The fact that the U.S. and the E.C. have disputes going on in many areas really inhibits them from coming in and presenting a united front to Japan," said Nigel Gault, an economist in the London office of DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting firm.
Because of the eroding European economy and the rise in unemployment, economists said the community and the national governments will be under increasing political pressure to take a hard line with Japan on trade, and not just in automobiles.
"Certainly at the moment I get the sense that in Europe there is growing support for protectionism," Mr. Gault said. "It's by no means the dominant sentiment, but it's growing. There's a general fear of cheap imports from all countries in Asia, produced at low labor costs, that are able to undercut workers in the E.C. and take jobs away."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: 64% OF JAPANESE SAY U.S. RELATIONS ARE 'UNFRIENDLY'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 5

 BODY:
As President Clinton heads to Tokyo for the Group of Seven summit meeting and his first official visit to the country he describes as America's most important partner, nearly two-thirds of Japanese polled describe their country's relations with the United States as "unfriendly."
The poll, conducted in both countries by The New York Times, CBS News and the Tokyo Broadcasting System, found Japanese feeling toward the United States to be more negative than at any time in the eight years the poll has been conducted. 
 Japan's view of the United States soured markedly during the first six months of the Clinton Administration, a time of greatly heightened tensions over Japan's trade surpluses, and much of the Japanese discontent appears directed at Mr. Clinton himself.
 
A Sour Atmosphere
 More than two-thirds of the Japanese polled said they did not trust Mr. Clinton to keep his word. But the poll was conducted after months of scandals in Japan that have greatly weakened the Government and left many Japanese sour on politicians in general.
On the eve of his visit, Mr. Clinton cast his position on trade with Japan in a softer light today, telling a convention of schoolteachers that he planned to set broader economic goals in Tokyo this week. [Page A6.]
In the poll of Americans and Japanese, it was perhaps most surprising that the perception of the relationship differed greatly on each side of the Pacific. About 70 percent of Americans described relations between the two countries as "friendly," while only 35 percent of Japanese viewed the relationship the same way. Sixty-four percent of the Japanese viewed relations as "unfriendly."
 
An Abrupt Change
 The change in the Japanese view marked a striking decline. As recently as last December, 53 percent of Japanese said they viewed relations as friendly; in 1985, when the question was first asked, 73 percent described them that way. In the most recent poll, only 4 percent said they expected relations to improve in coming years.
"We are seeing some pent-up sentiments finally explode," said Takashi Inoguchi, a professor of political science at the University of Tokyo. "Negative sentiments toward the United States are bursting out somehow and I think the bureaucrats and mass media in Japan are amplifying that."
The poll was based on 1,363 telephone interviews in the United States on June 21-24 and 1,395 face-to-face interviews in Japan on June 10-16. Each poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Much of the bad feeling appears to have been directed at Mr. Clinton himself, who was originally viewed in Japan as a bright young leader. Many Japanese once hoped he would inspire change in their own political system. Only 6 percent of Japanese described their feelings toward the President as "favorable," compared with 35 percent of Americans. Most Japanese, 63 percent, said they were undecided.
Mr. Clinton's favorable ratings rose to 41 percent in the United States when 622 poll respondents were interviewed again on June 27, shortly after the United States attack on an Iraqi intelligence installation in Baghdad. The Japanese respondents were not interviewed again.
 
Follow the Leader
 Several commentators here said they believed that the Japanese view of Mr. Clinton reflected comments from Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and other national leaders suggesting that Mr. Clinton has much to learn. "There is a view about Clinton, widely shared here, that he is inexperienced and doesn't know anything about free trade," Professor Inoguchi said. "Many think that he has turned out to be a tiger and has to be dealt with carefully."
Mr. Clinton is to meet with Mr. Miyazawa for two hours on Tuesday afternoon, but expectations are low.
So far, the two countries have been unable to agree on a framework for trade negotiations, with Japan accusing the United States of trying to set targets that place the onus on Japan to close the trade gap. In any case, 70 percent of Japanese who were asked whether Mr. Clinton could be trusted to keep his word said "no."
 
Who Is to Blame?
 Indeed, the poll indicated bigger disagreements among the Japanese and American public than at any time in years on the question of which side is to blame for the economic tensions. Forty-five percent of American poll respondents said Japanese companies are "competing unfairly with American companies," the highest such response since the question was first asked in 1985.
The Japanese, in contrast, overwhelmingly reject the charge. Eighty-five percent agreed with the statement that "the United States is blaming Japan for its own economic problems." Only 12 percent said Japanese companies were competing on unfair terms.
But Japanese also blamed their own leader for troubles between the two countries. An overwhelming 82 percent said Mr. Miyazawa was doing "a poor job in solving trade problems between Japan and the United States." They gave similar marks to President Clinton.
American respondents were more charitable to the President on trade issues: 31 percent said they thought he was doing a good job, 38 percent a poor job and 31 percent did not know or gave no answer.
The 64 percent of Japanese who described Japanese-American relations as "unfriendly" exceeded the previous mark of 55 percent in May 1987, shortly after the United States imposed sanctions on some Japanese electronic products. Washington accused Japan of selling semiconductor chips at unfairly low prices.
 
Domestic Unhappiness
 The poll also revealed some of the popular roots of the political rebellion that has shaken Tokyo.
Eighty-five percent of the Japanese respondents said they did not think Mr. Miyazawa was serious about limiting corruption. Sixty-one percent said they supported splitting the ruling Liberal Democratic Party in two. (The polling was completed just a day before Parliament passed a vote of no confidence against Mr. Miyazawa, forcing an election in which the Liberal Democrats are expected to lose power for the first time in 38 years.)
The poll also showed that Detroit's efforts to improve quality and cut costs have not made much of an impression on the Japanese, perhaps because they see little change in the product offerings since the last, ill-fated Presidential visit here. That was in January 1992, when President Bush came here with the top executives of America's Big Three automakers, who denounced both the Japanese and the agreements Mr. Bush reached here to sell more autos and auto parts.
In the poll, 48 percent of Americans said American-made cars "are a better value," a view held by only 1 percent of the Japanese. In contrast, 33 percent of Americans viewed Japanese cars as a better value, while 91 percent of Japanese respondents held that view.
Such wide differences carried over to views of technological skills in both countries. While 25 percent of the Americans said Japan would have a higher level of technology in manufacturing than competitors in the next century, 60 percent of Japanese said that. About 50 percent of Americans and 25 percent of Japanese said the two countries would be equally matched in technology.
Japan's negative view of the United States extends to fear of crime: 76 percent of Japanese polled said they thought it very likely or somewhat likely that they would be victims of crime if they visited the United States.
At a time when Japan, with United States support, is pressing for a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, the poll suggests that the Japanese public is less enthusiastic about being in the thick of United Nations disputes.
Asked if "Japan should participate in United Nations peacekeeping efforts in trouble spots around the world," even at the cost of Japanese lives, only 32 percent agreed and 66 percent disagreed. The same share, 66 percent, said they feared Japan would be caught up in another country's war if it increased its military power.
Such results also showed a gulf between American and Japanese views of Japan's responsibilities in today's world. Only 24 percent of Japanese said they thought Japan had a responsibility to give military assistance in trouble spots and 74 percent said it did not. Forty percent said they thought the United States had that responsibility.
 
How the 2 Polls Were Done
 The New York Times/CBS News/ Tokyo Broadcasting System Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted on June 21 to 24 with 1,363 adults throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, and on personal interviews conducted on June 10 to 16 with 1,395 adults throughout Japan.
In the United States the sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were chosen from random digits, permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers.
Within each household one adult was chosen at random at the beginning of the interview to be the respondent for the poll. The results have been weighted to take account of household size and the number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations relating to region, race, sex, age and education in the sample.
In Japan, the survey was conducted by the Nippon Research Center under supervision of the Tokyo Broadcasting System. Personal interviews were conducted throughout the country to yield a statistically representative sample of the Japanese public.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult Americans or all adult Japanese.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any public opinion survey may introduce other sources of error into the polls. The translation of questions between English and Japanese, for example, can sometimes result in questions that have slightly different meanings in each language.

HEADLINE: CLINTON PUSHING FOR JAPAN PACT

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5

 BODY:
On the eve of his most significant foray onto the international stage to date, President Clinton cast his position on trade with Japan in a softer light today, telling a convention of school teachers that he planned to take a broader set of global economic goals to Tokyo this week.
Noting that more than 40 percent of the nation's trade is with Asia and that this accounts for millions of American jobs, Mr. Clinton put a positive construction on the relations between the United States and Japan that had been missing in recent discussions. 
 "In recent years, when we looked across the Pacific, we focused on our trade difficulties with Japan," he said. "Well, the trade deficit with Japan is real, unacceptable, and we're working very hard to take steps with Japan to deal with that.
"But our relationships with the Pacific for the most part are good for us, and we will benefit from them."
 
Meanwhile, . . .
 What Mr. Clinton left unsaid, however, was significant.
United States officials have spent weeks trying to get Japan to relax trade barriers to reduce a $50 billion annual trade deficit, but they have encountered significant difficulty in reaching the usual raft of pre-summit-meeting agreements, particularly on critical issues like wider access to Japanese markets.
But Mr. Clinton put an optimistic face on those difficulties today, saying that he planned to appeal to Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and to President Kim Young Sam of South Korea to help win a new global agreement on open trade by the end of the year.
"The global economy is here to stay," he said. "We can't wish it away. We can't hide from it, and no political leader can promise to protect you from it. We simply have to compete, not retreat, and we have to do it while maintaining our position of world leadership."
Declaring that "the line between our domestic and foreign policy has completely evaporated," Mr. Clinton sought to link the domestic issues he has focused on and the foreign policy that has lately occupied so much of his time.
 
From Iowa to Seoul
 The meeting here of the National Education Association was the second leg of a trip that will take Mr. Clinton to Tokyo for a meeting of the leaders of seven industrial nations and to Seoul for talks on limiting the spread of nuclear weapons. On Sunday he stopped in Iowa to survey the damage caused by flooding in the Midwest.
In his remarks to the teachers' group, he said the Tokyo summit meeting would provide Washington with its first opportunity to showcase its determination to encourage global growth by reducing its own burdensome budget deficit.
Mr. Clinton said he would call for another meeting of the industrial nations in coming months, perhaps at Camp David, Md., to discuss the structural unemployment that is plaguing several nations.
The President said he also planned to use the trip to Asia to outline his plan to establish a robust economic relationship between the Far East and the United States.
"We cannot long continue to promote democracy when Europe is having the slowest economic growth in four decades, and America over three million jobs behind where we ought to be at this point in our development," he said, adding, "still with the strongest economy of all these industrial nations. We can do better and we must."
During his campaign for the Presidency, Mr. Clinton emphasized the importance of relations with Japan, a theme that he repeated today while expanding his definition to include South Korea.
 
Defending His Budget
 The President touted the budget bills that recently passed the House and Senate as evidence that the United States was "getting our house in order" and "putting the steel back into our competitive edge."
He did not point out, however, that the measures face a significant battle in a House-Senate conference to work out differences over taxes and Medicare cuts.
Mr. Clinton said the new taxes included in the bills are needed to craft a responsible economic plan.
"For 12 years, voters have been spoonfed pablum," he said. "They've been told there is a free ride."
But, he added, "The deficit is like a bone in our throat."

HEADLINE: In Canada, Elderly Praise Their Health Care

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, July 5

 BODY:
Charlotte M. Cohan, her bones weakened by disease, curled up in a chair at the Rotary-Laughlin Center with a cup of tea and some carrot cake.
"I always thought a nursing home was the worst place you could go to, the end of the line," she said as Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" played on the stereo. "This place is a godsend. I have a hundred friends here." 
 For her shared room and "more food than you can eat" at this downtown Toronto home for the aged, Mrs. Cohan, who is 82 years old, pays the equivalent of $700 a month, financing it through her government retirement pension. She also gets $87 a month in "comfort money" for personal expenses, like magazines and visits to the hairdresser.
Thanks to universal health insurance, benefits to the impoverished elderly in Canada are considerably more generous than those offered by the United States. In part they reflect a greater trust in the role of government in Canada, and a willingness to pay higher taxes for social services.
Fees from nursing home patients, for example, generally represent about one-third of the actual cost in either private or government homes. The balance is paid by provincial governments and community service agencies.
But Canada's different approach to health care for the elderly applies at higher income levels as well.
Americans must use their own money for nursing homes or other long-term care until they deplete their assets; then they can qualify for Medicaid, the Federal-state health program, a process that often leads to anguish and humiliation.
No such restrictions exist in Canada, where there are some means tests for government aid but families are not required to sell off their assets. Those who are better off may be required to pay more, but rich and poor live under the same roof, eat the same meals, go to the same social functions.
Canada's growing fiscal problems arise in part from its health system. But for long-term care it has a system that everyone can afford and that offers more for the money than many patients get in the United States.
The system for the elderly parallels Canada's universal health care, which has also won praise for being simpler and more efficient because the Government pays all health bills.
The Clinton Administration has said it wants to include long-term care in the health-reform proposals it is developing, but it may have to defer any major program because of the costs.
 
Fastest-Growing Age Group
 "We don't have quite the same idea that the only way you're entitled to government help is as a total last resort," said Raisa Deber, health economist at the University of Toronto. "We have a different set of priorities."
A result, said Sharon Sholzberg-Gray, executive director of the Canadian Long-Term Care Association in Ottawa, is that "affording long-term care has never been an issue for individual Canadians."
The elderly are Canada's fastest-growing age group. Some 3 million Canadians are over 65, or one citizen in 10. In 30 years, the ratio will be 1 in 5. American figures are roughly comparable: one American in 8 is over 65; in 30 years, the ratio will be 1 in 6.
The charge for standard nursing-home accommodation, depending on the province or territory, is $625 to $700 a month. The fee is set at about $78 a month under the income received by the poorest pensioners in order to leave the all-important "comfort money."
 
The Cost Is Lower
 Jessie Current, 90, pays about $1,650 a month at Rotary Laughlin. She is Canadian-born. Her late husband was an American in the pulp and paper business and they lived in southern Ohio. "This is nothing like the bills I'd have if I had to go to a nursing home in the States," she said. In the United States the average cost of a nursing home is $2,500 a month.
Using numbers from the provinces and from Statistics Canada, the Canadian Long-Term Care Association has calculated the cost to the taxpayer of all community- and institution-based care programs for the elderly at $3.9 billion a year. This is slightly over 10 percent of the $32.4 billion that Ottawa and the provinces spend on health.
In the United States public funds, mainly Medicaid, pay for more than half of all nursing-home costs. The Health Care Financing Administration reports Medicaid expenditures for long-term care at $38.6 billion last year. An estimated $15 billion to $20 billion of public funds also went into long-term care in Federal and state social-service grants.
 
A Fear of Poverty
 Most American and Canadian health economists agree that the quality of institutions that serve mainly Medicaid patients -- though they vary widely -- is generally below that of the publicly supported Canadian institutions. Medicaid pays nursing home fees that range from $1,200 a month to nearly $4,000 a month, depending on the state, usually well below what the better homes charge private patients.
So great is the fear in the United States of being forced into poverty by the cost of long-term care that more than 2.4 million Americans have bought costly insurance to cover the cost. In Canada, there is no such thing.
No country has a perfect system, but Canada's, while continuing a process of creative tinkering, has caught the attention of specialists in the United States.
"We have looked at Canadian long-term-care programs and found them very interesting," said Robyn Stone, who headed the Long-Term Care Work Group for President Clinton.
 
Some Spending Cuts
 The President is expected to give special emphasis in his proposals to expanding home- and community-based programs, as Canadian provinces are now doing. Keeping people in their own homes longer can improve the quality of life and save money.
Ontario, home to one of three Canadians, has just announced plans to spend $505 million over the next five years, mostly to expand and streamline home-care services for the elderly, like meal programs, home maintenance, transportation and nurses' visits.
The province's Health Minister, Ruth Grier, said in an interview that overall health spending is being drastically curtailed except in the home- and community-based sector, where the aim is to "help the elderly keep their independence as long as possible."
Olive Donaldson, a member of the nonprofit Victorian Order of Nurses, visits 12 patients a day, most of them elderly, in north Toronto. A "foot soldier," as she calls herself, "who is in the trenches every day," she provides home dialysis, intravenous medication, even "bowel routines" if necessary.
For her there is no question about the value of home care. "I feel it's cheaper in the long run," she said. "It takes longer to get well in a hospital. At home you're more relaxed. It's more supportive, and you're in charge."
Ontario government agencies provided some form of home medical care to 307,000 people last year, roughly 3 percent of the population of the province, but more than one-third of those over 65. The number is expected to grow to 340,000 in the current year.
 
A Higher Priority
 Many states in the United States already have well-developed home-care programs for the elderly, financed in part by Medicaid. The main differences are the higher priority given this approach in Canada and the degree of integration here between home and institutional care.
Dr. Duncan Robertson, head of geriatric medicine units at both the Sunnybrook Health Science Center in Toronto and the University of Toronto, points to an "artificial dichotomy" in the United States.
"In making choices, families must do a great deal more work and suffer more anxiety because the system is so complicated and disjointed, whereas in Canada, you literally have one or two contacts with placement specialists who can then access a full range of services," he said.
Basically, the Canadians run care for the aged as a social program, which means that the real risk of financial disaster for those facing long-term-care needs is incurred not by individuals but by society.
 
Tests National Character
 In their book "A Will and a Way: What the United States Can Learn from Canada about Caring for the Elderly," Rosalie A. Kane and Robert L. Kane, health economists at the University of Minnesota, call long-term care a test of national character.
Canadians, they wrote, "seem to show that persons and organizations of good will can grapple with long-term care and produce a program that both the country and individual users can afford."
Mrs. Kane added in an interview: "At the very minimum, the Canadian experience illustrates the art of the possible at a time when pessimism prevails in the United States regarding genuine, far-reaching long-term-care reform."
