HEADLINE: Music Notes;
Violinists to Play So Youngsters Can String Along

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The directors of Music for the World, a new foundation that sponsors music-education projects, have a theory: if Government agencies give money to the public schools for music programs, then music lovers should also chip in. To that end, Music for the World is presenting Fiddlefest, a benefit at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 25 in which 10 well-known violinists are to perform to raise money for the Opus 118 Music Center, a violin-instruction program in East Harlem, and Link Up, Carnegie's education program.
The specifics of the concert have not been announced, but the roster suggests a polystylistic evening. Soloists from the world of classical music will include Itzhak Perlman, Midori, Isaac Stern, Ida and Ani Kavafian and two members of the Guarneri String Quartet: Arnold Steinhardt and the violist Michael Tree. The others will be Diane Monroe and Karen Briggs, who play jazz, and Mark O'Connor, a country fiddler. A student ensemble from the Opus 118 Music Center, led by its founder, Roberta Guaspari-Tzavaras, will also perform. 
 "The original energy behind our organization was Walter Scheuer," said Eve Marko, the executive director of Music for the World. "He has been a member of the Carnegie Hall board for many years, and he has made films about music and supported musicians and students who were struggling to make it. But he founded this organization as a way of addressing the bigger picture, which is that people who are interested in music but who have not decided to commit their lives to becoming the next Heifetz now have no access to music in the schools.
"We are in the process of assembling a board of advisers, which includes musicians of all kinds. Because we feel that music in the schools must be not only classical music but any kind of music that can touch young people's hearts."
The organization was founded in June 1992, and Fiddlefest is its first public event. The beneficiaries are in some ways at the opposite ends of the organizational spectrum. Carnegie's Link Up program, the firmly established educational arm of a major New York cultural institution, sends teachers to the public schools to give students introductory classes about music before taking them to the hall for a performance. It reaches about 19,000 students a year.
The Opus 118 Music Center, named for its headquarters at 409 East 118th Street, is more of a neighborhood operation. It was founded in 1991 when Ms. Guaspari-Tzavaras, a public-school music teacher since 1980, lost her job when her program was dropped. Ms. Guaspari-Tzavaras's resourceful response to unemployment was to persuade the Board of Education to let her continue teaching in East Harlem schools so long as she made other arrangements about her salary. She then solicited private and corporate contributions and set up a foundation that pays for her program, which has 130 students between the ages of 6 and 13.
"I've been to her classes," Ms. Marko said, "and I've spoken to the parents of her students, who tell me that music is here to stay, not only in the lives of their children who are in Roberta's classes, but the siblings and the rest of the family. She has really made an impact. So we think of this concert not just as a benefit, but as an advocacy evening. The disappearance of the arts from schools around the country is an issue. But these organizations show what's possible with community support."
Tickets are $500 and $1,000 for the concert, a dinner and a champagne reception, or $35 to $100 for just the performance. Information: (212) 247-7800.
 
A Chicago Renovation
 The Chicago Symphony Orchestra's home, Orchestra Hall, is to undergo a $92 million renovation that will begin next year and is expected to be completed by 1998, the orchestra has announced. The renovation, which will not interrupt the orchestra's seasons, will include an expansion of the hall's stage, which in its present form is too small to comfortably accommodate concerts using full orchestra and chorus. The roof over the stage will be raised to improve the hall's acoustics.
Joyce Idema, the orchestra's director of marketing and public relations, said recently that the renovation would not significantly alter the look of the hall, and that the seating capacity of 2,590 would remain about the same. Because the stage is to be extended backward into the alley behind the hall, no seats in the hall will be lost. Seating may, in fact, be increased: the plan allows for the choral seating area behind the orchestra to be used by the audience, an arrangement more common in Europe than in the United States.
The largest part of the renovation is not in the hall itself, but in the addition of a new wing to the Orchestra Hall building. When the adjacent Borg-Warner Building is demolished in 1995, Orchestra Hall will begin building an extension that will include new office and rehearsal space.
The plan also allows space for a restaurant, a retail store, an exhibition area and an expanded music library, as well as upgraded recording and television facilities. A two-year feasibility study for the project was undertaken by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the architectural firm, and Lawrence Kirkegaard, an acoustician, but Ms. Idema said the team that would actually design and execute the renovation had not yet been named.
Orchestra Hall has been the Chicago Symphony's headquarters since 1905, and has been renovated twice since then. Its acoustics are considered to be fairly good, although some structural work in 1966 is generally considered to have interfered with the sound, something the current plan is meant to correct. A pipe organ was installed in the hall in 1981.
 
Hemidemisemiquavers
 Allison Vulgamore, the general manager of the New York Philharmonic, is to become the executive director of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra on Sept. 6. At the Philharmonic, Ms. Vulgamore coordinated the logistics of the orchestra's touring and oversaw its personnel, education and artistic administration departments. She joined the Philharmonic's administration in 1987, after five years in various administrative positions with the National Symphony. In 1991, during the period between Albert K. Webster's resignation as the Philharmonic's managing director and Deborah Borda's appointment to the post, Ms. Vulgamore was acting managing director, and was widely considered a candidate for the post. In Atlanta, she will be the chief administrator of an orchestra that in recent years has achieved considerable national recognition through a series of recordings with its former music director, Robert Shaw (and to a lesser degree with its current conductor, Yoel Levi).
*The New York Chamber Symphony of the 92d Street Y was awarded the 1993 Ascap Award for Adventuresome Programming of Contemporary Music. Each of the orchestra's programs during the 1992-93 season (not counting those in the Baroque series) included at least one new or recent work, and several also revived neglected 20th-century works.
*The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra will celebrate its centennial during the 1994-95 season, and is seeking materials -- documents, photographs, recordings and memorabilia -- both for its permanent archive and for use in special exhibitions and publications. Carnegie Hall began a similar archival project a few years ago when it was preparing for its own centennial, and turned up a trove of material, much of it from concertgoers who had hoarded boxes of programs, ticket stubs, posters and other items. Cincinnati's history has been fairly colorful: its past directors include Leopold Stokowski, Eugene Ysaye and Fritz Reiner, and it was one of the first American orchestras to make commercial recordings. Information: Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra Centennial, 1241 Elm Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45210.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Once Again, Baseball Kicks Dirt on Its Own

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

 BODY:
The Pittsburgh Pirates evidently were not going to let the San Diego Padres beat them at their own game. The Pirates had lost the bulk of their good players through free agency, but here were the Padres trading away their high-priced players, not waiting for them to leave as free agents.
So the Pirates last week went the Padres one better in the game of one-upmanship. They took the we-can-slash-our-payroll-better-than-you-can game into the front office and lopped two of their four highest-ranking executives from their staff. Last Wednesday, Mark Sauer, the Pirates' president, summoned Douglas Bureman, senior vice president for business operations, and Rick Cerrone, vice president for public relations, and told them their jobs were being eliminated and bade them goodbye. 
 "We can absorb their duties internally better than if I had lost any other vice president," Sauer said by telephone from Pittsburgh yesterday, explaining why he chose Bureman and Cerrone to eliminate.
The puzzling part of the Pirates' move is that they banished the vice presidents now even though they will pay them through October. The Padres at least didn't release Gary Sheffield and continue paying his $3.11 million salary. The Pirates could have kept the vice presidents in their positions until the end of the season, giving them an opportunity to look for new jobs without the black cloud of dismissal hanging over their heads.
Asked why he acted now, Sauer said immediate action was required because of "the ongoing financial pressure we're under, particularly with the loss of $7 million or so in TV dollars next year."
"It's important we do that now so we can withstand that loss," he added.
But why didn't he give Bureman and Cerrone the added time and avoid the suspicions that naturally arise when people are fired? "I wouldn't want to have two lame ducks at the senior level," Sauer said. "That would be very unfair to them."
Dismissal isn't very fair either, but if a theory about the whole episode is correct, it places a different perspective on the matter.
The theory, offered by a person close to the Pirates' organization, suggests that the severe step was not done out of financial desperation, but rather was designed as a move to give the appearance of financial desperation.
The Pirates are suing the city of Pittsburgh over maintenance of Three Rivers Stadium and the stadium lease. Their goal is to get a new, more favorable, lease. They especially want to make that point to the man who will soon be the city's new mayor. (If strains of this scenario sound familiar, it's because George Steinbrenner has orchestrated a similar game in New York with the Yankees and Yankee Stadium.)
By firing the vice presidents, the theory goes, the Pirates have created a crisis in Pittsburgh. Fans and news media alike have talked and written the past week about how bad things are with the Pirates. The theme has been that if the Pirates don't get what they need in the near future, the city will lose them.
This, the theory concludes, is precisely the atmosphere the Pirates wanted to create. If Bureman and Cerrone had been told privately that they would be jettisoned at the end of the season, it would not have served the purpose.
Sauer denied such an ulterior motive.
"We're in litigation with the city to terminate our lease," he said. "If we haven't gotten their attention in the last 15, 16 months, we never will."
Whatever the reason, Bureman and Cerrone face future life in or out of baseball with possibly besmirched reputations.
Baseball management is good at besmirching reputations, especially those of the players, who, after all, are the product that club owners are trying to sell to the public. Major league and club officials wonder why their stars aren't as popular among the fans as Michael Jordan and Charles Barkley; they don't understand that they have undermined their players' image by constantly whining about their high salaries and the production they get from them.
If baseball has an economic problem because of players' salaries, let the owners and their chief labor executive, Richard Ravitch, try to solve it with the union privately. Instead, they constantly take their case to the public, as if the fans can pressure the players into agreeing to a salary cap. That strategy is flawed for two reasons:
1. The players never have been and will not now be pressured by what fans think.
2. The last thing the fans want to hear is the owners' crying about the problem they created by giving lavish salaries to players of all levels of ability.
Baseball officials should be selling Barry Bonds, Ken Griffey Jr. (they easily could become baseball's version of Jordan and Barkley), John Olerud, Andres Galarraga, Cecil Fielder, Fred McGriff, Juan Gonzalez, Gregg Jefferies, the Toronto Blue Jays' fab five. They should be talking about the record rate at which fans are flocking to games this season, and the phenomenon in Denver, where 60,000 has become a routine crowd size.
Instead, they sell their problems, seemingly intent on putting their game in the worst light. The fans have enough of their own problems. They go to the ball park to get away from them. They don't need to add baseball's to their own.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
TANDEM COMPUTER WARNS IT MAY DISMISS SOME WORKERS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Tandem Computer Inc. of Cupertino, Calif., expecting a fiscal third-quarter loss, said it might dismiss some employees this month because of a drop in orders and a weak economy. The company, which made its announcement on Friday, would not say how big a loss it would post for the quarter that ended on Wednesday. A survey of 11 analysts by Zacks Investment Research produced a mean earnings estimate of 18 cents a share. That would have been 2 cents more than in the corresponding quarter a year earlier, when Tandem earned 16 cents.

HEADLINE: Ships Are Culprits As Foreign Species Invade Ecosystems

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
Kudzu, the galloping green vine imported from Japan in the late 1800's, has taken over much of the American South. The zebra mussel, which arrived from Europe in the late 1980's, is on the march in the lakes and rivers of the eastern United States, clogging intake pipes and threatening to disrupt water distribution. In Australia, a tropical toad imported from America in 1935 to control sugar-cane beetles is eating everything but the beetles and has become a plague on the land.
Alien species of plants and animals transported around the world by human beings are invading ecosystems on every continent and island, imperiling the natural ecology and to some degree the human economy. And now scientists have found that the kaleidoscopic array of marine creatures in saltwater ponds are being transferred routinely, every day, from one part of the world to another -- in the ballast tanks of ships. 
 Dumped into new habitats when the ships make port, the scientists fear, the billions of organisms are placing estuaries, bays and other inland waters in serious ecological jeopardy by threatening to decimate native species.
Ships have long carried sea water as ballast, but bigger and faster vessels with cleaner, more hospitable tanks have "upped the ante" in recent years, says Dr. James T. Carlton, director of the Maritime Studies Program conducted by Williams College in Mystic, Conn. Marine biologists say that scores and perhaps hundreds of ballast-borne invasions have consequently taken place in the last two or three decades.
"There was ballast water before," said Dr. Carlton, "but now it seems to have clicked into place as a major dispersal vector."
An especially compelling illustration has surfaced in a study in the current issue of the journal Science by Dr. Carlton and Dr. Jonathan B. Geller, a marine biologist at the University of North Carolina in Wilmington. They sampled the ballast tanks of 159 Japanese cargo ships arriving at Coos Bay, Ore. In the laboratory, the scientists discovered that the ballast water contained 367 different types of plants and animals, mostly in larval form, representing all of the major marine habitat groups.
"We found shrimps, crabs, fish, barnacles, sea urchins, starfish, worms, jellyfish, clams, snails, really the complete spectrum of marine life that the public is familiar with," said Dr. Carlton. Invasions of marine organisms such as these have been documented on every continent, the two scientists reported. "We could have been anywhere -- Seattle-Tacoma, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Tahiti, Australia" and probably found much the same kind of thing.
 
'Conveyor Belt' of Invaders
 When all the evidence is put together, Dr. Carlton said, "we see a conveyor belt of marine organisms wrapping around the world; there are several thousand species in motion right this moment, as we speak, in the ballast waters of ships."
People have transferred plants and animals from one region to another since ancient times. The global transplantation of organisms accelerated with the European explorations of the 15th and 16th centuries and again with the speedier transportation and expanded trade of modern times, and today flora and fauna in virtually very part of the planet are a mixture of natives and exotics. Some exotics have settled benignly into their new habitats, but others have aggressively eaten or crowded out native species to the point where some natives have been extinguished and others threatened with extinction.
Alien species have been introduced both accidentally, as in ballast water, and on purpose, and some of the purposeful introductions have turned out to be the worst. In a commentary accompanying the study in Science, Dr. Joel W. Hedgpeth, professor emeritus of marine ecology at Oregon State University, described the importation of the tropical American toad to Australia to combat the sugar-cane beetles:
"Unfortunately the toads are nocturnal feeders and the beetles are abroad by day, while the toads sleep under rocks, boards and burrows. By night the toads flourish, reproduce phenomenally well and eat up everything they can find. The cane growers were warned by Walter W. Froggart [sic!], president of the New South Wales Naturalist Society, that the introduction was not a good idea and that the toads would eat the native ground fauna. He was immediately denounced as an ignorant, meddlesome crank. He was also dead right."
Today the toads are thriving so spectacularly that some are the size of dinner plates. Nobody knows what to do about them.
In any bay or estuary, ecological factors like water quality, salinity, time of year, temperature and number of predators and competitors vary from time to time and place to place. If the combination is not exactly right when an invader arrives, it may not become established. "A number of things have to come together to make the invasion click, as it were," said Dr. Carlton. All it takes is a window of ecological opportunity for a successful invasion to occur.
 
Troubled Waters
 Perhaps 5 to 10 percent of species introduced to a new environment become established there, he said.
The Congressional Office of Technology Assessment is completing an extensive study of the impact of foreign species in the United States and is to issue a report later this year. Dr. Carlton, who is a member of the study's advisory panel, said it emphasizes the invasion of exotic plants and animals to the land and fresh water.
The study by Dr. Carlton and Dr. Geller raises a new issue. The researchers boarded cargo ships arriving at Coos Bay from 25 Japanese ports after passages averaging two weeks, during which some of the tiny planktonic and larval organisms died but many survived. "These ships have a lake of water in the middle of them," said Dr. Carlton. Typically, he said, the ballast tank is 70 feet deep and 30 feet square. "You could put a boat in there with an outboard motor," he said. The researchers lowered a net with holes the size of pinheads into the tanks to take samples. The samples were then analyzed at the Oregon Institute of Biology. They contained representatives of all major marine groups, including plants, plant-eaters, meat-eaters, scavengers and parasites.
This wholesale transport of entire assemblages of coastal fauna "renders bays, estuaries and inland waters among the most threatened ecosystems in the world," Dr. Carlton and Dr. Geller wrote in Science. Releasing such a vast array of species means that "at any time you could be inserting into Chesapeake Bay or Long Island Sound or Puget Sound a brand new parasite or predator that could decimate fisheries," said Dr. Carlton. "We are constantly seeing new invasions all around us."
He and Dr. Hedgpeth cited a West Coast example, the introduction of an Asian clam into the upper arm of San Francisco Bay, where it was discovered in 1985. Its larvae, believed to have arrived in ballast water from China, has attained a population density of nearly 12,000 per square yard and is, Dr. Hedgpeth wrote, "capable of seriously interrupting the basic food chain of San Francisco Bay."
But there is hope for a rescue, Dr. Hedgpeth said. An invader from the Atlantic, the green crab, has spread throughout the bay since 1990. Its body is only three inches across, but it is "a vicious little thing," he said, meaning that the crab is voracious and aggressive and able to force shellfish open with its claws. It could well control the Asian clam. The problem is that it may also ravage populations of native clams that draw clam diggers to bays north of San Francisco. The recent appearance of the green crab in one such bay is "an eyebrow-raiser," he said.
All told, said Dr. Carlton, San Francisco Bay has about 150 more marine species as a result of invasions; but given the ability of exotic species to depress native ones, the natives may turn out to be "a shadow of their former selves" in numbers. One concern is that this kind of ecological transplantation and thinning of native species will lead to similar assemblages of species in bays and estuaries everywhere -- "homogenizing the world," Dr. Carlton calls it. Since bays and estuaries are generally sheltered bodies of water with unique species mixtures, he said, they are especially vulnerable to invasion, much as islands are.
Can anything be done?
One short-term but partial solution, Dr. Carlton said, is to dump ballast on the high seas and re-ballast with mid-ocean water. This might reduce or even eliminate the number of estuarine species carried, and many mid-ocean species presumably would not survive in shallow inshore waters. But the maneuver might not be possible in high seas.
In the future, ships might be constructed in a way that would make it possible for the ballast water to be sterilized or filtered, two measures for which vessels cannot practically be modified.
"In the long term I think there's great hope," said Dr. Carlton. "In the meantime we have to hope that we don't sustain an invasion in a place like Chesapeake Bay or Long Island Sound or Puget Sound. That's where the roulette comes in."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton: Victor and Puzzle

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The President gave the small lunch for journalists because he wanted to talk about the Tokyo economic summit before he set off.
I listened earnestly, but the truth is my mind occasionally wandered off -- to a funny movie and to a budget cut that had escaped his attention. 
 Afterward, I stopped feeling guilty about my lapses of strict attention to summit solemnities because taken together the movie and the budget cut seemed to sum up both the President's triumph and his failure -- symbols, something all journalists cherish dearly.
The film was a wonderful assassination of journalistic prophets, a "documentary" prepared by the Clinton people and shown at the inauguration gala. One seer after another was recaptured at different points in the campaign capsulizing Mr. Clinton's chances of becoming President -- out, dead, so long, Bill Who?
The movie should have been the appetizer for lunch. For weeks the press has told us that Europeans think very poorly of Mr. Clinton -- bumbling, inexperienced, unsophisticated, unfit for exalted company.
But here was Bill Who, not only President but going to a summit where he will be the only national leader with a future longer than a blink, representing the country with the most political and economic stability.
In Japan and Italy, the Governments are busy arresting themselves. In Britain, the Prime Minister teeters and the Royal Family is embarrassing comedy. In France and Germany, President Mitterrand and Chancellor Kohl must be calling Mikhail Gorbachev for tips on setting up their post-office foundations.
But every time my good old naturalized American blood started pumping pleasurably at Mr. Clinton's in-your-eye triumph I remembered that budget item. I thought unhappily that it showed Mr. Clinton's puzzling failure to lead the country on the fundamental issue of the right of the citizens to live in peace and safety.
On Wednesday of last week, with the approval of Administration budget specialists, the House of Representatives cut $231 million from President Clinton's own anti-drug budget. The money was to have been spent on drug therapy and education.
On Thursday, the President swore in his new director of drug policy. Obviously nobody had told Mr. Clinton what had happened in the House because he talked earnestly about how his Administration was increasing the budget for drug therapy and education as essential ways of cutting drug demand. On Friday, the day of the lunch, word still had not climbed up the White House chain.
But, then, why should Administration budget people take too seriously Mr. Clinton's commitment to fighting drugs and the crime and fears it brings to America?
The White House virtually wiped out the anti-drug office that Mr. Clinton turned over to the new director, Lee Brown. The President gives neither direction nor passion to the war against drugs; forgive the unfashionable expression. For the Administration it is not an insy item: No careers are to be found there.
Mr. Clinton talks about creating jobs, but otherwise he has a strange air of detachment about what most Americans who live in the cities really want.
They really want freedom from the dangers of drug addiction for their children -- and freedom from bullets. They want guns in cities criminalized for almost everybody but cops.
They want the disgrace of homelessness handled -- care for the mentally ill, housing for the economically destitute and rousting for the exploiters and marauders of the streets.
They even dream of sending their children to schools without metal detectors, where teen-age girls respect themselves enough not to walk around with big bellies.
No President can give all that, nor government alone. But a President can preach and holler at the citizenry, implore and criticize it, tell Americans what home or school or church can do, what they have to do all by themselves, what government must do and where its limits lie. That is leadership by inspiration, the antidote to leadership by demagoguery.
Everybody tells Mr. Clinton to focus only on the economy, as if Americans had no other hope, dream or fear.
The last American President remembered solely for his impact on the economy was Herbert Hoover. Perhaps that may occur to Mr. Clinton after he returns from Tokyo.

TYPE: Op-Ed

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1659 words

HEADLINE: Bank Courts Growth in Marriages of Convenience

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Edward P. Junker 3d flirts with bankers for a living. A banker himself, he is chief executive for the northwestern Pennsylvania region of the PNC Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh. Two years ago, PNC stripped Mr. Junker and seven other regional executives of much of their operational responsibilities and told them to go out and find banks for the rapidly growing company to buy.
Set in the slow-growth Rust Belt, PNC says its earnings from its existing operations -- which stretch from Kentucky to Delaware -- will increase 6 to 7 percent a year at best. But like other expanding regional banks, PNC hopes it can grow at twice that rate by buying other banks. 
 So Mr. Junker hit the road, calling on the executives and key shareholders of most of the banks in the 20 counties in which PNC wants to expand.
 
 
Polite Overtures
 The flirtation is indirect and cordial. He will commiserate with them about how keeping up with regulations is getting harder for smaller banks. He will mention how PNC has invested in state-of-the-art technology. He will talk about how he has more time to meet with clients and to do the other things he likes best since he sold his bank to PNC in 1983.
Mr. Junker would never be so crass as simply to offer a certain amount of money. Nonetheless, "they know why I'm calling," Mr. Junker said. "Sometimes they are not interested. And sometimes they are just kicking the tires."
 Often, after years of coy rendezvous, a banker may eventually get serious. "As a rule, it's a long courtship," Mr. Junker said. After calling on scores of banks, Mr. Junker has been able to win two for PNC since 1991: the CCNB Corporation in Harrisburg and the First National Pennsylvania Corporation in Erie, his hometown.
"We had great respect for the company and thought they would take care of our employees and customers," said Lawrence F. Klima, the former chairman of First National, which chose PNC over four other bidders last year. And no small reason was the repeated contact with Mr. Junker. "He knew our directors and what made them tick as well as we did," Mr. Klima said.
As the storm clouds of the real estate recession lift, it is mating season for bankers. Their courtship rituals can be seen on the golf course, over steak dinners and before poker games at bankers' conventions. Their urge to merge is a survival instinct in an environment where growth is slow and competition fierce.
No one is more driven to master the art of romancing financiers than PNC's tough, plain-speaking chief executive, Thomas H. O'Brien, who sent Mr. Junker on his mission. PNC is already the country's 11th-largest banking company, with more than $50 billion in assets. But PNC sees its destiny as becoming one of the handful of truly nationwide banks that will survive a decade of consolidation.
Mr. O'Brien plans to buy big banks to get into new markets -- from St. Louis to Maine at first -- and smaller ones to increase its share in existing locations.
While this expansion strategy seems simple, it is very complicated to execute. It is not economical for banks simply to open branches to expand into a new location; market share shifts too slowly in banking. Nor can they just make unsolicited bids for banks they want to buy; hostile offers risk alienating key employees and customers.
 
 
Waiting for an Opportunity
 So PNC must wait for banks to get into financial trouble or for their executives to decide it is time to sell.
"The world isn't ideal," Mr. O'Brien said. "So we have to position the company to be opportunistic and be well prepared financially and with the infrastructure so we can react when the opportunities come. Inevitably they will."
PNC is poised to pounce once it learns a bank is for sale. It has a staff of merger specialists assembling files, with estimated values, on hundreds of banks that it may want to buy. Mr. O'Brien has also assembled a "red team" of executives from all its business lines ready to evaluate a potential acquisition target once negotiations begin.
Mr. O'Brien is not content simply to wait for deals to walk in the door. That is why he has assigned his regional executives to flirt with smaller banks. Mr. O'Brien has devoted himself to the more complex courtship of banks with more than $6 billion in assets; he is particularly fond of about a dozen.
 
 
The Big Ones Get Away
 Indeed, while PNC has bought eight small banks in the last two years, Mr. O'Brien has been unable to win over any of his big targets. Most tantalizing would be to buy a leading bank in Philadelphia, the largest market in PNC's region, where it now has only a small presence. PNC has been especially keen on the largest Philadelphia-based bank, the $22 billion Core states Financial Corporation, which has so far rebuffed Mr. O'Brien's advances.
One reason PNC may have a hard time closing a big deal is that Mr. O'Brien rejects arrangements that are billed as mergers of equals, with the power shared by executives of both banks.
Mr. O'Brien says that he will offer top executive positions to qualified people from the companies he buys but that the power will remain in Pittsburgh. "You can't have equivocation and vacillation and ambivalence," he said.
PNC's smaller deals have proved to be highly profitable. PNC bought banks with assets totaling nearly $5 billion for far less than it would pay for a $5 billion bank, Mr. O'Brien said. Moreover, because PNC has been able to merge most of these banks into nearby operations, it has been able to slash their expenses by up to 50 percent.
 
Appeasing the Chief Executive
 Even with smaller banks, the most difficult aspect of getting deals done is the future of the banks' executives and board members.
Mr. O'Brien said: "Things are finally going well, and the C.E.O. says, 'Why should I turn over something that I've worked all this time for to someone else. If I sell out, I'm not going to be C.E.O. anymore.' "
PNC offers these bankers jobs or severance packages. Nonetheless, banks are often sold when the chief executive is nearing retirement age.
PNC is also hoping more banks will become frustrated with the complexity of keeping up with banking technology and regulations. "It was getting too expensive for us to invest in the branch automation," said Mr. Klima, who sold the bank in Erie to PNC.
Once they decide it is time to sell, some banks simply run an auction. But in other cases, they choose a small number of banks to negotiate with, and the point of PNC's flirtation is to make sure PNC is not forgotten.
 
 
'You Have to Pass This First Test'
 "They have to feel comfortable; to trust us; to believe in us," said Michael N. Harreld, who runs PNC's Kentucky bank. "They want to know how have we treated the employees and the community in past acquisitions. Has the company kept its word? Some people may see these as soft issues, but you have to pass this first test."
The next test, for many bankers, is how much autonomy the bank will be granted after the merger. Here PNC is at a disadvantage, compared with some smaller banks that have a policy of keeping local managements largely intact. For a while, PNC used this type of decentralized structure. But Mr. O'Brien decided to bring most of the important decisions back to Pittsburgh to improve controls and further cut costs.
PNC does let regional executives make certain decisions on prices and credit and allows them to keep making charitable contributions.
"The C.E.O.'s live in the community and will stay there after the deal is done," Mr. Harreld said. "They do not want to be embarrassed when someone comes to them later and says, 'Look what happened to the community,' based on what you did."
 
 
Price Has the Last Word
 Deals, however, eventually get down to price, and since most transactions are done as stock swaps, the seller has to be convinced of the future prospects of the buyer. PNC has an advantage because its stock is selling at a price relative to book value that is higher than the stock prices of many of the banks it is bidding against.
"Where there is a bidding situation, the larger banks have a distinct advantage in that they can pay more," said William J. King, chairman of the Dauphin Deposit Corporation, a $4.5 billion banking company in Harrisburg. "The deals we do are based on relationships with people we've known for a long time."
Yet officials at PNC, more than at other banks, consider their higher stock price to be a trap as much as a benefit. Many large banks are willing to buy banks for stock at a price at which the earnings per share of the existing stock will not be diluted. PNC, however, will not give away more in stock for an acquisition than it would have paid in cash. This pricing discipline earns the bank praise from many analysts.
 
 
Discipline in Acquisitions
 "They are eager to expand, but they are very disciplined about how much they pay," Dennis Shea of Morgan Stanley said. "As a shareholder, that's how you want them to be."
Indeed, PNC is equally wary about completing the deals it agrees to. In February, PNC canceled an agreement to buy Ohio Bancorp of Youngstown for $250 million after inspection of the bank's books disclosed more problems than it had expected. "That was a fascinating transaction because most banks when they say they will do a deal, come hell or high water, won't walk away from it," Mr. Shea said
Pricing is the biggest factor in how many objects of PNC's affection make it to the altar. Mr. O'Brien says PNC is negotiating more potential transactions than before, but since the industry is earning record profits, the prices are too high for many of the banks, especially the larger ones.
"We can do the deals that the market gives us," Mr. O'Brien said. "Now what the defense gives us is the short pass -- the smaller deals. So we have decided to use lots of short passes to get to the end zone."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Tuesday about the PNC Bank Corporation misstated the amount by which the company expects earnings from existing operations to increase yearly. The company expects revenues from existing operations to increase by 6 to 7 percent and earnings to increase by 10 to 15 percent because of cost-cutting.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
CLINTON COURTING REBEL LAWMAKERS ON TRIP TO JAPAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, July 7

 BODY:
Landing in the midst of Japan's political turmoil, President Clinton set out Tuesday to build relationships with a new generation of politicians trying to overthrow the party that has ruled Japan for four decades. And this morning, in a speech at one of the country's leading universities, he sought to enlist the Japanese people to lower trade barriers for their own good and prosperity.
In a toughly worded address to students at Waseda University, Mr. Clinton outlined his strategy for relations with Asia but also argued that Japan's high prices and restrictive practices had "hurt Japanese consumers." He told the audience, mostly students, that major changes in the country's trading system "would benefit both of us," and argued that "you have a common cause with the people of America." [Excerpts, page A8.] 
 The speech this morning came on the first full day of the President's six-day Asia tour, built around the Group of Seven economic summit meeting that began today.
[About the same time, trade ministers for four of the leading industrial nations said they had reached a crucial tariff reduction agreement that would likely lead to a revival of stalled global trade talks. If the agreement represents a breakthrough, it could become one of the most significant accomplishments of the summit meeting. Page A9.].
 
New Political Landscape
 Mr. Clinton wasted no time making it clear, in several symbolic actions, that he was preparing to deal with a political landscape that was changing for the first time since the 1950's.
On Tuesday evening he moved directly from a meeting with the faltering Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa to a reception that included the opposition leaders who in recent weeks have broken with Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party, undercutting its majority in Parliament.
White House officials said the meeting was part of an effort to reach out to a new group of younger Japanese politicians who, whether they succeed in taking power or not after elections on July 18, seem bound to gain influence in America's economic and security relationships with Japan over the next several years.
Mr. Clinton said he took no position in the coming elections, but many of his comments appeared to endorse the efforts of the new parties and rebel politicians to challenge the status quo. Even before he left Washington, he spoke enthusiastically about the the rise of "consumer advocates" and other reformists in Japanese politics, and was quoted by The Washington Post as saying that a new generation of leaders in Japan would be "a big plus for us."
He continued that theme in his speech this morning, comparing the current changes to Japan's Meiji Restoration in the mid-19th century, when feudal lords were overthrown and the country opened to the West for the first time.
He described the American relationship with Japan as "the centerpiece" of America's strategic relations in the Pacific, where 40 percent of United States foreign trade is now conducted. He often complimented the energy and ingenuity of Japanese business, but warned that "it is clear that our markets are more open to your products and investments than your markets are to ours."
 
Change of Direction
 For the United States, which has built its postwar relationship with Japan by supporting the Liberal Democrats, his meeting on Tuesday night with leaders of the opposition -- and some leaders of the governing party itself on all sides of the reform debate here -- seemed part of a subtle effort to redirect American policy, distancing it from the Liberal Democrats.
"We come here with an outstretched hand and hope that all the ferment and change and political debate going on in Japan will be a very positive thing for your people and our relationship," Mr. Clinton told group of 30 or so Japanese leaders -- business executives, journalists and members of the governing party and the opposition -- gathering at the residence of the American Ambassador.
"Many of the things that you are debating, from political reform to economic issues, are being debated in our country and in other industrialized democracies," he said. "I think this period of change should be viewed by all of us with hope."
Several of the elder party leaders listened with obvious discomfort.
A senior Administration official, underscoring the impression that Mr. Clinton wanted to reach out to the new Japanese leadership in the governing and opposition camps, said, "We had to make it very clear that the President understood there was a power transition under way here, and is ready to work with it."
Mr. Clinton's comments came as American and Japanese negotiators worked to come up with a draft "framework" agreement -- the guiding document for how to conduct the next several years of trade negotiations -- by the end of the Group of Seven summit meeting.
At a news conference on Tuesday after his meeting with Mr. Miyazawa, whom few expect to be in office after the elections, Mr. Clinton declared that "there are still issues which divide us." But he said that Mr. Miyazawa had sent him "a very thoughtful letter which reached out across the gap between our two positions."
At issue was a fundamental difference of approach. The United States has insisted on agreements keyed to numerical targets that would produce "measurable results" -- such as increases in American market share or in the number of American-produced parts designed into a Japanese product. Japan has refused to enter any accord that could provide for unilateral action against Japan if the effort fails.
 
Coining a Bureaucratic Phrase
 In recent days Mr. Miyazawa has said that Japan would agree to what Japanese officials are calling, in a turn of bureaucratic phraseology, "non-obligatory reference indicators." The indicators appear to be vague economic measures that would not be held as binding agreements.
"It is fair to assume that the Japanese have moved in our direction," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said on Tuesday night, but he declined to say what concessions the United States was offering.
While the trade negotations went on, the Japanese public was instead transfixed by images of Mr. Clinton warmly greeting the opposition leaders who bolted from the governing Liberal Democratic Party last month, passing a resolution of no confidence that brought down their own Government and threw the country into political turmoil.
Mr. Clinton spoke with Tsutomu Hata, a former Finance Minister who led more than 30 members of Parliament out of the governing party, and Morihiro Hosokawa, founder of the Japan New Party. Both men are considered contenders for Mr. Miyazawa's job.
While Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, worked the room, leaders from the other Group of Seven nations were arriving here in a blitz of black motorcades. John Major of Britain, Helmut Kohl of Germany, Carlo Azeglio Ciampi of Italy and Kim Campbell of Canada all arrived for a meeting that many predict will produce few agreements of substance, chiefly because so many of the participants are politically weak at home.
But there is much on the agenda, from the Clinton Administration's efforts to get countries to agree to a target of 3 percent G.N.P. growth, to half-hearted calls for action in Bosnia and a move to halt to the spread of nuclear weapons. Mr. Clinton is also scheduled to see President Suharto of Indonesia, the leader of the nonaligned nations, in what Mr. Christopher called "more evidence of our commitment to Asia."
 
A Different Tone
 Mr. Clinton's tone upon landing here on Tuesday was clearly different from his last encounter with Mr. Miyazawa, in April in Washington. Then, to the distress of the Japanese, Mr. Clinton talked almost entirely about easing economic tensions, saying that had to come ahead of all else. But this time he sounded more like the Japanese themselves, speaking on several occasions about the need to maintain the security and political aspects of the relationship, and to keep economic tensions in perspective.
But for Mr. Clinton, the key issue may be whether he can keep up the pressure to achieve a broad framework agreement on trade in coming days. When the two leaders met for the first time in April, they vowed to have a framework together by the time of Tuesday's meeting, paving the way for them to begin to negotiate about specific sectors of each other's economy. But that was before Japan's political turmoil.
The sticking point has been the American insistence on "measurable results." Until recently, Mr. Miyazawa and the Japanese bureaucracy refused to even talk about any kind of "targets," saying they were an interference in free markets and an invitation to retaliation by the United States if the goal was not met.
 
An Exchange of Letters
 But after weeks of deadlock, and with the summit meeting and election approaching, Mr. Miyazawa wrote the letter to which Mr. Clinton referred in his news conference. Mr. Clinton responded in a letter delivered just hours before he landed.
Mr. Clinton was asked repeatedly whether it made sense to negotiate with a Government that seemed certain to be forced out in coming weeks.
"Conventional wisdom would have it that it would not be possible at such a political moment," Mr. Clinton said, sitting at Mr. Miyazawa's side. "But the Prime Minister has defied convential wisdom."
But he added, "That does not mean that we will get an agreement."
Japanese and American officials say they are discussing compromise language that would allow the United States to declare itself satisfied that Japan is making a commitment to "measurable results."
Officials traveling with Mr. Clinton said they would rather leave Tokyo this week with no agreement than with one that gave up too much. But it is not yet clear who, the Americans or the Japanese, would have more at stake if the negotations fail. Mr. Clinton would have to face Congress, where there are calls to immediately limit Japan's $50 billion trade surplus with the United States. But Mr. Miyazawa is in a classic bind, needing to show Japanese voters that he is tending to the relationship with America while avoiding surrendering to their demands.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Egypt Ties Are Strained In Detention of Islamic Cleric

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, July 6

 BODY:
Relations between the United States and Egypt, once the linchpin of American policy in the Arab world, have sharply deteriorated over a number of disputes that culminated with the detention of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, whom Egyptian officials condemn as a "creation" of Washington.
Three years ago, President Hosni Mubarak played the crucial role in assembling George Bush's coalition to fight Iraq in the Persian Gulf war by serving as host for an Arab summit meeting here that cracked the myth of Arab solidarity. 
 Now senior Egyptian officials, including President Mubarak, contend that the American Government repeatedly ignored their warnings about the danger posed by Mr. Abdel Rahman, whose followers in the United States include suspects in the bombing of the World Trade Center and in a plot to set off bombs in Manhattan.
 
Afghan War Effort by U.S.
 What is more, the officials say, the United States, especially at the height of the war in Afghanistan, courted the militant cleric as part of the struggle to woo Islamic fundamentalists in the fight against Soviet troops.
Egyptian officials are angry that Washington has shifted responsibility of any prosecution of the sheik to Cairo, because the American authorities detained him on immigration charges instead of charging him with a crime.
"Once the cleric became too much of a liability," an Egyptian official said, "rather than arrest him they decided to let him leave the United States a free man unless, they told us, we agreed to make an extradition request. This is another example of American ineptitude."
State Department officials said that under American law, Mr. Abdel Rahman, who is appealing an expulsion order, could leave and seek refuge in a third country that would support his militant goals, including the overthrow of the Egyptian Government.
The only way to counter such a departure, American officials said, was a formal extradition request by the Egyptian Government, which was delivered to the United States Ambassador, Robert H. Pelletreau, by Foreign Minister Amr Mousa on Sunday.
The anger expressed by Egyptian officials over American actions regarding the sheik represents a growing alienation between the two allies, especially as the Clinton Administration places greater emphasis on human rights issues and the establishment of democratic governments.
 
Cultural Differences Cited
 "The Americans, as they do in the whole world, come here and want us to be like them," one official said. "They understand nothing of our values or our culture, and the result is chaos."
Ambassador Pelletreau has expressed increasing displeasure with the human rights record of Egypt and has accused the Government of being slow to liberalize its largely state-run economy. Mr. Pelletreau has also personally confronted President Mubarak about what is seen as endemic corruption within the Government, a participant at the meeting said.
Earlier this year, Egyptian officials say, they were outraged after discovering that two employees from the United States Embassy had been meeting with prominent members of the Islamic Group, who consider Mr. Abdel Rahman as their spiritual leader.
A sense of abandonment by Washington has been made worse in recent weeks by some American Congressional leaders who have said the United States should begin cutting back its $2.3 billion in annual aid to Egypt.
 
The Power of Perceptions
 "Perceptions affect politics more than facts," said Mohammed Sid Ahmed, a columnist, "and the perception is that the Americans are indebted to the sheik for his support during the war against the Russians in Afghanistan."
The Egyptian authorities appear to fear that the United States, not wanting to repeat the mistakes it made in Iran, might be willing to have a relationship with a fundamentalist government here, rather than risk losing a cornerstone in the Middle East.
The Egyptian Government, struggling to fend off mounting violence by Islamic militants, could have exploited the detention of Mr. Abdel Rahman, and the arrest of at least 12 of his followers in New York, by carrying its campaign against Islamic fundamentalism to the outside world.
The Islamic Group has carried out bombings and assassinations in Egypt against Government officials, police officers, intellectuals, Coptic Christians and foreign tourists. The country's tourism industry, which once brought in $2.2 billion a year, has been virtually shut down. In the last 18 months 180 people have died in militant-related violence.
But what was an opportunity to build links between those under attack in New York, and those under attack in Egypt, appears to have been squandered. The high profile that the Clinton Administration and the American press have given to the sheik and to the arrest of his followers is seen by many Egyptian officials as an effort to enhance the stature of Egypt's Islamic militant movement.
"The mass media has turned out to be a propaganda tool for the terrorists, especially when through ignorance, the terrorist crimes are overestimated, and the terrorists capabilities magnified," Al Ahram, a Government daily, said a recent editorial.
Two Egyptian newspapers quoted President Mubarak last month as saying Mr. Abdel Rahman had obtained a visa in return for services to American intelligence. One paper apologized and said it had misquoted Mr. Mubarak. But officials continue to repeat the assertion, despite American denials.
The United States, Egyptian officials say, knowingly gave Mr. Abdel Rahman a multiple-entry visa in 1990 even though he was on a list of foreigners considered undesirable. State Department officials have referred to "an error" in issuing the visa in Khartoum, the capital of the Sudan.
"The Egyptians," a Western diplomat said, "seem incapable of imagining that a superpower ever makes a mistake."
 
Green Card Is Revoked in 1992
 American officials also say the Immigration and Naturalization Service mistakenly granted a green card, or a residency permit, to Mr. Abdel Rahman as a religious worker.
In March 1992, the green card was revoked by the immigration service because, officials said, the sheik had concealed that he was a polygamist and had been convicted in Egypt of falsifying a check. A judge ordered him deported in March, but Mr. Abdel Rahman remained free, until his detention on Friday, pending an appeal.
But these actions, including a decision by immigration authorities to let him enter and leave the United States three times after arriving in July 1990, are seen by Egyptian officials as evidence of the relationship between the Americans and the militants.
So the detention of Mr. Abdel Rahman and the arrest of this followers have divided Washington and Cairo instead of uniting the two Governments in a battle against terrorism.
"The Americans and the Egyptians need each other," said Mr. Sid Ahmed, the columnist, "but there is so much distrust and suspicion that it now affects every issue between them."

HEADLINE: Doctors Weigh the Costs Of a Chicken Pox Vaccine

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Ever since vaccines have consigned measles, mumps, rubella and polio to the history books, chicken pox has been the only major childhood illness that parents weather with their children.
Now, a chicken pox vaccine that has proved both safe and 97 percent effective in trials in children may be about to enter the United States market. But as eager parents await news of its release, doctors and Federal officials are hesitating about whether to use it. 
 Scientists have worried that the immunity granted by the new vaccine may wane over time, so that those who avoid chicken pox in childhood might get it as adults, when it is a more serious disease. They have also raised the theoretical concern that the vaccine, which consists of a live weakened strain of the chicken pox virus, might itself cause symptoms.
But at heart they are all struggling with a subtler question: Is chicken pox a bad enough disease that all children should avoid it?
"The major controversy is whether the medical consequences of chicken pox are serious enough to warrant a major vaccination effort, whether chicken pox is worth preventing," said Dr. Walter Orenstein, director of the national immunization program ofthe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, who will probably have to make that decision for the country within a year.
The new vaccine, which is made by Merck & Company, is being reviewed by the Food and Drug Administration. If the agency deems it "safe and effective," it will be approved for marketing, and doctors will then turn to the Centers for Disease Control for guidelines on its use.
 
2 Sides of Debate
 Parents who have lost nights of sleep and days of work dabbing calamine lotion on that notorious "dew-drop on a rose petal" rash, as it is described to medical students, know how they would answer. Chicken pox affects 90 to 95 percent of Americans by the end of adolescence, according to the Centers for Disease Control, and another 2.5 percent over the age of 20. More than 60 percent of the cases occur in children aged 5 to 9.
But from a medical perspective, chicken pox is more a monumental nuisance than a danger. Unlike measles, which is often followed by pneumonia, or polio, which can result in permanent paralysis, chicken pox in children is usually a benign short-lived illness with virtually no long-term consequences, which grants lifetime immunity. A vast majority of the economic cost of the disease is attributable to lost pay of parents who become housebound with children who are not allowed to go back to school or day care until their pockmarks have disappeared.
Some scientists say that it is nonetheless time to approve a chicken pox vaccine.
"To me there are enough complications and parents lose so much time from work taking care of kids with chicken pox that it is worth vaccinating," said Dr. Anne A. Gershon, head of pediatric infectious disease at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. She added that chicken pox can be devastating, even fatal, in children with poor immune systems, like those with cancer or those taking steroids for asthma.
 
Ruling Is Awaited
 But others balk at the idea of giving the shot to every child.
"Do you want to give a vaccine -- with unknown side effects -- to prevent a very mild disease?" asked Dr. Philip Brunnell, head of pediatric infectious disease at Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. "I think it's a difficult question and I'm glad I don't have to make the decision." He and others emphasize that to justify vaccinating everyone against a disease that for most is more inconvenient than harmful, the shot itself must be unquestionably safe.
The vaccine was discovered in Japan more than a decade ago and is now used to immunize all children in that country. It has been close to release in this country several times, but each time it has run into obstacles: a manufacturing glitch, now corrected, that resulted in a vaccine that produced a chicken-pox-like rash, and persistent demands from cautious public health officials for more and more data on the rate of side effects and how long the immunity might last.
"I've given up trying to predict when it will come out," Dr. Orenstein said. "In 1982 I said it was likely to come out soon. Now I'd say within the next year."
The extraordinary hesitation regarding the vaccine is partly a result of evidence that it is effective only for a limited time. A widespread vaccination program could cause a reduction in the number of cases of chicken pox in children, but an increase later in adults.
Although the total number of cases would be far lower, the number of deaths and hospitalizations might well rise. That is because chicken pox is a far more serious disease in adults, lasting many weeks and frequently accompanied by complications like pneumonia and, sometimes, inflammation of the brain.
 
Dormant Herpes a Concern
 
 
Some doctors have also expressed concern that the active ingredient of the chicken pox vaccine is a live, though weakened, varicella zoster virus. This virus belongs to the herpes virus family, a group of viruses notorious for their ability to outwit the human immune system and persist in the body for life.
These viruses often lie dormant in the nerves or lymphatic system, but occasionally re-emerge, producing disease flare-ups. Reactivation of herpes simplex virus produces recurrent oral or genital herpes. Reactivation of the latent varicella virus in people who have had chicken pox produces a painful blistering rash called shingles or herpes zoster; shingles most often occurs in the elderly or in people whose immune systems are weakened, generally many decades after chicken pox has disappeared.
 
Dangers of Miscalculation
 Could doctors in good conscience inject patients with a virus that would infect them forever? Would this mutant strain of the chicken pox virus be more likely to result in shingles many years later? A miscalculation would be unfortunate, since shingles is far more painful and heals far less well than chicken pox in children.
New research has alleviated some of the worries: Studies in children successfully treated for leukemia, who are prone to shingles, have suggested that the vaccine virus is less likely to produce shingles than the true chicken pox germ. But the answers to other questions, like how long protection will last, are not likely to be forthcoming.
"Some things can't be answered in a trial," Dr. Brunnell said. "You're just going to have to license the vaccine and see what happens. All the information you're ever going to have you have in hand."
Research in Japan has shown that children who are vaccinated retain immunity for at least 10 years. But it has also shown that while 97 percent of children develop protection from chicken pox after one immunization, only 75 percent of adolescents are similarly protected. Many experts say that adolescents and adults will probably need two shots.
The Centers for Disease Control recently commissioned a cost-effectiveness study to try to weigh these many variables. The results, which were presented last month, showed that for every dollar spent on chicken pox vaccine, society could expect to reap only 94 cents in medical benefits.
But the analysis changed strikingly if the indirect costs of chicken pox, like a parent's lost wages, were figured in. With such indirect costs included, the study found that society got $5.50 in benefits for every $1 spent on vaccine.
The benefit cost ratio for the combination measles-mumps-rubella vaccine is $3 for each dollar spent when only direct medical costs are included, and $14.40 per dollar spent when indirect costs are added in, according to Dr. Sandra Holmes, a medical epidemiologist at the Centers for Disease Control. The ratio for the hemophilus B vaccine is $2.40 for every dollar spent for direct medical costs and $2.80 with indirect costs added.
For research purposes, the centers assumed that the vaccine would cost $35 for a single dose, although no one is sure how Merck would price it, and many vaccines have cost more than predicted when they actually reached the market.
 
Easier Way to Cut Costs
 Some experts, like Dr. Brunnell, have suggested that there is an easier way than vaccinating to reduce the cost of chicken pox to society: by simply reducing the number of days children are kept home when they have the disease. Many schools do not allow children to return until the last of their lesions has crusted over, in the mistaken belief that the child is contagious up to that point. But the disease is most contagious before the rash appears. Most children feel well enough to return to class far earlier, Dr. Brunnell said.
"If the parent's lost work is the problem, then maybe we should send children back to school sooner," he said.
Anticipating that the drug agency may well approve the vaccine this time around, the Centers for Disease Control recently asked its vaccine advisory panel to determine how it should be used.
"From what I know right now, if it were my kid, I think I'd rather he get the vaccine than chicken pox," Dr. Orenstein said. "My 10-year-old had a very mild case, and I thought, what's the big deal? But when my 5-year-old got it, the child was very uncomfortable and we were up for several nights. It's that kind of problem that the vaccine would eliminate rather than serious disease."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Anne A. Gershon of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons says a chicken pox vaccine is worthwhile. Dr. Walter Orenstein, from Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, says there is a controversy over whether the disease is worth preventing. (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times) (pg. C11)

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED AT TRADE PARLEY

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, July 7

 BODY:
Trade ministers for the leading industrial nations said today that they have reached a crucial tariff reduction agreement that they said will likely lead to a revival of stalled global trade talks.
"We have concluded our deliberations successfully," Kabun Muto, Japan's Foreign Minister, said upon emerging from a meeting of trade officials of the United States, Canada, Japan and the European Community. "We believe it will result in substantial progress." 
 Details to were not immediately available, so it still remains to be seen just how far-reaching their agreement is. One of the major questions, for instance, is whether the United States agreed to reduce protection for the American textile and clothing industries sufficiently to satisfy the European Community.
But if the talks were indeed a "breakthrough," as some officials suggested, it could become one of the most significant accomplishments of the Group of Seven summit of industrial nations, which begins today. It would also be a surprising outcome, given how far apart the parties were just a day ago.
An agreement by the major trading companies to eliminate or reduce tariffs on hundreds of items is expected to serve as the basis for the resumption of worldwide trade negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Failure Could End GATT
 But failure to reach an agreement here, or the attainment of only a limited accord, could sound the death knell for GATT's seven-year-old Uruguay round, which aims to extend free trade rules to agriculture, textiles and services.
"Tokyo is the acid test," Peter Sutherland, the new director-general of GATT, said last week.
Asked today whether the new agreement would be significant enough to jump start the Uruguay round, one American official said, "I don't think there is any question it will."
Before the meeting of the trade ministers began last night, the four governments were so far apart that it seemed that any agreement would be somewhat limited. "There's some movement by everybody but, unless a miracle occurs, not enough to get a detailed agreement," said one participant, who insisted on remaining unidentified.
 
Quit at 3 A.M., Resume at 10
 But the trade representatives met until 3 a.m., far later than expected, and apparently made progress in narrowing the differences. "It's not yet completely agreed, but we can see the prospect of something coming up that 24 hours ago looked unlikely," one European official said early this morning. The trade ministers then met again from 10 a.m. to 12:30 to hammer out the final details.
With much of the developed world in recession, scholars and government officials are beginning to question whether GATT, or the principles of free trade in general, have outlived their usefulness.
The leaders of France in particular have said that developed nations need to be protected from competition with lesser developed nations that pay low wages and pollute the environment. Angry at the United States over duties it is placing on foreign steel imports, French leaders have openly said that no market access agreement should be reached in Tokyo.
This French position has hampered the ability of the European Community to make concessions in the market access talks, according to one American official.
At each of the last three summit meetings, the Group of Seven has resolved to complete the Uruguay round by the end of the year, always to no avail.
This time, there is a recognition that action, not merely words, are necessary. Officials have been saying for months that only a far-reaching agreement by the major powers to cut tariffs would coax the remaining 100 or so members of GATT back to the negotiating table by December to try to conclude the Uruguay round, named after the location of the first talks in 1986.
 
Setback in Tokyo Meeting
 But hopes for such a broad accord seemed all but dashed two weeks ago after the trade ministers had a particularly rancorous meeting in Tokyo. The Europeans said the United States was not going far enough to reduce tariffs on textiles and clothing. The United States complained about Europe's high tariffs on semiconductors and about its limits on the broadcasting of foreign television programs, ostensibly to preserve Europe's cultural independence.
It was after that stormy meeting that the ministers decided to schedule last night's emergency session in a last-ditch attempt to get an agreement before the summit.
Going into last night's meeting, the four governments were still apart on many areas, officials said. The United States had not amended its offer on textile tariff cuts and Europe had not made major new concessions on electronics tariffs and television programs, this official said. Japan, meanwhile, was not offering to cut trade restrictions on wood products and distilled spirits enough to satisfy its trading partners.
However, agreements had basically been reached among the nations to eliminate tariffs on pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, construction equipment and beer.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN TOKYO;
Excerpts From Clinton Talk in Tokyo

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, July 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from today's speech by President Clinton before the opening of the summit meeting of the leaders of the world's major industrial democracies.
Our first international economic priority must be to create a new and stronger partnership between the United States and Japan. Our relationship with Japan is the centerpiece of our policy toward the Pacific community. 
 Our two nations account for nearly 40 percent of the world's output. Neither of us could thrive without the other. Producers in each of our countries are consumers for firms in the other.
 
Solving Global Problems
 We are also joined in our efforts to address global economic problems. We have worked closely in an effort to move toward a new trade agreement.
And I hope Japan will join in the initiative I proposed just two days ago in San Francisco -- a meeting of the senior G-7 economics and labor and education advisers to look into a new problem with the global economy: stubbornly persistent unemployment in the richest nations of the world, even where there is economic growth, rooted in the inability of so many of these nations to create new jobs.
The economic relationship we have has always benefited both our nations. Americans buy huge volumes of Japanese products. American companies in Japan employ thousands of your citizens.

 	 	 		. . .	 	In the 1980's, when my country went on a huge debt binge, massively increasing public and private debt, Japanese purchases of much of that debt helped to keep our economy going and helped to prevent our interest rates from exploding. Still, our economic relationship is not in balance.
Unlike our relations with all other wealthy nations, we have a huge and persistent trade deficit with Japan. It usually exceeds $40 billion, with the deficit in manufacturing products in excess of $60 billion, in spite of the fact that in recent years our manufacturing productivity has increased very greatly.
It is impossible to attribute this trade imbalance solely to unfair Japanese barriers from governmental policies, to a unique distribution center system. Indeed, it is in part simply a tribute to Japanese abilities to produce high-quality, competitively priced goods, and to the skill of Japanese businesses in piercing so many overseas markets -- including our own.
 
Markets Are More Open
 Yet, it is clear that our markets are more open to your products and your investments than yours are to ours. And it is clear that governmental policies consistently promoting production over consumption, exports over domestic sales, and protections of the home market, contribute to this problem.
The trade deficit is on the rise this year, even with the market rise of the yen against the dollar. Though American purchases of Japanese products have remained fairly constant, Japanese purchases of American products have dropped markedly as a consequence of slow growth here in your economy with no offsetting government policies to stimulate demand.
This problem has, as all of you know, fueled resentment in our country, both from workers and from businesses who have worked hard to streamline their operations, reduce labor costs and increase productivity and now want the benefits that can only come from being able to compete and win in a global economy.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Harm to Japanese People
 This persistent trade imbalance does not just hurt American workers and businesses, it has hurt the Japanese people. It has deprived you, as consumers, of the full benefit of your hard and productive work.
For example, partly because of restrictive economic policies, the average Japanese family pays more than twice as much of your income for food as the average American family. And many other consumer products are far, far more expensive here than elsewhere, with these differentials going far beyond what can be accounted for by the transportation costs of bringing products to this market.
Our relationships with Japan have been durable, not only because of our security alliance and our political partnership, but because our economic relationship has actually served our interests and yours. I believe we must change this economic interest to improve the lives not just of the American people, but of the Japanese people as well.
It would be wrong for me to come here as President to ask you to embrace changes that would only benefit the people who live in my country. I believe that the changes I advocate will benefit both of us, or I would not be here pushing them.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
Principles for Trade
 Our governments have made progress in these last few days in crafting the basic principles of this new framework. And we will persist until we can produce a sound agreement that is in the interests of people in both countries.
What the United States seeks -- let me make clear -- is not managed trade, or so-called trade by the numbers, but better results from better rules of trade.
Openness like this cannot simply come from pressure from the United States. That is one reason I wanted so much to be here with you today. A new openness can only come, ultimately, when Japanese leaders and Japanese citizens recognize that it is in your interests to pursue this course.
So, today I would send this message to all of you and to the people beyond the walls here in this hall; you have a common cause with the people of America, a common cause against outdated practices that undermine our relationship and diminish the quality of your lives.
The ideas I propose are beneficial to both of us because they will increase the number and lower the cost of the products you are able to buy, the services you are able to access, and they will thereby reward the work, the education, and the skills that you bring to daily life here in Japan. You are entitled to no less.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We should take these steps together for ourselves and for future generations. I am optimistic that the people of Japan and the people of the United States can hear the same message and move toward the same goal.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
President Clinton pressed for trade concessions with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, but also began building relationships with the political renegades trying to overthrow Mr. Miyazawa and his party. [Page A1.]
The resurgent yen has angered Japan's exporters about as much as it has pleased the Clinton Administration. But some American executives and trade experts are warning that the strong-yen policy could backfire by making it too expensive for non-Japanese businesses to build operations in Japan. [D1.] 
 The United States agreed to provide Russia with at least $2 billion in loans and loan guarantees to halt a steep plunge in oil and gas production in that nation. [A8.]
 
The Economy
Many economists are not concerned about inflation, but a surprising number do worry -- including those who think that the growth of the nation's money supply presages a rise in prices. [D1.]
