HEADLINE: Rising Yen Might Widen This Gap

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration sees the recent strengthening of the Japanese yen against the dollar as one means of reducing Japan's monumental trade surpluses. But as the leaders of the seven leading industrial nations gather here this week, some American business executives and trade experts are warning that a strong-yen policy could backfire.
Yes, they say, a strong yen will make American goods less expensive relative to Japanese products and thus more competitive. But the strong yen -- the dollar has fallen more than 13 percent against the Japanese currency since the beginning of the year to a current level of 108.83 yen -- is also making it prohibitively expensive for some foreign businesses to build their own factories, distribution networks and marketing operations in Japan.
 
Conflicting Currents
 And such direct investment into Japan, American trade experts say, is critical to achieving sustained success in this notoriously difficult market. 
 But because of the strong yen, it now takes more dollars to buy companies, rent offices, hire employees, advertise or build plants in Japan.
"You've got to control your own destiny in this market if you want to really penetrate it," said Thomas A. Lynch, a partner with KPMG Peat Marwick, the international consulting and accounting firm. "That's why direct investment really matters."
The logic behind this emphasis on investment, rather than simply on placing more foreign-made goods in Japanese stores, is simple: exports follow investment. Trade experts say they have found a striking correlation between investment and exports.
"Overwhelmingly, U.S. exports of manufactured goods go to countries where there is substantial U.S. direct investment presence," Edward Graham, a trade expert at the Institute for International Economics, wrote in a paper presented at a Yale seminar.
The issue covers direct spending on business operations, like acquisitions, plant construction and investments in other operations. Such spending is distinguished from portfolio investments, like buying of securities or other such financial transactions.
Japan is expected to post a record $160 billion trade surplus this year, about $50 billion of which will be with the United States. But there is an imbalance in Japan's relations with the world that is even more lopsided than the trade imbalance: Japanese companies are among the largest foreign investors in the world, but Japan gets less business investment from foreign companies than any other industrialized country.
Direct investment from the United States in Japan, America's second-largest trading partner after Canada, is less than American business investment in Brazil.
In the last 10 years, for example, Japan made $325 billion in business investments abroad, a little more than 40 percent of which went to the United States. But foreign companies, facing stratospheric costs and informal barriers, if not outright hostility, have been able to invest a relatively minuscule $22 billion into business operations in Japan in the same period. American companies supplied about 40 percent of that sum.
At one time, the Japanese Government rejected assertions that it had stifled investment, but the evidence is so overwhelming now that it has begun several programs to entice foreign investment. Government-controlled institutions are offering low-cost loans and extensive information to help foreign companies.
"We are very aware of this imbalance, and we are very keen to improve the situation," said Makoto Nomura, a director in the industrial policy bureau at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Foreign business executives here say that the measures do not come close to breaking down the long list of barriers they confront, but they say the steps do help and may, over time, help change the hostile attitudes.
In America, for instance, Honda both makes cars and sells them to dealers through its own American marketing and distribution subsidiary. But General Motors has no production operations here and sells autos through Japanese importers.
 
A Shift of Emphasis
 The huge imbalance between outgoing and incoming investment has prompted some experts to focus on opening Japan to investment as a more promising approach to reducing Japan's huge surpluses than the traditional focus on getting Japan to buy more American goods.
That is why the yen's surge is seen as a double-edged sword. A strong yen does make Japanese goods more costly for Americans, pinching Japanese exports, while making American exports to Japan less expensive and thus more attractive. That is the macroeconomic impact.
But on the microeconomic level, where business executives make their daily decisions, the strong yen creates yet another hurdle for those struggling to penetrate Japanese markets. Some American Government economists argue that when costs in Japan rise in dollar terms, the yields on investments rise as well, making the investments attractive. Executives reply, though, that as the hurdle to entry rises they are discouraged from accepting the risks.
In the debate over how to nudge Japan to lower its trade surplus, the old approach of focusing largely on the movement of goods ignores the fact, experts argue, that most international trade takes place not just between countries but between multinational companies and their overseas subsidiaries. The freer these companies are to establish overseas units to produce, market and distribute their goods, the argument goes, the greater the volume of trade.
 
Trade Within Companies
 In his book "Rivals Beyond Trade," published by Cornell University Press, Dennis J. Encarnation of the Harvard Business School writes that the overseas sales of American multinational companies through overseas units are nearly three times the level of total American exports because overseas units buy and sell goods with third countries as well.
The underlying point is that these investments, not just low tariffs and open markets, are the engine for sales in foreign markets.
Even in Japan, experience has shown that trade does expand with investment. A recent study by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry found that affiliates of foreign concerns in Japan account for less than 5 percent of Japan's exports but about 17 percent of its imports.
As a result, in the fiscal year ended March 31, 1992, these affiliates imported $3.5 billion more goods into Japan than they exported. In other words, they did precisely what American trade negotiators have been trying to achieve, they whittled down Japan's huge surplus.
Japanese companies, from Toyota to Sony, have followed this strategy with notable success in America -- investing huge sums so that they operate through companies they control. The Sumitomo Corporation, for instance, sells about 80 to 90 percent of the goods it exports -- from steel plates to computerized industrial machinery -- to its own overseas subsidiaries, said Hiroo Kinoshita, an executive managing director.
 
Contrast With Europe
 This is the approach American multinational companies have used to build a significant presence in Europe, where the United States has a trade surplus. The only major market where the approach has proved nearly impossible is Japan.
In contrast to Japan, the United States gets business investment from abroad in almost equal proportions to the amount that American companies invest overseas.
The investment issue has been raised before by American negotiators, but the Clinton Administration has promised a greater focus on it.
Corporate Japan agrees that steps should be taken to encourage direct investment. "Japan has considerably more regulations on business than most other countries, and this undoubtedly obstructs the entry of new companies, both domestic and foreign, into the market," Keidanren, a group representing Japan's largest corporations, said in a study last year. "We take the view that in certain areas such as corporate finance, taxation, etc., foreign firms must be accorded preferential treatment."
The report also concedes that the keiretsu, groupings of companies bound together through cross-shareholdings, can obstruct incoming investment and that unwritten guidance from Government officials and other informal regulation discriminate against foreign companies.
Even when foreign companies do make a sincere effort to break into Japan by looking for an acquisition, the results have been poor.
"The opportunities we see are often ones Japanese companies aren't interested in," said Mr. Lynch of KPMG Peat Marwick. "I've never seen anything approximating an open auction for a company in Japan."
What is particularly frustrating for some is that the collapse of Japanese stock prices in the last three years and the decline in property prices was expected to help change that. Acquisitions were expected to be easier and more common -- at least until the dollar weakened against the yen. The figures on acquisitions, however, remain paltry and appear likely to decline this year from the modest total of $614.4 million last year, according to Ulmer Brothers, a New York investment bank.
"We thought a window was opening up," said Yoshinori Yokoyama, a partner in charge of the Japan office of McKinsey & Company, the big consulting company. "We tried to convince our partners in our other offices around the world to raise the opportunities with their clients on investing in Japan. But companies are quite cautious still. The costs are a problem that have just gotten worse."

HEADLINE: Costly School Overhaul for Massachusetts

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 6

 BODY:
All three branches of government are in rare agreement about the state of public education in Massachusetts: inadequate. But there is no unanimity on where to find the money to fix it.
Last month the state's highest court became the 12th in the nation to order lawmakers to devise a plan to close the financial gap between the wealthiest and poorest school systems. In the same week, Gov. William F. Weld, a Republican, signed a $1.3 billion measure adopted by the Democratic-controlled Legislature to raise spending in the poorer districts to $5,550 per student by the year 2000. 
 "The reform act moves in the direction the court has pointed us," said Robert Blumenthal, a counsel at the Massachusetts Department of Education. "They dovetail: the opinion calls for greater equity and the reform act aims at greater equity."
Some wealthy communities spend nearly three times what poorer communities do on each public school child. Lincoln, a wealthy suburb of Boston, spent $9,567 per pupil in the 1990-1991 school year; Douglas, a working-class community on the Connecticut border, spent $3,251.
But with state and local governments squeezed by recession and by widespread sentiment against higher taxes, it is not at all clear where they will find the money to close this gap. The measure just signed by Mr. Weld commits a relatively modest amount of state money, $175 million, for the fiscal year that began July 1.
The Supreme Judicial Court's decision did not specify a fund-raising mechanism. It did join a handful of other state courts around the nation in ruling that the State Constitution required that the public schools provide all children with seven specific skills -- from arts appreciation to solid writing and oral communication skills.
All state constitutions have education clauses that describe state responsibility for public education. The Massachusetts Constitution has had the same language since 1780: "It shall be the duty of legislatures and magistrates [and] the executive branch, in all future periods of this commonwealth, to cherish . . . the public schools and grammar schools in the towns."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Speculation on Fed Action Pushes the Dollar Upward

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday on expectations that United States inflation is picking up, a situation that could prompt a move by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
The Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, is concluding a two-day meeting in Washington today. Rumors arose that the Fed might tighten credit quickly to stamp out inflation, despite recent weak economic data. 
 Currency dealers said this year's rally in gold prices had heightened inflationary fears. And adding to concerns about inflation was another sharp gain in the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodity prices.
"The fact that we are seeing broad participation in this advance from most commodity arenas confirms that inflation has returned," said David Lundgren, president of Lundgren Financial Services.
Dealers said evidence suggesting German inflation might be easing led to speculation that the German central bank could cut rates again soon. "Dealers are now focusing on the next Bundesbank easing, which most expect to happen before the bank's summer break in August," said Chuck Spence of Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles.
In London, the dollar closed at 1.7000 marks, up from 1.6980 marks Monday. The dollar closed at 1.7040 marks in New York, up from 1.6978 at Friday's close. The United States markets were closed Monday for the Fourth of July holiday.
The dollar finished at 108.83 yen in New York, up from 108.55 yen Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar finished at 109.08 yen, up slightly from 109.05 yen Monday.
The British pound settled at $1.5040 in New York, down from $1.5095 Friday. Earlier in London, the pound fell to $1.5063, from $1.5110 Monday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Friday's quotes, included: 1.5130 Swiss francs, up from 1.5120; 5.7630 French francs, up from 5.7383.

HEADLINE: Drug Industry Musters a Coalition To Oppose a Change in Medicaid

SERIES: Special Pleaders -- A periodic look at lobbying.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
It looked like a consumer organization, and it seemed to spring up spontaneously to fight a provision of the pending budget bill that it said would condemn poor people to inferior medical care.
The group, calling itself the Coalition for Equal Access to Medicines, is an unusual union of poor people, minority members and public health advocates, but it did not come together effortlessly. It was created and financed by another interest group, one with perhaps the biggest stake in the outcome: the prescription drug industry. 
 Members of Congress who follow drug issues said they were unaware of the industry's involvement in the coalition, which describes itself as "an ad hoc volunteer organization."
 
Its Reason for Being
 Public statements of the coalition, like its letters to Congress and the White House, give no clue to its origins. But its purpose is clear: to defeat a measure the Federal Government believes would help control Medicaid spending on prescription drugs.
The drug executive who inspired the coalition acknowledged in an interview that one reason the group was formed was the industry's belief that consumer advocates and minority members had far more credibility on Capitol Hill than drug companies.
President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have accused the drug industry of charging excessive prices, and they warn that it will have to make financial sacrifices under the health plan the White House expects to propose this fall.
 
'An Obvious Self-Interest'
 The drug executive, Richard D. Stone, vice president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, the main trade group for prescription drug companies, said, "We don't want this to be looked at as a drug-industry issue alone because we have an obvious self-interest."
He said his association had organized the coalition with the help of a Washington lobbying firm, Apco Associates. "We hired Apco Associates in May to help us generally with public relations and coalition-building," he said. "We told them to service this coalition, to staff it and to help them."
The "organizing committee" of the coalition includes officials from the National Depressive and Manic Depressive Association, the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, the Lupus Foundation of America, the National Urban League, the National Council on the Aging, a Hispanic doctors' group in California and the Rev. Jesse Jackson's group, the National Rainbow Coalition.
Coalition members say they do not think they have been exploited. They say the cause is a good one: to insure that low-income people in the Medicaid program are not denied access to medicine crucial to their health.
 
Aimed at Approved Drugs
 The group's aim is to kill provisions of the deficit-reduction bill that would encourage states to establish lists of approved Medicaid drugs. If a drug was not on the list, called a formulary, Medicaid would generally not pay for it.
Medicaid, a joint Federal-state program, spends more than $6.7 billion a year on drugs prescribed for people outside hospitals. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that formularies would save the Federal Government at least $275 million over five years. States expect to save almost as much.
Mr. Stone calls the numbers "phony baloney."
The President proposed such formularies as part of his budget request to Congress in February. Formularies have been used by hospitals for more than a century. In theory, experts select the best, most effective drugs and exclude those that offer no significant therapeutic advantage.
Drug companies typically offer big discounts to get products listed on formularies. Under the Medicaid legislation, states could exclude an expensive brand-name product while covering similar, less costly brand-name drugs or generic versions of the same drug.
 
Inferior Health Care Charged
 Critics like Mr. Stone say formularies condemn poor people to inferior health care and do not save money in the long run because people denied appropriate drugs make greater use of hospitals, nursing homes and other costly services.
Most big hospitals and health maintenance organizations have formularies. But drug manufacturers fiercely oppose Medicaid formularies. They say state officials will select drugs on the basis of cost, not quality, and fear that Medicaid formularies will set a precedent for similar restrictions under any national health insurance plan that Congress might enact.
Referring to the industry's role in opposing formularies, Mr. Stone said: "We feel good about it. We think we are doing the right thing for patients."
Apco employees refused to discuss their work for the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association. "We don't discuss our relationship with clients or what we do for them," said Dan DuPont, a senior associate of the firm.
But Mary Fraker, an Apco employee, insisted in a letter written on behalf of the coalition that the group was an authentic "grass-roots movement." She maintained that the provisions of the budget bill allowing restrictive formularies "would have a devastating effect on the nation's 30 million Medicaid patients."
 
Overlapping Interests
 Apco Associates was formed in 1984 as a consulting arm of Arnold & Porter, a law firm. It was acquired in 1991 by the GCI Group, the public relations division of Grey Advertising Inc. of New York.
Drug companies and coalition members do seem to have overlapping interests. The drug industry has highlighted the shared interests by supplying the coalition with information and advice, including scientific studies and data to show what it considers to be the dangers of formularies.
The organizing committee of the coalition includes Charles B. Inlander, president of the People's Medical Society, a consumer group with 85,000 members. He said he had learned of the coalition from an employee of the Upjohn Company, the drug manufacturer.
"In the world of health care, politics makes strange bedfellows," Mr. Inlander said. "We don't take money from drug companies, and we have criticized the pharmaceutical industry, but we are not averse to joining anybody in a coalition."
Mr. Inlander said he feared that doctors would be less willing to take Medicaid patients if the doctors' authority to prescribe drugs was restricted by formularies.
 
Different Reactions to Drugs
 In the battle over formularies, drug companies say minority members have particular reason to be concerned. Mr. Stone, the vice president of the drug manufacturers group, said that black, white and Hispanic people respond differently to certain drugs.
For example, he said, antidepressants have greater side effects when prescribed for Hispanic patients than for non-Hispanic white patients. Likewise, drug researchers say blacks are less responsive than whites to beta blocker drugs, prescribed for treatment of high blood pressure.
The coalition has enlisted black clergymen in its campaign. A letter to Mrs. Clinton, signed by seven clergymen, says that if she supports Medicaid formularies she is violating her "moral obligation to protect God's little ones -- the vulnerable young, seniors, women, the disabled and the poor."
Both the House and the Senate have voted to allow Medicaid formularies, so the idea is likely to be included in the deficit-reduction bill that emerges from a conference committee. The committee will begin drafting a compromise bill later this month. The drug industry and the coalition plan to lobby members of the committee.
 
New Drugs Face Delay
 In theory, a formulary includes the most useful and effective drugs in each therapeutic category, including painkillers, antibiotics, antidepressants, tranquilizers, ulcer drugs and asthma drugs. But doctors and drug executives say it may take months or even years to get new drugs added to the list.
The organizing committee of the coalition includes Dr. Daniel Thursz, president of the National Council on the Aging; Nancy Sander, president of the Allergy and Asthma Network, and Dr. Richard O. Butcher, president of the National Medical Association, which represents black doctors.
"We see formularies as a type of rationing," Dr. Thursz said. "It may eventually be part of a universal health plan, but it should not apply just to the lowest economic class in our society."

LENGTH: 733 words

HEADLINE: Jersey City Lures 3 Tenants To Waterfront Development

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, July 6

 BODY:
In a display of competitiveness that was both economic and political, New Jersey officials said today that they had lured three new tenants and almost 400 jobs from New York City to a sparsely occupied office development on the Hudson River waterfront here.
The announcement continued a pattern of interstate rivalry for jobs that intensified last fall, when the First Chicago Corporation agreed to move 1,000 employees from lower Manhattan to Newport Tower, a 36-story building with a breathtaking view of the World Trade Center towers. 
 Dismissing the notion that New Jersey and New York were engaged in a jobs battle, Gov. Jim Florio, sounding very much the candidate he is, extolled the state's transportation and telecommunications networks and relatively low energy costs as factors that draw businesses.
"These firms didn't come here by accident," he said. "They were very aware of their own bottom line."
 
Investment From State
 Last fall, when First Chicago announced its move here, New York City development officials were angered and disheartened by New Jersey's approach at Newport Towers, which opened in 1989 but was only 37 percent occupied late last year.
At that point, New Jersey invested almost $7 million in the building, in return for a stake of about 8 percent. The money allowed the building's owners to offer tenants a variety of high-technology amenities for computer wiring and other interior office construction at no cost. Occupancy is now up to 43 percent.
Representatives for each of the new tenants -- the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Solar International Shipping Agency and Legent Corporation -- said yesterday that they felt that they could get more for less by moving to Jersey City and that they had not sought counteroffers from New York City.
Neither Solar nor Legent approached New York City to discuss moving, said Ana Marengo, a spokeswoman for Mayor David N. Dinkins.
"We're disappointed that they never approached us with their needs," Ms. Marengo said. "We obviously value every single job. New York is the world capital of commerce, and it's too bad that they're willing to stand by on the sidelines."
She said the city had been aware of the F.D.I.C.'s interest in moving since May 1992, but she said she did not know the extent of any discussions.
 
And Now a Few Words . . .
 In a brief address to a small gathering of development officials at the marina near the office tower, Governor Florio lapsed into what sounded like a stump speech on his record over the last three and a half years. Speaking of the devastating effects the economy has had on the job market in New Jersey, Mr. Florio, a Democrat, blamed the Reagan and Bush Administrations, saying, "You can't bounce back instantly from a recession that is this deep."
Never once mentioning his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, the Governor nonetheless provided a spirited defense of his record and of the state's virtues, of his own come-from-behind qualities and of his administration's "vision" to "divine and define the future."
Citing the most recent jobless rate (6.9 percent last month), the Governor talked of the hard work and tenacity that goes into creating jobs. "That's what the last three years have been about -- tenacity," he said.
Standing with him at the lectern was the newly elected Mayor of Jersey City, Bret Schundler, whose Republican administration is the first since 1917 in this city and the object of affection by senior politicians of both major parties.
The Governor clearly enjoyed using the power of his office to bring "a little gift for the Mayor," who responded with similar praise for New Jersey's competitive stance.
The F.D.I.C. may relocate up to 200 employees from Manhattan. Solar, a ship brokerage, will move its entire staff of 80 from Manhattan to Newport Towers. Legent, a computer software company based in Vienna, Va., will move the 90 members of its development staff here; the 25 members of its sales staff will remain in Manhattan. Legent has 2,100 employees at 75 offices worldwide.
Although the Governor's office announced that the F.D.I.C. would move as many as 300 workers here, Carol Austrian, an agency spokeswoman in Washington, said only 145 people would move from the New York regional headquarters offices on Madison Avenue. She said the agency had authorization to move up to 200.

HEADLINE: Big Three Auto Makers Had 9.9% June Sales Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 6

 BODY:
Sales of the Big Three auto makers rose nearly 10 percent in June as consumers again flocked to domestic models to replace aging cars and light trucks.
General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler kept the industry's spring sales momentum moving in June. According to sales figures released today, the Big Three had a combined sales gain for the month of 9.9 percent, compared with an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent for Japanese auto makers. The figures include cars and trucks the auto makers import for sale in the United States.
 
Domestic Sales in June Up
 Domestic sales in late June were up 6.7 percent, with the Big Three reporting a 7.8 percent increase, compared with a 1.1 percent improvement for Japanese companies that build cars and trucks in the United States. 
 On an annualized basis, cars in late June sold at a 7.7 million rate, their best since late December 1990 and way above mid-June's 6.6 million annualized selling rate. Light trucks sold at an annualized rate of 5.1 million, the same as in mid-June.
Car and light-truck sales have remained strong throughout the spring -- and now into early summer -- despite a decline in consumer confidence and stagnant sales for many general merchandise retailers. Analysts say car owners have taken advantage of lower interest rates to replace millions of cars bought during the mid-1980's.
But car buyers have not been ignoring the economy as they have shopped. Cars advertised as good values are among the most popular.
At the halfway point in the sales year, the best-seller list shows several changes from a year earlier. Most notable is the fall of the Honda Accord. The best-selling car in the United States a year ago, Accord appears poised to fall out of the top 10 among total vehicles and headed for sixth place among passenger cars.
The biggest climber on the list of best sellers was the Chevrolet Cavalier, an 11-year-old subcompact due for a new model in 1995. In contrast with Accord, whose sagging sales were partly attributed to age, Cavalier is succeeding despite an older body style.
Chevrolet is aggressively marketing Cavalier for value. Its under-$8,000 base model includes antilock brakes, which are still an option on many models.
Led by Chevrolet, G.M. is heading into the new model year with a heavy push on value pricing -- offering a set price on a well-equipped model. That can save a buyer hundreds to thousands of dollars over the same car with options purchased separately. It also lowers the factory's cost because it can build more models the same way.
All G.M. car divisions, including Cadillac, will be pushing value pricing this fall, especially in California where G.M.'s market share has suffered over the years from imports.
In June, G.M. car sales were up 1.2 percent and truck sales were up 12.3 percent for an overall gain of 4.9 percent. Its GMC Truck division set a 91-year record with 41,646 sales in the month.
"Not only are we setting month-to-month records, but the entire 1993 model year is shaping up to be a record year for us overall," said Ray Rota, GMC Truck general sales manager.
Ford reported June sales increases of 2.3 percent for cars and 16.8 percent for trucks for a total improvement of 8.8 percent over last June.
Chrysler also continued its stunning sales success compared with 1992. Car sales were up 37.7 percent and trucks were up 20.2 for an overall gain of 26.7 percent. Chrysler topped the one million vehicle sales mark 45 days ahead of last year.
Most of the credit on the passenger car side has gone to Chrysler's new LH midsize sedans, but Chrysler said its top car sellers in June were the older Dodge Shadow, Plymouth Acclaim and Dodge Spirit.

HEADLINE: Pros in the Caddy Shack: Country Club Recession;
An Engineer Learns to Carry Golf Clubs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMUS, N.J., July 6

 BODY:
Until Pentagon budget cuts crippled production of Trident submarines, Tom Kingsley worked as a mechanical engineer at the Groton Naval Base in Connecticut, teaching officers how to operate the nuclear reactors that power the subs. Two years ago his employer, General Dynamics, dismissed him.
Now, at age 29, he is caddying under the majestic oaks at the Ridgewood Country Club here. 
 Mr. Kingsley is not the only refugee from a sour economy carrying golf bags on the lush fairways at Ridgewood, which has a caddy corps of 135, one of the largest in the New York region. Alongside the high school and college students working for pocket money and tuition, and the career caddies who travel to Northern golf courses in the summer and to Southern golf courses in the winter, there are about 15 other well-educated and well-trained professionals or craftsmen, including an accountant, a lawyer, a chef, a truck driver, an electrician and a couple of salesmen.
Between caddying rounds at one of the premiere golf courses in the Northeast, they pore over classified job ads, read self-help books, reorganize resumes, grumble about the economy and, in some cases, struggle with their pride.
Mr. Kingsley says his most unsettling caddying jobs are for players in his age bracket, the late 20's or early 30's.
"They got one break or something, and we're carrying their bags," he said as he ate a container of fried brown rice between rounds the other day. "That's where it gets humiliating. We picked the wrong field, and we're in the wrong place at the wrong time. When you're 26 or 27 and making a nice living with a nice apartment and a nice car and moving right along, and all of a sudden you lose a job, it humbles you."
California and Florida, where he looked for jobs for several months, are glutted with unemployed engineers, he said.
"We are not building anything in this country anymore," he said. "We are not designing anything. Everything is coming from overseas. Imports are killing us."
His only professional job offer in recent months came from South Korea. It required a one-year commitment there, and Mr. Kingsley, who is married, is undecided about making it.
Ridgewood's caddy master, Dave Fagerstrom, said the unemployed professionals began trickling in a year or two ago. Some had carried at Ridgewood in their teens. Some came at the suggestion of friends after their unemployment benefits expired.
"The thought of coming here wouldn't occur to but one in 10 guys because most don't know golf or play golf or haven't caddied," Mr. Fagerstrom said. He's quick to note that all caddying jobs are filled now.
Those lucky enough to have caught on speak warmly of Mr. Fagerstrom for giving them steady work yet flexible enough hours to pursue interviews for new jobs. Stories of lives in transition abound in the caddy alcove outside Ridgewood's grand old Tudor-style brick clubhouse.
Ralph DelVecchio, 39, drove trucks, delivering overnight packages, for Purolator Courier until three years ago.
"The fax knocked that overnight letter business right out of business," Mr. DelVecchio said. Now he's honing his caddying skills in the hope of one day landing a regular full-time caddying job on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Tour.
"I'm pursuing what I love," he said. "Obviously I'm not going to make it as a player at age 39. Caddying on the tour is a craft and I'm learning the craft for that level."
Scott Ledlow, a 28-year-old salesman with a new master's degree in business administration, is caddying at Ridgewood again as he did as an undergraduate in the early 1980's. He pursued his master's degree after losing his job in marketing for a company that prepares computerized payroll systems for other companies. Though he has received no offers, he keeps going on interviews.
"Companies seem to feel things are going to be happening," Mr. Ledlow said. "It's just a matter of when."
Mike McSherry, 46, worked as a retail accountant for Stern's for 16 1/2 years before a corporate merger eliminated his supervisory job and the jobs of the company's controller and two assistant controllers a couple of years ago. A Ridgewood member who is the chief financial officer of a brokerage house recently offered Mr. McSherry a $25,000-a-year entry-level job in Manhattan. He said no.
"I couldn't see the commute," he said. "I'll probably kick myself."
 
'It's a Great Workout'
 Mr. McSherry wants to return to supervisory accounting work. "But companies can be very selective," he said. "I don't have a master's degree. I'm not certified. I'm competing against all these guys."
Stiff competition in the job market is also on Michael Petta's mind. He is a 28-year-old lawyer trying for a job with a small-to-medium-size law firm specializing in defending doctors against malpractice suits.
"The Catch-22 is they want experience," Mr. Petta said. "Trying to get started with no medical experience is challenging. You have to show you're willing to learn medical issues."
For now, caddying is fine for Mr. Petta. "I think it's an excellent, if not the ultimate, in-between job," he said. "It's a great workout for your legs, you're walking miles and miles in fresh air and sunshine."
The pay is not all that bad. Those willing to work long and hard can earn anywhere from $450 to $600 a week, straight cash.
Caddies receive from $25 to $40, depending on tip, for carrying one bag for 18 holes. Most routinely carry doubles, or two bags, on each 18-hole round. The best money comes from carrying doubles for 18 holes in the morning and then for 18 more holes for other golfers in the afternoon.
Drawbacks exist. The job provides no medical benefits, Social Security deductions or paid vacations. Rainy days are slow.
But the caddies do get to play Ridgewood free each Monday. And sometimes they are invited to other courses to play. Mr. Kingsley, the engineer, who usually shoots in the low 80's, went to the neighboring Arcola Country Club on a recent Monday. He took a caddy for the day.
"Boy, what a nice game when you have somebody carrying your bag for you," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Agency Plots Future After Account Loss

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Martin, Davis, Omon & Partners, which opened as Omon New York Ltd. in 1989, is pondering its future after the loss of its large Toyota corporate advertising account.
Joanne M. Davis, the president of the agency, disputed a report this week in the newsletter The Delaney Report that the agency had gone out of business. She said yesterday that its future was being evaluated, adding that billings, once as high as $25 million, had dropped below $5 million and the number of employees, once as high as 19, was now "a handful." 
 The Delaney Report estimated the Toyota account billings at $5 million to $10 million. Jim Olson, a spokesman for Toyota Motor Corporate Services of North America, said the account was moved last month to a new shop in New York opened by two former employees of Martin, Davis, Omon.

HEADLINE: Divided on Inflation;
Few Signs of Price Pressures, but Anxiety Among Economists Refuses to Go Away

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Blue-chip corporations from Sears to I.B.M. are sending out pink slips by the sackful, leaving millions of qualified workers sifting the want ads for employment. Whole industries, from airlines to cigarettes to computers, are hemorrhaging cash in a struggle to attract price-conscious consumers. Why, then, are economists worried about inflation?
One answer is that many are not. "You are looking at a global economy with lots of excess capacity," said Van Doorn Ooms, the director of research at the Committee for Economic Development. "It's difficult to see inflation on the horizon." 
 But a surprising number of economists, representing a variety of schools of thought, do have an inflation itch that they cannot scratch. And yesterday, many investors joined them as an index of commodity prices surged, rekindling inflation fears. [Page D16.]
These on-again, off-again anxieties are reflected by the Federal Reserve, whose divided governors are apparently hoping that tough anti-inflationary talk will obviate the need for action. Indeed, it is hard to remember a time when so many economists are of two minds on so basic an issue.
Start with the case for what is probably the majority view: that, for the moment, inflation is not a serious concern. Rising prices are a byproduct of scarcity, of too much demand chasing too little supply. This hardly fits the current market for labor: With 7 percent unemployment and this year's high school and college graduates scrambling for jobs, there is no discernible upward pressure on wages.
Nor, for that matter, is scarcity a problem in production. While a handful of prominent industries -- notably steel and lumber -- are operating near capacity, most are not. In fact, chronic overcapacity plagues businesses ranging from airlines to publishing to telecommunications. And even where American companies are beginning to fill their order books, foreign competition generally deters them from raising prices.
True, the rising value of the yen relative to the dollar has made it more expensive for Japanese companies to manufacture for the American market. And the resulting increases in Japanese car prices have been mirrored in higher prices for Detroit's models. But anecdotal evidence of import-driven inflation is misleading.
While computer simulation models do indeed suggest that a 10 percent rise in the exchange value of foreign currencies would increase Americans' overall cost of living by roughly three-tenths of a percent, the impact of the yen's appreciation has been negligible because it has been fully offset by the depreciation of the currencies of America's other trade partners. According to Morgan Guaranty Trust, a dollar actually bought more abroad in April 1993 than it did a year earlier.
In other words, Toyota prices may be going up, but the prices of Mercedes-Benzes and just about everything else imported from the rest of the world are going down. "You'd have to look beyond the computer models" to link price pressures to currency fluctuations, concludes Mark Lasky, a senior economist at DRI Inc. in Lexington, Mass.
That, however, is not the end of the story. Textbook analysis just doesn't seem to apply to current economic conditions. Consider the erratic course of economic growth and price increases in recent months. While the rate of economic growth was a tepid 1 percent in the first quarter of 1993, down sharply from the previous three months, the inflation rate inched up to nearly 4 percent. The inflation figures for April and May were back down to a reassuring 1.7 percent rate, but those who look hard enough can still spot some inflation straws in the wind.
Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, notes that gold prices rose to a two-year high last week and yesterday the Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 leading commodities surged on news of soybean crop damage and gains in other basics. Though there are myriad unrelated reasons why gold has risen, Mr. Yardeni points out that gold has been a reliable leading indicator of general price increases. He suspects that the recessions in Europe and Japan are bottoming out -- and that demand for goods and services will pick up worldwide. "For the first time since 1987," he concludes, "we are facing inflationary pressures."
That suspicion is reinforced by the analysis of Allan Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University and a member in good standing of the "monetarist" school of economics. Monetarists believe that one way or another, prices follow trends in the growth of the supply of money. And while some measures of money have hardly been growing, the ones of greatest significance in Mr. Meltzer's view -- funds available for loans, currency and checking deposits -- are up 10 to 12 percent in the last year. "The Federal Reserve has been pumping out money at a rapid rate," he observes, a rate that presages inflation.
 
Point of Higher Prices?
 Mr. Meltzer's concerns are shared by a prominent economist with little patience with monetarist orthodoxy. Paul Krugman of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology says the economy may be operating closer to full capacity than is generally believed, and thus may be closer to the point where increased demand for goods and services translates into higher prices.
During the 1980's the unemployment rate fell well below 6 percent without stirring pressure for inflationary wage increases. That led many economists to the cheerful conclusion that the "natural" rate of unemployment -- the rate that was consistent with stable prices -- had been permanently reduced.
But Mr. Krugman worries that this experience was a yet-unexplained anomaly, that the minimum noninflationary rate of unemployment is really between 6 and 7 percent. Moreover, this minimum may be going up rather than down, as industries from military contracting to banking shed employees in response to a combination of Government belt-tightening and increased global competition. "We have already seen a modest recovery from a shallow recession," he says. "There may not be a lot of room left for stable growth."
Such reasoning certainly influenced the Clinton Administration to back away from pre-inaugural plans to jolt the economy with temporary tax cuts and spending increases. And Congress, in its new-found enthusiasm for fiscal rectitude, scotched even the symbolic $20 billion stimulus left in the Administration's deficit-reduction package. That left the inflation-policy ball squarely in the Federal Reserve's court.
 
Greenspan's Stand
 Thus far, the Fed has confined its actions to threats. "We need to be especially vigilant not to be mesmerized by the current tranquility of the inflationary environment," Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said in April. And the Fed vice chairman, David Mullins, echoed that view late last month. "If inflation were to become re-established in the minds of the markets, with no timely response from the Fed, that could be damaging to the economy," he said.
Mr. Ooms interprets these warnings as a form of meta-policy, in which the Fed uses the prospect of tighter credit as a substitute for actually raising interest rates. Like nuclear deterrence, the idea is to achieve the goal without resort to force. "It's probably not a bad idea for them to jawbone down expectations," he says.
But Mr. Krugman is skeptical. He sees the Fed's current approach as a compromise between hard-liners who want to push inflation toward zero and more liberal governors who worry that the economic recovery will falter once again if the Fed moves to tighten credit. Such uneasy compromises have a way of coming undone.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American's Drop in Traffic Sends Airline Stocks Lower

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Stocks of several major airlines fell yesterday, apparently on news that American Airlines' traffic dropped 3 percent in June from the 8.9 billion revenue passenger miles flown a year earlier.
Some erosion had been expected, since fare price cuts this summer are not comparable to last year's half-price sale. But analysts say investors seem to have reacted to the failure of either leisure or business traffic to bounce back. 
 The stock of American's parent, AMR, fell $2.625 yesterday, to $61.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where trading volume was almost 1.4 million shares.
"Last Friday, American warned that traffic would come in a little softer than originally forecast," said Kevin Murphy, the airline analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. "But they suggested yields would come in a little better than expected. Consequently, they expressed comfort that their performance would be consistent with general expectations."
Donald J. Carty, American's executive vice president of finance and planning, said yesterday, "While traffic was down somewhat more than our projections, we expect our June revenues to be in line with our earlier expectations."
 
Follow-the-Leader Trading
 Mr. Murphy is projecting earnings of 40 cents for AMR's second quarter, although the consensus is that the carrier will earn 28 cents. Last year, the company lost $166 million for the second quarter.
Delta Air Lines stock fell $1.75 yesterday, to $47.125, and UAL, parent of United Airlines, was off 62.5 cents, to $125.375. Mr. Murphy attributed the declines in Delta and United to follow-the-leader trading. "Investors are all generally seeing there's no significant recovery in demand, domestically or internationally," he said.
The major airlines have been at the mercy of an American economy that had been in recession and even now appears to be improving only slowly, and they are suffering from weak economies in Europe and in Japan. Mr. Murphy also pointed to new upstart United States carriers as well as improved telecommunications -- what he described as an "information highway" -- that have made some business travel unnecessary, or at least optional.
A further sign of the global nature of the problem was provided by the International Air Transport Association, which on the weekend reported that the May worldwide passenger load factor of 64 percent (that is, the percentage of seats filled by paying passengers) was the lowest for any May since 1988. "The early summer season," the association said, "has not brought the hoped-for turnabout in the I.A.T.A. airlines' traffic and capacity trends."
The load factor for United States airlines was only 63 percent in May and 61 percent for the first five months of 1993, but both represented slight gains over the comparable periods last year -- 1.4 percentage points and 1.5 percentage points, respectively.

HEADLINE: Fed Official's Inflation View

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Further progress on reducing the rate of inflation this year is still possible, even though inflation picked up in the first few months, Susan Phillips, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, said today.
"It certainly is still feasible that we could have further progress on reducing inflation as we continue through this year," Ms. Phillips told the National Association of College and University Business Officers. 
 The Fed must insure that a "firming of prices recently doesn't persist," she said.
She does not expect inflation to soar, she said, adding that "the economy is well positioned for a period of sustained, noninflationary growth."
Ms. Phillips and other members of the Fed's Open Market Committee will meet this week to decide the central bank's stance on interest rates for the ensuing six weeks. They will also set long-term monetary policy goals for the remainder of 1993 and decide on tentative goals for 1994.
Many analysts say the Fed is likely to see the economy as strong enough not to need the stimulus of interest rate cuts. At the same time, the Fed is likely to see no need to push interest rates higher to curb inflation.

HEADLINE: France Sees No Recovery

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: PARIS, July 6

 BODY:
There is no sign that the recession France has been mired in since the end of last year is ending, Prime Minister Edouard Balladur said today.
"The French economy is in recession since the autumn of 1992 and there has been no sign of a pickup so far: production, consumption and investment are heading downward," Mr. Balladur told the state-sponsored Economic and Social Council, a group of politicians, industrialists and trade unionists. 
 More than 3.1 million people in France are unemployed, and if no steps are taken, the job situation will deteriorate rapidly by the end of the year, the Prime Minister said.
The extent of the downturn is exceptional, Mr. Balladur added, blaming the recent, steep slump in Germany's economy. He said he hoped the pickup in "Anglo-Saxon" economies -- by which the French usually mean the United States, Britain, Canada and Australia -- would spread to the rest of the industrial countries, including France.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
The Constitution: Is It Organic or Cast in Stone?

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
Main Currents in American Legal Thought
By Bernard Schwartz
660 pages. Carolina Academic Press.
$49.95
In the foreword to "Main Currents in American Thought" in 1930, Vernon L. Parrington wrote, "The point of view from which I have endeavored to evaluate the materials is liberal rather than conservative, Jeffersonian rather than Federalistic." What excited generations of college students was Parrington's notion that the literature of the American people was not purely literary but rather an outgrowth of their environment, ethnic differences and epoch. 
 An even more intense Jeffersonian approach characterizes "Main Currents in American Legal Thought," by Bernard Schwartz, the eminent constitutional scholar. The title of his weighty tome (hundreds of cases are cited, but with notable clarity) quite frankly borrows from Parrington's book. Mr. Schwartz, a biographer of Chief Justice Earl Warren, is a professor of law at the University of Tulsa College of Law. Running through his highly readable history of the evolution of American law during the last two centuries is his unabashed admiration for the judges, lawyers and Presidents who interpreted the Constitution liberally.
 As with Parrington's literary "Main Currents," Mr. Schwartz's legal "Main Currents" presents his narrative through the ideas and works of significant individuals. The result is a procession of the lawyers and jurists -- from John Adams, Alexander Hamilton, Thomas Jefferson and James Madison to Oliver Wendell Holmes, Louis D. Brandeis, Benjamin N. Cardozo and William J. Brennan Jr. -- who looked upon the Constitution as a living document that could serve Americans in their own time.
Mr. Schwartz cites chapter and verse to show that the early jurists and legislators refashioned the common law to promote an agent for change and progress. As chairman of a legislative committee to revise the laws in Virginia, Jefferson plainly sought to adapt the British common law to American conditions. His revision offered an opportunity to destroy the economic base of the planter aristocracy that dominated Virginia life. Jefferson deplored the land laws that concentrated power in the hands of owners of large estates. He wrote that Virginia and the new nation needed an "aristocracy of virtue and talent" rather than an "aristocracy of wealth."
A virtue of "Main Currents in American Legal Thought" is that Mr. Schwartz continually relates judicial opinions to what was happening in the country. In the 19th century, slavery was the great albatross: Southerners like Jefferson and Chief Justice John Marshall may have cursed slavery, but at the same time they lived by it. Marshall's account book shows that he bought slaves at various times and argued in court that slaves were property. It took the Civil War to destroy the peculiar institution and change the Constitution and the court rulings.
Two modern Supreme Court justices come to the forefront in the book: "If Chief Justice Warren's activist jurisprudence set the theme for the midcentury concept of law," the author writes, "it was Justice Brennan who did the same in the latter part of the century." Judge Learned Hand of the Federal Court of Appeals once referred to Justices Warren, Brennan, William O. Douglas and Hugo L. Black as "the Jesus Quartet." Brennan was a student of Felix Frankfurter (later a Supreme Court justice) at Harvard law school. After Brennan joined Chief Justice Warren's activist wing, Frankfurter supposedly said in his anecdotage, "I always encourage my students to think for themselves, but Brennan goes too far!"
The outstanding feature of Justice Brennan's view of the Constitution, the author writes, is its plastic nature. In a 1983 opinion involving the First Amendment phrase against the establishment of religion, Justice Brennan said that the burden of judicial interpretation is to translate "the majestic generalities" of the Constitution, conceived as part of the pattern of liberal government in the 18th century, into principles for dealing with the problems of the 20th century.
The arguments for and against the conservative doctrine of "original intention," the idea that the court should try to determine the original meaning of the framers of the Constitution, receive full treatment in the book. "We have no way of knowing how completely the statements recorded by Madison reflected the actual intentions of the 55 men who sat in Independence Hall during the summer of 1787," Mr. Schwartz says. "Advocates of original intention really urge the rejection of much that has become settled in 20th-century jurisprudence."
"Main Currents in American Legal Thought" is a bracing work of scholarship that could inspire readers to think about the nature of the right-of-center decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States today compared with the rulings by the great liberal justices of the recent past. The author leaves the clear impression that the liberals on the bench were much closer to the hearts and minds of the framers of the Constitution than are Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and the majority of his colleagues.

HEADLINE: Book Notes;
One Picasso, Two Writers And an Editor on the Spot

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

 BODY:
Norman Mailer has long been fascinated by Pablo Picasso, and so it seemed like a natural fit when the renowned author set out, he says, to write a biography of the renowned artist for his editor at Random House, Jason Epstein.
But there were a couple of difficulties, the most pressing among them being that Mr. Epstein happened, quite awkwardly, to be the editor of another biographer, John Richardson, who is working on a four-volume series on Picasso. Mr. Richardson's exhaustive dissection of the artist's early years, "A Life of Picasso: Volume I, 1881-1906," achieved both critical and commercial success several years ago. "I was apprehensive and told Norman that there might be a problem," Mr. Epstein said. 
 To make matters worse, when the editor showed Mr. Richardson a draft of Mr. Mailer's manuscript, which relied heavily on quotations from the earlier biography, Mr. Richardson disagreed with most of Mr. Mailer's analysis and refused to allow his material to be used. "Quite apart from not wanting to have my publisher bring out another book on Picasso while my own book is still selling, I think that both of us would look foolish," Mr. Richardson said in an indignant letter to Mr. Epstein in November in which he curtly called Mr. Mailer's book a "scissors-and-paste job."
That put everyone in an awkward position. "It had become a close situation at Random House because we both had the same editor," Mr. Mailer said. "So I offered to move publishers for the one book. It seemed simpler than to have an editor torn apart by two writers in dispute."
 
'Norman's Interpretation'
 Mr. Mailer, forced to excise large chunks of material from his book, took the manuscript to Nan A. Talese, head of her own imprint at Doubleday who said she thought Mr. Richardson was, at the very least, overreacting. "There's been an enormous number of books written about Picasso," she said, "and the facts are essentially the same. This book is Norman's interpretation of the facts as already known."
It is unclear when Mr. Mailer's book will be published, particularly because no contract has been signed with Doubleday, said Stephen Rubin, the president and publisher. "There's tremendous mutual enthusiasm for the project, but we're not even in negotiations yet," he said.
Meanwhile, Mr. Richardson said he planned to take the second volume in his planned set to another Random House editor, Sharon Delano. And Mr. Mailer said he would continue to publish with Random House. His next two books, Mr. Epstein said, are to be the second part of his novel "Harlot's Ghost" and a work of nonfiction about Lee Harvey Oswald.
 
Absorbing Poseidon
 Simon & Schuster's decision to merge its Poseidon Press into its adult trade division has given rise to much speculation about the future of Poseidon and its two established editors, Ann Patty, who is also vice president and publisher, and Elaine Pfefferblit.
The company said Ms. Patty would continue to publish books under the Poseidon name, much the way Nan A. Talese does at Doubleday, although Poseidon would no longer exist as a separate corporate division. Ms. Pfefferblit is being removed from Poseidon and is currently casting about for another job. Her current projects include Bruce Bawer's book "A Place at the Table: The Gay Individual in American Society," to be published in November, and two works in progress by Daphne Merkin.
Simon & Schuster officials strove to present the change as a positive move for Poseidon and Ms. Patty.
"It's an accounting change more than anything," said Carolyn K. Reidy, the president and publisher of Simon & Schuster's adult trade division, who said she and Ms. Patty had been searching for months for a way to make the imprint more economically viable. "Our feeling was that the only way to do it would be to remove it as a free-standing economic unit. There is no diminution in Ann Patty's stature or position."
 
The Balance Sheet
 Nonetheless, some present and former employees of the company are portraying the change as a sign of the friction between Ms. Patty and Jack Romanos, the president of the Paramount Publishing consumer group. And they say it is just another ominous step in the consolidation of Simon & Schuster's disparate publishing niches by the company's parents, Paramount Publishing and Paramount Communications, in the name of a more efficient bottom line. Other Simon & Schuster imprints that have fallen by the wayside in recent years include Summit Books, Linden Press and the trade division of Prentice Hall.
"I don't know what kind of commitment men sitting around in Los Angeles making movies have to the future of literature," said one high-ranking employee, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
But others within Simon & Schuster said the company had successfully found a way for Poseidon to go on, when its balance sheet did not always show profits (although its supporters say it would have proved profitable if it had been given credit for its paperbacks). "The alternative was to fold it," said one Simon & Schuster editor, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "They've demonstrated that they were willing to do that, and that's what they've done in the past."
Poseidon has been publishing about two dozen books of serious fiction and nonfiction a year, but it has no wildly best-selling authors who might have carried it along in the face of corporate pressure. News of its diminished status within Simon & Schuster has generated a flurry of telephone calls from authors worried about their own situations.
Mr. Romanos said the change in Poseidon was motivated simply by dollars and cents and was consistent with the company's effort to reduce the number of books it publishes by about 14 or 15 percent over the last few years. "It was an imprint with its own overhead structure, and it simply wasn't publishing enough or didn't have sales high enough to support that overhead structure," Mr. Romanos said. "It was a simple case of the numbers not adding up."
 
New Chicago Manual
 The Chicago Manual of Style, a classic reference book for writers, editors, proofreaders and the like, was last revised 11 years ago. Now it has been revised again. The new edition, the 14th, is to include expanded information about nationalities, tribes and races; it also includes a revamped chapter on foreign languages, with a new section on Hebrew. It is to be published by the University of Chicago Press in September and, at more than 900 pages, is 200 fact-filled pages longer than its predecessor.

HEADLINE: New Status for Stylish Art of Braiding

BYLINE: By RUTH M. BOND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Aminata Khafra sat in the sparsely furnished living room of her row house in northwest Washington making braids in the carefully parted hair of a young girl, a friend's daughter.
Ms. Khafra was slowly transforming 10-year-old Shannon Gopoul's hair into a "singles" style, in which at least a hundred tiny braids hang down from the scalp and rest gently on the shoulders. The style, which took five hours to complete, is one of seven that Ms. Khafra, 28, said she had learned by watching her cousins as a girl in Mali. 
 "It's a creation of the mind and the finger," Ms. Khafra said, gently turning her subject's head to the proper angle.
Ms. Khafra is one of many black women and girls who braid hair in their homes. And because of a new licensing law passed here in March that establishes hair braiding as its own trade, distinct from hairdressing and cosmetology, they will be able to move their businesses out of the home and into the economic mainstream.
"If I get my license, I'll open up a salon," said Ms. Khafra, who does braids for four or five people a week and charges between $70 and $90 for a hairdo that can last as long as three months. She hopes her salon will also sell African clothing like the robe she was wearing, a vivid assemblage of orange, green and brick-red strips of cloth.
Under the new law, hair braiding will have its own set of rules and licensing avenues, training and testing procedures. While many of the details still have to be worked out, a grandfather provision is expected for those who can show they have been braiding for clients for at least three years.
Braiders say that the most important part of the new law is that it separates African-style braiding from traditional cosmetology, which emphasizes the use of chemicals to straighten, perm, tint and dye hair. Several new salons, like the Sahel Braiding Parlor and Braids Unlimited, both in the Shaw-Cardozo neighborhood in northwest Washington, have opened here since the beginning of the year.
Many braiders call Taalib-Din Abdul Uqdah, 40, a co-owner of Cornrows & Company, a braiding salon in the Brightwood section of upper northwest Washington, the father of the new licensing law. For more than a decade, he and his wife, Pamela Ferrell, battled politicians, inspectors and the local cosmetology industry to gain greater recognition and economic opportunities for braiders.
The old regulations, which had not been updated since 1938, required anyone offering hair-care services to the public to complete lengthy and expensive programs offered by cosmetology schools, which generally emphasized changing the nature of black women's hair. Mr. Uqdah called the old rules discriminatory because they did not address the needs of African-American women who want to wear their hair in natural styles.
Cecilia Hinds, 32, another Washington braider, said that her life would have been much easier if the law had been different seven years ago when she was preparing to go into business. She said of her 1,500-hour course at the National Institute of Cosmetology in Washington, "It was a lot of time and money spent for something that you weren't going to be doing."
Washington is the second locality to establish separate licensing for hair braiders. Last year, New York State revised its cosmetology regulations to establish a "natural hair care" license. Braiders in other parts of the country, including Louisiana, Florida, Illinois and Michigan, are working to get similar laws passed.
The law in Washington also paves the way for the establishment of specialized braiding schools. Braiders say the schools are essential because making cornrows -- the generic name for coifs of African origin in which hair is intertwined in looping, twisting patterns that hug the scalp and resemble rows of corn -- requires a great deal of skill. Braiders must be taught the correct way to make forms like dufil braids, flat twists, rhasta twists, thick rolls and Nubian knots. Ms. Ferrell's book "Where Beauty Touches Me" (available from Cornrows & Company, 5401 14th Street NW, Washington 20011; $24.95) pictures more than 60 styles. The most complicated of the styles takes as long as 16 hours to complete.
Mr. Uqdah and Ms. Ferrell, who employ 10 fulltime braiders, see about 25 clients a day at Cornrows. They have developed a 750-hour training curriculum that they hope will be used as the basis for the new licensing requirements. It will include safety measures and hair physiology: improper technique can damage the scalp and can even cause baldness. Chemical processing will be taught only as background information.
Of great importance to many braiders is the preservation of an art form that dates back thousands of years. "I think this is a renaissance period," said Hiddekel Burks, a braider in Chicago and a founder of the National Braiders Guild, who is working to get a similar law passed in Illinois.
For braiders, new laws are important in their continuing efforts to win wider acceptance for hair styles that have met with much resistance from many employers and others who regard the African-inspired styles as hostile expressions of blackness. Those attitudes have led some women to sue their employers -- often successfully -- for the right to wear their cornrows.
But Aliska Moffett, who owns Cinnamon's Braiding and Beauty Salon in New Orleans, said that wearing braids is not in itself a statement against society. "It's more of a spiritual and cultural thing," she said, a way of continuing centuries of traditional African fashion and lore.

HEADLINE: Haiti: The Secret of Success

 BODY:
Getting the Haitian military to agree to a timetable for returning President Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power is a considerable achievement. The United Nations mediator, Dante Caputo, and the Clinton Administration deserve much credit.
But after pressuring President Aristide to accept an agreement that leaves real power in military hands for most of a four-month transition period, the U.N. and the U.S. are now obliged to insure that army and police commanders live up to their parts of the deal. They must end political intimidation now and actually surrender power at the end of October. 
 The transition is scheduled to begin shortly, with political consultations leading up to the nomination of a new prime minister by President Aristide. Other steps include limited amnesty for those involved in the 1991 military coup, suspension of international economic sanctions and provision of more than $1 billion in international assistance.
The most important changes in internal security are scheduled toward the end of the process, including the creation of a civilian police force, replacement of the military and police high command and the return of Father Aristide.
The obvious risk is that the military will continue to intimidate and even eliminate Aristide supporters while it still can, to influence key political decisions starting with the choice of a new prime minister.
The best deterrent against this would be quick reimposition of sanctions. A new Security Council resolution is being prepared that would allow Mr. Caputo and Secretary General Boutros-Ghali to reimpose sanctions automatically if, in their judgment, the military begins undermining the agreement. Its terms, passage and credibility are crucial to success of the whole enterprise.
There's an important lesson in the diplomatic endgame that brought this agreement. For more than 20 months, as Washington sent mixed diplomatic signals, the Haitian military defiantly rejected all serious diplomacy. But less than two weeks after the Clinton Administration sought and won stiff U.N. economic sanctions, the generals were at the bargaining table ready to deal.
The secret of diplomatic success is usually a matter of mixing threat, patience and compromise in just the right proportions. The Haiti agreement is a welcome sign that, after embarrassing stumbles elsewhere, the Clinton Administration may be getting the recipe right.
